reviews.review: Dutch Courage during WWII. We had been to resistance museums in other European countries that suffered Nazi occupation, and this museum rated among the best. Very good audio guides are available in multiple languages, at no extra charge. The exhibits and the commentary give a picture of what the Dutch people endured at the hands of the Nazis. It was interesting to learn that some Dutch people thought that since Hitler had done a good job of turning the German economy around, that he could possibly do the same for them. Also, I had not considered that Dutch colonies in Indonesia suffered at the hands of the Japanese during the war. Overall, a great experience. We went midday and there were no lines. Very polite and helpful staff.

Probably my favourite museum in Amsterdam. I really like this place. They have fun short exhibitions and the main one is not maudlin or depressing. It's an amazing collection, that gives an idea and a feeling of the challenges and difficulties of war without being depressing but often uplifting. Great for adults and children

Small but perfectly formed. This is a real pearl of a museum. It's not big but it does tell a fascinating story and provides a feel for what the Dutch went through during the war. It's easy to get to on the tram, just by the zoo and there aren't any queues. A must for anyone interested in the second world war.
A different way of looking at history. A museum that makes one think what would I have done, The area for children is also very good. Helpful staff. Audio guide included

really interesting and enjoyable. loved the history and everything about this museum it was a little small but has a lot of info, best to take some earphones with you so you can hear all the information given to you comfortably.

A must see part of history. This was more importantly to us than the Anne Frank house. We felt that we would get a better overview and understanding of what it was like to live in Holland and Amsterdam during WWII. It was an excellent experience. The Junior section was incredible, walking you through the virtual experienceserver of real victims from the war. It was very thought provoking and soul searching. ALLOW ENOUGH TIME. This museum took longer than we anticipated. We only had 1.5 hours until they closed, and we could have easily stayed for 3 hours.

Tells a great story.. The audio guide gives great context for telling the story of the Nazi occupation of the Netherlands. Gives you great respect for a people doing the best they could under awful, oppressive cirucmstances.

Not to be missed. A hidden gem. This museum presented an extraordinarily well balanced history of Holland's post depression and WW II occupation and how different people dealt with the times. Extraordinary in the literal sense of the word.

Interesting, well presented and focussed exhibition. This museum looks at the average Dutch person's experience when adjusting to Nazi occupation during WWII, and seems like a natural accompaniment to the Anne Frank Museum. It is laid out well and remains very focussed and interesting throughout, constantly coming back to the dilemma it lays out right at the start: To adapt, collaborate, or resist. It does a good job of giving context to the overarching events, while taking the time to tell some very personal stories which offer differing points of view.The ticket price (€10 adult) includes a free audio guide, which is a nice touch, and I found this to be a useful accompaniment to the exhibit, though my wife quickly grew tired of it and didn't use it. It repeated a lot of what was written on the displays, but also gave specific guidance around the collection of exhibits.Overall a very well presented exhibit told competently, and perhaps illuminating a side of a well-known story that you may not have thought too much about before. There is apparently 90 mins worth of recorded audio on the audio guide, which is probably a good amount of time to get around the museum. Also there was a section at the back that was sign posted as being for juniors, though I didn't go in here.

Informative, many artifacts from the war. Good insights into wartime Netherlands. Resist, ignore, or collaborate? not simple choose. Also good insights into daily lives for all. And of the devastating year of hunger following the war.

New take on WWII Museum. I have been to several WWII museums and while they are all interesting, I appreciated that this museum took a different look at the war and talked about both Jewish people and Non Jews alike. Having Jewish friends and neighbors and knowing what was happening you had two choices, help them or mind your own business and protect yourself. This is not only an exhibit on WWII but also human nature. Very interesting!

Amsterdam Mini Break. This totally opened my eyes to the plight of occupied Europe during WWII espesially the plight of the people of Netherlands, I was expecting stories of sabotage and brave undercover missions similer to how Hollywood and other media have shown the French Resistences role during WWII, but this was very very different it asks the question from the veiw of the ordinary family how would you act ? what would you do ? You've been invaded ! you're now occupied by a forigen army ! Do you sit back and accept the nazis rule or do you resist any way you can that will hinder the German war effort ?  There is so much to see here and it's a must for people of all ages especially todays kids who aren't tought about these thing's because it's not PC.

Not to be Missed - Ages 8 -80. Well done and highly varied exhibits combined with audio handset for additional information. Allow at least one hour. Many personal vignettes that appeal to young people as well as history buffs.

A wonderful museum, especially the children's section. This is an incredible museum, and for me and my children (aged 8 and 10) put the extraordinary experience of visiting Anne Frank's house the day before into it's wider context. At the resistance museum you learn about the experience of he occupation for Dutch people more broadly, as well as the huge number of Jewish citizens who suffered and died (60,000 from Amsterdam alone). The junior section of the museum is the best children's museum I have ever been to - my 8 and 10 year old were so completely engaged and absorbed we couldn't leave until they had watched and opened and listened to everything. I found the whole thing incredibly moving and they certainly learned a huge amount.

Thought Provoking. The Resistance Museum is extremely thought provoking. It asks the question what would you do in the circumstances various people find themselves in during the invasion and occupation - do you resist, cooperate, or collaborate. You'll learn how real people responded, and what the consequence of their choice was, and you'll think about what you'd do in similar situations. Amazing experience.

Interesting Walk through Dutch WWII History. The Resistance Museum gets a 4 star rating because it is a high second tier site in Amsterdam. I do not pretend to tell you that you must go here about the Anne Frank House, Rijksmuseum, Van Gogh museum or Red Light District. But if you have seen the mainstays, this is a worthwhile 2 hours to spend.The museum takes you thought the history of how the Dutch dealt with German occupation during the war. There is a lot of great detail and storytelling at the museum. There are also not a lot of places to sit. This museum is tiring with its detail from the audio tour to the exhibit descriptions. I left with a much greater appreciation for the history of the Netherlands in WWII, but also tired and needing a long sit in the cafe next door (worth going to for tea!).Bottom line, for longer trips to Amsterdam, go here... for quick trips, this may not rise to the right level.On a side note, the museum is directly across from the Zoo and around the corner from the Dutch Holocaust Museum.

A moving experience. The Resistance museum was a very informative experience. Well worth the 10 Euro entry price. I spent over 2 hours listening to the audio guide and reading the information.The museum does a great job of examining the choices individuals had to make in an occupied territory.If you are interested in WW2 history, this is a great place to visit

Go and visit this place where brave people gave their lives.. Our hotel was close by, but to be honest we stumbled upon it as we were walking in the area. I am so glad that I visited and read incredible stories and moving pictures.

A Sobering, Must See Museum. While the Anne Frank house in Amsterdam and the Corrie Ten Boom House in Haarlem are important, not to be missed places to visit, the Dutch Resistance museum also fits into this category. Its impact is not to be denied and they have done a materful and unforgettable job of telling the story of the Dutch Resistance during WWI. The Audioguides are an integral part of the story as they provide additional detail and background to the movement during this 1 ½ hour history lesson. This museum needs to be included in your list of museums in The Netherlands not to miss.

A difficult, important walk through History. "Enjoy" is an ungrateful word when reviewing museums that deal with the history of WW2; they are more often than not an unpleasant experience that we value for the necessary (if painful) insight, which can take some time to digest. The Verzets isn't much different; it features a detailed, remarkably objective walk through the history of the German occupation of the Netherlands during WW2, highlighting the social and political causes, consequences, and dilemmas of the Dutch people, as relevant today as they were then. Aware of the semantic charge, I can say I very much "enjoyed" this museum; not only for the wealth of its collection and its important message, but especially for the comprehensive way in which it is presented.

Really informative place. Should get more credit as a place to go. Good artifacts as you could trace the terror and tension of the Nazi invasion. You also got a real sense of the difficult questions people had to ask themselves. Also could see the courage of the resistance fighters and helpers. Must see place.

Very good picture of Dutch life in WW2. This museum should be seen if you have an interest in the War. It takes about 1-2 hours to see everything and it is very well presented. This is off the beaten path and there were no lines or crowds.

Good experience. Factual portrayal of Dutch delemma.. Very well organized with lots of photos. Good presentaion at the beginning of the situation the Dutch faced when Germany invaded. Surprised there was not more resistance as there was in France; but, then again different countries.

Life under the Nazis. We visited the Resistance Museum as part of a bust five days in Amsterdam. We went to this museum as the queue for Anne Frank house was just too long. It was a good choice and gave us a good idea of what life under Nazi occupation must have been like. We had some language difficulties as most of the dialogue was in Dutch or German (as you would expect) but we certainly got the drift of the explanations of what must have been an awful experience for those living in Holland.

Staff training required, otherwise good. We purchased tickets online before going in, then showed the ticket on my mobile to the man on the desk....he said it wasn't valid as he couldn't scan it!! He was pretty obnoxious even suggesting that we hadn't used a valid website to buy the tickets as he said the site we had used had no link with them. That was nonsense as a lady on the desk eventually got us in by ringing her office who confirmed they had had an email confirming our booking. This man even had the nerve to suggest we should have paid cash. It would seem he needs a lesson in good customer service, plus a brush up on modern ticket purchase procedures! When we eventually got in the museum was quite good.

Putting faces to history. The appeal of this museum is that it is not just about facts, but provides personal stories and photos, which makes it all the more real. Takes time to get through, so allow a couple of hours. Headphones provide wonderful information.

Fascinating. We found this museum fascinating. It winds round from when the Dutch were first occupied through to liberation and beyond. The displays are excellently laid out with descriptions in both English and Dutch. If you have any interest in the Second World War I thoroughly recommend this place.

Dealing with the complexity of the occupation. The focus of the Resistance Museum is the choices that the Dutch had during the occupation and the different paths that individuals took. It does not glorify or condemn, although it certainly shows the atrocities that were committed by the Third Reich and the collaborators. It is laid out as a series of rooms dealing with specific issues and events. Most of the labels are in English as well as Dutch, and there is a very good audio guide. Notably, the museum also deals with events in the Dutch colonies during and after the war.

Important place to understand European history. Absolutely recommend as a cultural place. This is an important place to know and to understand part of world history. Importants reflections on how the resistance was made in two ways: from the Dutch to Germans and to the Indonesian to the Dutch empire.

An intense but important experience. I would recommend visiting this museum which is a bit out of the way. I went with four friends and we all found it interesting, but a bit overwhelming. The exhibit rooms wind from one to the other. We wondered if that design was intended to give one a claustrophobic feeling, somewhat like the closed-in feeling that the Dutch must have had during the war. As a result, we all decided to forego seeing the entire museum because it was overwhelming. The exhibits are well designed although they present a lot of information and require considerable reading. An added feature is the pleasant restaurant with outdoor seating. I would go back again because this topic is important, but it is a bit intense.

Good experience. The museum is very interesting and informative and certainly makes you aware that the Dutch people suffered greatly during the war years. My only critcism is that the written descriptions alongside the displays were in quite small printing making it difficult to read some of those which were sited towards the rear of the display. There are some really interesting exhibits in the museum but allow plenty of time to get round them all.

I'm so glad I went here.. This museum doesn't get the publicity that the Anne Frank House does -- but it is absolutely a must-see if you're interested in history. It's one of the best laid-out, beautifully done museums I've ever visited. Learned so much -- not just about Anne Frank, but the whole period of the German occupation and the brave Dutch people who kept on fighting -- even if it was underground.

Museum of Not Much Resistance. It's a slightly strange museum. It does an excellent job of documenting the Dutch experience in World War II, but one of things that it documents is that there was in fact not a whole lot of resistance to the Nazis until it was clear that the Allies were prevailing. In particular, with a few shining exceptions, the Dutch kind of stood by while the Jewish population was deported and murdered. The museum is interesting nonetheless, with an excellent audioguide.

Important Museum. My husband and I very much enjoyed this informative museum. It was very well laid out with SO MUCH information to take in, mostly about the years 1940-1945, when the Netherlands were occupied by the Nazis. Cost was 10 euro/person, which included an audio guide. Allow at least 90 minutes to go through.

Very Informative - 2 Sep 2016. The resistance museum is all about the German occupation to the liberation of the Netherlands between 1940 and 1945. You get a free audio guide and if you want to go through everything it would take you around 4 hours. There is also a junior museum with a path for the kids to follow. Overall very informative but I would like to say that there is too much information nevertheless it is a must do for anyone who is into WW 2 history.
Sad. This museum had alot of history regarding the Jewish people. We left wondering would we adapt or resist....

What would you do?. A thoughtful journey through the German Occupation of The Netherlands during WWII. Very interactive with many artifacts that depict life for the oppressed, the collaborators, and the resistance. The audio program that can be purchased separately greatly enhances the experience, and are the best I have come across in terms of ease of use and volume/clarity. A definite must see!

Not so much a Resistance Museum, more a museum dedicated to life under Germna Occupation. An interesting museum, describing how Dutch life was in 1940 - 1945 while under German Occupation. Which was very interesting, but not what was expected. There was only a small part of the story that related to actual resistance. The most moving part of the museum is that it forces you to think about what you would have done - would you have collaborated, gone along, or would you have resisted? Difficult choices, all of them.

Fascinating museum . My wife and I visited this museum as we are very interested in this period of history. We found it very informative about what happened in Amsterdam during the war. I would recommend this museum for anyone interested in this period.

Interesting. A better name for this museum would be The Museum of the German Occupation. There was not much (maybe an-eight) on the Resistance itself. I understand that the Resistance didn't leave much of a paper-trail, so it is hard to make a museum. However I did enjoy learning about the stages of the German Occupation and how different citizens responded to it.

So glad we came. A small museum telling the story and moral dilemma confronting the Dutch people. We learned a lot. Though we are adults the Jr museum was the most interesting telling the tale of 4 Dutch children and following them to adulthood.

Resistance? Or Compliance? Museum. An interesting museum, but I didn't see much evidence of a resistance movement. More a documentation of occupied Netherlands and life under the Nazis. Quite a good collection of artefacts, but on the whole, the experience feels a bit tired and gloomy. Could do with some updating for modern exhibition presentation.

Possibly too much information?. I feel that when you are in Europe it is important to pay your respects to the atrocity that was WWII. I knew that the lines at the Anne Frank House would be insane so this was my compromise. And I wasn't wowed, It's a good museum, well laid out and with SO much information that it gets a little daunting. At the very least it wasn't what I was expecting.
Breath-taking. This is a must when in Amsterdam. I am not an art buff, however it is amazing to see such amazing work and many you will be very familiar with.

I wondered about Amsterdam in the war, so thought this was a must.. I had a free afternoon so picked this out of all the museums to visit. It was easy enough to find ,catching the train out of Amsterdam central. Get off at the stop for the Zoo , you are then only 5 mins away.It wasn't expensive about 11 euros to get in, took me an hour and a half to complete, but I did the whole lot! Listed to every 'station' giving you accounts of people who were there. There are quite a lot of photos too! It was encouraging to see many younger adults walking around as well. I would give it 3/4 out of 5 . I was expecting a bit more really, but maybe it's just I knew a lot of the story already. Don't be put off.

Definitely worthwhile. Great small museum dedicated to how the people of the Netherlands dealt with life during the Nazi occupation. Very well done. Free audio guide gives lots of interesting information. Definitely worth going - plan to spend 1-1.5 hours here

Very Moving . The whole museum is set up really well to take you on a adventure. As you walk through their are questions on the floor to ask yourself, and the whole museum is built around thinking what you would do in the situations the resistance fighters found themselves in. It quite an informative and moving experience. It's not like any museum you've been to before.

Gives an excellent impression of a crucial period in Dutch history. The 'verzetsmuseum' is a small collection of items that evoke the occupation of the Netherlands by Nazi Germany from 1940-45, and in particular the resistance against the occupation. An important part of this were attempts to rescue Jews from being deported and killed (the museum is located in what used to be a heavily Jewish neighborhood, which also hosts two synagogues and a memorial to those murdered, the 'Hollandse Schouwburg' right around the corner), but also politically motivated resistance by young and brash people, communists and socialists. Among other things the resistance carried out what was called 'terrorist attacks' on Nazi officials and Dutch collaborators, admittedly with mixed results but interesting for the analogy with what happens in other places under stress.

Sobering but should be seen. The resistance museum should be seen to appreciate the complete Amsterdam. Whilst it's a city full of vibrancy and colour, a free and exuberant city that welcomes all peoples, it also had a dark period which should be understood to fully appreciate what is here now. The museum covers the occupation years in a lot of depth with many photos, letters and memorabilia from that time. It's an unfortunate period in Amsterdam's history, but one that should be seen. A worthwhile visit.

Excellent museum. The Resistance Museum has been brilliantly setup. They have created a really moving and interesting display of the resistance movement, and what life was like for those living through World War II. It is easy to connect with the stories told and provides wonderful insight into a time of great social and political upheaval for The Netherlands. Be sure to get an audio guide!!

Get the I Amsterdam pass. If we didn't have the I Amsterdam pass, we wouldn't have gone to this. With that said, we were both so happy to have the new education about the resistance. Definitely worth checking out, even if you don't have the pass!

Very well done.. I loved this museum. It was small but packed with information and easy to get involved in individual struggles and their difficult choices during WWII. There is a special section for kids so that they can see what types of situations different families faced when making decisions during that time. I highly recommend this museum.

Sobering but excellent museum. This well thought out museum seeks not only to inform visitors about the Dutch resistance to Nazi occupation during World War II, and the bitter cost of that occupation for residents of the Netherlands, but also to prompt visitors to ponder the difficult choices and moral dilemmas confronting people in an occupied country. It brought home not only the courage of those involved in the Resistance, but why freeing this country from occupation was worth the many lives of American, British and Canadian soldiers that it cost to do so.

Highly informative and displays a different side of WWII.. Really loved the wealth of information at the museum and approach via personal stories of the Dutch people and the way they reacted to the war.

Learned so much . I like to learn the history of people wherever I travel. I didn't know much about the Dutch resistance. This museum taught me so much. I enjoyed the Junior exhibit the best. The stories of four children are followed during the war, after the war and into adulthood. Each had very different experiences and it was fun to go through their "houses" and see things through their eyes. Be sure to get directions at the front desk for the free audio guide especially for the junior section.

Too much information!. Reasonable price with audio tour included. Initial film very interesting but the information once in the museum is too vast to comprehend. Parts are very interesting but it would take you hours to read everything! All about the resistance to the Germans invading the Netherlands with some personal stories etc included to.

Excellent source of history..... Amazing to see the turmoil the Dutch people went through. This museum, while well documented and media displayed, is somewhat (to me) confusing in what direction to follow. There are side 'alleys' to enter without knowing if it's the main path or a sideway of further information. Very interesting the written words (appreciated the dual translation (to English) and the memorabilia. Sad to see the photos, the humanistic toughness touches you. So sad the stories of escape, survival, death, betrayal ... Similar in emotional response as a Holocaust museum, the evolution from late 1930s to mid 1940s is something we (may) know but reading and seeing real 'period' things is something different; quite an experience!A serious matter previously but in today's current time we should remember this as there could be some similarities.

Definitely worth a visit.. My husband and I both thought this museum was extremely interesting. It is a little off the main area but accessible by tram. It covered the build up to the war, the different decisions people made and gave you better picture of WWII. Our only regret is that we didn't have enough time to see it all. Most places close at 5pm and there is just so much to see in Amsterdam.

Interesting museum. We found this museum informative and interesting. The audio guide worked well and for 10 euros for entry and audio tour each it was decent value. Went on a Saturday morning and was not that busy. Not the easiest place to find, as we walked past it once! We found the museum moving and a good reminder of what happened.

Fantastic. The resistance museum was brilliant. It was really interesting to see WWII from another perspective other than the British or American. There is an audio tour which you can use to scan different areas around the museum and get a dialogue appropriate to that display. The experience takes about 2-2.5 hours if you listen to or read the majority of the information. The museum is bright, clean and well set out. There is a cloak room with free lockers to remove the burden of lugging bags around and the toilets were clean. Well worth the money and I would recommend this.

great little gem. this was a very interesting visit for us as we are both interested in the history of every place we go to. Was really nice to learn about the efforts of the Dutch during the war and very well put together.

Do not miss this excellent museum!!! One of our trip's highlights.. Incredibly informative and thought-provoking. Superb presentation of information. The children's section was excellent - for children and adults. Lots of buttons to push and stuff to see. All displays and audio in both Dutch and English. We were here for well over 4 hours with a 10 and a 12 year old and we all thoroughly enjoyed it.

Very interesting museum. It is worth a trip down to the Plantage to visit the Dutch Resistance Museum. They have an amazing and well organized collection of memorabilia from the Nazi occupation of the Netherlands and the Dutch underground resistance against the occupation. It also chronicles the Dutch people's efforts to protect the Jewish population.

Allow Plenty of Time for this Museum. I was overwhelmed by this museum. My niece loved it but it was too much for me to take in. We had earphones and mine didn't work right or else I was looking at the wrong exhibit and trying to listen. I'm a museum freak and i like to read everything and look at everything. My niece breezed through while I was still at the beginning it seemed. So, I felt rushed and didn't fully appreciate all the work that went into this museum. My advice - if this subject interests you go alone and take as much time as you want without feeling rushed. There's a lot to learn about the courageous Dutch.

Well Curated. I visited with my class of study abroad students (university). It is possible to book a guided tour in English. Our guide, Bonnie, was excellent. Since my last visit, the museum has opened a new children's section which is extremely well done. Highly recommended, particularly if you are also visiting the Anne Frank house.

Really enjoyed it and really good for price! . I saw this while searching through trip advisor and as I am interested in world war stuff etc I picked it out of places to visit. As an entry of €10 we were massively impressed with what this place as to offer plenty of information possibly a little too much. If you are into world war stuff then defiantly go you'll not regret it. Slight tip make sure you don't go too late in the day as there is over 2 hours of stuff to look through!

Touchy Subject in Holland. Very well thought out and informative museum. Lots of text to read on the displays but some interesting artifact as well. The number of people who actively collaborated, resisted or just went along with the Nazi occupation is a touchy subject in Holland and is dealt with to some degree at this museum
Well worth a visit. Spent a lovely afternoon here. Interactive, interesting and informative. Great place to take your children as well. Highly recommended

GOOD FOR THE UNINITIATED . There there is nothing new or exciting about this museum. The exhibits are adequate and the audio guide is actually quite good. It is best for those who are unfamiliar with events during World War II.

Worth the time!. You may have been to a Holocaust Museum, but The Resistance Museum tells of those people who risked their lives to save people on Hitler's "hit list." Well done and worth spending 2+ hours. Listen to all the extra parts of the commentary on the audio tour. You will be humbled.

Good value attraction. At the end of our 3 days stay in Amsterdam we managed to squeeze in visit before flight. We only had 2 hours. We saw most of it but 2.5 hours would have been better, although teenagers possibly wouldn't have absorbed much more information. Lots of interesting information bringing it home that Anne Frank was one of so many who suffered. Family ticket made it good value at the end of an expensive few days!!

Hooray for the Dutch. A wonderful museum showing how the Dutch dealt with the Nazis. Emotionally moving exhibits that were very informative. Well worth the time. Only problem I had was figuring out the flow of the museum.

On Your List. Excellent. Put your head into 1940's and have a wander through time in the Netherlands under Nazi/German occupation. Unlike other Museums they are not shy is describing the nationality of those who took over their country and the effect on specific nationalities.Memorable.

A must for WWII and history buffs!. I really enjoyed this museum and they did an excellent job organizing it. I really recommend watching the excellent and informative video at the start of the museum.

Make it part of your trip to Amsterdam. You won't necessarily leave this place with a smile on your face, but it's important to see what happened between 1940 and 1945 in the Netherlands, and also in the former Dutch colonies in the Far East from 1941. Very grim, but very interesting. The exhibits are excellent, and they challenge you with questions that faced Dutch residents when the Nazis marched in - adapt, collaborate or resist. Tough to guess what you'd do.

Interesting museum.. The museum is situated near the zoo, in the Plantage area. The walk from Central station took 25 minutes. You can also get a tram. It costs 10 euros for the visit but if you pick up a voucher booklet from your hotel it will cost 8. The American lady on reception was quite pleasant and informative. As well as information on the Dutch resistance to the Nazis, the museum also gives an overview of the different groups in Dutch society, communists, Protestants, Royalists etc.. and how they lived together up until the war began. Very interesting museum. You can get around the museum in about 90 minutes.

Exceptional museum. This is a real hidden gem - an exceptional museum with a real insight into the lives experience of wartime in Holland. Exhibits are informative, with easy translations. The junior section is creative and engaging (great for adults too). Moving and educational - and a welcome alternative to some very 'military heavy' museums.

Very informative. This is probably the best resistance museum that I've been to in Europe (there are several in other major occupied countries). A good opportunity to see how many brave Dutch citizens did what they could to assist the war effort.

Skip the Queue at Anne Frank's House and go here instead. Why wait on line for hours to see an empty room when you can walk through the Resistance Museum in an hour or so and come out with an excellent understanding of Amsterdam's role with the Nazis and Jews before, during and after WWII?My wife and I found the museum very interesting. The free audio tour is a must to truly appreciate all the work that has gone into the Resistance Museum.
Great exhibits. Tells quite a story of the valiant and effective efforts of the Dutch to resist the Nazis as well as assist Jews living in the country at the time. Well worth the time.

Very interesting museum. Very thought provoking to put yourself in the place of Dutch people during the war and wonder how you would have reacted in those circumstances. Lots of true life stories, videos and artefacts, plus an audio tour. Really enjoyed this.

To Understand Resistance. The museum is packed with photos, videos, and artifacts from the days when everyday people were trying their best to live through the horror of occupation. Learn how and what happened when folks resisted to survive and subvert.

SOBERING. This museum is not so much one filled with artifacts as it is one filled with stories - stories that provide the visitor with a sense of what it might have been like to wake up one day free and the next day the subject of a foreign regime. The museum was created by members of the Dutch Resistance to preserve their story. It is in its second location. It was a little hard to find, but well worth the effort. Of the many stories told two touched me more than the others: 1) A woman was taking her children to school and was stopped on the way by soldiers; that is the way she learned her country had been invaded by Germans. It made me wonder if my ancestors had similar experiences with Yankees during the Civil War. 2) Another woman who named her baby after the Queen in exile was imprisoned after placing a thank you in the paper for all the gifts people had sent her after they had seen the birth announcement. The Germans tolerated no references to the royal family.
a moving experience!. a very informative tour through the dutch resistance efforts during the second world war against the nazis ...

A tribute to those who fought and died for freedom.. Hard to imagine life as it was under Nazi occupation. The museum brings it alive. The never ending struggle for freedom is well depicted in the halls and walls of this museum. A must for history buffs.

Very informative!. Do visit this great museum tucked away near the Zoo in Amsterdam. It is very informative and interesting, but the best part of all is the Junior Museum located inside. I have never been in a more interesting, unique, multimedia, hands-on children's museum. Inside, you will explore the lives of 4 (real) Dutch children during WWII, learning about the different perspectives of children whose parents were either Jewish, Resistors, or Nazi Sympathizers. It's a maze inside, with something unique in each crevice, corner, and alcove. Make sure you do this first and then go to the adult exhibits if you have time. Supper at the Green Elephant is great too!
An Interesting and Historic Site. This museum was closed by the time we got there. Definitely a place to prioritize for our next visit.

Very well done. Visited on a rainy Sunday morning. So glad we came. The displays are very well done and the personal stories very interesting. Spent quite a long time here and learned a lot. Also enjoyed coffee and apple pie in the café next door.

Fantastic exhibition of WWII resistance . I visited solo and thoroughly enjoyed the exhibition. I felt it gave great context and through personal accounts, gave a fantastic overview of the resistance and how it fit into WWII in the Netherlands. The audio tour is nice if you get tired of reading, but not necessary (I would recommend though!). It made for a moving account and was an eye opening experience, and for this the museum deserves to be up there with the Rijks etc. as must visits in Amsterdam.On a practical note, they do have small lockers for storing bags, as well as offering suitcase storage.

Inspiring bit of history. This was low down on our list of things to do in Amsterdam, but I'm so glad we managed to fit it in on our last day. It's very informative of the Dutch resistance during the Nazi occupation and it really lifts your spirits that in such horrific circumstances people are willing to put their own lives at risk to help others. The museum was based around real people who had to make the decision to resist the Nazis, go along with it and pretend nothing was happening, or cooperate. It makes you wonder what you would do yourself if something like this was ever to happen again. It costs €10 but was free entry with the iamsterdam card or museumkaart.

Best historical museum in Amsterdam. A very honest exposition of the issues of Amsterdam during the WWII. The good and bad of the citizen's response to the occupation is presented. The displays and text (in english and dutch) were very clear and progressed the story line accurately.

Skip the Anne Frank House and Come Here. The lines around the Anne Frank House were pretty off-putting so we decided to come here. This is one of the most important and brilliant exhibits I've ever seen. If you really want to know what it was like for the Dutch people during WWII, come here. We each have to face the question: would we have resisted, accepted, or collaborated? This museum really makes you think about what we would do as average citizens.

A little gem. This has got to be one of my favourite museums in Amsterdam. Over the years this place has expanded and become better and better. With the option to have interactive audio to explain the exhibits it is well worth the visit if you would like to learn more about the resistance during the war.It is tucked away near the zoo and worth the entrance fee,

Excellent for Children. This museum is packed full of details and information. The entire basement level is devoted to children; their role in the resistance and the mock-up of their houses. The ground level is for adults. Highly recommended.

Excellent Museum About WWII Occupation. This is a very well put together museum covering how the Netherlands dealt with German occupation during WWII. At times I found it quite emotional, but it was easily my favourite museum I visited in Amsterdam. There is a lot of information with lots of quotes from actual people during the period and how they were feeling and dealt with various stages of the occupation. I felt like you could really get a sense of what it must have been like, and how the citizens were grappling with what to do as the occupation turned more and more restrictive, dangerous, and adversarial. I spent about three to four hours here but you could probably do it in less time if you wanted. The audio guide is useful and well done; nice to have one that actually functions properly at all stages of the museum. The entrance fee of 10 euros per adult was well worth it, I thought. Be sure to not overlook the part about the Dutch East Indies as well and how they dealt with the Japanese occupation there.

Easy to reach from Dam Square on the number 9 tram. Entrance opposite the zoo entrance.. A very interesting insight into the lives of the people in Holland during WW2. There was a mix of video, audio, picture, written word and exhibits. All on one level (there is a video to view on the first floor but it's also screened on the ground floor prior to entering the main exhibition area). Entrance is only 10 euros for adults. There were no queues so you don't feel rushed to move around the exhibition area. Very educational and thought provoking, worth a visit.

Full of History. This is my second time to the Resistance Museum having come previously in March. As before I think it's one of the best in Amsterdam, loads of content and it really does give good context as to what it was like to the resistance during the war.The audio guide (which is included in the price €10 for an adult) is very simple to use. Simply point at the small green squares located throughout the museum.There was an interesting exhibition on also with some very nice large canvas print photographs regarding how we in the present day treat the war. Really an added bonus.Would encourage anyone to come.

"Resistance is futile...or is it?". An interesting museum. For those of us from North America it is hard to imagine what was suffered by the Dutch during the German occupation, yet their determination to fight was extensive. This museum did a nice job of presenting a different insight to the Second World War.

A great collection of experiences from the Second World War . We wandered in to this museum since it was included in our I Amsterdam cards and it was a rainy day. As someone who really enjoys history and people's personal stories from the war I am really glad we went in. The museum is a collection of stories of Dutch resistance during the Second World War. Audio tour is free, I'll. Admit I didn't use it I prefer to read but for those who don't read Dutch or English It is a necessity. I found this museum to be educational and impactful an I'm glad it was a rainy day in Amsterdam that caused us to wander in.

An eye-opener. This is a very educational and sobering museum with excellent exhibits, an audio tour and a children's section. You can follow the stories of ordinary Dutch people and the decisions they had to make to survive the German occupation in World War Two. It was not very busy so we had time to really appreciate and contemplate the stories unlike Anne Frank House which was crowded and had very long queues. Highly recommended.

Very interesting museum. For those interested in World War 2 history this is an excellent museum. The audio guide is free, but I felt the signage was great and that the audio guide mainly repeated the posted information.
Very well done. This is a superb museum with a deep look into Dutch life during WWII. This is worth a trip out of your way to visit this place.

We learned so much - very worthwhile. It was eye-opening to learn what it was like for the Netherlands to be taken over by the Nazi's. Take a free headset and enjoy the well organized displays. Ok for children over 10 years. You will wonder what you would have done if you had been there.
A real education. We knew a little about what the Dutch went through but this was a real eye opener, a no holds barred resume of bravery and terror.

Very good concise and vivid picture of World War II in the then occupied Netherlands. The museum has stories, writings, videos, a movie and a room with parts of houses and Streets that paint a good picture of the occupied Netherlands during World War II. Adapt, collide or resist, that was the question then. The movie at the start if very worthwhile. It is in Dutch but with English subtitles. Most of the museum has two language choices: Dutch or English (no German, French or other languages though). Very important part of the European/Dutch history.

fantastic visit. fabulous museum, short tram ride from the centre then a minutes walk. Very good audio tour and exhibitions. Much less busy than Anne Frank House and much more detail. We enjoyed Anne Frank too but you're kind of processed around there whereas at verzetsmuseum you can go much more to your own pace. Children's exhibition was very good indeed. Aimed at 9-12 year olds but I think older teenagers would enjoy it just as much. Good toasties and pancakes just a few doors down!

DUTCH RESISTANCE TIMELINE WW II. A small museum presenting the history of the Dutch Resistance during WW II. Audio guides are included. Well laid out and worth a visit in conjunction with the Jewish Museum nearby.
Great museum. Not too expensive but a great place to spend a few hours learning more about dutch culture and history.

Lots of info!. The museum provided a lot of content and context for WWI, as well as culture in the Netherlands. We spent about two hours here and could have stayed longer to look at the Dutch East Indies exhibit - I just couldn't stand any longer. Lots of artefacts and videos, so very interactive. I think I was a bit overwhelmed by information though, but maybe that's no bad thing for a museum.

So glad I went!. This is an excellent museum for history buffs with a lot of information about WWII in the Netherlands. Everything is curated in Dutch and English, plus there are audioguides. The layout can be a bit confusing at times; you might want to take a photo of the map at the entrance. The museum has very interesting artifacts from the war. Although there is information about the Resistance, a more accurate title would be WWII Museum. This is an excellent counterpoint to the Anne Frank House. It's easily accessible by tram and is right next to the city zoo.

Mixed feelings. This is not really the resistance museum (which to be fare it does state on there web site) it is more an over view of dutch life spanning the years of occupation with lots of small stories about individuals who chose to resist. I left at the end wondering if there was any form of organised effort. The audio headsets are a must have and are easy to use and help tie in all of the displays . Personaly I prefer meseums with artifacts all over the walls and in display cabinets where you can browse more easily as opposed to narrow glass viewing windows. Overall its worth a visit and is reasonably priced.
Alright museum. Decent, well put together smallish museum. More like the Dutch Collaboration Museum but still worth a visit and the price.

Very well done & worthwhile experience!. We spent 3 hours there and could have spent even longer viewing the exhibits and reading these true stories. The museum is very well done though the subject is sobering foir sure. You start with a very good film that asks the question, "adapt, collaborate or resist?" As my father in law was in the Dutch Resistance, turned in by a "quesling" and sent to Buchenwald, this museum was important to our visit to the Netherlands. We were very impressed and would encourage everyone who visits Amsterdam to be sure and this worthwhile and very well done museum!

Awesome! . My husband and I spent over an hour walking through this museum. We loved the fact that they gave you an audio set for free in order to supplement your experience. We watched the 10 minute intro video which was helpful. The museum is really well done, very detailed and informative. We walked through around 2:30 on a Wednesday and it was very quiet which was nice. Some of the display cases are quite narrow so if there was a large crowd that could be an issue. Overall, we loved the museum and would absolutely recommend it!

A Gem of World War II History!. The museum is across the street from the Amsterdam Zoo and the tram stops right down the block! It is an excellent museum for anyone interested in learning about the Dutch experience during World War II and the German occupation. The museum is family friendly, as plenty of children were present. Admission is included as a part of the I am Amsterdam card. Wonderful!

Excellent museum. You will learn the story of the Dutch people in World War II when they were occupied by Nazi Germany from May 1940 to May 1945. Being an American...it's hard to imagine going through what the Dutch people did. Permanent exhibits in the museum recreate the atmosphere of the streets of Amsterdam during the occupation. Photographs, posters, objects, films and sounds from that horrible time, help to recreate the scene. It is an exhibition about the everyday life during that time, but also about exceptional historical events, resistance of the population against the Nazis and heroism.

Well organised; laid out; reasonable price with no hidden extras. Very friendly gentlemen on the desk upon arrival. EUR10 per adult which includes a token for locker and audio guide. We spent just over two hours making our way around the exhibits and information and thoroughly enjoyed the visit. Whether a history lover or not; this is a must see for Amsterdam. Can't recommend it enough.
visit. There are plenty of different scenarios and it gives you time to wonder how you would have coped. There aare also opportunities to sit and watch film clips.

Excellent historical review of Nazi occupation with great info about lessons learned when evil overtakes a city. wow. Being an American, we've never experienced what it is like to be taken over by a regime who's values and behavior you abhor. A great history museum that tells you what WWII was like for the Dutch without sugar-coating-but also done without absolutely grossing visitors (especially the children) out. Three cheers to their brave ancestors, so many of whom resisted the Nazi occupation with all they had. Never forget!
fascinating. great audio guide.we spent about 2 hours there.would be nice if there were more places to sit down while you are looking at the exhibits.lots of information

One great museum. Thoroughly enjoyed this place. Modern, interactive museum which tells the WWII Dutch Resistance story in an effective and informative way. Audio headsets are provided that cater for a range of languages that are a necessity to use.Not as busy as some of the other more renowned museums, it was a pleasure to wander through the exhibits in an unhurried and un-hassled manner.Modestly priced but also covered by the Museum Kaart, it is located opposite the Artis Zoo just a short walk from a Number 9 Tram stop.Would highly recommend a visit here; complements a visit to the Anne Frank House well.

Our Favorite Museum. The Museum tells the story of the Nazi occupation of the Netherlands in WW ll. It was fascinating to learn the history of that and to read the personal stories of how that affected not only individuals but the country as a whole. It was scary and chilling the way the Nazis first started their persecution of the Jews. It was one of those slippery slope things that just kept getting worse and worse. The vast majority of the displays are in Dutch and English. There is also a free audio guide you can use for your specific language. I spent 2.5 hours there and never got to the junior resistance and former colony of the Dutch East Indies during WW ll sections. Having been to both the Anne Frank house and this museum, my advice is if you only have time to see one of them this is definitely the one to go to. During our visit on July 31, 2016, we attended the story teller of Amsterdam, Karel Baracs', presentation/story " Why tram 8 no longer runs." It was excellent and brought tears to my eyes. He is scheduled through the end of August for this so check out the museums website for dates and times.

Would you Fight? Hide? or Collaborate?. A very thought provoking, informative and well laid out museum. I like military history and thought I knew quite a bit about the plight of the Dutch under the Nazi regime. I didn't.... but I do now!As you go around the theme question is "what would you do" if you and your loved ones were in the same situation?There are some tragic and sad stories, but this is a museum about resisting tyranny and the collective bravery shines through.Definitely one of the best places to visit in Amsterdam

Very interesting, informative and thought provoking museum.. This museum was very interesting, lots of interesting information. Available in lots of languages through Personal audio phone. Not a free museum but reasonable cost and well worth it. Junior section was excellent with a added bonus at the end. Great insight to the hardship and suffering of the Dutch people. Well worth a visit. Finish your trip with a coffee and apple pie in the attached coffee shop!

Interesting insight into WW 2 experiences of ordinary people. A chronological story of how the Dutch coped with Nazi occupation of their country. The options made for difficult decisions for many. The displays were quite simple but the variety was sufficient to keep us interested and involved for well over 2 hours. The labelling in English was much appreciated as was the free audio tour.

Decidedly well worth a visit. Telling the day-to-day story of the Nazi occupation of Holland, and the way the Dutch reacted to this, the museum does an excellent job of presenting a complex subject in an engaging manner, despite the difficult nature of the subject.

The adapt, collaborate or resist Museum . An interesting museum but resistance is a relatively small part of the story with the focus resting firmly on the choices between adaption, collaboration or resistance along with the considerable back story of the treatment of the Jews. Having seen numerous examples of Dutch economic and military power over the few days we have been there, it was interesting to see how weak the country has become militarily leaving it with little option but to adapt. The kids loved the Junior Section. As other readers have commented, skip the queues at Anne Frank house, read her diary and come her instead.

History kept alive. An eye opener of what the children experienced during the Nazi occupation. Each from a different perspective depending on their parents beliefs. A must for any age to keep those memories alive.

What do you do when everything around you is going very wrong?. Another sobering reminder of the atrocities of WWII. This museum highlights in a very creative and ingenious way the Resistance Movement within Holland, and also focussed on the ideas of Resistance to an occupying force in other parts of the world as well. The museum introduces us to four young people who were part of the WWII society in Holland and then followed them and how the choices of their parents impacted them all the way to the present -- a brilliant way to bring history to life.

I Had Absolutely No Idea. During our three hours at this incredible museum, I learned so much about what happened during the German invasion of the Netherlands from 1940-1945. As I am a history buff who has visited Amsterdam four times I thought I knew a lot about the Dutch involvement in WWII. I was wrong. I knew nothing. As a retired primary school educator married to a retired High School level Literature and Composition teacher, I was shocked that our collective knowledge of this topic was so extremely limited prior to this visit today. If you teach ANYTHING related to history, literature, world events, social idealism, political activism, etc from students aged eight-up, then this museum is a MUST visit. It will tear at your soul, rip at your heart, and open your eyes in one fell swoop. Located across the street from the huge Artis Zoo, it is easily accessed via tram 14, tram 9, or bus 22. I highly recommend this museum! NOTE: If you require reading glasses, please make sure you bring them. The bulk of this museum is in Dutch. The easy-to-use audio guide is in English, but there are many signs on the wall or in the window-box displays that have the information written in large print in Dutch and in smaller print for English. Due to some of the lower lighting levels in the displays, I had a difficult time reading the smaller print because I did not bring my reading glasses.

Resistance Museum. The museum is packed with things to look at, and gives a really good sense of Amsterdam's history. We had a very enjoyable couple of hours here.
Wheelchair access is good.

Great little museum. Visited here with my daughter. Its all on one floor and there is loads of info, well laid out. If you read everything you looking at around three hours. It is sigmposted in some parts, but a bit tucked out of the way. The staff were really kind and helpful.

Useful Insight Into The Effects Of WW2 On 'Dam. Worth a visit to be more aware of the life lived by Amsterdam residents during the war - also includes accounts of children's experiences that allow kids to compare their life with that of those trying to survive under the Nazis

Worth a visit but...... It was definitely worth a visit but it seems to me that really a more accurate name would be, The WW2 Dutch Experience Museum as there actually are few exhibits that specifically focus on Dutch resistance with most of them focusing on the Dutch experience during WW2 in general. The exhibits they have are really excellent, interesting and informative with a unique personal audio device that wireless connects you to exhibits with information. The museum does an outstanding job at presenting the Dutch experience and it is chilling to see actual Nazi posters and orders of deportation as well as learn about the cruelty and starvation the Dutch and particularly the Dutch Jewish people endured in WW2. The happy and sad stories of life before, during and after WW2 are told in a way that you will not forget.On your way there or back don't forget to take note that it is located across the street from where the civil registry building was destroyed by Dutch resistance to keep the information on where Jewish persons lived in the city from the Nazis. You will also be around the corner from an old Jewish neighbourhood including the theatre that was used as a central depot for those rounded up by Nazis before they were taken out of the city.
Good History Lesson. Nice, quaint museum about Dutch resistance to Nazi occupation. Not a high budget operation, but interesting artifacts and good reminders about what occurred.

Thought provoking. My friend and I purchased the IAmserdam pass and this was one of the museums listed. It is a chronologically arranged history of the Dutch resistance in WWII. We were engaged for nearly 3 hours with stories of how the Nazis invaded the Netherlands and the stories of the people as they dealt with this unbelievable event in their history. The most published incident of this time was Ann Frank; but, in this museum you see that there were many other very similar stories. I am very glad that we had the opportunity to see this museum.

The Missing Tram Number 8.. This Museum is one of the best and,certainly, the most moving I have ever seen.It is difficult to find even though we got off at the correct tram stop near the zoo and locals hadn't heard of it either!You are asked would YOU adapt or collaborate or resist and the question haunted us!It is explained why there is no Tram Route 8 in Amsterdam as that was associated with Jews being taken away.The newspapers,photos,objects,sights and sounds bring it all to life.The staff are excellent and welcoming.

Great musuem!. One of my favourite museums in Amsterdam, the exhibitions were fantastic and the audio guides meant that you received a lot of extra information too. I would definitely recommend a visit, we spent a good couple of hours here!

Marvellous and underrated museum . We arrived here in a recommendation from a friend no we are glad we did. On arrival, the staff were informative and helpful, ensuring we knew exactly how best to view the exhibits. The main museum is fascinating and you may need longer than anticipated as the free audio guide and the reading takes some time. We spent almost two hours here And enjoyed it all.I had two children ages 10 and 12 and the junior section was perfect for them. So much so they went in twice -- a very unusual occurrence in a museum...excellent facility for young people and very educational. Thank you for your excellent museum.

A very good account of the resistance. The museum is quite small but is arranged in a chronological and structured way looking at the history of the Nazi take over and occupation. It has a wealth of accounts from those that endured this time and gives a fascinating insight into the struggle for conformity or conflict. It's a harrowing subject in places but brings out the human nature and willpower of people to stand for what they believe in and is definitely a place to go to

Very Informative yet Personal. This museum really gives a good look into what life was like in the Netherlands during World War II. The information is organized chronologically, but focuses primarily on the experiences of individuals. This focus brings the war to life. I learned a lot from the temporary exhibition on the Dutch East Indies, both about the region and the war in the Pacific. This museum is free with a museumkaart. Most information is available in Dutch and English, and there are audio guides available in many languages. The introductory film is worth watching and sets up the theme of the museum.

Now this is truly special.... An amazing account of the Netherlands during WW2, all in such detail and approachability. If you're interested in the history of a war that shaped this city so much, I would even suggest skipping the Anne Frank House and spend an afternoon here in their beautiful exhibitions.

Disappointed in the presentation. Most of the information is not in English, only Dutch. Poor layout of some otherwise very interesting items. Could have been much better presented. It seemed as though the museum did not want to communicate the story.

Updated but not an improvement. I had the pleasure of visiting the Dutch Resistance Museum several years ago on a previous visit to Amsterdam. During that visit I spent 4 hours there and did not finish seeing the museum. It was one of the highlights of my trip- although the subject is not pleasant, it provided a good understanding of the humanity of the citizens of the Netherlands during a very difficult time in history. This trip, my husband's first, I was anticipating sharing the museum with him and finishing the visit. Much to my disappointment, approximately half the museums space had been dedicated to a section for youth. In order to accomplish this approximately half of the adult section had been removed. The museum now provided a very superficial overview of this very important movement. I was finished seeing it in less than 90 minutes.
Interesting museum. An interesting museum to look into how Dutch residents reacted and resisted occupation. Would recommend if you have an interest in the Netherlands during World War II.
Much to learn here!. Excellent museum. It's not very crowded with many exhibits about the World War. So many things to learn here with videos. A must for those who are interested in history.

Worth a visit. Allow a few hours. . This is a very well presented and informative museum that helps all who visit to understand what life was like fighting the evil of Nazism during the WWII. The courageous real life stories of people's struggles, incredible acts of bravery, and in many cases loss of life was so moving. To do justice to this museum you need to allow a few hours. The information is a combination of audio and reading written material. English audio is very good. Only complaint - it was s bit hard to find the place. Persist. It's worth it. It's across the road from the Artis zoo but the signage isn't all that clear.

Adapt, Collaborate or Resist?. The theme above is how the Resistance museum itself describes the role of the Dutch people during WWII. While the museum is well done (and the self-guided tour comprehensive) I think I was expecting to learn more about resistance efforts, of which there were few. There were some examples, primarily efforts of single individuals, and some interesting stories, such as a baby that got sent to a concentration camp because her parents named her after Dutch royalty and this created a buzz. I'd recommend a visit, just think of it as a WWII history museum.

Excellent museum. I can't believe this museum doesn't get more attention! If you're interested in the occupation in Amsterdam then you will love this museum. It has very detailed and interesting stories from many aspects of the occupation--things I'd never heard of or seen before. It's an interactive place, it has a great (free!) audio guide, but I ended up giving up on it after a bit, mostly because I just prefer reading at my own pace rather than listening along. But many others used the audioguide straight through, I noticed. The nice thing about this museum being vastly underrated is that it's not very crowded. We went around 1030 or 11am on a weekday and while there were a few others there it wasn't crowded at all. That's always nice when you're reading lots of exhibits. We could easily have spent 3 hours there! However we were crunched for time, so after spending about an hour and 45min in the main exhibit, we had to go. We did duck into the "juniors" section for a moment to look at one of the 4 stories of children who lived through the occupation. It reminded me a lot of Daniel's Story at the Holocaust Museum in Washington DC (in a good way). Recommend this stop!

A journey through World War II in the Netherlands. This museum is brimming with history, including information and materials from political parties, propaganda, protests, and a range of underground activities, accompanied by a free audioguide. The introductory video made it seem like there would be more of a narrative in which the visitor would reflect on whether they would have collaborated with, tolerated, or resisted Nazi occupation, and what the consequences of each would have been. I think this would be an excellent addition, particularly for students. That said, I learned a ton. Certainly worth spending a morning or afternoon here!

Great museum of history!. The Resistance museum tells of the history of the Dutch Resistance movement during world war ii. To get through the entire museum with the provided audioguide, you would probably need about one and half hours. Highly recommended to visit!

For WWII enthusiasts . I'd probably rename this museum the occupation museum... It's well done, highly interactive and informative about the period leading up to the German occupation of Holland, the occupation and liberation. Basically 1940-46.
Excellent for young teens to adults.
Very moving. A small museum but very moving in parts at what the Dutch had to put up with. Lots of info with audio. Good cafe next door.

Informative for young generation and history buffs.. Not sure what I had expected of this museum, it was informative, the introductory movie was well done especially for the young generation who have no idea what World War 2 was about here in Amsterdam, and the museum did a good job of chronologically showing the war and the impact that it made on the Amsterdam citizens. We did the self guided tour, without the English audio, all of the exhibits were written in Dutch and English, so that meant reading quite a bit. There were many small movies, and recordings that you could listen to. I came away being more informed on how the citizens of Amsterdam were put in a precarious position. Worth a trip for history enthusiasts.

Elegant neighbourhood. What's not to like about these gorgeous canals lined with elegant centuries old buildings. I took a stroll along the canal and did some photography because it's a true photographers heaven. In the sidestreets there is also plenty to see and to photograph. Lots of little shops and eateries with often cute details. If you want a different angle, take a canal boat that will take you to some beautiful spots. Amsterdam is a unique city and I think it's best to explore on foot or by taking public transportation.

A superb museum. A first rate museum and the highlight of our trip to Amsterdam. The children's section was especially well done. It takes you through the experiences of 4 children which made it very accessible. I would urge any family with children to visit. It would work for any age, mine were 10 and 13 and got so much out of the visit. Added bonus is that it is quiet, no queues and relatively inexpensive. Leave yourself enough time. It closes at 5pm and we were very rushed.

Did the Dutch resist at all?. This was a very nice museum with lots of interesting stories of people who lived under Nazi occupation. I found it to be a nice historical overview of life in the Netherlands during the war.That being said, when I think of "resistance" I think of "sabotage." I saw very little evidence of Dutch citizens trying to sabotage or hinder the Nazi effort. In that sense, the museum was a bit different than what I was expecting.However, this is still worth the effort if you want to get a feel for what living under Nazi occupation was like.

A lot of information packed in a small museum!. Truly interesting history of the Resistance Movement in Amsterdam. Many touching personal stories presented along with artifacts and objects key to the Resistance during World War II. Even my 12 year old nephew and 14 year old niece seemed to enjoy it as they could move along at their own pace and view what interested them! We were able to pretty thoroughly cover everything at the museum in around 2 hours so it's perfect if you don't have a lot of time. Though you could probably spend 3+ hours here if you wanted to see every last display. This would also be a great rainy day activity!
Interesting. Couldn't not come here when we were planning our trip. Lovely quiet museum with audio guides- really powerful experience

Fantastic. Top-notch museum. Presentation is excellent. I felt it really enhanced my knowledge on the topic. The exhibits and examples were well chosen and we lost a few hours in there without really noticing. Well done on such a fantastic museum.

Fascinating history lesson . Very interesting museum representing the choices people faced to 'adjust, collaborate or resist' the Germans. It's a relatively small museum but it's done well in a timeline style with an audio guide to add details. Not a huge amount on the resistance movement itself as the museum is more about living under occupation but it broadened my understanding of how the Dutch reacted during the war.

Incredibly well done!. This museum is so well done. We took our 7 and 4 year old boys and focused on the children's section. The museum maintained their interest for several hours as we learned about the four different children's stories. While the museum does open the doors for some deep conversations about war with children, the exhibits are not grad if or scary. I was very impressed.

Excellent, insightful, no queue!. If you are interested in the story of how Ansterdam withstood the occupation and resisted both the Nazis and their ideology, look no further. The story we know of Anne and her family in the annexe, is only one thread in the WW2 history of the Jewish people's and their gentile friends in this city. The exhibits are personal and human, and are testament to a willingness to oppose that speaks well of Amsterdammers. Overall the story is often more uplifting than you might expect, and in any case it needs to be told.

If you are interested in World War 2 this museum is a must. I went by myself here since the rest of my group took a bike tour in the rain. I must say, I enjoyed my afternoon more than they did :) This is a must see for World War 2 buffs like me. The museum is very well organized and has an interactive part for children. It is a good place to bring children because they do not have all of the graphic pictures in the interactive part like most museums have. To do it justice you need at least 2 hours but can be done quicker. It is right across the street from the zoo which makes it nice for families. There is a nice little cafe next to it.
Small but wonderful. A hidden gem that is located near the zoo and while it is not the most frequented site in Amsterdam it is profound in its effect. Definitely worth a visit.

Amazing museum ...... This amazing museum had been on my bucket list for a while. It definitely lived up to my expectations....my father in laws parents had been part of the resistance when he was a little boy in the Netherlands....this gave me an emotional insight into a little of what he went through. If you are visiting make sure you go into the childrens exhibition...it was awesome.....

A Must of the list of 'to do'. Learning about the 2nd World War always interests me. While searching for things to visit, i found this museum. It is a stone throw from the tram stop. Lovely staff, very informative all the way through and we used the headsets to absorb more information. Learnt a lot that day and very glad we went. Than you

Phenomenal museum!. As a teacher, I can't say enough great things about this museum. It was so informative about the role of the Dutch during WWII and their efforts at resisting the Germans. The two standout pieces to my day here though were the exhibit on the Dutch East Indies and the children's museum, which is part of the larger museum. I wish I could take my students (I live in the States though, so that likely won't happen) as it is designed for hands on and engaging young people. It give the true stores of 4 dutch children, each with different family stories (one from a DutchJewish family, one from a Dutch family, one whose parents joined the NSB, and another who joined the resistance). Kids can watch an intro to their story, and then step into their "homes" and walk through their experience. It is an excellent experience.

Fascinating exhibition on Occupation - makes you think. Well worth a visit. The title is slightly misleading as it is really about what it was like to live under an Occupation (however we knew this, having read reviews about it first). It is set out in a way to really make you think about what life would be like and how you might react, so more than just an historical narrative. Don't underestimate the size - there is loads to absorb you. The AudioGuide is well worth using
Resistance heroes. Difficult to experience but so important to see how so many heroes made a difference. Resistance is not futile....closes at 5 so get there early as 2 hours needed to see it all
Fabulous. This is a very interesting museum that showcases the brave and strong Dutch people who were victimized by the Nazis during the occupation. It's well worth a visit.
Amazing !!. Give yourself plenty of time to see everything in this museum. It gave so much information, and had outstanding displays. A definite must for anyone interested in history.

Where to begin? Our favorite museum during week in AMS. Wow - what a museum! We spent 4 hours there with 12 year old and not even sure we saw it all! Excellent exhibit - really see the life of the Dutch and how their lives changed during WWII. While main exhibit was great, the JUNIOR exhibit was even better. Follow the paths of 4 children - one Jew, one nazi sympathizer, one who is son of resister/clergy and one mesmerized by the excitement of war. You learn their stories through a remarkable and creative exhibit. Then to meet these people through interviews at the end and their fate. 4 children, 4 different positions of war and all damaged by their own situations. No one wins even when it seems some on the winning team. The creativity in putting this exhibit together is just amazing. Also was a photography special exhibit that was quite poignant. Plan a number of hours to see it all, excellent audio tour. Our top pick of all museums.

Interesting Museum. A very interesting museum, but appeared to be more about the occupation rather than the resistance movement - maybe my expectations were not aligned. Anyone with an interest in this area of history I would suggest to visit. Kept us entertained for 2.5 hours

A must visit in Amsterdam. This is a most interesting located near the Amsterdam Zoo. It tracks a most uncomfortable period in Dutch history during WW2.. Whilst many Dutch people resisted the Germans either actively or pasively there was a sizable minority who actively co-operated with them or fought in the German Army.Very interesting, there is a special section for children which presents the German occupation through childrens eyes - including when their parents did/did not support the Germans.A must see if you wish to learn about Holland's dilemas during WW2 and afterwards.

A must see. The museum contained a lot of information on the war in the Netherlands including the strikes and newspapers that I was unfamiliar with. I would highly recommend it to any history lover who visits Amsterdam.

Engrossing. I was recently in Amsterdam for the day and decided to visit a museum. The city is famed for its art galleries so I decided to go for something a bit different, and being a history buff this was the one for me.I arrived just as the museum was opening, I was welcomed by the friendly staff who informed me that the displays have Dutch and English descriptions. I was also offered a free audio guide, which I declined. Just after entering you'll find free lockers for backpacks etc.First off is a video which briefly explains the Dutch experience of the Second World War and the three options that faced the Dutch people: collaborate, adapt or resist. The museum is designed to make you think about how you would react in the same situation. The permanent exhibition is laid out in a chronological fashion, with period items, videos, audio recordings, and first person accounts. The exhibition is engrossing and is difficult to ignore a single item.The temporary exhibit at the time of my visit was a photography exhibition about the Second World War today. It features images of veterans meeting together at battle sites, volunteers searching for the remains of soldiers, re-enactors spending their weekends in uniform, and people visiting concentration and extermination camps.I spent far longer in the museum than I originally intended, but it was certainly worth it.

Great Learning Experience. Dutch resistance knew many differences faces. This museum provides a great insight into how many different ways citizens can battle against oppression and stick together through the harshest of times. Definitely try to visit and go for the free audio guide.

Worthwhile multi-media display museum. Primarily a display museum with both text and free audio players, there is a flow from immediately prior to WW2 through the liberation at the end of the war.It raised the nuanced moral and practical question after an invasion whether to adapt, collaborate or resist at the beginning of the war. It then showed the shift in attitudes toward general resistance.It was educational and worthwhile.Across from the zoo entrance, it was free with the IAmsterdam card.

Engrossing and educational. We went to this museum with our 14-year-old granddaughter and she, my husband I all enjoyed it. Most of the exhibits had excellent translations in English and many also could be accessed by a free electronic device that you simply touched to a symbol to hear more about an exhibit in English.We spent nearly two hours there and would have spent more time there if weird gotten there earlier.Very well done with lots of detail.
