It revealed the real struggle of ordinary people before, during and after the war. I had had no idea of the winter of hunger.This is a don't miss it museum.

If you're interested in history then definitely go. The staff here are lovely and very friendly. The museum is smaller than expected but because you're given an audio tour (using a small Bluetooth box that you can activate whenever you like at different sections) then it can take up to an hour. They have a really interesting section on 4 real life children during the war and how their lives turned out. Each child is different (e.g. Jewish child, child of a nazi etc). If you're into history then definitely go.

A different perspective for WWII history buffs!. Well laid out and informative. Although there is signage in English, non-Dutch speakers should request the audio tour gadget at Reception to fill some gaps. (These devices are activated by waving them across transmitters at various exhibits.)There's a library upstairs with a running visual that provided a good overview of the exhibits and in retrospect it would have enhanced understanding to see this first.Exhibits include crystal radios, methods of concealing weapons and equipment, printing presses used for producing freedom literature, photographs, letters and memorabilia.The museum is very school-age visitor-orientated, with an interesting area in the Verzetsmuseum Junior featuring four fictional children and the options presented to them by the position their parents adopted during Occupation - including collaboration, acceptance, resistance - and the ramifications of those positions Post-War.It's not a big-budget museum but it is educational, at times confronting, but ultimately inspiring.
Disappointed with the content.. Expected to gain an insight to the what and how the Resistance movement operated during the war years. Limited insight to their activities.

Moving Experience. This museum is very impressive, a stark reminder of the past and is brilliantly presented. It is not overly large in area but it's contents will thoroughly engross you and keep you reading for quite a good couple of hours.For the cost of 10 Euros you can wander through the pages of World War 2 history from a Dutch perspective. It is full of photos, videos and static displays that will evoke many emotions within you. You are also provided with a free audio hand piece that will help you understand the various features.It is well worth the effort to go along and be reminded of what should never happen again.

Thought provoking. A fantastic museum that explains the Dutch perspective in the lead up to WWII and the reactions of the citizens to the events that were occurring.The free audio guide was wonderful, as it gave more in depth information than the wall panels alone.I spent 3 hours here and the time just flew (I had thought an hour or so would be enough!)Highly recommended (the micropia museum is nearby which I also highly recommend).

A Must-See if you are interested in World War II history!. We visited this museum a couple of days after doing a walking tour of the city that focused on the Nazi occupation of Amsterdam. This museum gives a fascinating, sobering, and complete picture of what is was like for the people of Amsterdam, both Jewish and non-Jewish, when the city was occupied by the Nazis during the war. You cannot leave without feeling overwhelmed and moved by their experiences. It also makes you appreciate what freedom means and that it is something no one should take for granted.

Six days in Amsterdam.. Good museum, well laid out and presented displays. Bit noisy sometimes which cancels out your personal listening devises. All on one floor, no stairs to climb, but no seats anywhere. Very interesting and enjoyable.
Great to see the Dutch view of WWII. Didn't realise much about the Dutch involvement but this is a real eye opener. Very interesting. The inclusive audio tour is very helpful.

Very interesting museum. This museum provides a good introduction to the Dutch resistance during World War II. The exhibits are interesting and are accompanied by an excellent audio guide. An effort is made to showcase various forms of resistance. There were also many interesting descriptions of individuals who resisted the German occupation during the war.

The best tourist attraction and the most underrated. We were wowed by this museum. It gives a plethora of information about world war 2, the Danish resistance, and does so in an entertaining and empathetic way. We spent at least two hours listening to the audio tour and we probably could've spent another two if we go had come back after lunch. We ate at the cafe next door and it was great. I have a gluten allergy and they made me a sandwich in gluten free bread. Even adults should really check out the junior museum as it is really well done. Compared to the Anne Frank house, this museum was much more comprehensive and gave much more of the bigger picture of the Dutch and their role and reactions to the war. I am conflicted about recommending the junior museum for young kids. The stories of four children are compelling, and yet could be very scary for kids. It all depends when you want them to learn about the horrors of the holocaust. In the main museum there is a big picture of a pile of bones from a concentration camp so I think the main museum is for sure too overwhelming for a child or young adult. I would consider bringing my ten year kid who knows about the Holocaust to the junior side but not my 8 year old. I did see very young children on the junior side. Maybe European children learn about it earlier than Americans. But for adults the whole place is a can't miss. It's slightly off the beaten track, but public trams are very easy to take (the bus stop was Artis). Get their when it opens at 10 and you will have a head start before the school groups get there and make it a bit more crowded.

Amazing and emotional experience . I've been to both the Los Angeles and Washington Holocaust Museum but think this museum is as good or even better especially the Junior part. Planned to spend only 90 minutes but after 2 1/2 hours still could have spent longer. Made excellent use of personal experiences. Thoroughly recommend.

Sobering look at the Netherlands during WWII. This is a great museum for those with an interest in WWII and European history. While the Ann Frank House gets a ton of visitors, this museum gives more information and isn't crowded. Highly recommended
Don't miss this historical museum. Very interesting museum about the period just before and during WW2 in Holland with focus on the Dutch resistance under German occupation. Definitely worth a visit!

Real insight. Very interesting and at times harrowing. I did find the flow of the museum a bit confusing but the exhibits were well presented. Gave you a sense of what people went through, how they felt as victims and standing by watching. Insight into why some didn't try to resist, why some people did and how.

This is worth at least an hour of your time.. We visited this museum in it is sobering. Very well done displays it is good for children as well. Not little children they would be bored. There is a special photographic exhibit by Roger Cremers on World War Two Today. It is a very well worth seeing.

A sad but interesting place. Such an interesting place I learnt so much about the resistance which I did not know or realise while visiting. It is well laid out and you can easily spend a whole day there. Just down the road is the Jewish theatre that was used as a deportation centre which is free to go into and well worth a visit after the museum.

Eh....Mostly Reproductions. Not Really Worth It. I was not impressed by this place. It is strangely laid out and some of the objects on display are in small cabinets that you must look in to so you can see what is inside. There is a separate area for kids, and a wide open space that other displays are shown. When I was there, there was a photo display that took about 10 minutes to walk through. Not being Dutch, the resistance movement was not important to me, and seeing how most of Amsterdam was not destroyed during the war, I was bored to be honest. There are audio guides available at the front desk, and you return them once you finish walking through on a stand near the restroom. Not a bad place, just not super exciting.The museum is directly across from the zoo, which I would have preferred to go to.

Thorough Experience of Dutch Response to the Nazi Invasion. This museum works the themes of response to the occupation beginning in 1940, following a timeline all through. You can learn by reading, listening, looking and therefore understanding the different ways that the people decided to respond... Adjust, cooperate, hide, resist. The junior museum is wonderful in explaining to children the same reactions through 4 real characters. It is well worth about 2.5-3 hours, at a reasonable price for Amsterdam museums and churches.

Worth a visit. I didn't know about the different "Pillars" in Amsterdam's society before WWII, or how quickly the Netherlands was overrun by the Nazis. Went to the Ann Frank house after this, and I think this was the right sequence.

VERY INTERESTING. It's good to know that this brave organisation is remembered. The courage of the men, women and children who were active during the war is beyond words.The museum is easily accessible for all. There is a free audio guide for English. The exhibits are interactive. There is plenty to read,watch and listen to here so allow at least 2 hours for your visit. Well worth a visit

One of the most important WW2 sights in the Netherland. I spent a few hours there, many interesting information about WW2 and Nazi occupation of Netherlands, free audio guide, with detailed information.
Very well organized, you just need to follow the history line as you walk through, would recommend it to anyone interested in history.

Very very interesting. Loved this museum we went in the junior part as well and found it really good you follow the story of four children with different backgrounds all living in amsterdam during the occupation I think children would find this riveting it is easy to get commentary in your own language by just pointing the ear thing round your neck at the symbol on the wall.

best way to understand what happened in Holland during WW2. Good museum, very clear in its explanations, exhibits and presentation. Not surprising the won an award. Interesting for children as well and sometimes they show additional expos. Location near the former jewish quarterof the town and good to combine with the monumental jewish theatre (joodsche schouwburg) which is a memorial to the jewish citizens of Ammsterdam that were sent to the extermination camps.
Great unexpected gem. Figured a good place to spend an hour, spent 3 hours and worth every minute. Educational and sobering look at a terrible time in our history

Second World War. Very informative and interactive. The price was included in the Museum Card, and the audio guide was free.The audioguide allowed one to hear the basics, and then choose to hear more.We spent a pleasant hour wandering around the exhibits.
Spent All Day.............. This is one of the greatest places we went while in Amsterdam.Learned more in one day than last two years in high school.

Good substitute for Anne Frank-It´s not about one girl but about 80,000 people!!. When we decided to visit Anne Frank´s house, 3 weeks before our trip I found out the the tickets were sold out and with only 4 days in the city I didnt want to spend precious time in line. It isn´t easy to find this museum since it isn´t in the main reviews and in the free maps but it was a great pick!! You will find out about the Jewish occupation before WWII and how the country struggled to resist the Nazi occupation. It´s not about one girl but about 80,000 people!!

Visit Here Before You See the Anne Frank House. This museum was outstanding. I had no idea of the suffering that occurred in The Netherlands before and during WWII. After visiting, you have a new appreciation for the Dutch people and their strength during this terrible period of time. I recommend visiting this museum before you visit the Anne Frank House, because you will have a better understanding of the sacrifices which were made by the people who sheltered the Frank family and the others who were in hiding with them. We found the staff here quite helpful. We intended to purchase our Museumkaart tickets here, but they had only one ticket (There were two of us.), and the person responsible for the tickets was in a meeting. We were allowed to enter with one ticket and then returned to the reception desk later to purchase the other ticket. I believe that they went out of their way to accommodate us, since the museum was closing in 1 1/2 hours when we arrived. We are normally NOT directionally challenged, but we had a difficult time finding this museum. The best advice is that it is across the street from the entrance to the zoo.

must see. excellent but very sad, very informative about things that happened that were never told must see on your visit - to get there you catch a tram there and back from the city, near the train station

interesting insight into life in occupied Amsterdam & the heroic deeds that saved lives. Could have spent many more hours here as it was fascinating! Wide range of exhibits - some interactive - detailing personal stories and events throughout the occupation and the struggles of daily life & those who aimed to fight the subsequent oppression & persecution!Definately should be on the must-see list for anyone interested in history.

Informative . Having visited several WW2 museums which has made me want to find out more about the resistance, this was an obvious museum to visit. Much of the exhibition focused on the war which was interesting but I was hoping to find out much more about the actions of the resistance. There were some stories and information but I had hoped for a little more. However, it is still definitely worth a visit
Thing to remember. This Museum has an interesting history of the resistance movement, who saved over 7000 Jews during the Nazi they saved over 7000 Jews during the Nazi occupation of Amsterdam.

Fascinating. This museum is definitely my favourite in Amsterdam. It has loads of information about WW2 in Holland and how the Dutch were treated as well as how they responded. The museum is great with lots of interesting artefacts and has a lot of voice clips too. It also features an original cell door which is shocking to look at. A definite must for those interested in this kind of history.

Mediocre. PRICE It was extremely pricey for three people ( I think at this point we regretted not buying an Iamsterdam card, for free entrance into museums). You do get an audio player included though. IMPRESSIONSThe map before you enter the museum suggests it is small and you do one big loop, in actual fact there are many "side rooms" which you can easily get lost from and dates can get mixed up easily too. A better guidance system is needed. Considering how long it actually was, there were no seats and only 4 grab-and-take seats outside to be taken in. In this instance it didn't feel fair to take these seats away from those who needed more but after a long day walking anyway, I needed somewhere to plant myself half way round and round nowhere. There was an amazing photographic gallery which explores the WW2 for the younger generations. It considers that museums and memorials etc Aushwitz are no longer deemed as symbols to remember and think of those involved, but just a day out and tourist attraction. It also looks at reinactments of the war and deems it disrespectful that people are using the war as a reason to play and have fun. This was a thought provoking exhibition which has planted something significant in my mind. AMENITIES There are toilets I believe, but I never found them. A cafe near the entrance which is also accessible from the front street. Lockers for your bigger bags and a book for your opinions.

Everyday lives of people under the Nazi occupation. Visited in December 2014. The museum was one of the best ones I've ever been, very interactive, not too cramped and so informative on an important subject. "Resistance" might be a bit misleading name for the museum, or not the best one to descripe the actual content. In case you didn't already know, it's about the Nazi occupation and the viewpoint is how it affected the the lives of regular people. I always enjoy the micro level stories and it was very nicely done. Can't remember whether the audio tour is included in the entrance price but if it's not, do take it - it's a good one.
Excellent exhibits and displays. Although a bit disorganized, this is a very good museum with many documents and exhibits on display. Allow at least 90 minutes.

Brilliant. Absolutely loved it. Well set out, informative & interactive museum covering everything you may want to know about the resistance. We took two youngsters (14 and 11). The elder was absorbed by the main museum, and the younger in the junior section which includes replicas from 4 children's stories. Great learning space.

amsterdam june 2016. A history lesson for then Netherlands during WWII. Lots of information and pictures. The museum is somewhat hard to find. Look for the zoo, it is on the opposite side of the street.

Absolutely fascinating. If you're in Amsterdam you really should go to this museum, it's so interesting - those Dutch were a ballsy lot! Only downside is that with some of the exhibits you are not sure in what direction you should be heading so events are sometimes out of place

Worth seeing . Nice exhibition, very informative, time well spent! During your visit you will get to know the history of Dutch resistance as well as the history of 4 children who had different social status - a Jewish girl, a girl whose parents were a part of Dutch nazi party, a boy whose parents were a part of the resistance movement and.. I forgot the fourth right now. I recommend!

Interesting and informative. We visited here one rainy afternoon and found it interesting (especially my history buff husband)- I would definitely recommend if you have a few hours to spare in Amsterdam.

Excellent museum on ww2 conditions in Holland. Both my parents were children or teens during ww2 and lived in Holland. They have not really talked about what happened during this time. This museum does tell me what happened and why. It also covers what happened in the Dutch East Indies where my Dad served in the Navy after the war. The displays answered a lot of my questions. I also got the calendar so that I can read the background information at my leisure. I would highly recommend this museum

Very informative, but they can do better with the exhibits.. Not everything is in English, only dutch. 90% of the exhibits looks like middle school school presentation. Anyway, you learn a lot about the resistance during the Nazi occupation of the Netherlands.

Interesting visit but left some unanswered questions. The museum is easy to find - take the number 9 tram to Artis and walk 150m and you are there. I enjoyed many of the displays but came away wondering what the war was like for the Resistance and their families.

Wonderful Historical Museum. This museum chronicles the history and heroism of the Dutch Resistance during WWII. It is wonderfully curated with ample information about each of the exhibits. Many exhibits are multi-media driven to give you a better feel of the era and the movement.The staff here is wonderful. Very helpful with my handicapped mother and gave us tips on how to get the most out of the exhibits.If you like history, this is a great musuem for you.

Very Cool Museum. This museum was quite cool, and I learned a great deal from the exhibits. It is informative, well laid-out, and a great way to spend some time. They have a special exhibit specifically for children, which I didn't see because there were school groups there and I didn't want to disturb them. I would definitely visit again.

Interesting and unusual. Interesting account of Holland during the occupation. In Dutch (well, obviously!) but comprehensive English explanations. Much of it concentrates on "home life", rather than "derringer do", but of course that's how it was for most people. Also a reminder of the old Dutch East Indies during the war. Well worth a visit.

MOST INFORMATIVE BUT MISSING DETAIL. The various sections provide an insight into the activities of the Resistance during WWII and the coercion used on the majority of the dutch population by the Nazis.Additional "off site" reading for me provided additional information. At the peak of the resistance movement there were 300,000 members. The population of the Netherlands was 8,800,000.

Very informative. We decided to go here after visiting the Anne Frank House.This is a very interesting and informative museum. My advise to anyone thinking of visiting this museum is give yourself plenty of time. We thought it would be small but its not. Well worth a visit

Educational and Thought Provoking. For anyone with an interest in history or in human behavior, this is a important place to visit. The lead-up to WWII is well done, including a great description of the various political factions of the time. The question posed during the introductory film is whether each of us have been a resistor, a collaborator or an adaptor to the occupation. The museum then does an excellent job of presenting the consequences of each of these choices. The choice to resist was certainly a dangerous one and the bravery and ingenuity of the citizens who followed this path is to be respected and admired. All citizens of the world must be mindful of stereotypes and the demonization of entire groups of people. The old saying, "We must know our history or be doomed to repeat it." has never been more true.

Resistance misnomer. I wanted to know more about the Dutch resistance so visited this museum. It is resistance in the broadest sense and anyone after spy's, SOE, resistance fighters and escape networks will be sadly disappointed. The museum would be better titled 'Amsterdam occupied'. It was informative and the personal stories where harrowing and covered the years of occupation. The suffering of the population, the deportation of the young Dutchmen and then any men capable of slave labour for the German war effort and of course the plight of the Jews of any age or sex. Quite a bit was made about the passive resistance and underground press, and brave efforts to stop the Jews being sent to work and then extermination and the work done to forge exemption certificates for the Dutch. Why most of the exhibits were crammed behind small viewing slits forcing you to wait inline to see them l do not know. That was unnecessary and very frustrating. I can only presume it was to make you stay longer. A mainly document orientated museum.

Well done especially the children's exhibit. We pre booked tickets but found that it wasn't really necessary. This is a smallish museum (though we still stayed there for nearly 3 hours) which focuses on the choices that regular Dutch citizens needed to make under German rule: To try and ignore it and carry on, to collaborate or to actively resist, and the ways that this played out and the repercussions for resistors during German rule and for collaborators following it. The children's exhibit was especially hood we thought for adults and children alike. It was hands on and followed the experiences of 4 (real) children and their families. It also provided mock ups of houses where people were hidden (many people needed to be hidden, not only People of the Jewish faith) and encouraged interaction with the dilemmas faced by citizens. The entry fee includes an audio set which provided excellent coverage of the exhibits. This was a really good museum that brought the problems faced by Dutch citizens to a level of realism.

Fabulous. I really wanted to go here but my husband wasn't so keen. However... what a really well done and interesting place this is. We've been to the museums in Berlin and obviously in the UK but this was from a completely different perspective which we found really interesting. Well worth going, would highly recommend a visit and would go back in a year or two

A great place. What a place, thoroughly hooked from the time we entered. A very moving tour especially thought provoking. Not just for history buffs a must for everyone. A great experience for children too with their own exhibition where they could take on a character from the war.
Great for kids. We used the audio tour which was really interesting and the special childrens area was really good for adults too. We all learnt alot.

Very educational. I learned so much at this museum about how the Netherlands was affected after the German invasion. The things some had to go through and decisions that had to be made. Shocking in most cases but really interesting to learn. The coffee shop next door is worth a visit too.

Fantastic. Would totally recommend this if you are visiting Amsterdam. We were met by a very informative gentleman who gave us so much information. The museum is fascinating and thought invoking. What they must have gone through, I could never imagine. If you like museums then this is a must, can't recommend it enough.

The section for children is really good.. This museum is located opposite the main entrance to the zoo and we found it by accident.It was very good, particularly the children's section which portrayed their experiences during WW2 fro 4 different perspectives. If you are short of time, or do not want to go round the rest of this exhibition, go to the children's part. It sums up the situation very succinctly.Wee done! We really found it very interesting and most informative.

Thought Provoking . Smaller scale museum but packed full of interesting and thought provoking relic's from WW2. Not suitable for children (expect they would get bored quickly) but great for grown-ups. Its important for places like this to exist to remember the atrocities of WW2 and ensure they don't happen again.

Incredible Amsterdam Museum!. This is the perfect place to spend a rainy morning in Amsterdam! Get there early, right when they open, and you will be able to enjoy spending a leisurely visit before tour buses and school children arrive. There is a delightful pastry shop next door for a quick latte and apple tart to fortify you! Be sure to get the audio guide, as it is easy to use and super informative. We bought our tickets on line in advance, and this helped us enter quickly. The stories of the brave Dutch people are very moving and will bring you to tears. I learned SO MUCH! If you are a WWII buff, this is a must see.

Wonderful Educatiional Experience. This is a nice quiet museum, or it was on the day we visited anyway, located across from the Artis (zoo). It was a little busy when you first enter the exhibit but the visitors pan out as you proceed further into the museum. Museum is very interesting and informative, we also visited the Ann Frank house the following day which was a great follow up from what we had learned at this museum. There is a separate junior museum for ages 9 and up which is also interesting for adults.

Great museum but hard to find. We walked from Anne Frank's house & had a terrible time finding the museum but it was worth the trip. It's an audio guided tour with options for additional information so you can take as much time as needed based upon your interest. I found it to be very informative but the flow pattern was a bit confusing. The museum does close promptly at 5 so be sure to plan enough time, it may seem small but it's packed with information. The staff was very friendly & even called a taxi for us so we would have an easier trip back to our hotel.

Very educational and very well done. Very well documented musuem which has an audio guide in numerous languages. The labels are in Dutch and English but the audio tape provides more information. An excellent progression through time of information covering the Resistance Period in the Netherlands. A great value - in May 2016 the entrance which included the audio guide was 10 euro. They also provide a free locker for your belongings. You may take photos without flash. Well worth your time when in Amsterdam
Worth a visit. Interesting. Lots of information. Great idea giving out personal audio so you could listen at your own leisure

Good few hours. All based only on the resistance. Good few hours not too long and can get through quicker if needed. Audio available. Staff fantastically informative. Interesting to see the Dutch East Indies included. Can have a break in cafe and go back. Would be improvement to have sections numbered so flows better as was little confusing.

Don't miss it!. This museum was one of the best in town, we thought. It gave an overview of the Nazi occupation and the Dutch resistance, along with presenting enough details and personal artifacts to make it all very relatable and personal. I highly recommend a visit here. I found it engrossing and left wanting to find books to keep learning more.
Interesting. A different perspective but illuminating. The difficulties of being occupied and divided in support (some fascists and some strongly opposed). A different side to this story.

Would recommend this museum if you have any interest in history/WWII. This was a highlight of our trip. We visited this museum after visiting the Anne Frank house. I think it's a great museum and it helps explain the situation in Holland during Anne Frank's years here. We spent two hours in the museum. The museum gives a chronological breakdown of WWII events from the perspective of different groups of people in the Netherlands at this time. Most of the information was translated into English and the route through the museum was easy to follow. It also contained lots of interesting little snippets of information that you probably wouldn't find online or in a book.
Great little museum. Great museum - They have a walking map that takes you from the museum to Anne Frank House with stops in between with resistance movement information.

Excellent, informative and moving museum. This is a really interesting museum - it is careful at the entrance to let you know that the aim of the museum is to provide information on the different aspects of resistance without offering judgement and I think it achieves this aim. The information and displays in Dutch and in English, with a free audioguide, are engaging and informative, and gave me a lot of food for thought. I thought it dealt with the idea of resistance against an occupying force and the different points of view, and different coping mechanisms on this sensitive subject really well. Definitely worth a couple hours' visit and a return visit - lots to think about and to take in.

Worth your time. We were impressed by this museum. Their new children's exhibits were excellent. Though we were traveling without our kids, it made me wish ours could experience this museum. We travelled last year, but I still recall many of the exhibits vividly. I'm thankful to have learned so much.

Don't miss it. I add my recommendation to not miss this museum. It does an excellent job of detailing the experiences of Amsterdam (and the Netherlands in general) citizens under Nazi occupation during WW II. To me, it was a very moving experience. In fact I ended up spending over 2 hours touring the exhibits. While there are English translations for some of the artifacts, translation is not available for everything. For that reason, the audio tour is absolutely necessary to fully absorb the exhibits. We arrived at opening time on a weekday without an advance reservation and had no problem getting in without a wait.

Take time to visit this musem. Really interesting to hear more about the resistance movement in Holland during the war. The museum is ideal for children and the free audio guide is very useful. Always the question - what would you have done? This question is always relevant, now as then.

Outstanding museum!. The Resistance Museum is a glimpse into life in the Netherlands during the Nazi German occupation from 1940 to 1945, and it really is extremely well done. The curators make an incredible use of space (which, the Dutch are pretty great at this, so it makes sense!) to really guide visitors through the chronology and some of the finer details. You'll want to come with plenty of time and energy, as it's a lot to digest. Having a variety of media and interactive parts of the exhibit helped. Absolutely get the (free) audio guide. Very much worth the visit, one of my favorite museums I've ever visited.

Emotional and thought provoking journey back in time. I would highly recommend a visit here - you are taken on an interactive journey through the Dutch resistance during the Second World War and it really is fascinating to see how people survived. What these people did for themselves, their families and complete strangers to keep them from harm is astounding.The emotion of the photographs and stories really is palpable and this museum is a fantastic way to preserve the memories of the brave people of Holland.

Worth a visit but hard work. Fascinating information on the resistance and Netherlands during WW2.Media guide is a must, although you really have to keep your eyes open for the markers- missed quite a few.Can be quite emotionally harrowing, but you should know this before you sign up of course.Not on same scale as Van Gogh or rijkmuseum but informative and worth a visit

Good Overview and Exhibits. Thought this museum was well done. It gave a good overview of the issues of the time. It also presented the issues of Dutch colonization of Indonesia and their fight for independence.
Learn about the Dutch resistance.. Very informative museum with a great deal of history and facts about WWII.make sure to see the opening film upon arrival.

Impressive thought provoking museum. This little museum packs a real punch and at 10 euros a tickets (at time of review) it is a must do. It really delivers in telling the story of the resistance movement and its importance in the occupied Netherlands of World War Two. It doesn't white wash over any of the struggles faced and the harsh often brutal reality of this time. The other part of this museum looking at The Netherlands colonial past is also interesting and the changing exhibit was also fascinating, looking at how we perceive and interact with sites of war has changed.I would certainly recommend this museum if you are visiting Amsterdam. Staff were also friendly and toilet facilities were available.

Don't miss this museum to help you understand the impact of the German occupation of the Netherlands during WWII. exhibits are very well done showing how the Dutch people coped during the German occupation of their country during WWII.

Disturbing And Honesty. Don't miss the children's section. This museum makes an honest and thoughtful attempt to look at troubling moral issues. There was also an excellent special exhibit on the dutch colonial role in Indonesia that was disturbing but again painfully honest.

Impressive Museum !. The verzetsmuseum is a very good alternative if its to busy for the Anne Frank House, it gives im impressive image and memorial on the awful things that happened during the war with the jews and what the people did to resist the Germans

Extensive and well thought-out. Lots to see and read and learn in this very informative museum. Really put things in perspective regarding the decisions ordinary Dutch people had to make when Hitler took over their country: adjust, collaborate, or resist.

Absorbing and thought-provoking: don't miss it!. We visited this museum one afternoon and spent about 2.5 hours wandering through, reading and listening and looking. It offers a thorough and fascinating presentation of the ways in which the Dutch people responded to the Nazi occupation during WWII. Well worth the time, and particularly helpful to children and youth who may be unaware of the severity of challenge faced by the Netherlands during the late 1930s and into war years. It also helps to raise one's awareness of the importance of taking a stand against present-day anti-democratic speech and actions. A must-see for anyone visiting Amsterdam.

Decent museum with a fantastic temporary exhibition. This museum provides a detailed look at the Dutch Resistance during WWII - so basically what it says on the tin. The Dutch language is obviously hard to follow but the audio guide is extremely thorough and major blocks of information are provided in both Dutch and English. The highlight for me, however, was the temporary exhibition of photography from Roger Cremers, which examines the notion of remembrance tourism. The exhibition is only till September, but I'm sure it'll be replaced by something just as good. A must for any people interested in WWII history

Resistance Museum showed how the people rebelled and over came a bit of the NSDP rule and started recovery of the people. I came to this museum realizing what was going on and how they worked to quicken the recovery of the people to become self ruling after the NSDP were out and how the people can make a difference once they work together.
Very well done!. Gave a great overview of what the Dutch went through during the occupation. All the displays were described in English which made it very easy to follow.

Great Additional Museum to Combine with Anne Frank House. This museum gives a complete timetable of Nazi activities against the Jewish population in Amsterdam during World War 2. Combined with a visit to the Anne Frank house, one can begin to understand the terrible times the Jewish population endured. A very moving museum. Very interesting. Time needed here at least two hours. Free with the Museumkaart. Make sure you get an audio guide.

Moving and thoughtprovoking. Handily near the Zoo and Maritime Museum, this would be part of a great day out, though definitely worth a visit in its own right. The main exhibits tell the broad story of the Nazi occupation in Amsterdam, while offshoots look in depth at the personal stories of people who resisted in simple ways, or were torn by their hatred of what was happening, yet who feared even more what would happen if they did not collaborate. I thought I knew quite a bit about the occupation, but this taught me a lot more about the workers' movements. The whole is packed with photographs, posters, original documents and eyewitness testimony which makes for a fascinating visit.

Love this place. Visited twice!. We toured this museum several years ago. So much information we ran out of time and swore we would return. The name of the museum is misleading because the museum is so much more than the resistance. Politics, collaborators, persecution of the Jews, the hunger winter and the drafting of men to work in Germany were topics well covered by this museum. Must see for historians.

Very educational . We enjoyed our visit to the Tristan's museum and it really helped put things together after just having visited the Anne Frank house. The displays were well done and the audio tour was excellent. The only slight negative thing was some times to was hard to know where the audio tour was referring to because each sound station covered several displays and some times we did not know exactly where they were referring to. Would recommend a visit and it took us about two hours to do the whole tour.
Interesting. Very interesting museum which we enjoyed visiting, loved the world war 2 today exhibition. all on the ground floor as well, so great for less abled visitors.

Very informative . Glad to have spent an hour in this well designed and unique museum. Felt it was a must to understand this important time in the history of The Netherlands. Information presented in unique and personal ways. Special section designed for children creative and educational. Highly recommend a visit to this museum.

EXcellent museum about the Dutch Resistance during WW2. This is an excellent, self-guided museum about the Dutch Resisatance during WW2. All displays have both Dutch and English audio and visual descriptions, including an audio pod guide which you bring with you and touch to the various audio guides by most of the displays. Very well done.

A few interesting stories. We did learn a lot about the Dutch resistance and the brave people who were involved in it. However, after visiting the Camp des Milles transition camp in Aix-en-Provence, this one was not nearly so interesting. Had I not visited Camp des Milles, this museum would have been more striking. The best part of the museum for me is the personal stories and quotes from individuals involved in the resistance.

Nice museum, not much of resistance . The museum in nice and tells a lot about the Netherlands in the time of the war. Also, tells a lot about the Jews in the war and it was very interesting. But we thought, that there was not enough about the Dutch resistance, considering the fact that the museum is supposed to be about it.. I think it's also a good museum for kids (starting 10-11 years old) about the subject.

A testament to human bravery and strength. A smaller attraction than the more well known museums and galleries but still one that is worth seeking out. When visiting Amsterdam it is easy to get tunnel vision and she the Anne Frank museum as the only insight into those troubling times. The Resistance Museum offers a wider look into one of the darkest times in modern history. There is a degree of overlap, and how could there not be, but one of the strengths of this museum is in showing the little ways in which the general public rebeled, resisted and otherwise assisted Jews, the Allies and made things difficult for the occupying forces. A very worthy place to visit.The Musuem was also hosting a temporary Children's exhibit. Warning! This exhibit can break you. Detailing the fate of trains full of children shipped from Amsterdam to Sobibor, it is almost too successful in personalising this atrocity; which almost lends itself to abstraction through the massive figures. Brilliant but haunting.

Never forget. This museum is a must for all visitors, children and adults., to Amsterdam. The presentation of the story of how the Dutch participated with and also resisted the evil forces that devastated Europe is particularly important in these troubled times.

Excellent!. This was our first stop during our visit to Amsterdam. It is very well set up, especially the section about four children who lived during the Nazi occupation. The area in the museum that discussed the Dutch involvement in the West Indies was also informative. Well worth a visit!

Informative. This museum is very informative. On entering we were told it was all in English but sadly it wasn't. We don't read or speak Dutch so were unable to access all the museum has to offer. There is a LOT of reading!

Bring some time. You should bring some time when you go there and want to see everything. Many interactive parts and a good audio guide.
A must do when you have some more days in Amsterdam.

Don't Miss this Museum!. On our last day in Amsterdam we made sure we got over to this museum. It is extremely well done! It explains the Nazi occupation and the reactions of the Dutch in 3 differnt ways. Some chose to be collaborators, others to passively accept, and many to resist the Nazis. While many picture captions are in Dutch we found there was enough English to explain what was happening in each. The bravery and strength of many of the citizens was remarkable! Those that joined the Nazi's didn't fare so well. This will take you about 1 1/2 hours to enjoy. If you get an opportunity, go to Arnhem and see the museum there too!
Better than Anne Frank house..... Good overview of the situation in the Netherlands during the war. Way better than Anne Frank house, without the hassle and waiting.

an unusual WW2 museum. If you go to see artifacts, equipment, etc., you'll be disappointed. The thrust of this museum is how different people chose to be collaborators, to passively accept, or to resist the Nazis. Although placards and some audio is in English, obviously most of the displayed posters, newspapers, etc. are in Dutch or German, so you won't get much out of it if you can't read those languages.

Small but great. This was a very nice small museum. I had no idea of the history of Amsterdam and WWII - other than the Anne Frank story. This really tells the story of the sacrifice of the people of Amsterdam.
Interesting. Lots of interesting details maybe things I hadn't heard of. Plenty of audio detail and original artefacts on display.

Amazing tour guides. I visited this museum as a maths teacher on a school trip with a bunch of disaffected 13 year old girls who were not happy at the thought of another museum. We had a tour starting with a film and the whole experience was amazing. The guide (they all spoke perfect English) had our girls enthralled, desperate to answer his questions, to ask questions of their own, and to know everything he had to tell them. I myself am rather disinterested in history but found his explanations deeply affecting and have thought about the museum a lot since then. I plan to visit Amsterdam to take my own daughter there when I can.As an aside... While we were visiting I decided that a girl on the trip needed hospital care for an injury she had sustained earlier. The museum called us a taxi, and one of the guides, Marjon, came to the hospital with us to translate. She stayed with us, teaching us Dutch, for the several hours we were at the hospital, and then helped us to find the rendezvous with our tour coach. Whether that says more about the Dutch people or the museum staff I'll leave it to you to decide, but I was bowled over...

Interesting but not compelling. I did find the museum interesting in understanding the political and social climate in the pre and inter war years but learnt little about the actual activities of the resistance that I wasn't aware of already.

Very Powerful Experience. This museum told the story of average Dutch people and how there lives were affected by the German occupation during WW2. It was amazing to realize the great negativeimpact these people felt.

If You're a History Buff - You Will Like This Museum. This smaller museum gives a first-rate presentation of WWII and the Dutch Resistance to the Nazis. The exhibits artistically display the chronological sequence of the Nazi movement. Photos, artifacts and videos galore.Even the West Indies conflict was covered near the end of the self-guided tour (audio headsets provided in your choice of language). Museumkaart accepted (and highly recommended if you were visiting several museums in the Netherlands.)My wife and I also toured the Jewish Historical Museum but preferred the Resistance Museum because of the extent of the history of WWII.

A must see exhibition of the forces that countered one another.. With Hitler taking advantage of the financial woes in the 1930's and promising to make the country great again, his forces conquered much of Europe in short order. The Dutch language made the Netherlands suffer slightly less at first but soon their people were being threatened and resistance to the German war machine as well as the Nazi sympathizers in Holland was required. The resilience of the local populace was demonstrated by the resistance. Very informative and moving.

Educational trip through human experience in a time of extreme duress. We knew little about how the Dutch dealt with the invasion, and gradually realised that there could be no compromise and had to organise and make underground war against the Nazis. Very well illustrated in creatively curated displays. An underrated treasure.

Well worth a visit. This was a very well done museum of the Resistance in Amsterdam. It was recommended to us by our Holocaust walking tour guide. Some interactive displays and many personal testimonials by the brave resistance fighters in Holland. I would highly recommend a visit here! We're sure glad we did!

Good Museum. The Resistance Museum is a great stop for learning about the German occupation of the Netherlands - especially if you are using the Holland Pass - silver admission. The free audio is helpful and the displays are informative. It is easy to reach by tram.

Unexpected surprise! . We decided to head towards this museum to investigate.It didn't look very exciting from the exterior however, it was very informative and made you think.about the difficult decisions the Dutch had to make under German occupation.A definite MUST SEE!
A bit out of the way, but riveting. Moving exploration of the history of the German occupation during WWII. It does not try to make heroes of the entire Dutch nation, but truly tells it like it was.

Unimpressive from the outside, but totally captivating inside. The free audio guide is excellent, and the displays with their commentary (in both Dutch and English) was even better. Resistance to the Nazis' takeover of the Netherlands was fascinating, especially as the restrictions increased. This museum really put the Anne Frank story in all of its scary context.
Worth the trip. Fascinating how the Dutch Resistance movement was such a pain for the Nazis. Well worth while lest we forget how horrible the Nazis were.
worth a visit. Very interesting museum. It is not very big but shows you how the Dutch people managed during the occupation.Headphones available to relate the stories to you.
A real insight into wartime life in Holland. Gives some idea of the dilemmas facing ordinary people faced with an increasingly oppressive and brutal regime
Worth a visit!. I wasnt that keen in going here, but very glad I did. Interesting exhibits brought history to life and gave me a much better understanding of WW2

Informative and emotional. This museum is packed with information! My favourite was reading the personal accounts of resistance in Dutch history. It was very interesting to learn about and bear witness to the struggles during Nazi occupation. You definitely need lots of time to see it all though!

Muddled museum. This museum should be called "Life in Amsterdam during the 2nd world war. It did include information about the way the population tried to resist the Germans, but it covers much more than that. There is also a section on Indonesia.The museum is interesting and the audio commentary quite good, but the display is old fashioned and needs updating.It takes about 2 hours to go round listening to the whole commentary.

Must see. A visit to this museum is an insight and eye opener to learn great deal more about resistance against Nazi occupation during WW2, in comparison to Resistance Museums dotted all over France, this museum is altogether very different. it's a must see must go.

Good alternative for the Anne Frank house. WW II has had a deep impact on this country. Rotterdam has lost his heart, but rebuilt a vibrant city. But Amsterdam lost its soul by the near extinction of the Jewish community of 100.000. This museum provides information about this war and does so very well. Especially for children as well. I was impressed. The museum is located opposite Artis Zoo and near the old synagogues. Its name Resistance museum is a bit misleading, because it is more about WW II. I suggest to skip the long queues of Anne Frank house and go here instead.

Very informative and well set out museum. This museum is located near the zoo and an easy tram trip from the centre of town. Admission prices were quite reasonable. The exhibition were well displayed and information. for us the main feature was that the information about the display was in English. The museum gives a very good insight into what happened during the occupation.
Resistance Museum. This museum presents the stories of people who lived in Amsterdam during the German occupation in WWII. It is very well done. Give yourself 2 hours to fully experience this museum.

The strength of the people. The Dutch Resistance Museum. A story of the dutch people in WW2, suffice to say, life was grim during this period of nazi occupation. A very good exhibition, excellent audio presentation, definitely a must see.

The Resistance Museum. This museum was extremely informative and very interactive for adults and kids alike. I did find it a bit hard to follow some sort of path through the exhibit however so I know maybe markers or signs would make the transition from one area to the next a little easier. I would recommend this visit follow the World War II Walking Tour if possible.

Enlightening. This museum chronicles how the Dutch responded to the Nazi's occupation of Holland. Some supported the Nazis, some detested them and helped Jews hide and escape the terrors of wars and concentration camps. If you have a couple of hours to spare in Amsterdam, this is a recommended stop. Accessible by tram. Located across the Amsterdam zoo.

Thought-provoking museum. History should teach us something and this thought-provoking museum challenges the visitor to imagine what course of action they would have taken in similar circumstances - collaboration? Pacifism? Resistance? Without realising fully what would have been the consequences of each action, it can be too easy for us to judge unfairly; the museum endeavours to present each case and for this reason this visit proved to be very informative if debatable. The displays are detailed, though occasionally I found reading the font a little difficult, but the audio guide helped with this. Occasionally the route round was a little confusing. Overall, however, an interesting approach to this subject.

Amazing. I never expected to spend as long as i did in this museum. It is really fascinating and well worth visiting. A little off the beaten track away from the usual museums, but worth the effort. Incredible array of stories and information,with lots of nooks and crannies holding more stories. Very well presented.

Museum requires at least 2 hours to get round.. Lots to read and watch about the resistance movement and first hand stories. It is set out in a very varied and interesting manner, although, it is similar in many ways to other museums, books and TV showings.

Didn't go in the museum, but the restaurant is to be avoided. Slow service and mediocre food at elevated prices -- this place should be avoided if you can help it. Maybe it was our fault for being foolish enough to choose a restaurant connected to a museum, but we were tired and needed some food. The two waitresses were busy and possibly also just kind of disinterested; it took a long time for everything, from ordering to getting the bill. At the end my girlfriend asked for a top-up on hot water in her teacup--for these 10 oz of hot water they charged us full price for another tea. Not the waitresses fault, but apparently their restaurant policy. Classy.

Study Abroad Museum Trip. I went to the Dutch Resistance Museum with my study abroad group from Radford University in the U.S.A. It was the best walking tour I went on all summer. I visited the museum in July of 2015. We took a private tour with Femke Akerboom. I will never forget her, nor the words she spoke to us. She took us on a sobering walk through Amsterdam. She spoke with such passion and connection to her city. I had the pleasure of talking with her about books for my classroom because I was studying to be a history teacher. I purchased books and refer to them now as I begin to teach the Holocaust to my middle school students. I have her personal stories, the cities stories thanks to the Dutch Resistance museum, and my own personal experiences of the city that I can take back to share with my students. Thank you to the Dutch Resistance Museum and thank you Femke.

Very interesting!. Very interesting museum. Information and exhibits presented in an varied way: radio clips, photos, accessories from the period, stories. There is a special youth museum and a special part about the Second World War in Indonesia. Staff is highly enthusiastic. Even though it's a tough subject, it is presented in such a way that everybody learns something and leaves with the idea how important it is to show items and talk about the Second World War. Doable in 1,5-2 hours.
Very moving. Very well presented with excellent graphics and very informative with lifelike visuals and sound effects

We'll-organized and documented. We had already bee to the Anne Frank House by the time we went here. This gave us a wider view of the war experience for the Dutch. The daily effect on people's lives eventually became extreme and this was documented in photos and individual stories. It explained why the Dutch refused the offer of 5000 German soldiers' assistance with their 1953 flooding. Audio tour is included and offers many options for additional info. It can get tiring towards the end.

Thought provoking. Very well organised and presented story of the German occupation and the Dutch resistance. The entrance fee includes an audio tour which leads you through the exhibits. Some great details of individuals' experiences.

No punches pulled. This in many ways is very similar to the war tunnels in Jersey. Both talk of collaboration and resistance, although the resistance in Hoilland was on a greater scale of course.The exhibit is well laid out with plenty of multimedia, but what I liked about it was that it used non-PC language and talked honestly about collaboration and indifference to suffering, as well as some of the amazing acts of bravery that Dutch people carried out. I will always have in my mind the bravery of the people in the Stork factory.Very draining, but an excellent way to ensure that the past is remembered

Wonderful musuem , intersting and thought provoking. We went here thinking it would be interesting ,we didn't realise how good it would be ,We should've gone earlier in the day as we spent over 2 hours here and could've spent a lot longer .The stories of ordinary people taking you from before the war started to the end , and what life was like for them .From people risking their own lives to help others ,to others who thought the invasion was to help the country .Made you think how you would react put in that situation .Would definitely visit again

Interesting Museum. Was recommended this museum in lieu of the Anne Frank House (which I still went to). I found it interesting and learned a lot about what life was like for the Dutch before, during and after WWII. All displays had English labels or you could just use the free audio guide provided.

So much information to take in!. This was a very good experience overall. It thoroughly tells the story of the Dutch Resistance, all while putting you in the shoes of the Dutch citizens during WWII.We found it to be a bit emotionally draining, but we will never forget our visit here.

Thought provoking museum. Very well laid out museum. The section designed for children is really excellent. You follow 4 young people and the reaction and action each had to the nazi invasion. Most of the exhibits and displays have English translation and the audio guide is excellent. There are some very surprising facts and it makes you question the action you would have taken ion there position.

Don't take the past for the present, time does repeat itself.. This is one of the most informative museums I have ever been too. My title says it all. The Netherlands during WWI went neutral, with that they took for granted that they would be once again during WWII be neutral; but history tells us differently. This museum is top notch well displayed and the time lines are in tune with history.

Interesting . A good museum with plenty of interesting artefacts. It tells the story of the Dutch during WWII.Very interesting to read personal accounts and be inspired by people's tales and bravery.Didn't take too long to go around the museum. A worth while visit.

first-rate presentation of the complex history of occupation and resistance. The Resistance Museum is located in a quiet, elegant neighborhood near the zoo. It is one of the most informative and thoughtful sites I have visited dealing with the topic of occupation and resistance during WWII. Many, many artifacts from the period, voices recorded as sound or on paper, thoroughly documented accounts of both resistance and collaboration, detailed explanations of the diverging factions among resistors -- just excellent. The separate exhibit for children was top-rate as well: not pandering, but real engagement with how children might think and feel about the events of that time. I was very impressed by the museum's choice to follow the fates of four real people who were children during the war. The parents of these four children made very different political choices (or had choices forced on them) and the children felt the impact of those choices and fates. We see details of the children's lives and hear their stories, and in a final exhibit, we meet them again as elderly people, talking about how the war changed their lives. Fantastic.

Interesting information.. We were unaware of the individual acts of courage of so many people. The museum is a little cramped and curating could be improved with better signage; some exhibits are difficult to read because the font is small or displayed awkwardly.

The Junior Museum is FANTASTIC. We wanted to show our kids this important bit of history, but had low expectations for how interested they might be. Imagine our TOTAL delight when the staff pointed us to their Junior Museum section which was EASILY the best exhibit we've seen for a long time for kids. Our 8 and 12 year sons were totally engaged and as we made our way around the extraordinarily well done exhibits, they were able to grasp the realities and stories of World War 2 in a new way. Absolutely worth your time!

A real find. We just stumbled on this place by pure chance. Had intended to go to zoo but it was wet and went here instead. It's just across the road from the zoo. We have 2 young kids ( 10 and 5 )and this place was a real find. There is a dedicated kids museum that follows the story of 4 Dutch children from different backgrounds during the war. The headset was great for the kids and the kids museum was well presented and very interactive. The 4 children's stories were told factually and my son was truly engaged with and moved by the children's tales. We spent nearly two hours in this area. We spent only a short time really in the main museum as the kids were tired. But what I did see impressed me. I would really like to visit when I return to Amsterdam. We finished our visit with cake and coffee in the very pricey museum restaurant. We visited here before our visit to the Anne frank house and if you are sketchy on your history , I would recommend visiting here first as it will enhance your visit to the Anne frank house. It certainly did this for my son.

Phenomenal museum. This is a must see for history lovers. I have been here three times and every time I see something new. The Museum Jr. exhibit is perfect for kids. I have taken two groups of middle school teens to this and they loved it, even the ones that were not sure if they liked history:-) The four stories of the kids are riveting and very interactive. The other parts of the museum have excellent audio guides to help you get more personal stories. Truly a gem!!

Don't miss it!. I hadn't heard of the Resistance Museum before our visit but I would recommend it to anyone with an interest in history. We had teenagers with us so we were guided towards the children's section which had us hooked from the start. The stories of 4 children's experiences were fascinating. Our visit lasted over 2 hours as all of us found the museum so interesting. Staff were very helpful too.

Interesting reading, audio guide a bit weak. A tour of Holland's involvement in the Second World War with signs up about the moral dilemmas that faced the Dutch. Some interesting artifacts and information about the resistance that appeared over time. The audio guide was a little naff. I'd say this was made more for kids (there were a few on a school trip) but also good if you want to know more about Holland's role. Photos are of Hitler's head from a statue (not sure how real) and a propaganda poster.
Could be better. This is a interesting museum with lots of information however it is not really about the resistance it is more of a war museum.

Learned a lot but a me away feeling it could be improved. Spent two hours there. Fabulous welcome and the audio tour is included in admission. I liked the overal thematic approach that there are three ways people could respond to the Nazi occupation (live life as usual, collaborate or resist) but felt that that theme wasn't consistently and clearly followed through. The narrative didn't always hang together however the story is one that everyone should hear.

Good museum but do your research. Use your museum card to get in free and then finish with a coffee and cake next door with your ticket.Best to do a history of Dutch underground before you go. Then you will get more out of the visit. They have a kids section too

Kid section the best!. Well worth a visit. The kids section is very well done - it follows 4 children during the Nazi occupation who have different takes on the period. One child's father is in the Resistance whilst another child's family are very pro-Hitler. Fascinating stuff and makes no judgments - just presents things as they were.

Amazing Museum. The Resistance Museum was a great way to learn about the issues leading up to the occupation of Holland, the invasion, how Dutch citizens either colaborated, resisted, or did nothing, and what happened after the allies liberated Holland. There is also a section dedicated to the Japanese Occupation of the Dutch Colony of Indonesia, which when Indonesia was liberated, lead to a war of independence from the Dutch. Really well done displays and audio tour.

Great museum, great value and friendly staff! . Even if history is not your thing, I would highly recommend you visit this museum. It's so interesting and I really did learn a lot. They have done it so well and they provide you with lots of information but not to the point where it's overwhelming. I really enjoyed reading individual stories, it was very moving. You can also get an audio tour in English if you require it and this is included. I used it in some parts and read in others.The staff were super friendly. Some of the most friendly people I have come across in Amsterdam with a great sense of humour. Go here! It's only €10!

Very interesting. This museum will take 1 1/2 to 2 hours to visit. It provides a pretty objective, tragic and sometimes funny history of the occupation of Holland by the Nazis. It is located some distance from other sights but can easily be gotten to on the Tram that stops about a half a block away. If you are tired of walking and don't want to see another old master, go here.

Superb museum and fitting tribute to a brave generation. This museum was one of the highlights of a recent three day break in the fine city of Amsterdam. Being interested on WW2, this museum was top of my list bar one other entry (that being the Anne Frank House). This museum highlights the courage of the dutch people and the reality of life in the Netherlands during WW2. Filled with many artefacts and interesting items (incl. a bust of Hitler), this museum is an absolute must for anyone who has an interest in WW2.

Thought Provoking. The Dutch Resistance Museum should be on your list of things to do when visiting Amsterdam. As a lover of history and WWII, this was first on our list. The entrance fee is minimal, it was not crowded, and the audio guide was very helpful. The layout is fantastic and the exhibit walks you through the timeline of the German occupation and Dutch resistance during the early years leading up the WWII, during the war, and after their liberation. It's an important story to tell and the museum tells it in a necessary and beautiful way. The exhibits are very interactive and full of primary sources. You're not just hearing the story, you feel like you're living it. I can't tell you how many times I got goosebumps while walking through. It's small, but the knowledge and information inside is so plentiful and thought-provoking. It gives you a very thorough outlook of what the Dutch went through. 10/10.

First rate museum. This is a first rate evocation of Amsterdam life in the run up to the Second World War and during the Nazi occupation. Very detailed exhibits, lots of interesting stories of life under the Germans and a very good section on the war and aftermath in Indonesia, then a Dutch colony. Allow two hours to do the exhibition justice but don't miss this great museum.
Interesting and thought provoking. Really interesting museum offering a different slant on the Nazi occupation. Our favourite museum in Amsterdam.

Unexpected and wonderful. Just walking past to go to another museum when we happened upon this one. What a great museum. Really friendly when you enter and it tells a story that most people will probably not know. The audio tour is a must and take the time. We were told that an hour would be enough time. Oh that was so wrong. We had to go back the following day as it was packed with facts and it really needs to more time to go through properly. I still never got to the junior section but please make this one to see on you visit to Amsterdam.

great museum, kids really loved it. we only did visit the resistance museum for kids and it was very good. very well explained and a lot of interaction. really build with the kids of 2016 in mind. with sound, music, video very well done.

Provocative, thoughtful museum. This museum provided a very engaging and thoughtful approach to what it was like to live in German occupied Netherlands. It offered a very balanced approach to the alternative options of adjust, resist or collaborate. The junior museum was excellent because it followed the lives of four young indiduals who had each had unique experiences of the war and covers their experience as young children during the war. Then at the end there are interviews with them as seniors, both making the stories you heard quite real and providing perspective. Very interesting if you are at all interested in the Second World War.

There are so many museums in Amsterdam but do not miss this one!. Located in the Plantage area you can combine this visit with the zoo, the planetarium, and the National Holocaust Memorial.Thought provoking and in many ways inspirational, this well designed museum guides you through the history of Dutch resistance to the Nazi regime. It asks you, as an individual, how would you react if your freedom was taken away from you overnight?Pods are available free of charge to give you a running commentary of the exhibits.

An excellent museum build around a very good central premise; what would you do??. Museums similar to this often fail on two grounds, they have a tendency to ignore the fact that much of the population either collaborates or at least takes the course of least resistance and they fail to make visitors think about what they would have done if faced with the same question. Chile's famed museum of the resistance to the dictatorship is a classic example, after two hours you're still none the wiser about why 45% of the population voted to keep the dictatorship.This museum takes a very wise course, building the exhibition around the central premise; would you resist, collaborate or muddle through? It’s also honest enough to admit that many public officials really felt that the best thing they could do was to stay in office rather than resign and be replaced by Nazi's. It tracks very accurately how as the occupation wore on and the measures being taken against the Jews (and others) became more and more harsh this middle way eventually became impossible. It also doesn't shy away from the fact that the Dutch Nazi party had over 100,000 members at its peak and that much of civil society co-operated with laws such as registering Jewish owned businesses which could only have been designed with one purpose in mind.I would strongly recommend it, even to those with a familiarity with the topic. When I visited it was reassuringly busy with visitors of all ages which is all one can ask.

Well laid out & thought provoking. Well worth a visit!. I really enjoyed this museum. It is laid out chronologically so you really get a sense of how resistance slowly builds in reaction to Nazi policy. It focuses on ordinary accounts and personal effects so you really appreciate the impact on Dutch citizens. I also enjoyed the smaller exhibition on Dutch East Indies. The section for young visitors is really well designed - very interactive and aimed at their natural curiosity and imagination. Plus zoo is opposite so you can have a full day out here.

Excellent surprise right across from the zoo. This was a great visit. They have put together a very meaningful experience for the visitor. Not only is the plight of the Dutch Jews explained but their powerful resistance to the Nazi invasion is explained in detail. It's a great place to visit. Don't miss it if you have time. We were glad we went!

Fascinating, . A fascinating museum, even as an amateur military historian I learned quite a lot from my visit, it flows fairly well, the audio guides are a must, as well as being informative, it is educational and provocative. It also pulls no punches in its display of The Netherlands' post war colonial war in the Far East, this part not being for the faint hearted!The restaurant adjacent to the museum is also worth visiting.

Thoughtful and Educational Exhibition. I visited the Dutch Resistance Museum in February. The museum’s aim is to analyse how everyday people coped with the Nazi occupation in Holland by looking at examples of those who resisted, adjusted and collaborated with the regime. The museum does this through the use of videos, interactive exhibits, diaries, newspaper clippings, artefacts and more- making for a comprehensive and multi-sensory exhibition. At the end of the museum there is also exhibition that focuses on government bias in the media by looking mainly at the Dutch Colonial Wars in Indonesia, but parallels are also drawn to media reporting of conflicts today. I found the museum really interesting and liked the way it provokes important moral questions and issues for you to consider as well as educating you on an extremely important part of history. The museum itself costs 10 euros for adults and comes with a free audio tour. The staff are extremely friendly, welcoming and helpful- they seemed to genuinely want to help you get the most out of the museum. I'd definitely recommend.

Learned a lot of things about the Dutch Resistance. We wanted to visit this museum after seeing the film Black Book as it had peaked our interest in the Dutch Resistance and how they played an important part throughout WW2. It was fascinating to see the lengths that people went to to try get around the Nazi occupation and just generally survive in such hard conditions. The audio tour was very informative and the displays were very well presented. The actual museum is located in a good location near to the tram sop and opposite the zoo.
interesting. I learned a lot about the Netherlands during WWII. The scary part was the parallel between pre-war Netherlands and our current political situation in the US.

Very interesting and educational. An excellent museum format which is very educational. There is a section designed for the younger audience which is good for adults too. The whole experience is balanced with an exhibit on the Indonesia independence conflict. We were shocked to find out we had been here for 4 hours when we sat down for a drink in the heat cafe attached to the museum.

A very balanced approach to a shameful part of our history. Museum challenges people to consider what would they do in similar circumstances. Many people were hidden similar to Anne Frank, but many had to pay for this to happen as well as courageous people hiding people for altruistic reasons.
Fascinating but a huge amount to try and take in. So much detail and information, it actually felt a bit overwhelming, but material very well presented.

Explains a Lot!. This museum really explained to me how the Nazi's took over territories. The museum explains all the subtle and not so subtle moves toward full takeover and all. It happened in stages and they explain it so well. I felt educated after the visit. Maybe not high on folks lists but I recommend it. The old tech devices were really neat!

Enjoyable two hours. Great insight into the resistance movement. Helps you understand just what they had to do to try and survive. Still hard to believe this happened in our world. Museum is across from the Zoo.

The Resistance Museum. This museum was unexpectedly great. It features a lot of information about the Nazi occupation, of course. But it also includes an entire section about the Dutch in Indonesia, some of which doesn't paint the Dutch in a very flattering light. All of this is explained throughout, and I learned a lot that I had not know previously. If time allows, spend a couple of hours. It is very good.
A must see!. We went to this museum before we went to the Anne Frank Haus and if you are unfamiliar with the history of the Dutch people, I recommend visiting the Dutch Resistance museum!

Only OK. Good. Excellent artefacts etc. but very difficult to view as behind glass with very small area to look through. Quite tiring and not many places to sit throughout, difficult for older people who may not be too good on their legs for such a long time...we were there 3 hours and missed bits out.

Local aspects of WW2. Apart from the Anne Frank House this was the only place we went that centred around the Second World War. Lots of information on Amsterdam through this period, how people reacted, how the facist laws slowly emerged and how the locals retaliated.

nothing to write home about. We popped into this museum as we were looking for something to do before going to Anne Frank's house. It was ok to waste a few hours but overall I found it a little tiresome. If you have a massive interest in the 2nd World War, in particular the Dutch side of events, then I would recommend you pay the museum a visit.Overal - ok

An infinitely superior War memorial than the Ann Frank House. Visiting here the day after the dreadful experience of the Ann Frank house makes me wonder why the Tourist Board of Amsterdam don't advertise the fact that one is a great, informative and factually accurate experience, while the other is a money making machine that leaves this visitor feeling ripped off and exploited. Dutch War Resistance is a proud moment in Dutch History.

Very well producted exhibition. The title may be a little misleading - there's not a whole lot about actual resistance fighters - but nevertheless this is a really informative and well produced history exhibition about life in Nazi occupied Holland. Great multimedia displays, and interesting layout made this a very worthwhile place to visit. Recommended!
