Fascinating. Well worth a visit. A lot to see, and both interesting and humbling. Easy to get a bit lost, free audio guide repeated largely what could be read.

Mostly about how it was living during the WWII. The museum mainly consist of information about how it was to live in Netherlands during the was, I not find very much about the resistance. The museum were still nice illustrated with a really good audio guide.

Well worth a visit. A well presented history of Holland's 1941-1945k occupation. Started with a short film and followed with an excellent audio tour, suitable for both kids and adults. Some great historical pictures, photos and articles to look at. Good value for money at €10 per adult ticket.

Very interesting . Really found this very interesting found out a lot about how the Dutch managed during the war. It was informative discovering how there was a split between the population, gets a bit heavy after a while a lot off info to take in, you need a good hour and a half. The junior part is very informative.

One for the history nerds. As someone who likes his WW2 history, this place is a must visit however I think it's a useful place for people to visit to get a different perspective on a period of history that as a British person we hear so much about but never think about the part of the Dutch in any great detail.This place is included on the IAMsterdam card so entry was easy and the audio guide is included. You don't need the audio guide for the museum but I like them and the podcapture guide is great; no numbers to press in, just point at the box on the wall and it plays automatically.There is also now a Versetzmuseum Junior for the younger ones telling kids stories from the period so a good way to introduce the younger ones to the stories on offer and give some context.This period of history in Holland can often be reduced to just Anne Frank so places like this are important and worth visiting.Also the cafe next door is pretty decent.
Good Museum. The museum was informative and worth the visit. The free audio was worth using but the layout of the museum was a little confusing. Great hands on children's exhibit.

Amazing value and content. This story of wartime resistance is a beacon of hope during dark times both then and now, as it can't fail to make you reflect on human and inhuman nature, fear, manipulation and ego. It's easy to think this is from the past but it continues to play out somewhere in the world right now and in it's powerful provision of food for thought, you'd need to be pretty hard-nosed not to to be affected by the theme of this collection of stories, told from all sides.Run by volunteers, the welcome and helpful advice shared to ensure you receive the most from your visit is second to none. Do take the free audio guide; the access it gives to more information, brought to meaningful life, will leave you impressed by the thought given to the selection of information and materials displayed in a way that intrigues and teaches so well. The best curated collection of information I've seen on this trip and I'd suggest this as a perfect partner visit to the Anne Frank House, which has been conserved as best as is practically possible. Here you get so much of relevance to the wider story.Allow plenty of time to view. The amount of information is enormous but never daunting as it draws you to want to know more, rather than overwhelming you - and you have control over how much information you want to access or give greater emphasis to. There is a whole special exhibition for the younger ones and an additional display too.In terms of content, interest, affectation, enjoyment and value this tops my list of visits. I've paid far more plus extra for an audio guide to look at a collection of beautiful 'stuff' that seemed so fickle and self indulgent, beyond demonstrating true merit of the artist. This, by complete contrast, seems significant in a truly human context and I would suggest the museum increases it's admission fee or have a clear collection point for donations. Well done to all concerned. I shall be returning but not alone.
Very interactive and informative. Great museums that teaches you in a very interactive and informative way about the period before, during and after the 2nd world war.
Interesting. Small museum, bit off the beaten track, but worth a visit. Good audio guide, but not all the exhibit descriptions are translated into English. Staff were really helpful.

Informative. This is one of my favorites in Amsterdam. They share so much information and their displays are beautiful. The location is a bit away from downtown, but there is a team that stops nearby.
Very interesting indeed.. Very well presented. I particularly enjoyed the archive film footage. Upsetting and thought provoking in parts.

Great visit. This is a lesser visited museum which meant no queues for us on a Saturday morning.It was an informative, educational experience and poses some interesting questions to us all, adjust,accept or resist? If you have an interest in history this may be worth a visit.There is also a very nice tea room next door.

Very interesting. Had a walk about 15 minutes from the centre. Found the museum but unfortunately didn't have enough time to appreciate all of it. Lots of fascinating accounts and film. Very cheap to get in.

Without a doubt the best museum I've been to in a long time. I knew very little about the Dutch Resistance during WW2 so decided to pop into this 'little' museum, intending to spend an hour in there to warm up and in terms of Amsterdam museums it was cheap.We went at 2pm and got around half way through the museum (there are four areas) and before we knew it we were being told the museum was closing so we would have to leave - we had been there three hours without even feeling anywhere close to that. So we paid and went back again the next morning intending to spend no more than an hour there just to finish our visit and we spent another three hours there. Definitely take the audioguide - it is very very good and gives you the option to listen in more detail to personal stories if that's what you enjoy, which I do.Don't be put off by the 'junior museum' if you an adult - it is not only for children and we spent a good amount of time in there. It tells the story of four Dutch children through the war, including reconstructions of their houses which you can walk through such as where a Jewish girl hid - they're actually very realistic. And we had no children with us. This was very much a highlight of our trip.The exhibition about the Colonial Wars is also very very good, Very honest and direct, which adds to it. It is really harrowing, but also very informative because I honestly knew nothing about the wars until the visit. The whole museum is very thought provoking and when looking for things to do in Amsterdam I don't feel like it's given enough credit. It does give you a lot to think about, posing questions to you such as what would you do during the German occupation? Staff are also very very helpful when you have any questions. I would recommend to everyone, and despite my two visits in as many days, I wouldn't hesitate to return.

Thoroughly compelling. A thoroughly interesting museum which focusses on life from a variety of angles in The Netherlands during the Nazi occupation. A very well laid out museum which flows in a chronological method, assessing Dutch lifestyles throughout the thirties, leading into the threat of war and the subsequent invasion. Very, very informative with terrific attention to detail of the key points. Incredibly thought provoking with the right degree of emphasis placed on the menace and brutality of living under the Nazi regime. There is also a section of the museum dedicated to the Dutch Colonial War of the late 40's which proves a fascinating insight into a conflict which is not widely acknowledged or discussed.The museum also has a section dedicated for children which looks at the occupation from the perspective of four different children.Very engaging museum and a must for anybody wishing to learn about this period of time from a Dutch perspective.

Fantastic for kids . We spent an afternoon here, the kids section is excellent and the whole thing was very informative and interesting. Lots of artefacts and stories and well worth a visit with the family

Thought Provoking Museum . This really asks how would you react under occupation. The free audio guide is very good and easy to use. The cafe next door is also great for snacks. Free on the I amsterdam card so don't miss it. Easy to find opposite the zoo.
Fantastic. spent hours at the museum, thoroughly enjoyed the whole experience, my 14 year old son also enjoyed it very much.

Great for WW2 enthusiasts and history lovers. A very interesting and interactive museum for anyone with a desire to learn more about the Dutch during the Second World War. Great interactive junior section to keep younger visitors interested too.
Special place. Always impressive to be here. Special exhibitions with a serious tone. Much to see and to read. Love the entourage.

Very interesting! . Visited the museum with my boyfriend who isn't into history as much as I am but he found it to be really interesting in the end. I was so pleased to be able to visit the museum on my visit to Amsterdam, I love history, especially ww2 so it was a very interesting and informative for me personally. The museum it's self has a lot of documents/displays/information and artefacts! It's a great way to understand the German invasion of Holland. It took us about and hour to go through and only cost €10 each! Totally recommend!

Interesting and well worth a few hours. This really is a museum in 2 parts and I'm not sure that's as well highlighted as it could be. First bit quite straightforward is around how the Dutch coped with German occupation in WW2. Very good audio here and I really enjoyed actual recordings from real people involved, from all walks of life. 2nd part is about the end of the Dutch Colony of East Indies. This I had not realised at all (we all tend to focus on WW2 a bit). Basically only a few days after Japan surrendered and got out of Indonesia the Dutch then had another fight on their hands. And it took till 1949 before they gave it up and the new Republic was formed. So well done, again this had great tales from real people involved.

Small museum. The museum consists mostly in old documents and photos presenting the dutch citizens' life during different wars.Many exhibits are presented in strange show cases so that they can be seen only through narrow windows,as in a weird peep show...Worth a not very long visit though it's not between the most interesting museums of Amsterdam,at least in my opinion.Across the street is Micropia and Amsterdam Artis Zoo.

Most interesting. Had a good time at this museum. A little bit of a walk out of the centre of town. Just near the zoo. Really interesting and honest museum. Just showed how easy it was for hitler to railroAd his way through Europe. Was surprised how may people were actually hidden during the war and the bravery of all those around at that time. Really good museum and thought provoking. Would recommend to anyone who enjoys recent history.
Interesting. Interesting exhibition but not very interactive. Nice movie upstairs but hard to hear due to poor acoustics. Audio tour is a plus!
Interesting. This is worth a visit, its not a massive exhibition but there is lots of information and the audio tour is very good. Not too far from the centre so easily in walking distance.

Thought provoking. The museum tells the story of resistance in the Netherlands in the WW2. As well as the excellently presented artifacts it also challenges you with "what would you do in the same situation?" An interesting question for us Brits and l guess Americans too.The displays are very well laid out with good explanations. We lost direction a bit in the middle as it weaves around a bit in the central area. You get a sense of what it would be like to live under occupation.The holocaust section with the map of where Jews lived is very poignant. The cafe is excellent too.

Well presented and captures the ambivelance. This museum sets out the facts about the various factions and social dimensions that existed at the time of the wars and how they changed and developed into Dutch society today. There are special sections on colonialsm too.The Dutch have developed and direct adnd non contentious way of presenting information that covers many of the less pleasant aspects of human judgement.

Interesting to see increased resistance towards end of war.. Well worth visiting while in the city. This will be of particular interest to students of WW2 and events and sympathies during the Nazi occupation.

A visit with our grandsons ( 11 and 9 years old). I can highly recommend a visit with younger children. It makes them aware in very educational way what life was for children during the second world war.
Must visit!. There are many museums in the Amsterdam, but if you want a museum that is not too big, but packed full with curiosities, then you should go to this museum. Its an excellent museum.

Average.. A great deal of information to take in, but mostly written to small, personally didn't think there were enough exibits of from the actual resistance, maybe because there was a lot of collaboration by the Dutch.Having visited a few Resistance museums, this didn't measure up anywhere as good.Lino Len

old fashioned, worthy but reminiscent of 1970s school trips. This place needs a bit of a relaunch, the stories of suffering and heroism deserve better. It was enough to put you off the fascinating history.

Not to be missed. I think this be my most favorite museum of all time. We were so fascinated, we spent almost a whole day here. While the museum is small, it is simply packed with information. The displays wind you thru the history of the resistence in historical order with displays and vitrines full of objects and text. We even loved the children's area, where, even tho' we are adults, we went thru all the stories and played the games. Really a special, special place. The only complaint I have, and it is a big one, it that the museum needs to spend the money to redo ALL the didactics (labels) since they are poorly done, in small print and often badly located to read w/o stooping. Since the museum is all about information, that information should be well presented. Absolutely use the audio tour.

Loads of detail. This place is worth visiting.A really detailed story of the Dutch people before,during and after the 2nd world war. The audio guide is excellent.Definitely more of a history lesson than an exhibition ,but one that is very powerful.

A nice childrens section. A great museum to go to with children between age 8-12: it tells them in a very entertaining and interactive way what it was like to be a child in WW2 from different perspectives. All based on true stories, an authentic place. My daughter and I loved it, we learned a lot from it.

Really very good.. Follow the tourist signs to Verzetsmuseum. It's not marked out as Resistance Museum until you get there. The facilities are excellent and there's a cafe interconnecting which provides excellent food and drink. Lockers are available, lavatory facilities were excellent and the staff are extremely helpful. There is, mercifully, no gift shop, just a few books in Dutch and English and the compulsory Ann Frank volume too of course.The museum itself will take you longer than you might have thought to go through. The explanations are all in English and Dutch and an audio guide is available. It's a very thoughtful and interesting exhibition which delves quite deeply into the political philosophies of the time. If you’re interested in Dutch and European history and how the EU has developed from the socialist policies of 1940s Germany, because that’s what the z in nazi stood for, then you’ll find this museum very thought provoking. There’s a poster in the museum that commemorates the anniversaries 1673-1943 and shows a Dutch man of war and a German U Boat heading towards England. The Dutch smashed the English at the Battles of Schooneveld off the Dutch coast on two June days in 1673, thus saving Holland from a British/French invasion. This poster is a 1943 call to the Dutch to rise up and invade England.The museum is full of interesting little historical anecdotes and memories such as that. There is much here beneath the surface! Those who wear reading glasses should bring them.

Sobering. We had two children with us and the museum definitely catered for the children. They made the exhibits come to life with their concept of seeing the occupation from differing eyes.The exhibits are well presented, for the children as well. A very good museum and a must see in my opinion.

It's ok. It's a bit out of the way, maybe coupled with the Artis Zoo? It's a relatively quick museum that is very text heavy in lieu of many artifacts...it was interesting, don't get me wrong, but I am not sure it was worth the effort to get there in the limited time I had in the city. Maybe save for a 3rd or 4th day if you are in town that long.
Winter visit . Good informative museum and interesting exhibits. Worth a visit and well paired with Anne frank huis. Smaller and no issues with crowds or queues. Staff very friendly.

Excellent. Stopped here while on the hop on hop off bus tour. Very interesting place to visit and we enjoyed our morning there. Educational and informative. Definitely a place to visit when in Amsterdam. (Just don't order coffee in the coffee shop next door - probably the worst coffee we've had in our lives!!)

Do not miss ! Excellent for juniors as well. We were not sure but ended up going, and were happy we did.The museum offers an interesting view of the resistance movement during world war II and the German occupation.It is somewhat apologetic, and tries to cope with the question of "what would you have done".There is mention of Dutch occupation of other countries.An excellent junior part presents a clear friendly story to the youngsters - I would highly recommend for the teenagers.
A Quick Visit. The museum was very good,informative and opposite the zoo..I caught the hop on hop off bus and the stop was nearby.

Historical WW II Museum. It's about the resistance movement as well as what life was like during the German occupation. The exhibits are a bit disorganized but it all tells a very good story. I spent about an hour there and that seemed to be enough time. Worth the price of admission as I learned things I didn't know before.

A decent museum filled with tons of histort. Less of it is about resistance per se than what life was like during WWII. It is a good museum with a ton of information. It just misses out on 5 stars for me, but I absolutely recommend going.

Small but informative museum. Few of my Dutch friends had visited this museum so I thought I'd give it a quick tour. Small but well curated exhibits and friendly staff. Audio tour very informative. Easy to walk to from center city.
outstanding. if you visit one museum in Amsterdam I would highly recommend this one we spent hours wandering around great stories of normal people during the worst of times

Worthwhile. A very intimate museum which captures the essence of what Holland was like under German occupation in the second world war.
I would recommend the Cafe-Restaurant de Plantage for lunch nearby.

DECENT MUSEUM, BUT VERY DISORGANIZED COLLECTION; NOT SURE I'D VISIT AGAIN. Let me start by saying that I am very much a WW2 enthusiast, so I was excited to visit this museum while in Amsterdam. What I found was a decent collection with a few good artifacts, such as radios used by the resistance, etc. However, the layout of the museum is really, really poor and disorganized. It makes it really hard to follow. If you have some time to kill, it might be worth it, but otherwise, I'd probably skip this one. Also, it's quite a distance from the city center. You need a cab or Uber to get there in a timely fashion.

A must for history buffs.. This little museum is well laid out. There are many interactive displays. The methods and manner of resistance were amazing to view. This is a highlight - and a plus, there aren't the crowds that accompany the other major museums.

Hidden Treasure!. Visited at New Year with older teenage children. This museum is very well laid out and gives some wonderful background leading up to the occupation period through liberation. It was raining on our visit and we easily spent more than 2 hours here. Free audio in English. We even used a coupon available from the Central Tram office and admission included a two for one coffee at the charming café next door.

cheap museum with additional visual multimedia information. the museum has a very quiet atmosphere compared to many other museums in amsterdam. the prices are also very good. the stuff is very friendly. the temporary "indonesian kolonial war" exhibition had many interesting pictures. near the museum is the zoo of amsterdam.

Excellent museum. I particularly wanted to visit this museum whilst in Amsterdam, as well as the Anne Frank house. I ended up visiting both on the same day! I thoroughly enjoyed this museum, it was very informative, lots of information about what life was like for Dutch people under Nazi occupation. I would definitely recommend visiting. I thought it was a shame that this museum seemed lacking in visitors, considering the numbers queuing at the Anne Frank House.

An unexpected find!. We didn't plan to go here whilst in Amsterdam as had focused more on Anne Frank's House but so glad we did. It was briliantly set out, a great way to learn about the Netherlands during Nazi Germany and had lots of interactions allowing you to really get to grips with the history. We used the english translator devices, which were great and easy to use. We went into the Junior part which we also loved as you got to follow four different stories, go into their houses and learn about the different people making up Netherlands at that time e.g. Nazi supports, Jewish people within the Netherlands etc. It wasn't expensive and we spent nearly all morning in there. An unexpected find and most definitely a great one! (p.s. there was also another bit about the colonial war - again very interesting, particularly as i knew little about Netherlands involvement in Indonesia!)

A lot of reading. Its a good museum and does exactly what it says on the tin but the museum itself is quite small and some of the exhibits look quite dated. It can be quite interesting but there will be a lot of reading of plaques on walls.

Interesting. Despite the resistance only lasting a short time, the museum contains a huge amount of information about life under Nazi rule. There are plenty of interesting objects and stories, all laid out very well. The staff were unfriendly and quite rude when we tried to use a UK student card (need an EU/Global one apparently), which is a shame. Our visit lasted about an hour.

Far better than we it would be. The Dutch Resistance Museum is situated opposite Amsterdam Zoo and was recommended by our friends, as it would have not been our choice. However it was a really interesting museum that was very informative and told the story of the Dutch Resistance in the Second World War. We always take an audio guide (when available) and this proved a real bonus at this museum. There was lots to see and to finish the restaurant in the museum offered a super steak sandwich to end our morning's visit. This museum gives a great insight into the Dutch people and there attitudes in the war. Would recommend without hesitation.

Much better than expected. A very honest view of the resistance with an additional display about the quite unknown period of Dutch colonialism post-war. Well worth a look if you are remotely interested, perhaps a good precursor to the Anne Frank House to set the scene.

The Netherlands under Nazi control. Impossible to get into the Ann Frank house, and on reflection I don't think it would have been worth it anyway. If you really want a comprehensive account of how the Netherlands were dealt with by the Nazis and how the Dutch coped, this museum is a must. Get the best out of it with a free audio device to amplify the exhibitions/photos you will see. I was very moved by the Dutch bravery and defiance.

Had never been here before, good history but slightly dull exhibits. Good to take in some culture after a few days of the other things Amsterdam has to offer. Having visited most of the other larger museums in past travels and not really familiar with this neighborhood we went to check it out. The staff were great and helpful. The exhibits themselves were interesting although a bit dull after a while. Using the listening devices at the stations was helpful in learning about how the war and Amsterdam played together. Glad to have checked it out, and probably if I ever return to that area of the city will be to go to the Zoo across the street.

Unexpected Delight. With rain forecast for the day, we decided it was a good,day for a museum. The kids ruled out art and having spent time viewing a number of museums about World War II in Germany we decided this would be a great 'underground' view of the non-fighting side of the war. There is a great mini movie introducing the museum and idea of "collaborate, resist or adapt" for civilians during the war. The museum also had a junior interactive area covering 4 children's lives during the war suited for children aged 8-12. Our 10 year old happily spent her time here, leaving us free to view the adult area. Audio guides were included in admission and there were good English explanations alongside the majority of displays which included Priests' sermons, underground newspapers, letters.Out it on the list. There is a restaurant for a coffee stop at the end.

Fascinating museum - its name misleads. This is an excellent museum offering extraordinarily detailed displays focusing on a broad range of experiences of occupation during WW2. The only surprise is its name 'Resistance Museum'. In fact resistance to occupation is just one aspect of its focus. Collaboration, suffering, and surviving feature equally.

Let yourself get lost in history . Husband wanted to check this place out so we got there via hop on/off bus which was handy and a little discount. Wasn't that interested in going, more going to support husbands choice. Ended up being reverse with him finishing the tour early and I spending up to an hour and a half in there reading watching videos and listening to Dutch individuals and community's responses/reactions during the time of WW2. I could have stayed longer in there as I didn't quite get to every cubicle/corner to hear and imagine what they went through. There is a cafe or restaurant attached but didn't venture in as it looked a bit pricey for a simple cup of coffee. Overall, had a productive time in there and would visit again to finish the tour.

A very interesting place to visit. I surprised how much there is of interest to read and see when visiting this place. It took me much longer to get around than I imagined it would. As I have an annual museum card, i'll certainly be back to this museum then next time i'm in Amsterdam.

Go to the children section straight!. We went to the adults section first. We know little about Netherland during the WWII so not bad to seeing all the displays and videos. It is not bad but not outstanding neither.My little girl feels bored so we took her to the children section. OMG, it is amazing. The children section is set as a little village, with 4 houses living with 4 children. Each child has a different background - one Dutch boy, one Jewish girl, one girl whose family supported the German, and one Dutch boy whose father helps the Jewish and other Dutch in needed.Each house is then filled up with interactive subjects, i.e. drawers of kitchen can be opened, it then showed an object to tell anecdotes etc. There is even a little remake of schools, a priests altar, an fighter plane etc. The whole place are "touchable" and so much fun for adults too.The stories are told from the eyes of the child when they were little. At the end there are videos showing what they are now, and their thinking about the past. No judgement, no prejudice, but to let the viewers think.I didn't go to Anne Frank museum for fear of the queue. But this museum gives us a chance to see what are the people at that time, from different backgrounds, their thoughts and acts had made up the history.Call first to make sure the children section is open to public. Staff warn us that at some days the children section is only open to school visits and close to public.Buy the book of the children section. My kids love reading the stories of the four kids again and again.
Educating and somber. Lots to see, need a few hours to take your time and see it all. Lots of reading about the Dutch Occupation by the Germans. Good set-up. Very interesting and glad we went.

A good museum to combine with The Anne Frank Huis. As the Dutch period of resistance lasted all of five days before the Germans took over we expected this would be a short visit! In fact, we spent an enjoyable two hours, and that was without the time we could have spent in the modern extension on the post-World War II colonial conflicts. There is a free audio guide, lots of contemporary war exhibits, and it covered the dilemma of do you collaborate, acquiesce, or resist when war comes to town, very well indeed. Not recommended for young children who like 'hands-on' activities as insufficient exhibits to entertain them but good for older ppl and adults who are interested in the Dutch war perspective. Well done to the friendly staff.

Well worth the trip. This was an interesting visit taken in conjunction with a trip to Anne Frank's House. It was fascinating to see how the general population of Holland coped with occupation in WW2.There are a lot of interesting exhibits and newsreels from the time and it is well worth going a little further afield to see

Worthwhile. A worthwhile experience for all ages. Not judgemental at all, but offers insights on "collaborate, adapt or resist" that every family and individual had to make and the consequences that followed. Very nicely done.

Detailed, well laid out, a lot there, very interesting. Very good detailed museum with a lot of information and artefacts. A lot of important history very well displayed. Free audio-guide is very good. Easy to get to. Good size. A good way to spend an hour. Very helpful staff. Real effort has gone into making this place a good experience and it really works.

Good presentation. well balanced.. I go to resistance museums when I can. This is a good one and well worth a visit.I judge such places by the quality of presentation and the balance. It is a difficult subject and neither overt jingoism or "glossing over" have a legitimate place. This avoids both while presenting a carefully crafted central question. The short intro film is where we are first presented with it and this is worth seeing.The well presented exhibits are mostly in Dutch with some English so it is advisable to take an audio guide.Worth a visit and a short tour, an hour is enough for a first visit, and the day can be combined with trips to many of the other attractions of the Plantage area.

Well worth the trip. I enjoyed this small museum as someone interested in World War II. It poses lots of thoughtful questions to the visitor and does an incredible job recreating the emotional aspects of the war. The exhibits are quite comprehensive. I had a little trouble following the order of the exhibits and I think I'd have preferred a guide rather than the audio program (I had questions) but overall, this was one of the highlights of my visit to Amsterdam. Unfortunately the staff was quite unfriendly which detracted from the experience a bit.

It paints a good picture of occupied Holland in WWII. As a Dutch teacher based in Amsterdam I can recommend you all to visit this museum with your children. The Verzets Museum gives a good image of what it was like to live under German occupation in WWII. It shows the many Dutch resistance stories, but also give an insight into the everyday lives of the Dutch children in these troublesome times.
Interesting History. A stay in Amsterdam should include a visit here to the museum of Dutch Resistance which is a very well organized museum providing a picture of the Dutch experience of WWII.

Interesting War Stories. Went in looking for WWII stories and I was greatly impressed. A 1hr walk through the museum with the audio guide and you will have an idea of what were the dilemmas and problems that the people of Netherlands were having during WWII. Many great stories were on display and I enjoyed my time spent in the museum. Recommended to take the audio guide and take your time to listenly through the narratives. It would be worth your time if you are interested in modern history.

First visit.. This is a fascinating museum! I have heard many stories from my parents about what it was like growing up in the Netherlands during World War II, but this museum really brought it to life.

WWII and Indonesia. The occupation experience in Amsterdam is more realistically presented than one sees in similar French museums, as not everybody was a heroic resistant from the beginning. There is no sharp line between acceptance of defeat and collaboration, and many who passively endured were not collaborating. There was an additional exhibit on the Dutch experience in Indonesia - similar to the French in Vietnam. And there was special emphasis on the Dutch media's sanitized coverage of that period.

One of my favourite museums in Amsterdam!. I absolutely love WWII history so the Resistance Museum was one of my must sees in Amsterdam. The way this museum set out is very intelligent. It shows the stages of occupation and the ways the people resisted. It also is set in a way that makes you ask yourself the question: what would you do? After visiting the Anne Frank Huis it was also a positive experience to see all the Dutch Jews and other members that were sheltered by normal Dutch people. This was super inspiring. It's a very interactive, informative and thought provoking experience!
Well worth a visit. The museum is very thought provoking with a lot of exhibits covering the period of Second World War.

A very interesting museum to visit.. This is a small museum but don't be fooled into thinking you can whizz around it. Give yourself plenty of time as there is a lot to take in and the audio guide gives lots of information. It follows the life and times of mainly the Dutch Jews during WW2. Plenty of sound effects, pictorial representations, maps, timelines and photos. A difficult and harrowing time for these people is portrayed really effectively.The audio guide is included with the entry admission.

Very comprehensive and interesting. This museum tells in detail the story of the Dutch resistance against the nazis in a very interesting and engaging way. Shows relics from those who had to endure this time in history and plenty of testimonies from those that tried their best to keep their country in good hands. Very moving as well I must say. I didn't know what went on in the Netherlands during WWII, wow! what a great people!

Well worth a visit.. Been here before.Theres has been a great improvement. Dont forget to get your handset when you pay. There are info points in the museum, but the handset gives you a better background to what really happened.The handset is in with cost of admission.A very good museum and well worth a visit.

It was a 10-hankie, but inspiring!. Tragic yet inspiring as the Dutch refused to give in to the Nazis. The resilience of these people when it seemed all was lost -- especially that last cruel winter of 1945 when there was little food. The museum also relates what happened with the Japanese in the Pacific, as the Dutch had possession in that area. A MUST for viditors.

Good insite into Dutch History...use your Amsterdam Card here. Well worth a visit where you have to read all the information so make sure you give yourself a good couple of hours...we lost track of the time while we were inside because there was so much to read that was so interesting yet horrific to read and take in what happened to the Dutch people. We used our Amsterdam card again here.

Fascinating WW2 history. We learned so much at this museum about the complicated politics of the Netherlands before WW2, and the difficulties that faced people during the war. It's a nice small museum and well worth the trip.

Lots of history with a free audio guide. I never pay to get audio guides but this one was free. It helped me learn more about the impact of the Holocaust on Amsterdam and specifically how the people fought against the Nazis. It was quite interesting to learn the role they played. Just the right amount of reading mixed in with listening. Would recommend to all!

crash course in Dutch History. a quick guide to what was happening in the Netherlands during the last century, focusing mainly on the reasons and outcomes of the World Wars. also how the wars affected daily life for common people, and the various classes of society. a real socio-ethnic-anthropological treat !! they also had a temporary Dutch East India exhibition when i visited in Nov 2015

Well curated museum. We spent a couple of hours in the Resistance Museum. it is well curated with the layout and the free audio guide encouraging you to read all the information (and there is a lot of reading to do). The museum focuses on the stories of individuals and helps put you into the picture: what would you do - collaborate, run away, hide, resist ... It certainly makes you think. The story covers the pre-war context and what happened during the war with various newspapers, newsreels and artefacts of the time.There is an associated children's exhibit also focusing on individual children.

Very interesting and knowledgable museum. My fiance found the museum and we went on a rainy cold day last week. The staff were very friendly, paid our entrance fee and was given listening electronic guides that were just scanned against a display piece in the museum and it would speak in English. we first watched an 8 minute long introduction video about the part that dutch resistance party played during the second world war. The museum was very interesting, had many original pieces from the war on display and people's stories at the time. I really enjoyed the museum and so did my fiance, we would recommend it to anyone who likes to learn more about the second world war.

Excellent presentation on occupied Amsterdam. We visited the resistance museum in Paris, and it was good, but the Amsterdam Resistance Museum is better. The multimedia tour is free and good, but most of the information is on the wall panels in Dutch and English, so if you don't like multimedia tours, you don't really need to use it. We found the introductory video to be very useful as a preamble to entering the exhibits. This museum is a nice complement to the Anne Frank House. It puts the Frank family's situation into perspective.

Superb. Intering, well-presented and just the right amount of information and variation in attractions. Fantastically executed, a lovely areas of town with good restaurants, and I wish I'd had more time to explore.

Kind of a strange museum. The definition of resistance was not quite what I expected. Don't think this is a museum all about spies & underground revolt. Resistance is broad term here which includes Jews in hiding and disgruntled ministers. Audio guide did not add much, though included in the admission.

Very interesting. We could not wait to see this museum and we found it very interesting, but the set-up of displays is a bit confusing. The areas are in a winding pattern and we kept finding ourselves going backwards in time so that the stories were confusing. Overall the museum is good, but plan to spend a good amount of time.

Much info about Dutch resistance during 2WW. This rather small museum is very informative. It tells the story the Dutch jews and the resistance movement, including the fact that part of the country was liberated in the end of 1944 and the rest first in may 1945. Moreover it tells the story of the war in Dutch East India and the liberation of Indonesia from Dutch colonial power.

Too much text. This museum is very interesting - after just over a year I still remember many little facts I read here. A drawback is that most of the information is textual - newspaper fragments and photos - which could in principle be consulted on the internet. There are also some concrete items, such as illegal presses, a suit as worn by the resistance, keys used for liberating prisoners, weaponry.
Good insight to life during WWII. Well worth a visit. Shows what life was like in Holland during the occupation. Lots of interesting exhibits and commentary in many languages.

An insight into Dutch life under the occupation. A museum base around the moral dilemmas faced by those under occupation. Do you submit, resist or hide. Help others or turn away. A great place for children to visit to gain an understaning of these issues. Not a big museum and bear the zoo so could combine the trip for youngsters.

A must-see . My father first got my interested I the Dutch resistance as a child. He explained despite not being as well-known as the French resistance, in his opinion, the Dutch resistance was probably more important to allied efforts. The museum has a lot of information and if you move counter clockwise upon entering the museum, the layout makes sense. There's also a great special exhibit on the occupation of Indonesia and how this occupation inspired the Indonesians to secure their independence after the war. It's rare to find a WWII museum that can address both the European and Pacific theaters in an organic way, but the resistance museum does a nice job. The only downside is as others have mentioned, it is a bit difficult to find. It is diagonally across the street from the zoo. Like for red vertical cloth banners. That's the museum.

Very interesting. This was a great museum telling the story of dutch people during the resistance. However, it is not well advertised - we only found out about it as it was on our free map! spent hours in here. Great!

An insight into the Dutch psyche. A good presentation with excellent audio commentary. Doesn't seek to judge, but to perhaps explain why some Dutch collaborated, some accepted, and some resisted the German occupation of their country.

Never forget. Verzetsmuseum has quite a large collection of photos and memorabilia relating to the occupation of the Netherlands - certainly a must see for those interested in history. Expect to spend a minimum of two hours viewing the museum.

Inspirational. I visited this museum on November 11, Veterans Day in the US, as a way of commemorating my late father's generation of WW2 soldiers and their allies. You can do it in an hour. The museum is thoughtfully laid out and allows you to understand the ways in which individuals can rise above terrifying circumstances and overwhelming odds, and fight back.

Highlight of our trip. A lovely museum and well worth the visit. All the displays are interesting and informative; definitely a must-see if you're interested in this time in history. I went at a quieter time in the day which I think is best as there is so much to see and read; it's nice not to have to rush or deal with the crowds.I will definitely be returning at some point.

Better than Anne Frank from a history point of view. Anne Frank House is a pilgramage and this tells you what happened in Amsterdam and the Netherlands during the Second World War. A great compact museum in a lovely part of town.
Tip:
Take the audio tour and visit the Hollands Theater 100 yards down the street. This was the deportation centre for Amsterdam jews.

wonderful interesting place. A little bit hard to find but well worth the visit especially if you have an interest in the WW11 history, allow yourselves plenty of time as there is a lot to read and look at, plus films to sit and view.

Very Moving Displays. This museum described the experiences of the Dutch during World War II. The informative displays included photos as well as documents and objects dating from that time. The museum really made you think about humans treat other humans.
Fascinating. I intended to spend about 30 minutes here but ended up spending 2 hours. Living at the other end of the world, I found this museum to be full of interest. A 'must see'.

Great historical resource. I visited this based on a recommendation in the Rick Steve's Amsterdam book. I was not at all disappointed. This gave a fantastic overview of how the Dutch fell under the Nazi rule, which led to the several resistance movements. This is a must for history buffs!

Interesting personal stories. Well presented with lots of personal stories that you can really connect with. Interesting presentation of the way various individual and communities reacted to occupation.

Messy but informative. The museum has a small opening and may be easy to miss. It is opposite of the Amsterdam Zoo so look out for that too. Tickets are fairly priced and they have a (new?) extension to the museum for kids. They provide a free audio tour guide for the whole museum which will come in really handy as most of the information will be from the recordings. The audioguide can easily top 2 hours of content. Although there is alot of information on the Dutch in WWII, the information is delivered sloppily. Panels are thrown all over the place and they expect visitors to know their way through the labyrinthine museum. A nice restaurant/cafe can be found right next to the museum, offering quick sandwiches and drinks. Cloakroom and wifi are available, but do bring along a 2e coin for the cloakroom (you will get it back after using it).

Great museum. This museum does a great job of describing the invasion on the Nazis in this region. It gives a great overview of how different the groups of people were impacted. I think it would be a great field trip for schools.

Well Worth the Visit. The Resistance Museum is the best place to discover what the Netherlands went through during the Second World War. It is laid out chronologically but concentrates on individual experiences of everyday Dutch citizens. The audio tour is a must and provides the best interpretation of what you are viewing. My other half is usually not great in a museum and leaves much sooner than myself. This museum caught his attention and interest and kept it through to the end. I strongly recommend your visit to this museum.

wonderful museum. Very informative. Very well done. As other reviewers have said, they really pack a lot of information into the space. I would highly recommend this place to anyone with even a little interest in WWII.

Best small Museum in Amsterdam. Small by museum standards, this is one of my top 3 places on our last trip to Holland. Leave 2 to 3 hours for this place and get the audio. you will not be disappointed, especially if you are a history or WWII buff.
Eye Opener. This museum is a must. I've traveled through Amsterdam many times and I always tell people if you only have time to visit one museum then this is the one.

Opposite the zoo - don't miss it!. I really enjoyed this museum. The content wasn't all about reading and there was a good mix of interactive media and pictures. As mentioned in the title it's just right across from the zoo. Somehow even knowing this I couldn't find it and ended up with only 45 minutes inside resulting in me missing a lot!Great exhibit and you should definitely check it out.

Lots of Reading but Interesting. More reading than anything, but very interesting. English explanations. Interesting ephemera, tools of espionage, airdrop containers. Benches interspersed for those who need to take a break. Perspectives from many points of view. Definitely broadened my understanding on how things progressed for the Dutch after the bombing of Rotterdam, surrender, relocation of the Royal family to Great Britain, 1941 strike in protest against the pogroms, subsequent deterioration of conditions. Two hours about right, although you could spend more or less time depending on your interest.

If you're not into queuing to see paintings, this is the place to go. A very informative museum, I definitely got my money's worth: for the €10 entry fee you can get a free audio guide (I strongly recommend it). The museum is open 10-5 Tue-Fri and 11-5 on Sat-Mon. I visited on a weekday thinking it will be nice and quiet, it was until a whole school group turned up. There's a lot of information so make sure you're not in a rush. There are cafe's nearby for a break afterwards.

Another must see if you are into History. What a time this was for the world and right in the heart of occupation these brave people featured in the museum risked their lives to save others whether downed airmen or jews the Resistance helped when there was no one else to assist.

Humbling if a little muddled. Lots of information to take in regarding the Nazi occupation of the Netherlands, and whether the Dutch people should join or resist occupation. Some harrowing pictures/texts which is to be expected with a museum of this nature.My only real complaint is that it feels a little muddled. With so much information available, it doesn't quite flow properly. Easy to find using he tram network too.

Best museum I've been to . This museum is just fantastic. The front desk staff were so welcoming and kind. We arrived at 4pm and it closes at 5, and you'd need at least 2 hours to soak it all in. The staff were very friendly in letting us know that it was closing, but they still didn't make us feel rushed. He just suggested to not do the audio tour because it would take too long. It is laid out in chronological order which makes it very easy to understand. The information was well written and in depth (and in both English and Dutch). The museum itself is very interesting to walk around and look it. Lots of interactive parts. Overall we left with a very good understanding of the Resistance. We were able to understand the reasons why people joined, and why some people didn't. It's a museum with a different perspective. Lots of anecdotes from survivors of the war. Overall 10/10, fantastic experience. Just go before 4!

Very humbling. This museum is very humbling to walk through. There is a lot of information and memorabilia from the time of the Nazi invasion. Come prepared to read! Didn't get the audio guide but was there about 2 hours. Museum has a good layout and there are lockers to put your belongings.
Very very interesting. A great place - but be careful, there is so much to view and read you might need longer than anticipated!

A very worthwhile museum. The Resistance museum was very well presented, with a good layout. We stayed about 2 1/2 hours. The audio tour was very good, especially the individual stories of people and their experiences during the war. There is a nice café next door for before or after your visit.

Very Interesting. Visited Friday 30th October.Tram 9 or 14 passes it. Zoo entrance is on right and museum is on other side a little further up.  Once we got our audio guide the layout of museum was explained to us.We visited all sections including The Young Museum area.There was an awful lot of information to take in so give yourself plenty of time for your visit.
Simple and excellent story telling. Inexpensive with good visuals and story telling. Have to walk a few blocks from Hop On Bus Stop. Worth the visit.

Would you or i have the courage to resist ?. A museum that questions you ,it leaves you to answer would we have had the courage to resist when faced with such a cruel oppressor,very good exhibits and well laid out another must do to understand the modern history of holland and its people .
Fascinating. Really well laid out museum. Good audio guide. Learned a lot. A good partner to the Anne Frank museum. Well worth the visit.

Ambitious display over resistance . Besides telling the history of resistance in WW2 this museum is asking you the question: would you apply, collaborate or resist if ever put in terrifying circumstances like the ones in Holland in 1940s? I don't think anyone can tell the answer, tough we all would like to be on the right side. The question in it self is worth the time spent! The displays is allso well made and laid out in a modern and interesting way.

Very comprehensive. We saved this place for the last morning before a cruise. We walked across town to get there (it's also very accessible by public transit), and it's in a part of town that doesn't attract too many tourists -- the quieter setting was a plus for us. It's a place that needs some time to go through many of its excellent multimedia exhibits. Definitely worth a visit if you have more than a day or two to spend in Amsterdam.

History Alive. This was a very informative exhibition showing the events of those times through the eyes of the people so the emphasis was on the social history which I liked. We are pleased to hear that there are plans for a Holocaust Museum too.
Worth a visit. Thought provoking & interesting museum. We visited as a family - 2 adults & 2 teenagers. And we all learnt a lot. Would definitely recommend.

Don't resist and allow yourself time!. I hadn't done much reading about this so wasn't expecting anything in particular when we visited but left feeling cheated as I hadn't left ourselves enough time to do!With a 13 year old I was expecting s bit of feet dragging but the exhibits and the museum style kept his interest. This coupled with free audio pods (which weren't necessary as everything was translated into English) meant that it was easy to listen and examine the exhibits at the same time and created a story in the mind as we travelled around the museum. We got so caught up we lost track of time and after 2 and a bit hours found ourselves rushing to hear the stories of children who had parents with different beliefs at this time and the impact it had on their lives and outlook, (all of who are still alive today). I would recommend this museum for adults and children (from about 9 up) or split the family up with younger children going to the zoo ( just over the road) and the older ones joining them later after they have experienced the museum. The very helpful staff recommend 3 + hours and from our experience this seems about right.
Thought Provoking.. A museum that really makes you realise how lucky you are . The stories of individuals ( particularly Jewish people), were heart breaking to read.

Details of the life of many during Nazi occupation. Really well documented, described in context, and terrible description of wartime Amsterdam by the newspapers, pictures and personal stories of families lost to the holocaust. Moving and important. Captures the uncertainty of the moment as it unfolded when no one could anticipate the dreadful saga that now in hindsight seems one could predict.

A museum that really makes you think. The Verzetsmuseum (Resistance Museum) is in a really nice part of town near the zoo. On entry the staff were very friendly and helpful. The museum explores the resistance in a very interesting way that makes one think "What would I do in this situation?". The museum explores the many ways in which people resisted the Nazi occupation of the Netherlands in a frank and open way. When I was visiting, the museum was also hosting an exhibition exploring individuals' stories about the Holocaust as researched by students. This was well constructed and moving. The final section I visited was about the Dutch East Indies, whilst interesting to learn more about the non-European parts of the second world war I did find it hard to relate to this section. Altogether one of the best museums in Amsterdam, well worth a visit!

History of Dutch Bravery During WWII Revealed. This museum is filled with so many interesting facts about the Dutch resistance during the War, that were unknown to me. The area has many interactive settings and lots of memorabelia. Everything is set up chronologically and easy to understand. in Dutch and English, possibly German ( I don't remember).

Informative, interesting & worth a visit. This museum was very interesting and informative, giving a background on the Dutch resistance during the Nazi occupation. It is a smaller museum, but it does take at least a couple of hours to go through all of the exhibits and displays. There are audio guides available at no cost as well. This is a good museum to visit before you visit Anne Frank house because of the background it provides. Very interesting and worth a visit.

A moving and educational experience. Wow - what a moving experience.We made a real effort to go the this museum and we are so pleased that we did.Everyone is offered a free device which narrates the various parts of the museum.Both my wife and I learnt so much about the resistance in the Netherlands during WW2.If you are in Amsterdam then it really is worth visiting this museum.

Poorly organized. We really wanted to like this museum but it was poorlyorganized- we felt like we were walking left then right and then didn't know where to go. There was too much info- I know there can never be enuff to explain that period of time- but we felt overwhelmed.

Well presented, informative and non judgemental. A surprise. Took advantage of this in place of visiting the Ann Frank home. The history of how The Netherlands was occupied, how the population was treated and their reaction. How groups of people supported each other and worked with the Queen and her allies to oust the occupiers

Really Interesting. A small museum but gave a fascinating and at times heartbreaking account not only of the Dutch Resistance, but of the situation in the Netherlands at the time of the War. We spent a couple of hours but could have spent longer. Well worth a visit

A chilling reminder of evil times, portraying the Dutch with truth, courage and determination. A well presented museum, easy to find yor way around, and ample supply of original documents of the time.A somber reminder of how temporary and fragile life has been in the years gone by.

Occupation and Resistance. The Resistance Museum takes you to another time and place to experience life in Holland during Nazi occupation. There is no way one can possibly know the fear, bravery and determination of the Dutch people unless you experienced it first hand. This museum exposes us to the challenges and hardships these people encountered - the unsung heros - the Dutch Resistance. This is a small museum filled with excellent displays. Using original items, pictures, banners, sound and video, you soon feel you are living among these ordinary people who did extraordinary things just to survive. This museum also gave me a better understanding of what it was really like to be Jewish during such dangerous times. I think this is a great lesson in history and we should all learn from it. Lest we forget.

Must see WWII remembrance.. Netherlands was occupied by the Germans in WWII. Resistance flourished. In this museum there are guides that take you through the museum in an hour and a half. All about WWII and the resistance movement. A must do if you are interested in war history.

Great experience. I found this to be one of the more interesting museums I have been in. I didn't know much about the Dutch Resistance (other than by reputation) and this place did a great job explaining many aspects of their efforts. They also had exhibits on the worldwide Dutch military presence. I highly recommend it for anyone into military or Dutch history... .
Very well done museum. Incredibly well thought out and put together museum. Great interactive displays which keep you interested and engaged.

Very Interesting Museum. The museum had a lot of interesting displays and history. I love history, especially the years surrounding WWII. It was a little harder to find, especially using public transportation (a bit of a walk from the closest tram). Once inside, it's pretty easy to figure your way around. It did take us about 3 1/2 hours to get through and we didn't read everything. Towards the end, it gets to be a bit long and we tended to skip over some of it. Not everything is in English, so it does make it a bit harder. If you're interested in WWII, it's worth visiting.

Disappointing. The museum takes you through the story of the Dutch people from the 1930s to the end of World War II. The exhibits are mostly documentary in nature and whilst there are descriptive notes/info from the audio tour with them you cannot fully appreciate them if you don't speak Dutch. The flow of the museum is chronological with side rooms on specific issues, e.g. the jews and the railway workers. Whilst I found the museum interesting I feel the experience could have been enhanced if you were given a brief overview document of the story when you entered the museum and a small map showing what section was which. Personally I would have liked there to be more on the general resistance to the Nazis, what there was felt a bit niche. It would have help if the lighting level was increased thereby making it easier to read some the descriptors.

Great history. This museum was very interesting and explained the ingenuity of people helping the Jews to escape the Nazis. The exhibits on show are great and you come to appreciate the terrible times suffered by all during WWII.

Very Informative about life during WWII. The museum is designed to tell you about life under the german occupation during WWII. Very well laid out and informative. Took us about 2 hours at an easy pace to see all of the exhibits.

Somewhat disappointed. I thought the museum focused more on the lead up and history of war, as opposed to the resistance movement. But having said that they did a great job of presenting history of the Netherlands in WW2.
Very informative. Very informative, make sure you leave lots of time, takes a while to read all he displays. The audio guides were a good help. Info was displayed in English all the way round :)

Not to Be Missed!. This was the most surprisingly excellent museum I went to on my trip to Stockholm, Berlin, and Amsterdam. This museum does a superlative job of showing you the reality of Nazi-occupied Europe. It is both informative and emotional, and finds just the right balance between interactive and static exhibits. There were so many items on display here that registered with me—the propaganda posters, the journals, the concentration camp uniforms, the photos and videos of Amsterdam citizens greeting the Allies.I cannot recommend this museum highly enough! It's included on the IAMsterdam city card, so do not miss this.

went here after WW2 tour. Spent an hour in this museum after our WW2 tour with Peter Schaapman. Very informative, and suggest getting the free hand held recorder to listen to interesting facts regarding the exhibits.

A fantastic museum. This was an amazing museum, which unfortunately suffered a leak as we were about half way round and we had to leave the museum.Till then the museum presented the story of a nation under a hated rule and the impact on the population as a whole.
Well worth a visit. We learned about this late in our trip. It has a meaningful story and tells it in a very solid format.

Very moving. Not a fun stop, but an important place if you want to understand the experience of occupied Amsterdam. Thought it focused too much on the Jewish experience and not as much on the experience of ordinary citizens of Holland. Worth the time.

Good Museum to understand occupied Netherlands during WWII. The museum is well laid out and has a lot of information ranging from from late 1930s before the war through to the liberation in 1945. Including many interesting stories from people that were involved. At 10eur, the entrance price is one of the cheaper ones in Amsterdam (the museums are all very expensive) and the very comprehensive audio guide was included in the entrance price. Free storage lockers too (2eur deposit you get back). Worth a visit if you want to understand more about the history.

Very interesting and great for kids too. We were informed about this museum by our B&B host and as my husband is interested in this subject we went along. It cost 10 euros each for adults, this included the use of audio equipment. We also ventured into the kids area where there was lots of little seating areas for the kids so that they could sit and listen to the narration. This museum is certainly worth a visit.

Interesting but not well presented. Spent about 2 hrs here as I am a World War II history but it was even hard for me to plod my way through all the poorly presented exhibits. So of the exhibits tags are unreadable and there doesn't seem to be any clear plan/take away message to this museum.

A very worthwhile trip- You can learn a lot- very good audio guides. We were here briefly but it was on my list to go as it had been recommended to me. Solid learning experience - great for teenagers and adults. Great audio with many exhibitions to tie it together. Sometimes the audio was confusing as to which item it was talking about. I would have liked more movies as well. But over all a very worthwhile trip.

Very well done and informative!. We found the Resistance Museum quite interesting. One of the exhibits that stands out in my mind was a drawer you could open revealing plastic coated actual information cards on each Jewish person in the area. Seeing the real thing is always so much more interesting and moving. We enjoyed learning the chronology of what happened year by year to the Jews of the Netherlands, not having much prior exposure. It was all very disturbing as is any exhibit of such a dark period in our history but very well done.

Defiant opposition to cruel occupation (at home and abroad).. Second visit confirms that this is an informative and well organized museum depicting the impact of the German and Japanese Occupations of the Netherlands and the East Indies respectively. The personal stories and the insight of teenagers to their changed circumstances are powerful. An opportunity to also obtain English language materials from the bookshop reception.

Good museum - Coherent and Comprehensive. The story of The Netherlands under Nazi Occupation is not a widely known WWII history, so this museums offers a fresh perspective and a slightly different angle to histories from, for example, France or Poland. The museum is a little linear, but does an excellent job in introducing visitors to the subject. Dutch Resistance was certainly more benign than in some other European countries but no less admirable and the museum describes the situation throughout the war very well. Lots of primary sources and artifacts, and a broad understanding of what constitutes 'resistance' which is fascinating. Certainly worth a visit if you're a History Buff

Excellent insight into life during WWII. This was an amazing museum. I highly recommend this one to all visitors as this museum gives you a great understanding of what it was like to be in the Netherlands during the war and the many efforts to resist the Nazis. The information and artifacts are superb, and the audio guide gives even more context to what you see throughout each exhibit.

Not your average WWII museum. My wife and I were blown away by this museum! After seeing numerous World War II museums they can start to feel the same but this was is very different. This museum focuses on the experience of the Dutch specifically. With the Dutch, they were fixed to surrender early and suddenly. After that, the Germans occupied the country but wanted the Dutch to join with the Germans in the fight. So rather than sending the people to terrible work camps, they were nice to the Dutch, giving some freedoms. This is where the whole theme of the museum shines. The museum breaks down into three options, assimilate with the Germans, adjust your everyday life around the new restrictions, or rebel against the Germans. From here, all stories are told in one of those 3 contexts. It's a very fascinating way to tell the stories and the museum is very interactive. My wife and I stayed 3 hours and that's only because we only prepaid for 3 hours of parking!

World War II museum is a better title.. This museum is not well advertised and we had some trouble finding it. I was eager to learn about Hollanders who resisted the Nazi regime. Yet, it was more about the war in general. How the Nazis tried to placate the Dutch but when the Dutch didn't go along, the Nazis came down hard. While I enjoyed the museum, it was a bit scattered and lacked systematic advancement. I especially liked the children's section which was very personal and educational. So,glad we went.

Another Resistance Museum. Now visited Resistance museums in Lyon, Besancon and here in Amsterdam. This museum essentially deals with how the population coped with the German occupation, either Adoption, Resistance or collaboration. Also deals with the plight of the Jews.

Excellent . My husband and I spent close to 3 hours in this museum, found it fascinating. Excellent at listing events in a chronological order. I would recommend this museum as a must while visiting Amsterdam.

Thought provoking and thorough explanation of the Netherland's experience during this war. This is a several hour visit - the best Musuem I have ever visited -for it's thought provoking value. It is not a passive activity and great for kids -adults should also see the kids section - excellent. (And parents - graphic images that kids should not see are sequestered into one room - well marked.)

Thought provoking.. I really enjoyed this, although it is probably in the second tier of 'things to do' if you're on limited time in Amsterdam. It poses the question "What would you have done?" Would you have collaborated, resisted or 'kept your head down and gone with the flow'. Interesting to see how different people reacted. Small scale, personal artifacts and stories. I enjoyed it, but it's located a little out of 'tourist central' for some.
Story of Dutch resistance in ww2. Very well laid out and very tastefully done. Explains well the difficult issues faced by the Dutch people during ww2.
interesting. very good incite to the resistance in Holland during the war, get an i Amsterdam card get in free to most of attractions and free public transport

Interestingly Different WW II Museum. We loved this museum. Mostly in story form, it reviews the events and outcomes resulting from Hitler's invasion of The Netherlands in WW II. Powerful stories, including the braveness of some individuals, most of whom lost their lives as a result.

Well presented showing the hardships experienced by the Dutch during WWII. A good alternative to Anne Franks house to learn about the hardships experienced by all in Holland during WWII. very well presented

high lights ?. Not as easy to follow displays as you might think, the hand held translation machines work well enough and are essential even if they do cost another 3 euros, some interesting exhibit's but don't expect to see to much in the way of arms or larger items of interest, its mostly ephemera based but interesting never the less the average layman will find things of interest but if your good with your military history there is little new I'm afraid. hour, hour n a half should have it covered. its 10 euros for entry + 3 for the translator and no food or drink is allowed in the museum.

Some context for an amiable city. Amsterdam with its marvelous museums, comfortable restaurants, ease of getting around, by walking or taking the trams, and ever friendly residents to offer directions and recommendations, is a most amiable city. That makes the German occupation in World War Two that more frightening: how a once neighboring country became an occupier, than an oprpessor, then a ogre. But Germany did, and all needs to be reminded of the horror, This museum documents the awful days, Not as dramatic as the Anne Frank House , which tells the story through agifted, sensitive child who was so needlessly killed only weeks before liberation, but the Resistance gives that tour a needed context. It lends Amsterdam a needed history to appreciate it more, and not incidentally make the city's nefarious Red Light district such a contradiction. Contradictions abound.
A surprise. Very surprised that I didn't visit this interesting museum earlier! This part of history is just interesting and meaningful to lean about. I'll definitely visit again sometime.

Average.... Had a chance to look at this museum my last trip to Amsterdam. For first timers to Amsterdam there are a number of other locations that would be a must see. The information provided at this location was good however they did not have a large number of items to view.

What would you have done?. A huge collection of images and documents from the German occupation of the Netherlands, with a few other exhibits like the presses used to print resistance newspapers - you'll need at least half a day to absorb it. The captioning is dense - the audio guide really helps. There's an excellent children's area focussing on the experience of 4 chidren after the invasion. There are few images of the holocaust but seeing its administration is just as chilling. This museum brings you individuals - their life and death decisions, deceipt, politicking, hard choices, but above all the dreadful uncertainties that faced them 75 years ago. I left feeling I'd shared some of their experience and some of the uncertainty - a sobering visit.

important museum. an important museum to visit - to get a better understanding of complex situations during WWII - children's section also very well done and informative - my only problem was that the air in the museum was stuffy - worth taking the time to see

Must go for WWII buffs. It is a place that is quite informative and tells alot of stories that might not be well known to people outside of Amsterdam.One of the highlights was seeing Anne Frank's neighbour in the children's section.Takes about 4-5 hours if you see 80% of the exhibition with the audioguide.The audioguide is one that has an infrared sensor or NFC of some sort to be interactive. It also means that its one person per audioguide. Not such a big issue as one ticket entry allows an audioguide which is included in the price.Start with the video upstairs and don't miss the children's section as i found it as informative as the adult side but seen through eyes of children.There was also an exhibition of the prisoners of Dachau which was also quite good.
The War. We learned new facts regarding the war in general, very informative and very interesting if not a little sad.

Thought provoking.. Gives a vivid sense of life, from many aspects, in an occupied ccountry. Well set out with informative free visual and media guides. Even as adults found the junior section of the Museum excellent. So glad we visited.
Effectively Presents Complexity. Excellent and comprehensive look at Dutch choices in both the Netherlands and West Indies during WWII. Comprehensive displays with audio.

Superb experience. A can't miss for anyone interested in World War II history. Take time as an adult to go through the children's section. It is priceless. You absolutely must have the listening device to fully enjoy it.

History buffs will like this. Not as impressive as Copenhagen's Resistance Museum (before it burned down), but still very good. Captures well the individual stories and courage it took to fight the Nazis. However, the museum itself isn't all that well organized to walk through.Just be patient. Audio in English is provided. Staff friendly. Metro/tram stop about six blocks away. Easy walk.

Moving. This was by far one of the best experiences in Amsterdam.
An unspoilt museum that seems to pride itself on being a true representation of WW2.
I was actually moved to tears at some parts.
Especially good for the history lovers.
History lesson. Very interesting am interested in WW2 history and is an eye opener to what the Dutch people encountered during the German invasion.

Excellent (and often moving) experience. . What this museum lacks in size it more than makes up for in content. Jam packed with photographs, artefacts and information, this museum will easily consume a good few hours of your time if you are interested in learning more about what happened to Holland's Jewish population and dutch resistance of the nazi occupation. We found this museum fascinating and could easily have spent even longer here. Personally, I came away from our visit feeling very humbled and with a whole new admiration for this country and its people! Very well worth it!
Interesting.... Good Museum with interesting information on the Dutch resistance during WWII. Worth a visit if you are in the area.

Great place to learn about Holland in WWII. Don't miss this gem honoring the men and women who resisted Nazi occupation during WWII. Everyone flocks to the Anne Frank House for one reason or another and the queue there is unbelievable. But this unassuming museum showcases the Dutch's resistance and perspective on their place during WWII and, in my humble opinion, tells more on the history of this period than the little hidden annex. Learned much more than I anticipated. It was humbling and disturbing. It makes us appreciate peace and freedom all the more.

Left knowing more than when I came.. The museum was interesting and I learned from it. But the museum seems a little stale. Not too exciting but lots to learn if you are interested in reading the exhibits. We reached it by public transporation.
History buffs do not miss this. This is a great museum if you want to know how the Dutch resisted the Nazi oppression. There are many videos explaining life during that period
Interesting insight. An interesting insight in the life of Netherland during WWII. It shows how the people coped with the invasion. The audioguide is obligatory, specially for non-dutch speakers.

Learned a bit of history here. My wife and I learned quite a bit about the challenges of the people of the Netherlands during WWII. Somewhat inspiring that so many resisted the tyranny of the Nazi state.

A humbling and disturbing must see museum. We wanted to see and learn more about the Nazi occupation of The Netherlands and the Dutch resistance to that occupation. The displays, pictures and narratives were outstanding, educational and provided a different perspective on the war. The experience was disturbing and humbling. We're so glad we went to the Resistance Museum and highly recommend you do as well.

a disappointment in a city full of wondrous musems. Don't bother if you want to find out about how the Dutch resisted the Nazis because you will learn little. The exhibitions are static, tired and skim over any details about how and when the resistance was organised. It was so disappointing.
great place. Good info, very interesting, gives a good picture of life in Amsterdam during and immediately after the war

Discover Little-known History of Dutch Anti-Nazi Defiance!. It was enlightening to discover the extent of Dutch anti-Nazi Resistance.
