To the degree that any Dutch Jews were saved, much gratitude goes to the non-Jews who helped them. This jewel of a museum is engaging, informative, and inspiring. The staff is warm and helpful. Lovely cafe next door. I will return when I visit Amsterdam again.

Time Well Sent...Get your history lesson here. Wonderful stories about individuals with photos/memorabilia and short films. Lots and lots of short stories about many different ways the Dutch resistance fought the Nazis. Great for ages about 10 years and older.

A must do in Amsterdam. A must see in Amsterdam. We went on Rick Steves' recommendation and it was well worth it. The museum exhibits constantly ask visitors three questions: adapt? cooperate? resist?

Great museum, a must for every visitor in Amsterdam . The museum is very educational, well structured with great explanations of the audio guide that is provided for free.
Gives a comprehensive and interesting look on the lives of Dutch people in WWII.
Ask yourself the question. Fairly sophisticated multi media presentation with some excellent exhibits. Gives a greater appreciation of life in that time.
Resist or collaborate?. Highly recomnended - it provides insight into the Dutch resistance. It somewhat justifies the collaborators but the exhibits are telling and honestly presented.

Excellent educational experience. Visited The Resistance Museum an hour or two before closing time and was so engrossed in the stories I had to make a return visit to finish seeing the rest of the museum. Lots of information - easy to read segments of texts, lots of items on display.
Would definitely visit again, and recommend it to other museum-goers!

Wrong name for museum as very little on actual Resistance. A big disappointment as was to be a key visit during my trip. Needs a title change referring more to Dutch WW2 experience. The few items relating to actual Resistance were poorly displayed in difficult to see display panels, presumably designed to add some "mystery". Better suited to Disney rather than an adult audience. Also too much trying to rationalise collaboration and avoidance rather than active resistance. The heroes were those who fought against occupation and they should not be compared to the rest who did not, or worse.
Worth a visit. Really interesting museum. Definitely worth a visit, especially if you're particularly interested in history and wars.

Brilliant WW2 museum. As an historian by profession I was very much looking forward to this museum - and it did not disappoint. Everything was very well laid-out, with all text in Dutch and English (We took audio guides but didn't really need them in the end). Mostly focuses on occupied Holland, but there is a smaller section devoted to Dutch Indonesia under the Japanese near the end which was also very good. Some fascinating artefacts like the bicycle with a scooter's front wheel demonstrating the rubber shortages. As a British visitor it was surreal seeing air raid displays - which we are very used to of course thanks to the Luftwaffe!! - and remembering that it was Allied bombings they were afraid of following the rapid German conquest.
Great museum, not crowded.. Really good museum, not very big but packed with a lot of history. Expect 2 hrs. Very good story of WW2 resistance of the Dutch.

Important museum but not very engaging. The museum imparts interesting and important information but not in an involving manner. It is an old-fashioned museum with photos and captions, not interactive.

Outstanding museum. This museum was great, the path through the exhibits follows a timeline of historical events. The exhibits themselves include a wide variety of multimedia which makes it constantly interesting. You might be viewing actual footage, movies, historical papers, analyses, etc. A thoroughly engaging experience. A great opportunity for education of people who weren't around during that era.

Great Newer Museum. Excellent exhibits showing the Dutch side of WWII. Very detailed and well thought out displays. Children's exhibit excellent too. A family member was part of the Dutch Resistance and a POW during WWI so this was a huge history lesson for our kids.

Very thought provoking. Set in a quiet neighborhood across from the zoo, the museum presented decisions the people of the Netherlands had to deal with during World War II. Consequences were shown for various types of decisions that people. Personal stories were told for the various situations the people were put in.

Dutch Resistance during WW2 occupation. A comprehensive presentation of what occupation by Axis forces meant for the Dutch. The progressive imposition of control by the Axis forces, the deportation of the Jews and some strong stories from those deportations was educational. Also a small section on the Japanese occupation of Dutch colonies in the Far East. Needs to be seen.

Dutch Resistance Museum. A memorable event.. Did a private tour of the Resistance museum. The historical aspects of the Dutch occupation and the effects on Dutch society was an amaizing perspective on the effect of the occupation on the Netherlands and the issue of compliance vs. resistance. Guide arranged thru museum was extremely knowledgeable and was great.

Not as interesting as I thought it was going to be. After the introduction film it started out quite interesting and quickly became a bit boring for me although my wife enjoyed it. It is just plaque after plaque and there was very little about what the resistance actually did.

A part of history. This was a must see for me as my grandfather was part of the resistance in WWII. It was unbelievable to see and hear what people endured under the German Occupation of the Netherlands.

Fascinating. What a great museum, so well laid out and a massive amount of information and interactive displays. We all learnt so much and could have spent all afternoon here. Don't waste your money going to the Anne Frank house. This museum is way more informative, there is no line up for admission and it is included on the I Amsterdam card.

Many voices. Great information about the Dutch experience of the war. There are many personal profiles that show the range of people's experience's. We were a family of five adults, and all agreed that this was a highlight of our trip.

Very interesting. Arranged in chronological order and visually interesting, this museum tells the story of German occupation from the perspective of ordinary Dutch citizens. The audio guide is useful.
Well worth a visit. Great museum with lots to seeNo queues Allow lots of timeGreat insight to pastFriendly staff Well worth the visit

Interactive Sensorial Tools used to convey Dutch Wartime Resistance. Both informative and educational museum !
Details individual lives and experiences of some Dutch people who made conscious and dangerous decisions to 'make a stand' - small or large against the occupying Nazi regime.

Put yourself into the experience. The resistance museum was confronting. The interactive displays bring home the fear and desperation of the Jews in Holland. There is a junior area that follows the experience of four children. It had been designed for children but as an adult I found it fascinating. You find out later what had happened to them Well worth a visit.
Resistance. A very comprehensive museum, very well set out and easy to understand and follow. Most informative in all aspects.
A place to help us all remember. This place makes you realise how resilient people can be. What a fantastic history lesson but so much it was hard to take it all in.

Needs some variety. I felt the museum wasn't as interactive as it could have been. Basically every "stand" is the same. A photo with some writing next to it and maybe something to flick through. Made it seem a bit monotomous to me. However, the subject of the museum was very interesting and it was informative.

Fascinating historical perspective, well worth a visit. This museum is situated across from the zoo in the Plantage neighborhood. It is an easy and lovely walk from the main tourist zone (red light etc.), past the botanic gardens and through a leafy green residential neighborhood featuring a quiet canal side park. The museum building is of modern design. The admission fee is modest and they offer free audio tour headsets, which I recommend since they offer additional information beyond what you will find on the display placards, such as individual personal stories.This museum follows the chronological and social history of the Dutch resistance to Nazi occupation in WWII. It is a fascinating look at the agonizing decisions each Dutch citizen faced as they dealt with the mounting restrictions imposed by the Nazi regime. This museum is an excellent companion visit to the Anne Frank house, to give a more complete picture of the Dutch experience in WWII. The displays are more about information rather than artifacts, although there are some fascinating personal items to look at, along with newspaper clippings, propaganda films, and secret devices like homemade crystal radios hidden in matchboxes etc. There is a junior section geared for children. I think younger children might find the main area boring since it is text-intensive.The surrounding neighborhood is a quiet respite from the maddening tourist crowds of the Dam Square and the Red Light District. There are several restaurants nearby. Try the Cafe Koosje, one block away, for a cozy casual lunch or beverage break on your way to or from the museum.

History brought to life in this hidden gem.. My son wanted to visit this during a family visit to the City. It was a moving experience and brought to life the sacrifices made by those who lived in occupied Europe. The displays and media are very informative, we could have spent another 2 hours if we had read and listened to all the media displays. Very well laid out.

Fascinating Exhibition . This is a really interesting exhibition not how the Netherlands coped with Nazi invasion in WWII. An interesting & more accessible museum than Anne Franks House - i.e. no queue! Well worth the visit, with excellent audio guides that provide detailed insight into the questions the Dutch faced following occupation: carry on as normal, work with the Nazi's, or resist!
resistance. a very interesting museum showing the Dutch history of resistance during the war. Also showing the fate of all Dutch Jews and how people reacted.

Looking back at recent history. This is a museum that I would recommend any young persons interested in history to visit. It tells of the persecution of the Dutch Jews and how they were fooled into admitting they were Jews and there ill treatment. The museum tells how some of the Dutch men and women were transported to Germany to work in factories to replace German workers now as soldiers. My wife and I thought that we needed more time to visit this place to absorb everything

A must see if you are a history lover. The museum is a very informative and interesting but also a sad reminder of histories past in the Holocaust.Myself and a friend, both very interested in history learnt several different facts that some education and media institutes either forget or do not tell others. The museum also had a children's section, which I personally think is amazing as I believe that children should learn about this part of history.The museum has various stages which include audio shows, to artefacts and images, all of these had English translations and spoken audio if needed.
Very moving. Great little museum, off the beaten track somewhat - but worth it! Very moving and informative visit - spent 2 hours here and could have spent longer!

I Amsterdam included. We visited the museum as it was next to the zoo, and also included in the I Amsterdam card. The museum provides audio guides in multiple languages. It shows the various stages through the war / occupation with videos, artefacts and audio commentary.Very interesting to see what happened in other countries during the war.

Fiercely Against Naziism, as well as Protection of Jews and Others.. We expected to learn a great deal about the ways residents of the Netherlands shielded, hid and protected Jews, but were surprised to realize there was more than that critical and noble behavior. Residents of Amsterdam were passionately resistant to everything and anything that supported the Nazi party and its supremacy actions and attitudes. Many rooms of the Museum depict remnants and relics of situations and places where Netherlanders pushed back against Nazi Oppression.

Very informative!. This museum is well-organized and very interesting. My history-loving 7 year old was captivated by the children's exhibit and in the regular museum there was only one small area referring to the concentration camps that I felt would be too much for him. Definitely worth a visit. We stayed about two hours at a leisurely pace.

Great Museum. We did this museum on a lurk and glad we did! I would say 1.5 to 2 hours is an ample amount of time to go through it. Was a very interesting experience and we learned a great deal. They even have a section tailored to younger children.

Amazing. The children part is a MUST. We spent almost three ours just in the children part of the museum listening to the stories of the four characters. The material is presented really well and the stories are really poignant. Easy enough for ann8 years old to follow, in English and Dutch, and deep enough to make kids understand the different realities

A very thought provoking museum. I could have spent a lot more time here. Exceptionally well put together and is quite thought provoking. What would I do in those circumstances?. I hope I never have to make the choice! The exhibits lead you through - with highlights on different individuals from a wide range of subjects. Well balanced and very interesting & informative

Very instructive. As a French I didn't know many things about the Dutch's role and life during WWII, but it is not true anymore ! This museum deals with almost all the aspects of the period (state role, but also civilian life, which interest me much more!) I warmly recommend this museum (and I'm not fond of history usually!)
Find out what really happened in WWII !!!. Excellent displays and audio tour, brought home how courageous ordinary Dutch people had been during such a difficult and horrific time in World history.

Well worth a visit. Located virtually across the street from the Artis zoo, the Resistance Museum is well worth a visit. It includes many reminders of the horrors of WWII. It is not big, but to fully appreciate the displays one should allow at least 2 hours for the visit. We visited on the day before taking the WWII history walking tour and found that each activity complemented the other.
Sad, moving informative museum. This was an amazing museum with exhibits, photos and information about what occurred here during World war 2.

packs a punch, lots of information in a small museum. The museum in all on one floor, there is a great video, and loads to read. Everything in is both english and dutch. There are also audio guides but when we went they had run out - the museum is very popular on the weekends. The museum tells the story of the dutch resistance from invasion by the nazis to the allied forces retaking the country via personal stories of Dutch citizens. The museum is small but incredibly dense (in a good way) it isn't as sad as some WWII museums but is certainly serious. You also find out how the dutch organisation methods made it very easy for the Nazis to round people us.
Well worth a visit.. Very very interesting - well worth a visit. Take time to go round. I was interested to read about the experience of people in Indonesia as well as Amsterdam.

An Unforgettable Museum. This is a museum not to be missed if you have visited the Anne Frank House of Amsterdam. The displays and information throughout my tour of the museum was really moving. The museum tells much about the life and situation of Dutch people before and during the German occupation in the Second World War.
Thought provoking. We liked this museum. A well presented and logical layout. Great interactive displays. Came away knowing a lot more about the Dutch and WW2
Not to be missed. Well worth tracking this museum down. Very interesting look into Amsterdam at the time of WWII with a bit of history leading up to that time.

The Junior exhibit is the best part and not just for kids. The "Junior" exhibit is the best part and not just for the kids. We went to this museum the day prior to going to the Anne Frank House. It gave a wonderful perspective of the many other kids that had a similar experience to Anne. The kids section take your though the lives a several children in an interactive way. Our kids got a lot out of it and I felt it was better than the rest of the museum.

Not a priority. Interesting to see the photographs of that time, most of the information was in Dutch. Sobering to see how many people died defying the Nazis. The warfare, machinery uniforms and guns were well displayed.

A must see, emotional and informative.. We decided not to go to the Anne Franks Huis because we did not book a slot and the queues were over 3hrs because of the rain. This place was a fantastic alternative or addition to going to the Anne Frank house. The museum is extremely emotional and informative, it offered many personal accounts of peoples experiences during the war which were very similar to Anne Frank but not as widely known. The museum offered a very balanced view of the facts from this period of history and opinions from the people who lived in Amsterdam at the time. Very friendly staff and free audio tour included as we walked around the museum. There is also a junior part of the museum that presents real stories from children during the war in place of the famous Anne Frank story, this was a great way of helping children understand the horrendous tragedies of the holocaust and why it happened.

Lame. If you have nothing else to do, you could stop here. I certainly wouldn't waste time if you could think of anything else to do. After going to this museum and carefully looking at all of the exhibits, I'm still relatively underwhelmed by the Dutch resistance. Not quite sure they should have dedicated a whole museum to it...

Very interesting. Museum does a wonderful job of placing texture on its narritive. Many stories of individuals and the choices they made during the occupation of Amsterdam. Very well laid out with loads of individual aspects in great detail. Highly recommended.

Excellent museum. This is a very well laid out and highly informative museum detailing all aspects of Dutch resistance during World War Two. There are any superb objects, pictures and displays from the period along with detailed testimonies from those actually involved in resistance activities at all levels. And some not involved.... A special section is devoted to life in the Dutch East Indies during WW2 which, unlike the matters covered in the main exhibition, was almost wholly new to me. Located in the very attractive Plantage area of the city this beautiful building - which was originally a Jewish cultural centre - also contains a relatively small but well stocked gift shop.

Dutch Resistance Response To Nazi Occupation. Very informative museum detailing the Dutch resistance effort during World War 2. Museum is well laid out and it tells various individuals stories of dealing with the Nazi occupation. A good way to spend a few hours in Amsterdam.

I learned a lot. We just happen upon this museum and thought it would be interesting since it was a topic we did not know a lot about. We found it to be a well-laid out museum. I felt like I left with a greater appreciation for and knowledge of the Dutch resistance. Also, it was a nice break from looking at art :). We were in Amsterdam for 7 days and I'm glad we visited this museum.

Worthwhile Stop. This is well worth the visit and very educational. Little kids - no good, but anyone with an interest in Holland and WWII - great. A little redundant at times, but easy to maneuver and thorough. Allow about and hour to 1 1/2 hours once inside.

Fascinating even for those with little knowledge of WWII. The audio tour provides a look at the personal impact the Resistance had. Our group included five teenaged girls, and they were very interested.

A family weeks in amsterdam. We went here after, the Anne Frank house, it puts the experience of the Netherlands in the 2nd world war into perspective. It is a very engaging museum and all children and young people who are taken to the anne frank house should visit here too. It will consolidate the period of history and is still to be remembered.
We must not forget. This was a very informative museum and tide in nicely for us as we have been to Poland and seen Auschwitz.

Great museum. Excellent museum. Great if you are interested in history. It is all about the history of Holland in the 2nd world war. Very visual. Great in that everything is in English also you get a free audio guide. Also no queue. If you are considering Anne Frank house, which is also great but have limited time then go to this one instead as theres a 3 hour wait at Anne Frank house, but no queues at this one.

Best Museum . With only a few days in Amsterdam, figuring out which museums to visit is quite a task, but I'm certainly glad this one made the list. It is incredibly well put together and quite interactive. You can choose how in depth your tour goes, which is nice when you are pressed for time in a city with so many places to go and see and things to do and eat. I urge you to put this museum on your check list. It was by far the best museum experience I had on my visit to the city!

Great Museum. This is a genuinely great museum telling the story of Holland during World War 2. A thoughtful and unvarnished narrative is provided of a people whose response to the Nazis was initially characterized by great passivity(though with some notable exceptions). The bottom line is that this is a thought provoking, informative and deeply moving museum. Allow 2 hours to experience it properly.

Best museum in Amsterdam . Did this on our last day. In both a English and Dutch. Lots to see and unlike the other museums in Amsterdam this has an informative narrative to keep your interest as you go around. Tells the story of the German invasion of the Netherlands, the Dutch resistance and also Dutch-Indonesia resistance against the Japanese.

A must see if in Amsterdam. This is one of the best museums I have been to and extremely well done a must see if in Amsterdam. Especially as we tried to book Anne Frank House a month before we left and it was completely booked out until well after we came home a month later.

Very informative and subtle. Audioguide was redundant. And no place to sit, so consider walking back to the lobby for a rest halfway through! But the content and exhibits were first rate. For an American it was a very good way to learn about the "grey areas" of occupation. Not everyone was cleanly a hero or villain. In fact most were both or neither.

What a great find. This is a small museum about the Netherlands and the war. It covers all of this, including the lead up to it and the dutch view on the Germans. They provide audio players to take your through the exhibits.We found it very interesting and sometimes quite moving. Ended up spending over 2 hours looking around. Well worth the time

Great for WWII history. You have a choice of touring the museum with a self audio guide or by reading the captions in either Dutch or English. A great history for learning about their involvement in World War 2. Very easy to get around but a little hard to read the captions at time. Overall learned a lot about the Netherlands and their involvement in World War 2

Excellent museum. This is an excellent, informative and moving experience - a must see in Amsterdam. Expect to spend 2 hours minimum if you want to read the all the information given. It gives a different perspective regarding WWII and is thought provoking. There were no lines to get in and the museum itself was not crowded.
Best war museum. Second World War in Holland and in Indonesia shown in an engaging and moving way. From a visual point of view one of the best museums of its kind.

Fascinating and worth a visit. This museum explains so much about how the Nazis were able to take control of the country and the people. It's an important part of the story that is rarely told. Use your MuseumKaarte for free admission.

Really made me think would i have adjusted , collaberated or resisted. Told to see it by a friend , glad I did , very moving, thought provoking and challenging .When my grandson is a little older I'm taking him to Amsterdam and will include this and Ann franks house

What would you have done?. A fascinating exhibition which really makes you think and question your own actions. Hopefully, the decision to collaborate or resist is one I will never have to make. There are lots of stories here - simple acts of defiance (such as after being asked to sew up holes in a Nazi officer's socks a lady proceeded to sew up the footholes), heroic attempts at escape (kayaking across the North Sea) to heartbreaking, 0actual letters thrown in desperation from a transport train enroute to a concentration camp. The section on individuals incacerated in Dachau is worth the admission price alone. We also toured the junior section of the museum which is absolutely stunning - a gorgeously desinged interactive display with fantastic real stories depicting the different lives of children growing up in occupied Amsterdam/Holland. Do visit, it truely is a worthwile, sobering, enlightening and educating experience.
Truly Moving. Truly wonderful Hotel, with a real and moving insight into the Struggle of the Dutch people during WW2
Compliments a visit to Anne Frank House. The museum is very well done and holds your interest with a good audio tour. Well worth a couple of hours.

I could easily spend all day here!. This was such a cool, interactive museum with tons of information. There was an audio guide, and a lot of pictures and replicas, and it's very colorful. You move at your own pace with the guide and listen and read along, and explore the dioramas and different scenes. It was extremely informative, and the information was heavy, but you learned all about the Dutch resistance in WWII to the German occupation (and much more), and it was truly heartwarming to see Amsterdam take the time to create a museum to teach this history. You learn about all different aspects of the resistance, and there's even an introductory video, a screening room showing 1930s and 40s propaganda, and even a section with personal interviews. There's a ton of information to learn about the war there that you won't learn anywhere else, and I'm very glad I visited the museum.

3 days in Amsterdam. My father told me to visit this on our trip and we truly enjoyed it! Couldn't get into the Ann Frank Museum so this was another option. We used the audivoxes which helps explain everything. If you love World War II history, then this is a great visit. Small, so can be done in less than 2 hours.

Very comprehensive. This museum is packed with information. We had no idea and had to go over a 2 day period to catch it all. Gives a very good accounting of events/time periods and the Children's part is actually very helpful to get a feel of how things had gone from being a young child to an adult in that time period
Interesting. Definitely worth a look allow at least a couple of hours to truely get the best out of this museum. Increased our knowledge of the suffering of the Dutch/Jewish people at that time.

Stimulating, effecting, thought provoking.. What an amazing presentation! This museum begins with a very well presented video to pose the dilemma of living in an occupied country. Do you just get on with life as best you can, do you collaborate, or do you resist? The museum does a fantastic job in showing what it is like to suddenly find yourself living with an occupying force. It also shows how clever (devious) the occupying Nazis were in drawing people into thinking things were not going to be as bad as they thought (at first). It presents real people making real, difficult choices to amazing effect. A very thought provoking experience, my friend and I were discussing the issues for the rest of our stay in Amsterdam.

Best non art museum. A must. Story is told with excellent exhibits and commentary. Can be emotional to see how people were treated by other humans. History repeats today. What a shame. Some good lessons to be learned here.

Excellently constructed and moving museum not to be missed. This museum is well worth a visit as it is very well put together in a manner which is realistic and accurate. It gives real life and meaning to the events it describes, and focuses on the lives of ordinary people in Amsterdam and the Netherlands which were horribly and irreversibly affected by the events of World War II.

Food for Thought. Factually comprehensive museum for all ages. Fascinating and informative but you need plenty of time to do this museum justice, it covers a lot. We spent 2-2.5 hours but could have spent longer, perhaps a second visit would be needed to take it all in. Visually stunning in its presentation of the facts, leaving you with food for thought.

An interesting museum and a must for War History enthusiasts. This was an interesting and well laid out museum. There was a lot of great and fascinating information that I didn't have prior knowledge of and it gave you some sort of feel as to what life may have been like in that time.

The best time. This is a must do! We spent over 3.5 hrs here with a very happy and engaged 12 yr old. Learnt so much and left wanting to learn more. Brilliant and no queue ( which is why we didn't do Anne Frank ) .

Worth a Visit.. Located opposite the Zoo. Friendly staff & helpful. Interest display of Dutch Resistance during WW2. It's gives you an understanding of the hardship in their day to day lives whether to resist or collaborate the occupation. A good exhibit of the Dachau work camp with research done by students in this exhibition. Recommend a visit. Friendly staff also gave us advise on our visit to Amsterdam, he was very helpful & nice to have talk to. Thanks.

The best 10 euros I spent. I visited this museum with a friend in the spring of 2014. I absolutely loved it. I spent over 2.5 hours in the museum and did not even get through every exhibit. Highly informative, taught me a lot about World War II and what it was like for Jews living in Amsterdam. At times, I felt like I was there. Great combination of audio and written texts. Definitely worth the 10ish euros I spent here. Definitely more reasonably priced than the museum right next to the I AMSTDERDAM sign.

Good review of World War II history. The Resistance Museum is set up chronologically so you can follow the history of the German invasion of the Netherlands. Entrance fee includes an audio guide. Each section of the museum contains both audio, visual and readings further explaining how the Dutch survived through the war. An initial film gives a general overview. Exhibition in both English and Dutch. The museum is across the street from the zoo, which is walkable from central Amsterdam.

Misleading title but an interesting display of artifacts. The resistance museum is an interesting collection of tales and artifacts from the period of German occupation during WW2. It doesn’t offer much however, by way of information on the Dutch resistance, so the museum name is a bit misleading. I realise that they cannot fabricate things which did not happen, but if you think that you will see tales of espionage & ways in which the Dutch operated an underground resistance movement through the war, then you will be disappointed. It certainly offers interesting anecdotes and details personal experiences from that time, displayed very well and worth seeing from a historic perspective, so if you are a history buff you will love it. If, on the other hand you are a spy buff, then unfortunately there’s not really anything for you to see here.

Interesting. Fair price to get in and free audio if you like. The place is well set out and there are English signs on every display and you can push audio buttons and then the display speaks in English.Its a very good incite and sad in parts about how the Jews were persecuted through the second world war in Amsterdam.Its of the beaten track opposite the zoo so can easily be missed.Found the staff helpful and polite and the place had good aircon.if you are into history of second world war and Amsterdam this place is for you.

worthwhile but at times confusing. I would like to give the museum 5 stars for presentation, but I feel that I have to take away 1 star for a confusing format. The audio headset should have been given with more explicit instructions. While I am far from a techie, I have been to many museums and I have never been as bewildered by a listening device. Fortunately, a kind Dutch customer helped to show me how to swipe the headset to produce the narrative. The chronological order of events seemed to weave in and around with no clear pattern to me. I will grant that this may be due to the design of the building.Ok--the positives: the initial film is wonderful, breaking down a terrible era to very human terms. The historical information was not "dumbed-down"--it was assumed that the audience had a basic understanding of the period, as a result, I learned many interesting things, such as, that 25,000 Dutch volunteers served with Germany on the Russian front. I admire the honesty of the woman who admitted she lacked courage and who could criticize when one considers the danger. I considered this museum a wonderful testament of honesty to a time that many people would like to forget.

Worth the visit. My hubby and I visited with our 17 year old son - his idea! We walked from the train station and, with the help of phone GPS found the museum quite easily. (Too far to walk if it had been raining, though)I found the receptionist a bit brusque both to us and to a group that we passed on exit. The price of €10 each surprised us but we had walked for so longer were not turning back at this point.The museum was interesting - most of the wall notes were in English as well as Dutch and we had a translated interactive device which gave extra information all the way around.Some parts didn't interest me - the Indonesian army and the 'modern day resistance' propaganda - but on the whole informative few hours.
Dissapointing. I took a bold decision to see this instead of the anne frank museum. Wish id don the massive ques for the anne frank museum. Bonus is its across the road from the botanical gardens.

Brilliant museum worth visiting. We arrived at opening time and didn't leave until four hours later, exhausted but full of thoughts and musing. This is a place that will stay with me for many years. I loved that there are many details about different aspects of life under the Nazi regime during WWII - not just the Jewish view, or the resistance fighters view, but also included the views of people who tried to remain neutral or who joined the NSB (the Dutch Nazi party); with honesty they spoke and shared opinions and thoughts. The "Junior" exhibit will appeal to all ages but is designed for children 9 and older and is very interesting, very hands-on and extremely well-done! Worth visiting no matter what age you are. It's a small space but there is much packed in, lots of artifacts and antiques. Buy the book about the "Junior" exhibit and consider donating it to your child's school or the public library near where you live; fantastic resource!

A very good under-visited museum. We only went here because we couldn't get in to the Anne Frank House. It turned out to be a great experience. We learned a lot about the Dutch resistance and there were many interactive elements that would keep children
Young people's section is fab. This was the teenage daughters' favourite. A fascinating and inspirational approach using mixed media. A definite must see.

A must visit. . I always try and visit these museums wherever I go in Europe to reflect on what people suffered through World War 2. The fact that 78% of Dutch Jews were murdered at that time is a horrific figure. This particular museum was great, very informative and touching. It is only ten euros and takes a full morning or afternoon. Very interesting, thank you.

Enjoyed this out of the way museum. We visited this museum and were pleasantly surprised at the complexity of the exhibits. They were very well presented and easy to read and understand. We were meeting some friends and were unable to spent more time.

History at its best. Is one of the best museums I have visited.Very interactive, makes you understand the struggle and issues of Netherlands in the Second World War.Is very touching.You need at least two or more hours to see it.

Engaging. This museum focuses primarily on the German occupation of Amsterdam during WWII and challenges guests to consider the difficult decisions that residents of that city had to make: adapt, collaborate or resist. Very thought-provoking and well worth a visit.

Worth a visit. Thought we could be done in a couple of hours, but found out it took longer to see. This multimedia presentation was excellent, but also sad. The free audioguide did repeat some of what was listed under each exhibit, but was a must. The other nice thing were the free lockers for your belongings. You first had to put in 2 euros, but then when you return the key, you get your 2 euros back from the locker.
A look at life during WWII. Lots to look at and take in, and also a very good Junior section which is fun and informative for adults too

A great Museum. This museum was very impressive, telling the story of the people who lived through the war, each in their own way. War, and how individuals survive such times, is very complicated and personal, and the museum does a good job of explaining the complexities of decision making in such times. The exhibits are well organized, with many explanations, audios and videos. As a person born in Amsterdam during the war but moved at young age to Canada - the exhibits were so interesting and matched the stories told to me by my family.

Comprehensive World War ll overview of the Dutch people and their valiant efforts. It cost about 10 euros for museum admission. You are then given an audio tour that is activated by scanning on the different prompts by the displays. So you are able to go at your own pace. There are many stories of the dutch who valiantly resisted the Nazis during World War ll. It was very informative and good information about Holland during the war.

Absolutely fascinating. Not to be missed!. This is one of the museums you can access free-of-charge with the 'I amsterdam city card'. (Buy one, as you get many benefits, including free public transport.)It is located opposite the zoo and a tram will take you very close.This is a really impressive facility. Its displays explain how Holland was invaded and occupied by the Nazis. It is remarkably honest about the response of the citizens of the Netherlands and the displays address the very complex issues related to how those citizens responded. It describes, for example, how one young Dutch boy was 'encouraged' to associate himself with Nazi groups because his father determined that it would be better to go along with the occupying forces.This is just one of very many personal real-life scenarios that are recounted with very frank honesty. It gives one an appreciation of the terribly complex and difficult decisions that Dutch people had to make. It also graphically recounts how any resistance was met with violence and barbarity. I learned a great deal. I hadn't, for instance, realized that an equivalent of a Dutch Nazi Party emerged and there is a very striking photograph of its leader visiting a German concentration camp in the company of Himmler. The information, appropriately, is very Dutch-centred, so that statistics relating to prisoners sent to concentration and extermination camps may seem odd, since they strike you as relatively small, but they reflect the Dutch citizens and not the much larger Jewish individuals from throughout Europe. That said, several displays detail the atrocities experienced by Jews of Dutch nationality.An area also recounts the terrible experience of those in Dutch-Indonesia who suffered under the Japanese occupation.One comes away with the impression that the 'Dutch Resistance' was not perhaps as well-organized or active as the French equivalent but that may not be fair. That said, it is clear that substantial and determined resistance did take place and it was met with brutality on the part of the occupying forces.The information is presented via photographs, videos, copies of letters and newspapers, historical artefacts, etc, with lots of explanatory signage. Multi-lingual audio 'guides' are available, which are activated as one comes to different displays. It was the best such system I have ever experienced.The displays are very detailed and there are lots of them. It will take you at least 2 hours, if not more, to work through everything. There are very few seating areas, so prepare to be on your feet for most of the time.The frank manner in which the occupation is tackled is commendable; I doubt whether many countries would be willing to openly tackle the range of relevant sensitive issues in such a manner. It gave me an appreciation of issues that one simply cannot comprehend, unless you have gone through the experience. It was a real eye-opener and highly thought-provoking.Even though this may not be one of the better-known museums in the city, it can get very busy and quite crowded. That can, sometimes, make viewing individual displays awkward. But it is worth tolerating any slight frustration. I think this deserves to be on a not-to-be-missed list of tourist venues in Amsterdam.There is a limited 'souvenir shop' area but no café. However, there is an excellent bar/café/restaurant on the street next door.This is one of the most moving, impressive and fascinating museums I have ever visited. I thoroughly recommend it.

Cheap and very interesting!. With being only 10 euro to get in, this is worth every penny. It begins with a video of the period set during the war, and what will be expected within the museum. The museum is filled with very touching stories about courageous individuals whom a lot, who have studied the Nazi era but not in Holland itself, may have never heard about, This is very fascinating for anybody. The audio system is also a very good feature where you can listen to the description of every section on a personal device. I would recommend this museum to anyone looking for something different, and to step back from the business of Amsterdam center itself.
Well worth a visit. Loads to see and very interactive displays. Very interesting visit - strangely a few locals didn't know where we had been when we mentioned out visit

we were particularly moved by the stories of courageous individuals like 'The redhaired girl'. Very disturbing but extremely well set out and interesting with amazing artifacts from the time.We would have visited the Ann Frank house but there is apparanttly always a three hour queue.This museum was a 10 minute tram trip away and we just walked in.It is well worth a visit and there is a junior section too which is more suitable for children.

Fascinating and thought-provoking. This museum is a little off the beaten path but easily reached by tram. It's across the street from the Amsterdam Zoo. It asks the question: what would you have done if you were Dutch at the time of the German occupation? Do you resist, adapt, or collaborate? There were costs to any of those options chosen. The museum does a great job of personalizing the events but also sharing the incredible scale of the suffering of the Dutch people and especially the Dutch Jews. There is also a very nice cafe next door that's a good place for lunch and coffee while pondering what you saw.
good but not great. The museum was very thorough and we co6ld listen along in English and written information was in English. I didn't like it quite as much as I thought I would but it was good.

Missing Some Key Pieces. As a WW2 enthusiast, I understood the effort that Germany made early in the war to try to convince the Dutch to join their cause, and when they didn't, forcibly shipped them (Jews and able bodied men) to work for the German war effort. But, as an American tourist, I did not see any credit given to the US and Canada in breaking the starvation blockade "Hongerwinter" that ended with a "Berlin air-lift" type of food drop. This was a significant climax to the German blockage of Holland. Why no mention! 22,000 dutch citizens starved to death because of this blockade.

Nice museum but not really about the Resistance.. Quiet museum located near the zoo. We saw this museum after taking a walking tour on Amsterdam in WWII so much of the info is was redundant. However, it really is not about the resistance. There was little resistance in the war. It is a museum about living under the occupation and the deportation of the jews.

Emotional, sobering view how good people survive terrible times.. There's no frills here, but the exhibits and displays knock you over with understated, sometimes gut-wrenching emotion and drama. The perspective is broader than you might expect, not one of a particular population or group. You leave with a more measured view of difficult decisions made in turbulent times, a greater undrstanding of the Dutch character, and full insight into how good people survive terrible times. Highly recommended.

Worth the visit, beat the crowds. The content is top notch. The museum looks slightly tired -- a few dings and notches out of the drywall -- but overall this does not take away from the content. A few of the display windows are small, and the signage inside a bit difficult to read at times. Good English translates. Audio tour comes with the admission, and is worth using it.

Cohesive and Brillaintly Laid Out. This museum is a gem among European museums. It gives a nuanced background into Dutch culture before the war which is integral to understanding the Dutch experience during occupation in WWII. Rather than dodge blame or obfuscate the issue, the designers lay out the entire issue from 4 pillars of society and how they "adapted, collaborated or resisted" Nazi policy. It was easy to navigate, beautifully and solemnly displayed, thoroughly capturing collective and individual experiences. The partitioning of displays also allow for privacy which is a testament to the designers. This allows personal reflection and emotion with out public display. The museum did not moralize but instead instructed and illuminated which allows for contemplation of how you may of reacted to occupation.

Squeezing a lot into a small museum. A little off the beaten path for most tourists in Amsterdam is this museum that focuses on the Dutch Resistance movement during the German Occupation in WWII. Audiotour will help explain how the Dutch value of obedience plus the pre-war division resulted in how the Resistance movement formed after the invasion of Rotterdam and subsequent capitulation. Not a great deal from a artifacts standpoint and not very interactive as it is a low technology, old school museum, but nonetheless good information and a must stop for any WWII historian visiting Amsterdam.If you're not into WWII history, probably a lower priority in this town where there is so much to do and see.

Too Simplistic and Barely Notices Jewish Dutch Lives. The reason to come here is to learn about the lives of Dutch people in WWII. Unfortunately, this museum gives a very simplistic and unsatisfying portrayal of this experience. Trying to make those that either collaborated with the Nazis or did nothing feel less guilty the museum forgets to properly celebrate those heroes who resisted. The best part is the book store where I got the book "Henk's War" which is worth reading to understand about the resistance. I've read a ton of books about WWII in Holland. There were many active non Jewish and Jewish resistance fighters and there are many excellent stories that need to be told about them. The section about the Jews during the war is teeny tiny and there is a larger exhibit of the war in the East Indies. Shocking really.

Great underappreciated museum. This museum was fascinating, and asked over and over again the question everyone who thinks about World War II or other incidents of grave danger should ask themselves: what would I do? Would I collaborate and try to succeed in the new environment? Would I lie low and simply hope to survive? Or would I be brave and resist? This museum made it clear that that was a very hard decision to make in 1940, even though we now know that the German invasion of the Netherlands was a dreadful event, not just for the Dutch, but for all of Europe.

Interesting Dutch WW2 history. The Museum has an introductory film and excellent presentation. The museum cover more than the Resistance. The impact of the Nazi invasion is described in detail. It also presents the invasion in the Dutch East Indies and the experiences of the population during the occupation and afterwards. Be sure to take the free audio guides. The person at the cashier told us not to take the audio guide because of the English signage.

A must do!. We was told about this museum by another tourist so thought we would go along as it was raining! We was very glad we did visit - what a great and informative museum! Just goes to show there were so many in hiding and so many willing to help others!! Definitely this to anyone including families! The cafe next door was also a great find for lunch!

A great place to visit to help us understand what the Dutch went through in the war. Lots to read and exhibits to illustrate. Mostly always translated into English.There is a Junior exhibition on at the moment.

Learnt new things - viewed new thing so worth a visit. I know quite a bit of history surrounding the outbreak of WW2 and the occupation of European countries by Germany. However this museum was really specialised in the sense that the information was so unique to Amsterdam and Holland that it made the visit really interesting. Lots of things to look at and good audio information to explain and describe the exhibition. A popular attraction but you don't feel crowded. About €10- which is a fair price and audio guide is included. Really enjoyed the visit.

Poor Effort. This really isn't a very good museum at all. There is no narrative explaining the organisation of the Dutch resistance (perhaps because it was actually so small and weak). The introduction film seems to be aimed primarily at the 5-8 year old range (we are told for example "the Germans were against the Jews").The exhibits are simplistic, confused, randomly presented, and provide very little in terms of concrete information. Dutch collaboration (a huge and interesting subject) is dealt with by a couple of recruiting posters for the SS tucked away on one pillar. Information is at least given in English as well as Dutch. The organisation by the staff is poor, the museum is small and gets very crowded, and the entrance price is very steep for what is on offer (€10) They recommend you spend 3 hours to visit. As someone extremely interested in this period of history, I'd say more like 15 minutes is justified.

Time Travellers. We thought that we would try something a little different, as none of us are really interested in art. In the process, we stumbled across this little gem.For anyone with an interest in WW2, especially if you cannot get to Anne Frank's house, then this museum is a must. It is written in both Dutch and English, with very advanced (and free) audio guides which accompany you throughout the exhibits. Also, I was pleasantly surprised to discover the two additional exhibits on other Dutch Resistance and Amnesty International, they were extra little bonuses.The Junior section is also highly recommended, regardless of your age. We had to wait for a silver haired couple to get out of a house for ages to take a proper look. Plus if you swing by, the title of my review will become much more poignant. All in all, with its close proximity to the Zoo and tram lines, a great museum. The best we've been to, surpassing Anne Frank. Although give the Cafe a miss, especially skip the steak!

A Serious but Necessary Museum. Very thorough review of life in the Netherlands before and during the war. Very thought provoking. The Museum explores different stories of the Dutch citizens who collaborated with the Nazis, did nothing, and actively resisted. Balanced and insightful - makes you wonder what you would have done. Heart wrenching at times. Bring Kleenex! We spent more than 2 hours here.
fascinating museum. very well done. excellent museum.very well organized and presented.incredible artifacts. great history of the war in Netherlands.

Thought provoking, not your average walk through a museum. I'm not one to visit a museum more than once after I've seen it all the way through. I have made an exception for this museum and would visit it a 3rd and 4th time if given the opportunity.Of course it gives a good perspective on WWII through the eyes of the Dutch but even more so it gives a good perspective on the Dutch people themselves. Viewing the exhibits and walking with other museum goers felt like one of the least touristy things I've done on my many visits to Amsterdam. I highly recommend a visit to get a better idea of where the Dutch come from and what they are all about.

Very interesting museum. You could spend hours. Lots of interesting details and great curators. The topic is not exactly cheerful, but this museum makes it very interesting by focusing on the life of normal citizens and how there we affected by the Nazi occupation. Some stories are very moving. By the way - the bistro right outside is very good.

Losing the forest for the trees. This is a cluttered museum that ultimately fails its mandate: documenting and explaining Dutch Resistance. What exactly was the Dutch Resistance? Was it just an assemblage of random acts of foot dragging? Was there any overarching organization? Were there any demonstrable successes or failures? The viewer is mired in detail, but there is no core narrative, perhaps because ultimately, there was no real resistance from the Dutch. Surviving an occupation is not the same as resisting it. Tedious and confusing museum.
Very Interesting. Excellent museum right opposite the zoo. The information given is very interesting. A great place to spend a good few hours.

DUTCH POPULATION DEFEATING NAZIS OCCUPATION. it s just amazing to see how the Dutch resisted the nazi occupation , keeping their sense of humor even in the most extreme desesperate situation , helps to understand the very nature of the Dutch people , a great and free nation.

Proud of my Dutch heritage!. Born in Holland just before the WWII, this visit answered a lot of questions about how the Dutch managed to survive the occupation. The exhibits and plentiful pictures provide an insight to how they lived through the 1940 - 1945 period. Allow at least an hour to absorb the fascinating history of the Dutch resistance.

An excellent museum, well worth a visit. The exhibits are extremely well-curated. There is a nice balance between the greater story of WWII in the Netherlands and in Europe more broadly, and the stories of individual Dutch citizens. Multiple perspectives are represented - even though it is the resistance museum, the choices and constraints on those who did not resist and those who accommodated are shared as well. There is also a childrens' section of the museum which is really nicely done. Highly recommend!

Fascinating record of Dutch resistance. Fascinating insight into the resistance during world war 2 with interesting exhibits detailing the changing level of resistance of the Dutch peoples from occupation until liberation. There is an introductory film which gives an overview before you begin the route through the museum. A free audio guide is included in the entrance fee and is worth taking. There is a great deal of material to read but even if you choose only to view some parts of the exhibition it is well worth a visit. There is a small bookshop and a café / restaurant.

Outstanding treatment of a lesser-known story. Copenhagen boasts a very similar museum to the Amsterdam Versetzmuseum so having been fascinated a few years ago by the minutiae of German occupation of a people that were considered near equals rather than sub-humans by the occupiers, we had high hopes for our visit. We weren't disappointed.The 2.5 hours we spent flew by and did not include the temporary exhibition on Dachau. The quantity and quality of the exhibits themselves were outstanding and, in many cases, highly moving such as the improvised prison xmas tree or the poem written in blood. Others were highly entertaining like the satirical cartoons at the expense of the Germans or the soldiers helmet enameled to serve as a chamber pot. Not everything was labeled in English which was both a pity and a relief as it would have taken a full day to absorb everything on display. The audio guide added nothing to the excellent English captioning but did offer an alternative way of navigating the exhibition. I was pleased that the persecution of the jews didn't dominate the story and was portrayed as just one, albeit sickening and pivotal, feature of the occupation. If I have any misgivings about the Verzetzmuseum then it would be to say that the rhetorical question "Adapt, collaborate or resist?" which takes centre stage on the website and introductory film was rarely addressed in the exhibition itself. As a result, despite the oppression of the occupation being brought to life and provoking personal thoughts of how one might respond, because so few unflattering stories were told about Dutch people, it could be argued that the impression was of Amsterdammers being reinvented as a city of heroes in the soviet revisionist style of history. Nonetheless, as someone whose ancestor was shipped off to Auchwitz from Amsterdam, having first left some of his genes in England, this was a truly thought-provoking and unmissable experience.

Wow!! A must see whilst your here. You will leave in awe.. My husband and I found this be one of the best museums we have been to, it was interactive enough without to be on your audio set all the way round. The stories from the perspective of the Dutch resistance were powerful and mesmerising. Most museums and concentration camps we have visited focused on the horror of the events, this too captured the horror but the hope in some of the individuals was truly amazing. These people were so brave and some children's stories of what they did to assist the resistance left you in awe.This museum is also so easy to find, take the no.9 tram get off at Artis, turn left and it is righ across from the Zoo. You can also pay 2€ which you get back for a locker to put all your belongings in, this was fantastic as you could concentrate solely on the exhibit.

Not just resistance. This museum was not quite what I expected. I expected it to tell lots of stories and specific examples of just how the Dutch resisted the German occupation. The museum was more about the war in general I thought.

An Amsterdam must. For those interested in WWII history, this is of particular interest. The hand held listening devices compliment what you are seeing. The displays are awesome and evocative of what happened to the people of this small country invaded by the Germans. It is also interesting to see the story of an entire people, unlike the Anne Frank experience.

A visit here may change you. This is an intriguing museum that explores the Dutch resistance to Hitler's occupation of the Netherlands. It asks you to think about how you might of responded given the situation. I had never considered many of the questions this museum brings and up and I am the better for the experience.

A lot of interesting information!. I'm a local and even though I learned in school about WW2, I learned a lot of new information and facts from this museum. They take you on a tour from when the war started and through the progress of the war until liberation at the end. There are a lot of images, clips, interactive things and infographics as well as original artifacts and for example radio broadcastings from the day the Germans invaded the Netherlands. This makes it feel like you were there from the beginning to the end. In the end me and my partner were even discussing if we would join the resistance if we were in that situation. How a museum should be!

Fantastic museum. This is an amazing place. History is presented and we are allowed to enter the climate of pre WWII Amsterdam...and travel the course of the war with a dutch perspective. Really well done.

Brilliant and informative. This was a really informative and well laid out museum, it gave some great insight into how the Dutch dealt with the Nazis taking over their country especially in and around Amsterdam. You get a free audio guide which is a must as there are English translations up but for things like old newspapers, letters etc there isn't so the guide is essential. We took our 16 year old who thoroughly enjoyed it too. If you have younger children there is a whole section just for them. Well worth the 10 euro entry price. It's not massive inside but if you want to see and read everything allow a good couple of hours.

Interesting subject, well presented. The museum told the story of the Dutch Resistance in chonological order. It used personal stories and experiences to make the stories come alive. Well worth a visit, particulary if you find WWII interesting.

Very informative...wonderful. Loved the museum. Headsets with the audio tour are very helpful. It was a little confusing as to where to proceed next...felt a little jumbled but the information and exhibits were well done and informative.

You Must Go!. This museum needs you there! Take at least two hours out of your schedule to visit. There is so much I learned about the Dutch resistance during WWII. The museum is put together really well, and is quite a monument to those that helped out. It is very eye opening to see all that the people went through. You should certainly visit!

Excellent museum. I'm not that interested in the resistance in world war 2, but I found this museum fascinating! Free with an I Amsterdam city card, this museum talks about the resistance the Dutch gave during their occupation. The youngsters section for children 9 and up explains different points of view of the war from the perspective of a child of the time. Worth visiting for adults too. It's a long tour, but the museum offers folding seats at the entrance so you can sit and listen to the free audio tour in English. Very highly recommended!

Don't miss it!. With the theme of our visit relating to Anne Frank after attending the Play - "Anne" and the Anne Frank museum, we decided to visit the Resistance Museum. We were not disappointed. The museum was laid out in an interesting manner with many interesting displays and provided multi-lingual assistance. The theme presented made all think about what it must have been like to live under the German occupation. We discussed it for days afterwards. Very thought provoking. Don't miss it!!

Underrated museum- so interesting!. A very large and interesting museum, right opposite the zoo! Full of easy to read information, I learnt so much about the Dutch and World War Two. This museum had no queue whatsoever, unlike the other museums in the centre which seemed to all have over a two hour wait! This museum is underrated, probably because it is slightly outside of the centre. I thought it was even better than the Ann Frank house for representing Jewish life during the war.

Excellent museum!. One of the best museums I've been to! Well laid out and many interesting and interactive features. Learnt so much about the Dutch resistance and efforts and sufferings during the war.

Complexity well presented. This museum is the antithesis of hype and self congratulation for their resistance , but rather follows through on the three themes of "accommodation","cooperation" and " collusion". At every step the complexities of having been an occupied country, with Rotterdam having been leveled, is palpable. Individual stories are woven into the larger social and political realities and I was left with an understanding of what kinds of decisions needed to be made, in the context of war.
Moving. A maze that leads you through the hard times and suffering of the Dutch under the Germans, not to be missed.

They try but just not quite there yet. I really wanted to go to this museum hoping for an experience rich in the history of the dutch resistance movement. Although the museum imparts some information about those who helped Jews in The Neverlands the museum falls short in that the presentation of materials is dated and not that interesting to listen to. I was hoping for more in depth info about those who helped and I would have liked to hear more about their specific stories. The museum could use some updating of presentation of materials. I kind of felt like I was stuck in a museum from the decade of the 70's.

more informative than the Anne Frank House. Less hyped than the Anne Frank House this gem near the zoo gives a condensed and informative look at not only the occupation and resistance but life before and after the war with display cases and a free audio tour, worth every penny. Tips* the short film upstairs at the start is excellent, could be overlooked, don't* children need to be old enough to show respect* no eating and drinking inside, bags can be left at free lockers* allow at least 2 hours it closed promptly at 5

Smell the tulips, remember Hollond, and Cry for the Jews!. The museum was an excellent choice, but Anne frank's House was the best place to see. It is also a heart breakerfor those of us who love Jewish history.
WOW, this place is amazing. So much information presented in a captivating manner. They have a kids exhibit which is PHENOMENAL. A must see.

Loved it!. In Amsterdam doing Holocaust research and this was my FAVORITE place we visited. It displays the reliance of the Dutch people and really brings to light the hope that people had even during dark times. Loved the displays and information!

Great find. On the museum pass, with free audio tour, this is a worthwhile exhibit to demonstrate the nazi takeover and propaganda attempted to wins the minds of the Dutch. Spy ware is also on display. Very educational about the effects of WWII on the Netherlands and it's citizens.

Great place to learn about Jews in Amsterdam during the war. Very informative...quiet and not a lot of people when I went. I got to take my time look at all the displays and really get a sense of what life was like for Jewish living in Amsterdam. I spent almost 2 hours there and felt it was worth every minute. My most favorite place I visited in Amsterdam. Highly recommend to all.

Thought provoking experience. You can spend a decent amount of time at this museum, as there is much to read and look at. If you're interested in the rise of the Nazi regime in Holland from 1940 to 1945 - this is for you. The museum looks at all forms of resistance particularly during this period but also looks at other forms of political resistance going on today. If you think this sounds a little bit dry, well it's not an all singing all dancing Museum, but I think most people would find it an interesting experience for a few hours. The museum tells an interesting, thought-provoking and horrifying story of what the people of Holland had to go through in this time. If you went to the Anne Frank house and enjoyed it I would definitely recommend this museum. The staff are great, after about an hour in the museum I went out for lunch and then when I showed my ticket came back again and spent a couple more hours in the afternoon. Also If you're there towards the end of the day, there is a fantastic chicken restaurant on the same side of the road opposite the zoo serving rotisserie chicken from about 4 PM!! If you get off the tram (line 9) by the zoo the museum is really close by (30 seconds walk away on other side of road)

Very informative, picture of some Dutch life during the war. Was it fun? No, how could such a thing be fun.But it was good to see many sides of life during the war. The 'power in numbers' was evident as it seemed that much of the Dutch resistance came in the form of strikes. While individuals helped others across the country (and some chose not to help), there were many strikes aimed at weakening the ability of the occupiers to continue their efforts. For such a small population, it also seemed that there were many many parties/factions among the Dutch, with their own meetings, newspapers, and the like. Quite interesting.
Well Worth a Visit. Extremely interesting and at times quite moving, reading the different individual's stories makes it very personal. There's an awful lot to take in but it's well worth a visit.

don't miss it. often overlooked, but just by several excellent cafes and restaurants eg plantage; very moving, personal museum, really enjoyed it. I had no idea that so many children were sent out to the farm areas, nor about all the groups that formed under the invasion forces, nor that so many were sent to camps who were not Jews. A marvellous exhibition

Informative, interesting but not easy reading the stories of real people.. Almost opposite the zoo, this museum is easy to find and not far from the botanical gardens too. It is not the easiest place to visit because it deals with some of the horrors of the German occupation. However, it is very informative and interesting although it is easy to get disoriented following the exhibitions.

Has some Good Points, but Not the Best WWII museum. My boyfriend and I are WWII history buffs and on a rainy day in Amsterdam it seemed like a no brainer choice for a museum since the Van Gough needs to be booked in advance. While this museum has some interesting points, I believe the Anne Frank house is a much more "real" and vivid experience of what it was like to live in Holland during WWII. First off, the museum isn't in the most centrally located. I'm all for exploring and getting off the beaten path as we did a day trip the afternoon before, but after a twenty minute walk there it is pretty clear the museum is on its own in a residential neighborhood for attractions besides the zoo. The museum has a few interesting artifacts such as a radio made out of a match box, a resistance newspaper printing press, but that is it for the most part in terms of artifacts. The idea of the museum answers the question of whether the Dutch people consolidate, adjust of resist to the Nazi occupation. While there were a few stories of resistance and examples of fighters turned into concentration camps, the fact is the country hadn't updated their army since 1900 and were easily won over without fight. While there are examples such as Anne Frank (not in the museum) and a few other citizens who had interesting stories - the Netherlands did not have a influential role in the war which made the museum lack in interest.

Thoughtful Display of Lesser-Known Dutch History. This museum inspires, delights, and breaks hearts. Through thoughtful displays, videos, and objects, the museum tells the heroic story of the Dutch resistance and the tragic story of the murder of the Dutch Jews. (Make no mistake: this is heavy subject matter. But it left me wanting to talk about what I'd learned: it didn't leave me depressed.) Amsterdam has many interesting museums, but this one leaves you with a unique appreciation for courage of the Dutch people.

I found this an informative and moving account of the Dutch experience of the war.. There is a lot of reading so probably not great for small kids, but gave an overview of Dutch society at the outbreak of war and how Nazi occupation affected people and what they did to survive. Many very moving personal accounts and acts of incredible bravery during a war which casts a long shadow on our present.

Unexpected treasure. Very informative and interesting presentation. Really got into the nitty-gritty of life during the Nazi occupation. I found it totally engrossing and definitely worth the time. I wish I could have spent more time there.

Bring your reading glasses.. This is a reading-intensive museum. There are lots of information panels about the history of of Dutch resistance against the Nazis, and about the artifacts on display. Unfortunately, the artifacts are poorly displayed in cases inside walls; these cases tend to have narrow windows that allow about one person to look at the artifacts. Many of the artifacts are paper products, so the lighting is quite low, which makes it harder to read the information panels. There were a lot of personal accounts of living during that time, although not much information about actual acts of sabotage. If you can persevere, you will learn something.

Loved this museum. This is a great museum for adults and children alike. The exhibits are interactive and presented in a way that really keeps your attention. It was really interesting to hear/see about the resistance movement and all the people who tried to put a stop to the horrendous murdering going on, despite the associated risks. Very well worth a visit.

All should go here. We walked away from here quite emotional and knowing so much about what happened in the Netherlands during WW2. We gained a deep understanding of the dilemmas faced by the citizens at various stages of occupation. Thought provoking. The courage and ingenuity displayed by the resistance is to be respected. Didn't know anything about the role of Queen Wilhelmina before our visit. What a woman! And the brave dairy farmers, refusers to register...wow! The interactive displays and varied presentation of sound, artefacts, etched was outstanding. I recommend this place above anything we saw in Amsterdam.

Make time to see this museum. A colleague recommended that we visit this museum while in Amsterdam and I am glad we did. It is a mixture of high and low tech presentations and gives a comprehensive overview of how the resistance movement grew over time. It provides an interesting perspective and insight into why some citizens just accepted the German occupation, others collaborated and others resisted. There are many original newspapers, etc., and the audio guide was great.

Great insight. I visited this place today and it was a great place! It gave me an insight of what it was like to live in Holland at that point in time! Worth a visit also if you have an Amsterdam card it's free!!! Happy days

An enjoyable history lesson. We learnt so much about this dreadful period in the Netherlands history at this museum.The interactive and static displays combined with the audio guides provided us with an interesting and educative few hours. There were optons to personalise one's tour with the extra selections available on the audio players and the various recordings and films ihroughout the exhibitions.I can recommend this site to those foreigners who, like me, have only a scant knowledge of this country's involvement in the Second World War.

Brilliant!. A good alternative to Anne Frank's House which we couldn't get into. Vast queues and no e-booking slots left. Fascinating accounts of those who resisted and moving stories of how Jewish families were hidden in ordinary people's homes. The bravery was incredible. At the end there is a fantastic exhibition about The Dutch Colonies, so a different take on Occupation. It takes into account the Tenko stories. Really worth a visit.
A little disappointing. Not a lot to view and did not explain what the resistance were involved in, unless I missed something. Disappointed as I thought this would really interest me.

Great museum. My first stop on my visit to Amsterdam and well worth the time and money. The museum is a fair distance from the city center and probably not as crowded due to its location. I arrived just after they opened at 10 AM and there were only a few other people. An audio guide is included with your ticket and it is very well done. The museum walks through the impact WWII had on the city and its people, both Jewish and non-Jewish. There is a lot to see and you could easily spend several hours. I highly recommend if you are interested in WWII history. Admission is covered by the Iamsterdam City Card!

Insightful with a good flow. After having been somewhat disappointed with the German History Museum in Berlin (very disjointed), we were a bit skeptical of visiting The Resistance Museum, but the rain made our decision easier and we were rewarded with a very well done museum exhibiting life in Amsterdam before, during and after WWII and their Nazi occupation. Entrance fee is reasonable (10 euro pp adult) and comes with an audio guide. Flow is sensible and laid out well. The exhibit was not overly crowded the day we visited (even with the rain) and so it was easy to see what you wanted. I would say it takes more or less 2 hours to go through in total.

Off the beaten track, but well worth a trip. this is a great museum if you want to avoid the crowds associated with the more famous museums in Amsterdam. It is great value at ten euro and you could easily spend two hours enjoying the exhibits without feeling rushed or crowded by others. The free audio guide works very well as it has extra information to the boards and it is very easy to follow. It details the German invasion of the Netherlands and the concentration camps as well as stories of how people helped the Jews to hide during the war.I would recommend this museum to any one visiting Amsterdam.

Excellent Museum Tie-in to Anne Frank House. Very well-done museum chronicling the Dutch experience during World War II. Encompasses much more than the Resistance movement, including life under occupation.

Great experience watch out for school tours. The museum is fascinating to see how Dutch people handled the German occupation differently. A unique experience in contrast to many other WWII and Holocaust experiences. Two tips - First, watch out for school groups. One arrived in the junior area at the same time as us, the museum has a policy where they have priority over other visitors. Because of that we were asked to leave exhibits on multiple occasions which was frustrating for the kids and hard to enjoy this part of the museum. Secondly, the junior museum only is in Dutch, they have audioguides for the kids. If the adults want to participate make sure to get them one too.

This is the best museum of its type. This is the best museum of its type and we highly recommend going there. It is right off a tram line and easy to get to. Well layed out and very informative. We got the (free) audio sets which were very easy to use and added alot to the experience.
Glad I went. The history covered here is important for self reflection and the audio guide is good. I plan to return.
