Great . Really enjoyed this museum. Wonderful and informative exhibits about the role of the Dutch during WW2.

What would YOU do?. This museum really makes you wonder what you would do if your city was taken over by a foreign force. It gives thought-provoking insights into the everyday lives of everyday people. I arrived at 3pm and couldn't believe 2 hours passed so quickly - I could easily have stayed another half hour. The free audio guide is fantastic, giving you extra information to what is on the displays.

Important corner of Amsterdam . Excellent depiction of life before during and after the second world war and the decisions people were forced to make. The young resistance exhibition was particularly good. Use of English audio guides were very important. Staff very friendly.

Don't miss this very good Museum. This is a great museum. We had no idea of how the war affected the Dutch population or their Jewish citizens. It will open your eyes to many things about this time in history. Very hands on. Well worth your time.

Informative. Pretty good experience. Everything is written in Dutch with ~90% also translated into English. For free you can get a translator lanyard to carry around that will speak to you at most spots in the museum. Spent almost 2 hours here.

Lots of stories from a sad period. There is lots of good information and human interest stories in this museum. We took the English audioguides, although they seemed to duplicate some of the information that was on the display labels (Dutch and English). My main criticism is that the museum is one big open space with room dividers. Some of the displays have sound, and so there is always a small level of noise. On the day we were there, a school group was going through. With the voice of their tour guide and the conversations of the students, the sounds in the museum became kind of intrusive, Otherwise, a very moving and informative space.
Brilliant story telling. Small place near the zoo and very well done and laid out. Tells the story of the country's occupation in a wonderful way that takes you to the times from many perspectives.

Unbiased, well thought-out museum. If you have an interest in World War II and/ or Dutch history and modern culture then it is definitely worth a visit. The audio tour is particularly good as it is short and to the point. And let's you select only topics of interest to you.
Great place to learn about the 2nd WW. Really interesting to learn about the Dutch résistance. I would recommend this to anyone who is interested in history.

Go to the junior bit even if you aren't with kids . This place is small, welcoming and without queues, which for a start is a bonus in Amsterdam. While the main bit of the museum is interesting with a couple of small exhibitions I confess we spent most of the time - around 2 hours - in the children's section, on the recommendation of a friend. Made to look like you've travelled back in time, you visit the houses of 4 children who led very different lives in the war. Lots of interactive bits, things to open, things to sit in or climb through, stories fed through audio guides in a number of languages etc. Based on 4 real life stories, all survived the war. It's educational and fun without trivialising the horror that so many went through. My 9 year old said it was the best thing she'd ever been to and she learned more about families in hiding there than she did following the trudge of hundreds through Anne Frank's House. Staff were friendly and helpful.

GOOD EXHIBITS WITH NO DIRECTION. What a shame that this excellent museum is spoilt by the museum not having the walking directional arrows painted on the floor. There are so many rooms that feed off in many directions that it is easy to go into a room several times. I even found it hard to find the exit.But don't let this put you off from visiting as there are many good exibits and video display aides.

Worth a visit. This is a bit off the beaten path for Americans, but worth the effort. The museum does a good job explaining the growing resistance, and finally a formal resistance movement, of the Dutch toward the Nazis. The floor plan is confusing but the info is good. I walked out shaking my head about what people can do to each other, but also admiring those who stand up to brutality.

New insights, sensitively and impartialy given. The displays and interactive approach makes the history accessible in an interesting way that at the same time challenges you to consider the quandary faced personally by each citizen at the time. If you reflect during your visit you will find that you might begin to challenge some of your personal positions on current issues
Very average museum. I thought it was going to comemmerate the courage of the Dutch resistance fighters, but it told the story of the people's resistance towards the German oppresion.
Discover Resistance. An interesting perspective of the Netherlands' part during WWII. Better understanding of how the country participated in resisting the Nazis. Well worth a visit.

great walk through and well set up. fantastic example of how a museum should be set up and work. it has an easy to follow flow and a free audio tour. (granted this didn't work all the time) but in that case it does not hurt to read. Just remember 2 euros for the lockers for your bags. The staff are also very friendly get there and have a look :)

Interesting Pictures. Very detailed information on the various resistance efforts in the Netherlands. Lots of great pictures. Not such a good place for kids, since there is a lot of reading to really understand what was going on.

Great insight into the war for the general population. Very interesting and well worth the visit. A different perspective of the war. Particularly interesting was the impact of Indonesia's fight for independence on the Dutch citizens living there.

Well worth the visit. Great museum, possibly the most interesting of all the Amsterdam museums.Not a huge place, but enough material inside to keep you for a 2-3 hours minimum time needed.Very friendly staff although I tried to stay longer than I should of.Sadly ran out of time and had to leave before spending the night in the museum.
A Revealing Look at the Resistance.. This small scale museum showed the various ways the Dutch resisted and it offers a look at the ability to function in spite of fear.
Young people should go there!. Very, very interesting. The museum left me impressed and greatful for the courage of all the resistance people.

A moving experience. This is a wonderful museum which brings to life the dark days of the occupation of Holland. I was born towards the end of the war in Holland, and grew up with many stories about the occupation and resistance. This museum provided the images to accompany the narrative I grew up with. The children's part of the museum is particularly moving, and extremely well done. We visited the museum on the day commemorating the liberation of Holland - double thrill.

Interested in cukture and history??. Culture, history and so much more. Make sure not to miss this when you visit the Netherlands. Enough public transport available to reach the museum. Many small cafes on the way so you won't go hungry. A must see.
One of the highlights.. This was an amazing museum I could have spent all day in, fascinating stories and insight into living under German occupation.

A Wonderful Story. The stories of those who resisted in any way, shape or form to the Nazi party are worth telling over and over again. This museum has done a fantastic job in preserving the past! The audio guide was amazing and the staff were all so friendly and helpful.

Best kept secret. For starters don't go there thinking that you will see some type of resistance army like the French. What you will get is a really good story about the treatment of the Jews in Amsterdam after the 2/3 day war. You should also go visit the Hollandsche Schouwburg (Joods Cultureel Kwartier) museum.

Memorable!. We were moved by visiting this museum. We learned a lot about the struggles which the Dutch people faced in the 1930s and 40s and which continue to challenge people around the world. The pictures, texts, movies and displays all point to important choices and consequences which we all face. We hope to return!
Never give up. Another must see in Amsterdam - the story of five long years of German occupation of Holland - We must never those who paid the ultimate sacrifice

A very good alternative to the Anne Frank House. This is a well organized museum which describes the politics of The Netherlands during the second world war. The audio tour is adequate and is included in the entry fee. There was no lineup to enter. although the is little reference to the Frank family the essence of what happened to the Jewish people in Holland is well documented. The queue for the Anne Frank House is at least 3 hours Holland Pass does Not work as front of the line at that venue.
Very good small museum. Although a little difficult to find, this small museum is really worth a visit. An audio guide is included in the price.
Nice if you have an extra hour. Not time consuming but very worth it! Short and to the point. We got there with only 30 minutes until close and got thru - could have used 15-20 more minutes

Good Experience. A good museum, however I feel it should have been called Holland 1940-45 as this is what it was. There was good information however there was not much about the Dutch Underground in 40-45.I enjoyed my visit

Hidden gem. This museum is fantastic. We visited upon opening and the and there was no crowd or line to wait in. The staff is very helpful and friendly. There is a self guided audio tour that I highly recommend. I gained a much better understanding of the daily life and struggles of Nazi occupied Amsterdam. We took our time and spent a few hours here. We had visited the Anne Frank House the day before and while that was moving this was much more informative and interesting. I highly recommend visiting The Resistance Museum.

a fabulous experience. for learning about the Dutch resistance and also the whole history of the WW!! experience for the day to day existence during the war years here. first rate - I would put it on the "don't miss this" list for AMS.

Fascinating and Thought Provoking. This wonderful museum takes the visitor into the lives of the average Dutch citizen when the Nazis occupied the Netherlands. It asks, "What would you do? Just try to continue your ordinary life? Cooperate or collaborate? Resist and fight back?" We spent three hours here and only left because the museum was closing. There is also a special children's section which we did not visit.

My favourite museum in Amsterdam. I'm so glad we made the trip to this museum (easily accessible by tram if you don't fancy the walk). It involves the visitor in the choices facing ordinary Dutch people during the Nazi occupation: to co-operate, collaborate or resist? This is illustrated via the stories of individuals, the choices they made and the reasons why. I found it fascinating and extremely informative, and would recommend it over the Anne Frank house, say (not least due to lack of queues!)

interesting and informative. We chose to take the audio tour -no extra cost as this gave a more I depth view in to the exhibits. Whilst we were there, there was an additional exhibit on the concentration camps very informative and moving but this is only there for a limited time. There is a cafe next door and on production of your ticket you can get a free coffee re fill. Tip if you have a back pack for example you will need to put this In a locker before going round a 2 euro coin is needed but is refunded upon your return.

Excellent presentation but not what I expected. I anticipated a museum dedicated more to the Dutch Resistance of WWII but this museum, located in the Jewish district, is appropriately more about the Jewish population during the war. Some exhibits, looking through small windows, did not work well for groups. On the other hand, the collection of artefacts and the interpretation were very good. The new pavilion recently opened by King Willem-Alexander was excellent, the projection system is quite amazing. Also, the audio podcast touch system was very good. An excellent value at 10 Euro.

Outstanding and humbling.. One of the best museums I have ever visited. My 12 year old daughter and I spent six hours here and had to be thrown out at closing time! The Junior Museum is incredible for adults as well as children and the main museum is so full of incredible details, facts, personal stories, artefacts, letters ( written in blood!). It was so accessible, well designed and very, very moving. We were fascinated by the choices Dutch families had to make. I loved the political and economical background that was given. My daughter was fascinated by the story of the girl who a member of the Stormtroopers....Dutch equivalent of The Hitler Youth Movement, especially hearing her talk as an elderly woman today.. It was absolutely outstanding and we ran out of time to see everything. Give yourself a day here if you really want to do this museum justice. Excellent! Really great value and audio guides are free!

Adapt, Collaborate, or Resist?. We spent an entire day at the Dutch Resistance Museum. No crowds, no lines, and an excellent set of presentations. Throughout the exhibit, the question you are asked is, Adapt, collaborate, or resist?" It tells an evenhanded story of that challenge which the Dutch faced.
a little history gem in a backstreet. brilliant very informative. Shows what choices the Dutch people had. A really amazing cafe which you need when you have finished looking around.

The brave Dutch. This is a fabulous museum which is well organised, wonderful displays and uses authentic artifacts and many forms of media from this period of time to tell the stories of Dutch resistance; Print, radio, movies, photographs.The layout is comprehensive, starting with life in Holland before WW2, with the invasion of the Nazis and the changing political landscapes of Holland. It covers the work of the resistance and there is a big focus on the children, how they were transported out of Amsterdam and fostered by other families in Holland. The museum is so very interesting, information is given in English and Dutch, after two hours we had reached saturation point, and we had not visited all that is to offer. I highly recommend a visit to this museum to connect to the human element of war. We used our Museumjaarkaarts to enter this museum.
If you like history, it's a must. It is a small museum, which may take just 1 hour to visit (or more if you like to go deeper) but it is pretty well organized and you may learn a lot of things

So Glad We Didn't Miss This. Fantastic museum displaying a good deal of information of Dutch resistance during a despicable time. The courage of the people...The museum is so well organized making it easy to explore and learn. Definitely an underrated museum. I agree with other reviewers that if you are American you really don't understand what it is like to have monsters come into your country and take over. This museum does a great job in giving us the "feel" of what things were like during that awful time.

World War II as You've Never Seen It. The Resistance Museum was one of the highlights of our trip and a perfect pairing with our visit to the Anne Frank House. It is very organized and well laid out with a very thorough audio guide. The museum is a bit misnamed (at least in English) as it follows the choices that every person had to make during the war, not just to resist but also whether or not to collaborate or even remain neutral (adapt) during that time. I thought it explored each option compassionately and with honest explanations of the consequences without villainizing any one person's choices. There are many artifacts, newsreels, videos, and recordings of people explaining their situations and choices from the time. The museum more or less follows the occupation period chronologically and ends with liberation. I would suggest it for children over the age of 12 due to some of the content. There are no stairs or impediments for those with mobility issues (one of the few in Amsterdam), and coin return lockers are available just inside the entrance. Included in the Museumkaart. We spent two hours and explored at a slower/leisurely pace.
Very interesting more than I expected worth going to. Informative, interesting presentation worth the time and effort, helped to understand the Dutch better

You Understand. If you're American, it's hard to really, really understand what it's like to have your country overrun and controlled by some nasties. And the Nazis were the worst of the nasties. But... if you give this museum enough time and emotion, you'll get what it was like and appreciate what the Dutch resistance did in WW II.We actually stayed where the protests started and saw pictures of our plaza during the 40's.When you walk out of here, you'll be asking yourself what would you have done... accepted, collaborated or resisted. IF you don't then you weren't paying attention and shouldn't have come here in the first place.

A recognition of bravery. This is one of the most uplifting museums visited. It was a reminder of how dreadful persecution is, but also a testament to the bravery of the Dutch. It was interesting to read about the many different ways they showed their displeasure about the Nazi's behaviour, not all of them violent. I thought I'd be very depressed as a result of visiting the museum, but it actually had the opposite effect - giving you hope and faith in human decency.

An Interesting little museum. This interesting little museum opposite the city's zoo, is well worth a visit. This museum tells the story of Holland during the second world war; why Holland was drawn into the war even though they had declared themselves a neutral county and how the war affected the Dutch people. I discovered things that I didn't know before. There are a couple of downsides to this museum. There is a lack of places to sit and rest as you make your way through the museum, to reflect on the information displayed. And sometimes it is difficult to see the contact in the displays to activate the automatic self-guided tour. However, I would recommend this attraction.

Interresting historie and good. Loved this museum. It gives a good picture of the motivations of people during WW2. Lots of interesting information told is a easy/ understandable way. Gives a good idea of what life was like and which choices people were facing (without judgement).The children's section is the best! as if you go back in time, you can literally enter reconstructed houses. Stories are told in a realistic way.

Adapt, collaborate or resist?. Well worth a visit to learn about life in Holland during the war. Right from the start the question is posed of adapt, collaborate or resist and it illuminates on the decisions made and the difficulties the people had.There are some great displays, information in Dutch and English. Well worth getting the audio, no extra fee for that. Admission 10 euros, well worth it.The section on Dachau was very moving.There were no queue's, we just bought tickets at the door. Located across from the zoo, many cafe's nearby.

Well Worth a Visit. Enjoyed this museum about the resistance. It is worth watching the little video they have on the upper floor before going through the exhibits, although it is based on the assumption you know nothing about the Nazi invasion. (The video area isn't that well marked.) The video talks about one of the themes of the museum. When you are occupied do you collaborate, accept it, or resist? The museum follows what happened in Holland from the 1930's, to the invasion by Germany, and the years that followed. You can either read the information (almost all of it is available in English) or there is also an audio guide. There are pictures, some videos, artifacts, etc. It is quite well done. At some points it got a little confusing as to where you were expected to go next to follow the story chronologically. That would be about the only problem I had with it. We were there about an hour and a half. You could certainly spend longer, but by that time we had been on our feet all day and there was really no where to sit and rest for a moment or two. If you are interested in the war, definitely something to go see.

Not on most guidebook trails. A very unpretentious museum with a wealth of information regarding the German occupation of the Netherlands. Takes about 2 hours to go round, but well worth the time if you are interested in twentieth century history.

Fantastic. Went to the museum on Saturday 16th May 2015. A fabulous way to spend a few hours. Very informative with great displays. Very easy to follow electronic translator devices that were free. A nice wee cafe next door. Make sure you purchase the €0.50 pocket booklet of WW2 places to see in the city that leads back to Anne Frank Huis. My wife & I used the 39 places to see as a bit of a pub crawl as well & took several hours & a great way to see the city.
great small museum across from the zoo. Go to this one. No lines. Learn about WHY people acted the way they did in occupied Netherlands in WW II

Thought provoking well worth the visit. Forget the long que's at the main museums and Ann Franks house and visit this gem. It gives a balanced view of the situation during WW2 and people's response to it. It really made you think about what your response would have been. Very interesting with the added bonus of none of the long que's at the other museums.

a quick visit. Although I thought I knew about the Dutch during the 2nd world war, this visit brought home to me, just how brave and selfless most of the Dutch were.Very caring and protective towards others less fortunate than themselves, in a very scary and trying time during the occupation during the 2nd World War

Our Response Colored By Previous Knowledge. Although the Resistance Museum does have an extensive exhibit space, the information is quite basic. If we were not already knowledgeable about this topic and the times, we would have appreciated this more. Thus, for those who seek basic information, do go and learn. For those with more experience in this topic, the experience will be of limited value.

Very interesting!!!. This is a must do in Amsterdam! Be sure to take your time to experience all the exhibits. There is also a children's portion of the museum and I sure wish we had arrived earlier in the day to view it, too! Take tram 9 or 14 if your hotel is a distance away! Its so worth it.

Fascinating Museum. Fairly small but well done museum about the Dutch Resistance, starting with when The Netherlands were first invaded. The Germans originally thought the Dutch would be welcoming because of their the common root of their language, but the Dutch found many ingenious ways to resist and thwart the Germans.

Excellent!. The audio tour is a must. The posters, news clippings, and artifacts tell the chronology and story of The Netherlands during WWII. As with any (temporarily) conquered country there are collaborators and there are resisters. This museum explains everything very thoroughly. If you have any interest in WWII or why your freedom should be appreciated today then I highly recommend this museum. It is just across the street from the entrance to the Amsterdam Zoo.
Excellent!!!. Excellent history of the Netherlands and WWII. Still amazed that this happened here as well and people were like sheep. A ditto of what happened in Germany. People were so stupid.
The Resistance Museum. A very moving museum. Take your time to walk through the exhibits. Worth the time. Watch the individual videos. Spend a couple of hours here. You will be glad you did.
Excellent Exhibits - Extensive Data/Details. One could spend half a day here, if you read and fully examined all the exhibits. Very well designed/layed out. Must visit for any history fans.

A powerful museum. This is a terrific museum that chronicles the Nazi invasion and Dutch resistance. Stories of survivors and resistors are chronicled in an interactive and engaging fashion.. Unlike some museums, this one is not as difficult - in terms of pictures, etc. so it's a good place to bring the kids. plan to spend 2 or 3 hours here.

Extremely interesting and very well done. I really enjoyed the displays at the museum and the audio guide was very good. Plenty of attention was paid to different aspects during the Resistance. Wonderful and well worth the price of €10
Good for Families and near the Zoo. Leave enough time to see everything, we had to rush through at the end as spent longer than we expected.

Absolutely an Amazing experience!. Went to this museum hoping to become informed about how Dutch people lived thru the war. This museum more than met my expectations and moved my heart. So remarkably resilient were these people during the war! Particularly touching were their efforts to hide, protect, and shelter Jewish people and children. Tragically, so much of their efforts failed. We Americans have no concept of what it is like to live thru occupation, thank the dear Lord.

Balanced and informative. My 15 year old son and I visited this museum and loved the way real stories were presented. It showed how people in their daily life tried to help those in need. We thought it was so interesting and spent an easy 2 hours there. Upstairs is a small exhibition of how resistance was managed in other countries. Cheap, informative and interesting and some beautiful stories.

Poignant. At a time when we are near VE day a visit to this museum really puts things into persepective. A thorough catalogue of the daily struggle and trials of the inhabitants of the Netherlands. Really outstanding of a moment of history which is hard to imagine in this day and age.

Engaging presentation.. The museum poses the question: how should one have interacted with the Nazis: accommodate, collaborate or actively resist. The museum presented pros and cons for each choice. The museum has great visual, video and audio presentations in Dutch and English. The museum presents general themes, but also tells the story of individual people and how they coped with Nazi rule. It is entertaining and instructive. There is an adjoining cafe. A two hour visit would be good. We started listening to the free audio guide, but found that it duplicated the wall signage a lot. Admittedly, we did not listen to the added extras on the audio guide. Because I do not read Dutch, I was unable to decipher some of the historic posters and historic artifacts. But there is a lot of very good material in English at this museum.

worth a visit. Interesting museum with lots of newspaper cuttings, photos and film clips. Particularly liked the profiles on individuals involved and their roles. Reasonable english translation but would have been better with audio guide - they had run out when we there!Allow about 1.5 hours for your visit

Fabulous if your a history buff. Not to be missed, near the zoo this museum took us 2.5 hours to peruse. We learned so much about the brave Dutch people and their country during WW2 that is not really in the history books. The children's exhibition makes it easier for children and adults to understand what went on during WW2.My only criticism would be that it was laid out in a fashion not easily to follow. It might be a good idea to have arrows painted in the floor or each exhibit numbered to make it easier for visitors.On the whole a great experience and highly recommend for a visit.

Hard look back into history. Small museum, well organized, worthy of a several hours long visit to explore how life changed for Holland during the nightmare of Nazi influence.and the steps the Dutch took to resist their oppressors, especially in support of their Jewish citizens which made up a quarter of their population.

Brilliant . We arrived early as it was the first thing that we'd wanted to do... Unfortunately we were so early that it wasn't open for another hour so we headed down the road for a coffee. On our return we still had 20 minutes to wait however the kind staff invited us in and we began the tour with our complimentary audio guides. We found the museum to be very informative and insightful into the occupation of Amsterdam during the Second World War, full of accounts from every aspect with good visual effects to aid our education. We enjoyed that with the audio guides you could gain more information on certain subjects by holding it against various posts on the walls (needless to say we used pretty much every one). It was a thoroughly enjoyable experience and my highlight of our visit to Amsterdam. I would advise anyone to visit and experience the fantastic museum which can easily keep you intrigued for at least two hours.

What a brilliant lesson in hidden history. This museum is excellent value. It is definitely a no rush place - and certainly you can loose yourself within the stories it tells. Designed to get you to ask 'what would you do?' - it takes the story of a town, and individuals within it, to show what life was like living under the Nazi occupation. It leads you through how the occupation began and developed, and gives insights in to why some people resisted and others didn't. But without judgement.....always asking what would you do? The stories of individuals lead us to recognise that sometimes the smallest acts of defiance were also resistance, and mattered too! The museum also offers a welcome to children, with a special exhibition and stories of their peers, making it relevant. Excellent and well worth the visit.
Interesting but unknown story. Did not know a lot about this movement in Amsterdam. Told the story well in the exhibits. Really got to see what went on in the city during Second World War atrocities

Wonderful underrated museum. Would have liked to have stayed longer. I learned a lot about the Dutch resistance (and cooperation) in The Netherlands during WWII. There was also a small exhibit on the Dutch East Indies during and after WWII and what happened to both the Dutch living there as well as the East Indians (now Indonesians) and the Dutch resistance to giving up the colony.Highly recommend this museum. I think this was my favorite of all those I visited. Learned about young Dutch men hiding to avoid transport to German labor camps toward the end of the war. Jews were not the only people being hidden by the Dutch. Brave people helped many to survive. 17,000 of those who hid survived the war!

Very poignant. A very well presented museum which relies on excellent historic documents and accounts to tell the story of the occupation of the Netherlands during WW2. Includes the persecution of segments of society and how resistance to the occupation increased throughout the war, Some very heart rending histories.

Never realized the extent of the resistance before I visited. Although this museum is quite small, it is so packed with history and information. I had never realized how organized the Dutch resistance was during the war until I visited this museum. I appreciated the way the information was presented in a timeline format.

An important visit. This museum covers an important piece of history. There was a lot of information and at times we saw exhibits in the wrong order because it was a little confusing. But overall, we absorbed a lot of information. Very important to learn about the holocaust and the impact of the war on the people who were living in Holland at the time. You will need about 2 hours there, using the audio tour.

Worth a visit. Our granddaughter (age 14) felt the stories of the children in the juvenile section helped her the most in understanding the dilemma of "what decision is the right one". We also found this interesting especially when tied to the interviews at the end of the exhibit. Hearing their reactions to what transpired and the results of their decisions (or their parent's decisions) was very interesting and highlighted even more the difference in perception of what is "right" and what is "wrong".There are a lot of pictures and a lot of information to digest. It gives you a better understanding of the questions each person has to answer when they are occupied. Do you resist and if so, how? Do you work within the system to try and effect as much good as possible and if you do, is there a line you can't cross? The stories of bravery were powerful. It is always amazing to me to see the difference that one person - one brave person - can make. As our granddaughter said, "You'd like to think that if something like that happened, you would do the right thing - but when it happens, you don't know if you will actually have the courage.

Thorough and Thoughtful. While planning our trip to Amsterdam, I had the Anne Frank house on the list. Then I spotted this on Trip Advisor. We had so much on our list of things to do that we decided to skip the long line at the Anne Frank house and go here. This museum is so thorough and covers every aspect of the societal changes and has an incredible amount of information and artifacts. We spent a lot of time here and we're very glad we went.

Off the beaten track and well worth a detour. This museum gave a great overview of life in Holland during WW2, and I would particularly recommend it to visitors of the Anne Frank House as it gives a broader context to this sad little cameo of Amsterdam under the Nazis. There is an excellent interactive audio guide and lots of information and exhibits / documents from the period. Many personal stories are told, and this adds to the interest. My only criticism would be that it is hard to find one's way around the museum if one wants to study it chronologically.

Nice. Fantastic piece of history that explains the Netherlands paper during WWII ,also gave testimonies of Jews and Dutch victims of the conflict, they have original goodbye letters, weapons ad sabotage tools for the German Resistance a must for all WWII Lovers,

Dutch history during WWII. While we really got a lot of information out of this visit the museum itself doesn't have a great lay-out and many of the exhibits are so small only one person can look at a time. The audio tour was worth it---but often replicated what was written--word for word--in the exhibits, so you can really do one or the other...great history about the rise of fascism in Europe and the plight of the Jewish population. Museum is in historic center of what was the Jewish community of Amsterdam pre-war. Amazing stories of very brave people.
Dutch history. Brilliant. Well worth entry fee. Lots of history which was new to us. Gets busy so get there early. Staff really helpful and you get a free audio to take round with you.

An unusual museum, for when you are keen to go off the beaten track. Lot's of pictures in this Museum which is friendly to non-Dutch visitors. It gives you a good impression of WWII occupation and resistance circumstances with some kute features. Content could be bit richer for my taste. An unusual museum, notably in/near the old Jewish Quarter, that's for sure.
Excellent museum. A very comprehensive picture of what life was like for resistance workers and ordinary people in Amsterdam during the War.

Was a nice museum but just. Most of what was covered I had read before the items that were new to me, was that the Netherlands collectively refused to go along with the Nazis which forced the Nazis into starving the population after sending all males to work on the war effort. Additionally, I wasn't aware of sending the children to farms. However, more effort should have been awarded to those who helped allied air crews escape back to England, sharing what little food starving people had and showing how careful the resistance had to be with a starving populace.

Fascinating museum. Very interactive. We were thrown ou of this museum at closing time after having been there 3 hours. It was so good we are seriously considering a return visit on our one day left in Amsterdam. Lots of good objects telling the story in an inttelligent and iner sting way. It can take some time if you look through all the flip up books and listen to all the options on the audio guide. I couldn't pull my 13 year old daughter away.
Very good. A wonderful museum well laid out and very informative.Lots of things to read and a goid video to watch for an overview.
very informative. the stories of the dutch resistance, the children stories were a great addition, it did get a little repeatative though by the end

Total immersion into life during WWII. This museum takes at least two hours to fully explore. Filled with videos, audio, interactives, first-person accounts, and memorabilia, the museum recreates what life was like here during World War II. I continue to think about their stories and wonder what I would have done if I had lived during this time. It is a very important museum.
Resistance Museum. A real unexpected treasure. Can recommend a visit- really well laid out. You can follow the story of the Dutch people before during and after WWII.

A must see. Give yourself a lot of time....this is an intense and fascinating museum. We thought we would spend about 90 minutes and we spent 4 hours! It is informative and provocative. Bravo to the curators.

One of the better museums I have been too in a long time. Although most of the e chi its were in Dutch, enough were in English to satisfy our thirst for knowledge. The introductory film shouldn't be missed. It raises some thought provoking questions about what would you do in their place.

Very informative. Really educational, museum had a range of exhibits which really portrayed the Dutch experience during the war, which being from the UK I had never given too much thought to before.Good audio guide and temporary exhibition as well.

Important Museum. I especially liked the "Junior" exhibition where we get to see what life was like for different kinds of children during WWII in The Netherlands. We get to know actual real people, not fictional characters made up by someone, but real people who are still alive.

A look back in history. We went to the Resistance Museum after visiting the Anne Frank House. This was my second trip to this museum and I am glad I went again! The museum provides you with a very interesting perspective of the struggles and challenges that people faced leading up to WWII, during the war, and post war. I think that the museum does an excellent job of showing the different avenues that people took when faced with the rising Nazi party--adapt, collaborate, or resist. I would recommend that you set aside 3-4 hours for this museum. It looks small, but there are so many artifacts and so much to read! The zoo is literally right across the street, so you could make a day out of the two attractions.

Interesting view on wartime life in The Netherlands. Well laid out and thought through collection and recollections of life experienced in wartime Holland. Some surprises such as the near starvation environment endured by city and town dwellers. Worth a visit, probably before visiting Anne Frank's house, as this provides a wider viewpoint. No queues which was great.

Peoples struggle. In constrast to many other resistance museums, this focuses on the struggles and challenges of "common" people. They also have an instructive exhibition designed for school children.

Excellent museum, don't miss it!. This was a fantastic museum and well worth the walk from my hotel (it was a nice sunny day)! Two months after my visit and I am still struck by the museum displays and stories of resistance by the Dutch. The price was very reasonable and they have English audio guides. This allowed me to really absorb the history. I only wished they had a greater book selection as I very much wanted to read more about the Resistance. I highly recommend this museum. Even if you are not interested in WWII history, the stories of strength and determination can speak to all.

More a Story of German Occupation. The displays in this museum are all bilingual (Dutch/English) and gives an interesting account of German occupation of the Netherlands in World War 2. Although there is mention of Dutch Resistance, I expected more on this subject. Nevertheless, I found the museum interesting and informative. There is a useful audio guide. The displays were well ordered and we spent almost 2 hours in the museum.There are toilets and a locker room for baggage and coats (returnable 2 Euros required to operate the key).Well worth a visit.

SO INTERESTING. ... that we spent about 4 hours here (and ran out of time to 'do' the Jewish Museum, which is nearby).Very well laid out, with English captioning . Added greatly to my knowledge of how the Dutch suffered in WW11. (the Hunger Winter, for example). Excellent cafe-had very good onion soup. Free second coffee was a nice touch . Staff were friendly and helpful

Well worth it - especially if you have children.. We followed up a visit to the Anne Frank Museum with a hike across town (you can get a guide from the Anne Frank museum that points out things of interest). Entrance opposite the zoo. I am glad to say, it was well worth the walk. With a 7 and 10 year old, we went straight to the Junior section which follows the lives of 4 children during the war. The attention to detail was excellent - with houses and things to discover for the children. Informative for them and us. The main museum itself is also good - but take a look in the junior section, even if you don't have children!

My favorite museum in amsterdam. This museum is a hidden gem in Amsterdam. It is right next to the zoo and Micropia; to get there you can take the 14 tram or the 22 bus. My family has the Holland Pass, so we got discounted entry to the museum. There is also a complimentary audio guide which is really helpful as there is a lot of information in Dutch. The museum is divided into decades and by region. There is a whole section devoted to the Dutch East Indies and the resistance there; I didn't know about this previously, it was fascinating to learn about. There is a section too on the rise of the Nazis and how they took over and how Dutch people resisted. There are tons of personal accounts and artifacts everywhere. The audio guides provide a lot of background information and insight, which I really liked. There is also a junior museum, which was amazing. It follows four children of different backgrounds through their personal stories and their lives throughout the war. The whole museum is very interactive, especially the junior museum. My only wish is that I had more time to spend in the museum; I was there for almost three hours and still didn't finish it! I plan on going back when I next come to Amsterdam to finish it. That's how great it is!

A bit boring if you are not interested on nazi occupation in Netherlands. The whole exhibition is mainly in dutch which I don't really understand. The collection of exhibits is quite big dating from 1930s-1940s. They provide free audio guide with different language options. If you are not interested in WW2 or don't understand dutch, I recommend you skip this museum.

don't miss this. Small but excellently designed museum. Don't skip these for the big ones. It tells the war story from a different point of view and generates such interest and that I went back to read up and learn more at home.The audio aids are a useful adjunct to the exhibits. It is about a 5-8 min walk from the tram station and across the road from the zoo.

A Rich Experience. Relatively small but well curated and structured - good idea to see the 10 minute introductory video upstairs first (ignoring it's rather silly "down with the kids" style). Makes good use of text, sound, video but not so much that it's overwhelming. And poses a clear question to visitors - what would you have done? Audio tour just about worth it, but items are well labelled.

Enlightening and Important. We Americans haven't had to live under occupation since we first declared ourselves a nation. Museums like this are very helpful in giving us the perspective we lack. Here the German invasion and occupation; the poltical exclusion, deportation and murder of Dutch Jews; and various individual and organized acts of resistance (and their consequences) are presented in very personal ways: through individual stories, using objects and archival material. And there is the ever-present question, asked at the exhibit's entrance: What would you do? Adapt? Accommodate? Resist? Hope things will improve? Look at the context, so ably presented here (in Engish and Dutch), and answer honestly.

A reminder of the evil that lurks. An impressive display of pictures, article,s letters and artifacts not only from WWII in Amsterdam but also including a section on the Indonesian situation. I did find though that at times it was difficult to find the right chronological order to follow for the displays and in some cases it was not possible to read the notes relating to a displayed item.

Packed full of information. It was great to hear the story of the war from a different angle for once. Loved seeing and reading the story of the Netherlands in the war. Admission fee is fair, but it is a little away from some of the other museums, but is close to the Jewish Quarter and we visited here before heading to the Jewish attractions up the road, also very close to Micropia.

A small museum packing in lots of info of life under Nazi occupation. Not the best museum on our trip but worth the effort all the same. The audio guide allows you to move at a varied pace and take in more info as and when. There is a route aimed at children and there was at least one group during our visit so patience may be required. And why not? It's an important lesson for young and old. We missed the 'Intro Film' which, from a quick check at the end, I think would have set everything in even better context. Don't make the same mistake.

A gem!. This museum is slightly further out near the zoo but do make the effort to go! It was brilliant - it really explained what it was like for the ordinary Dutch people during the occupation. Don't miss the children's section it is very interactive and with the headphones we learnt a lot. This is a must !
Very interesting. Brave brave people what the Dutch went through was awful! Makes you really think what happened in World War II they were true to there friends

Well worth a visit. Although this museum it a bit outside the centre of town it is well worth the visit.Your meander through the exhibits which begin in the 1930's and end with liberation in 1945 using an audio guide to explain what you are seeing.I was surprised to learn that 300,000 people were hidden (a la Anne Frank) from the Germans. There are many first hand accounts of the hardship which people suffered just living under the occupying forces.
Really interesting. Really interesting museum, with lots of personal stories from Dutch people in WW2. Definitely recommend.

If you do nothing else.... If you do nothing else...Visit the Versetzmuseum. I had no idea about the Netherlands during the 2nd World war and what you learn here tells you so much about the Dutch and how they deal with adversity. It also tells you so much about Dutch culture and the impact that World war II still has today. Can't say I loved it, but it had an amazing impact on me!

Bravery. This museum brought to life what the Resistance did during the occupation of World War II and just how brave so many were to hide their Jewish friends and find ways to undermine the invaders.

Very Informative. We were given an audio guide in English which was very good, you could press buttons to hear more about something.For us there was probably a little too much information, too much reading, but very interesting. A smaller museum with the main points for a little less admission fee would have suited us better. We spent about 3 hours inside, we could have spent longer, but you get bored of reading a lot.I did read one review that somebody didn't want to pay the extra for lockers, but you pay 2 euros but then get it back afterwards.

Definitely a hidden gem. I visited the museum right after the Anne Frank House and I think the two go hand-in-hand and are both must-sees. The museum tells the back-story of Amsterdam during WWII and explains why and how families such as the Frank's had to go into hiding and what life was like in the City.It is hidden away opposite the Zoo, no lines to get in and you receive a free audio guide tour. It is very interactive with a lot of videos, recordings and artifacts of the time on display.

Hidden gem. Brilliantly presented museum telling the story of the life and times of the people of Amsterdam during WWII. Not surprisingly this was an emotional experience at times.Well worth a visit - and no queues!

Brings perspective. Unless you're in any particular situation it is easy to be judgmental. This thoughtful and insightful museum makes no judgment on those who chose not to actively resist, but nevertheless chooses to include them as part of the whole story of the Dutch under occupation during WW2. There are photos (with Dutch & English text), films and extremely personal accounts of individuals. Entry includes headphones with audio in your language of choice, and the staff are very helpful answering questions. What impressed me was that it wasn't only a story of those who actively resisted, but it put the period (political, economic, religious) into context, making the point that not everything is black and white.
brilliant. a fantastic and educational place to visit. very poigant and gives an insight to the suffering of the dutch during the war, done in an interesting format.

Somewhat of a hidden gem. I had no idea this museum existed until I accidentally found it by walking the streets of Amsterdam. When I first walked in, the attendants were very gracious to not make fun of the very little Dutch I knew and spoke to me in English, which helped a lot. I first took a right and watched the informational video on Holland during World War II, which you have a few options of languages to watch it in. After the video, I walked through the exhibit. It was extremely informational and well put together. Most of the exhibits are interactive and are in Dutch and English. My only regret was I arrived late in the day and only had a limited time to go through. The one exhibit I really wanted to see but couldn't because I ran out of time was the resistance in the Dutch East Indies against the Japanese and follow on revolution, which resulted in modern day Indonesia. I highly recommend this museum to anybody that is in Amsterdam.

An excellent museum and a powerful telling of the story of Dutch resistance and sufferings in World War II. We visited this museum after the Anne Frank and felt the two are complementary. Don't miss the younger peoples' section. The main part of the museum is excellent, but the telling of the stories of 4 children in the children's section was even better and one of the most memorable parts of our visit to Amsterdam. Everyday memorials of extraordinarily daring people.

AMAZING Museum on the WW2 Dutch time Under Nazi Occupation.. If you are into WW2 and that time of history, this is a great museum. It is so well done and very interactive. Great for kids too. Adapt, Resist or Collaborate. Wonderfully done and lots of things to see and learn about. See and hear actual stories from those who adapted out of fear, those who collaborated and those who resisted. Super interesting!!

Worthwhile Visit - So Much Information!. I was very glad that we made the trip to this museum, there was no huge line to get in ( a welcome relief from days of waiting in line at other Amsterdam attractions!) and lockers to put your bags and jackets in. The overall exhibition was much bigger than I thought going in, there was so much information to take in and lots of great things on display. If I could go back I would have got the audio tour in English, while most of the writing is captioned in English it is a lot of reading and there are some places that don't have English subtitles, it's free so would recommend taking it. If going with kids the Junior section is great, lots of interative sections and wonderfully designed. Learnt a lot and was good to get a different prespective on the war!

Very enlightening about Holland during WW11. This museum was full of information and explained very well. Would be a great place to take children as they have a special children's room. It has the homes of 4 very different children and how the war affected them. Also telling us how their life was after the war. Enjoyed the whole experience and would recommend this to my friends.
Worth a visit. Went with my parents (both in their 60's) we all enjoyed this very moving and thought provoking museum. Great photos stories and displays

A little known side of Dutch history. Learn how bravely the Dutch people resisted the Nazi onslaught at home, their protection of and help to their Jewish countrymen and their fight against the Japanese in what is now Indonesia.

Learned even more about the Nazi Invasion and WWII today. This Museum was the last on my museum stops and really should have just seamlessly moved with the Jewish Quarter museums to round out the total story. (after all the Jewish Quarter I was exhausted but should have continued on.--So I highly recommend it) Once again, the interactive nature of the exhibition helped you to be part of the Resistance Movement..even as the other interactive museums have brought you into these parts of the Dutch Historys. This museum helps to outline how the Dutch people were taken by surprise with the German invasion, and then how the resistance developed. These heroes nearly always sacrificed their own lives and desperately tried to save the children. It was incredible. And then, the children themselves formed their own resistance patterns (the Junior Resistance temporary exhibition) and then the children who were sent to the country (because they were starving) I have had a hard time understanding this history, but these museums and this one in particular help to describe the Dutch belief that flooding the land through the dykes would save them from entry, yet they were not ready for air travel and paratrooping in the German troops. Humbling. Well presented. Thank you Amsterdam.

Great with kids. A very informative adn well illustrated exhibition where children (between 10-12 years old) can experience what it would have bee to live in Holland during WW II.he story of 4 children is told who had a totally different experience. One Jewish girl, one son of a resistance man, one daughter of a collaborator and one son of someone who acted like the dutch majority and did neither resist or collaborate.
A fascinating glimpse of life under occupation. A thought provoking and fascinating museum which deals honestly with difficult issues. Well worth a visit.

Alternative content. This is not the usual war museum. As Holland was occupied fairly early in the conflict, this museum concentrates on the dilemma of having to live under an oppressor. The free audio guides do give more information than is contained on the exhibits and works off an RF chip, so you can take a walk through at your own pace. We spent nearly 4 hours there and it was very thought-provoking.

Resistance Museum. It reveals very honestly the dilemmas of an an occupied state which had many links to Germany although not to the Nazis. The exportation of the Jews seems to have been the turning point.
Detailed and interesting. Fascinating accounts of life in nazi-occupied Amsterdam. So much to see and so much detail, you could spend hours here.
Excellent. Very good museum, well worth a visit. Some excellent photos and a very stirring presentation. Good facilities to drop off your bag etc and very helpful staff

Resistance Junior interesting for Juniors and Seniors as well. A decorum of imitation streets and wall-sized color photographs evokes the atmosphere of the war years. Authentic artifacts, photos and documents , film and audio clips tell the story of people in wartime. But there is more.... special for the youth. Youngsters can step in another world and another time. Use the time machine to the Netherlands during the waryears and sympathize with Eva , John, Nelly and Henk . Eva is Jewish , Jan has parents in the resistance, Nelly is in the youth club of the Dutch Nazi party and Henk comes from an ordinary family.In Resistance Junior young people can get acquainted with the poignant period of recent Dutch history. The Resistance Museum tells a story that is important and remains important.
Good to see. A good museum to go to give a very in-depth view of what was going on in Holland before and during the war at 10euros per person I did think it was a bit expensive

Well worth a visit. Being fascinated by WW2 this place along with the Holocaust Memorial along the road from it is worth a visit and 10 euros of anyones money to see how the dutch resistance worked during the war from start to liberation. It is fully interactive with English speaking handsets that you point at a tag on the wall and it explains that section. I would allow around 2 hours though you can do the tour in 90 minutes but if you are fascinated by WW2 then allow yourself that little bit extra time.
Interesting and thought provoking. Well told history of the resistance in amsterdam, interactive and easer to navigate. Useful baggage storage

Informative and well-organized. This small museum is very interactive and informative, and does a good job of demonstrating the difficulties faced by the Dutch population during and after the Nazi occupation. The staff are helpful and friendly and the free audio guide adds to the experience, with additional information like radio broadcasts and first-hand accounts. Some of the display cases are very small and I can imagine that when crowded, the museum can be a bit hard to navigate. Still, there was a good flow to the material and how it was presented. It was provocative and made you think about what your own response would be: resist, adapt, or collaborate?The exhibit about the Hunger Winter, during which many Amsterdam children were shipped to rural farms to avoid famine and starvation, was particularly moving. The exhibit followed the stories of 4-6 children who were sent to the farms, and in photos and stories, shared their experiences during and after this period.Well worth a visit if you're interested in the history of the Netherlands during WW2 - the context the museum provides will enrich your experience in Amsterdam!

An incredible experience. I found the resistance museum a brilliant, informative, interactive and detailed experience. It showed the impact of the war on Holland as well as the lengths gone to by its civilians to undermine the many wrongdoings during that time. I found the temporary exhibition about the hunger winter very interesting as my grandmother was a child in Holland when that occurred. They also accepted the musuemkaart. Would absolutely reccomend.
Interesting place!. We decided to go check this museum out, thinking we'd be there for 2 hours. After about 4, we pride ourselves away. Well done and great audio tour included!

Resistance is costly, not futile. For a small space and reasonable admission fee, this museum offers so much. I was advised it may take 90 minutes to complete the self-guided walking tour, assisted by free-to-use audio guides. And yet, I spent well over two hours there myself. Besides the main exhibit which examines and depicts the various responses to The Netherlands' capitulation to the Nazi invasion, there is a young person's interactive exhibit (limited to 8 people at a time and full when I went, so I continued on), a limited edition exhibit that featured interviews from 8-10 Dutch recalling their experiences during the "hunger time" when all foods were confiscated for export to Nazi Germany and the difficult decisions their parents made to send their children to the countryside in hopes they would find kindly foster families to feed them. Finally, another compelling exhibit of the impact WW2 had on Dutch colonies - particularly modern-day Indonesia. Wonderfully done exhibits with preserved artifacts, films, videoed personal histories. A very worthwhile museum to support in its efforts to keep us mindful of our past. May we never repeat those times!

Great museum. We went to this museum after reading the good feedbacks here on tripadvisor. The staff is very nice. The museum is fully bilingual all labels in Dutch and English, the videos with English subtitles. If you don´t speak English there is also free audioguide on other languages. The museum is quite interactive and you learn a lot about the life in the Netherlands during war time. It was a great experience.

Adapt, collaborate or resist?. This is such a thought provoking museum, using various sources and personal stories to show the impact the Nazis had. We used the audio guides for free, which werent too overloaded with info. It's not the biggest museum, but we stayed there for over 3 hours. We highly recommend a visit.

Thought provoking. Puts the question :
Collaborate , integrate or resist ?
Not as easy as you may think.
Run by real enthusiasts.

very informative, unknown museum in Amsterdam. Learned about this museum from the travel writer Rick Steves. Very well organized and not crowded at all for the most part until later in the day, some school aged kids came in on a field trip. Overall learned a lot, had some great pictures and informative audio commentary which were easy to use. I think it is definitely worth a visit.

Essential history, including for children from about 10 onward. A must see for Amsterdam visitors and residents alike. Everyone should know about Holocaust history, now fading rapidly from memory. This museum does a comprehensive, poignant job of telling the story of the brutality of the Nazis to Dutch Jews and their efforts at resistance. We spent over 5 hours there -- and we're not Jewish. What I learned at the museum makes me appreciate the insistent slogan, "Never forget!

Truly fascinating. A small museum but an outstanding one. All signage is in English as well as Dutch. The main exhibition takes you chronologically through the Nazi occupation of the Netherlands and covers almost every theme possible. The mechanics of government, employment, shortages, education, recreation, the Jewish community, the resistance, the role of the Church, communications, political parties and much more are explored. The many personal stories included throughout the exhibition are a highlight; they bring home how difficult life was for the Dutch people during this time, the different choices they made and the different fates that awaited them. Unfortunately I didn't have time to explore the display on life in Occupied Dutch East Indies, but I would gladly go again to see this and the rest of the collection again.

Brilliant! A must for everyone, adapt, collaborate or resist!. This was one of our highlights. The museum is situated opposite the Amsterdam Zoo. Tram 14 drops you off 3 minutes away. A comprehensive look into life for the Dutch people under Nazi occupation. Learned a lot. All information in English as well as Dutch, very useful! We spent a good hour and a half here. Cafe next door is convenient but we gave up waiting to be served, a bit pricey too. We went a hundred yards down the road and found a fantastic cafe, fresh baked bread, fresh ingredients and great atmosphere. Shop around there are some gems.

Visit!!. This museum really clarified what life was like in Holland / Amsterdam during WWII. There was an amazing amount of information and lots of personal stories that brought tears to my eyes. I can't even come close to imagining what it was like to live in these years...but this museum put a lot into perspective. I would highly recommend this museum, it is well worth a visit!!

A very different war museum . Whilst most museum exhibitions dedicated to World War Two tend to focus on the weapons and fighting this museum is very different. The Netherlands fell quickly to the Nazis and didn't see much fighting so instead this museum focuses on the lives of the people in an occupied country. Do they cooperate or resist? What happens when they do? There's some fascinating exhibits here and I left feeling I'd learned a lot of things about WWII other museums hadn't covered.

Must-see for WWII buffs. We have visited so many resistance museums in Europe, and each has a different story to tell. The Dutch Resistance story is so worth hearing! The audio guide is excellent, as are the exhibits, which present a worldview, but also the experiences of Dutch individuals who did their part to save their country from the Nazis. The museum takes a unique approach, asking the question that every citizen had to answer: Go along with it, Collaborate, or Resist? The answers are touching and surprising. Depending on how interactive you want to be, give the museum a good 1-2 hours. Great little lunch place next door, the Brasserie, which had lovely homemade soups and sandwiches!

Good museum.. Was a good museum, however at 10 Euros I expected it to be a bit bigger, however there was plenty of interesting information and displays to look at. I think me and my boyfriend were only there for 50 minutes and I am a bit of a history geek, however, if you love history I would definetly check it out!

Informative, well organised museum. This museum was laid out very well and was complimented by good free audio guide.I would recommend this alongside the Anne Frank House. The staff in the museum were very polite and helpful. The museum fee was reasonable.
Well laid out. I throughly enjoyed my visit and would recommend it to others- It is situated very close to the Artis(Zoo) and a short tram ride from the centre

A step back in time and an eye opener. For me this was a very good place to visit, my grandfathers fought in WWII but rarely spoke about it. This gave me a true insight into what actually went on, the exhibits were really good, a lot of them gave me a tear in my eye from the pictures of what had gone on.If you are interested in any way regarding the true WWII then I would recommend visiting the museum.The staff were helpful and well informed.

Dutch Resistance Museum. Great museum; well-organized; excellent free audio guide. Especially appreciated how the exhibit was framed - adjust, collaborate, resist - and how the attitudes of the Dutch toward the Nazis evolved and hardened over time.

Well intentioned but slightly disappointing. This museum is a little out of the centre but in a nice part of Amsterdam. We got in for free with our IAmsterdam card.The museum was a little confusing to work your way around with no signage to guide you in the right order. The personal statements from people involved in the war were very interesting and often moving, however some of the exhibits and tableaux were a little thin on actual material and information.I was disappointed there wasn't more about the actual resistance movement itself. There was a lot of description of the build up to the war, which did provide useful context but also overshadowed the rest of the content.I found myself getting a little lost in the layout of the museum and confused as to where I was supposed to go next. There were also rooms off to the side that held more exhibits but it wasn't immediately clear if you could enter or not.I admit that the presence of a large and noisy school group, whilst we were there did not help matters however I was still a little disappointed overall not to hear more of the brave people and actions they took during the war in Holland.

Well worth it. As an American born in the 60's its difficult to understand what it must have been like in Nazi occupied Europe during world war II. This museum takes the visitor on an end to end journey of the dutch experience and for me it was very emotional, educational, and has given me a great deal of insight into what it must have been like at the beginning through the ever increasing German brutality and the resulting resistance movement, the hunger winter, and the eventual arrival of the allies and the process of regaining freedom. Then add to this narrative the story of the Dutch East Indies and the battle against the Japanese and the difficult transition to Independence and you cannot help but to be overwhelmed with the impact of these events. Go see it, you will be glad you did.

Dutch Resistance Museum. After seeing the line at the Anne Frank House, we decided to go to the Resistance Museum instead. I'm sure the Anne Frank House is fascinating, but I think this marvelous museum provides a much more complete view of the events of this horrific time in history. Recordings by actual survivors paint a sad picture of all the Dutch people had to endure and stories of their struggles provide amazing details. There are many artifacts and photographs and quite a few inter-active displays in different languages for visitors to experience and learn. Audio tours are also available. We found it to be a highlight of our wanderings throughout this wonderful city.
Never Forget. Spent 3hours there Emotionally draining but a must to visit for anyone interested in what Holland and Amsterdam went through during occupation years

A surprisingly good museum. I went to this museum on a whim and I found myself pleasantly surprised. It wasn't huge, but I ended up spending quite a few hours inside. I especially liked the stories of the children who were saved by being sent out of the country, as told by the children themselves (though decades later, as adults). If you have extra time and you've already seen the more-mainstream museums, come spend some time at the Resistance Museum.
Thought provoking. This is a thought provoking, even sobering museum which confronts the many contradictions of Holland's World War II experience. It's definitely worth your time and money.

Worth a visit. This is a great place for a visit. It is a bit away from the centre of Amsterdam, about 20 minutes walk from Dam Square. It is opposite the zoo and just passed the botanical gardens, so the area does have plenty to offer visitors. The museum itself was well laid out and the staff were very helpful. Audio tours were free, but not entirely necessary as all the inofrmation was displayed on the walls, but it did point you in the specific direction of notices and pictures. All information was clearly displayed in both Dutch and English. It was very interesting to hear about the war from individual viewpoints, including children. There was a specific area aimed at children, although we did not visit that bit. The entrance fee was 10 euros each and our visit took us about 2 hours, so good value.

An ordinary but meaningful museum.. It's a very Dutch place. It was very story telling. You can see the place through with all the displays. Very thoughtful. It's not grand style and has its own merit.

Small, but informative.... The resistance museum is small enough that you can easily see it in an hour or so, but packed with all kinds of interesting stories and slices of daily life in occupied Holland. Definitely worth a visit.
Interesting place to visit. It's quite a cool museum with lots of things,photos old stuff to look at. Don't ask them where the collaboration museum is...it's not something they like to talk about.

Worth a visit. Like most people in the UK, I barely knew anything about how the Netherlands was affected in the Second World War - the most I knew was that Churchill and Hitler bombed one another - and that's boring; I like to find out about the people.This museum teams the overall facts of the war with individual stories of resistance members and ordinary Dutch citizens whose names would otherwise have faded into history.It was a moving, informative experience and one of the very few museums that explained that the war was not just about Britain and Germany.Definitely worth a visit!

Go there!. I spent here almost three hours and it was worth it. This place really makes you think and ask what would you do. After I left the museum I was almost surprised to see the sun shining and hear the birds singing. This museum touched me so deeply.

Thought-provoking. This museum is well-organized and chronologically details the Resistence Movement through video clips, letters, newspaper articles and eye witness accounts. Throughout, the question is posed ~ "Would you adjust, collaborate or resist? I came away impressed with the efforts of the Dutch people.

An outstanding museum - bring your kids!. This is an outstanding museum, keeping alive the important messages of history. The new "Junior" section is targeted at children and tracks the stories of four children during the war via interactive / multi media story telling to brilliantly engage, entertain and most importantly educate children. Well worth a visit

An important museum. The Jews suffered a lot under the Nazi occupation, but they were not the only ones. And the museum makes you think a lot - to survive, do you go along, do you run and hide, or do you actively and openly resist? This question gets processed over and over in a well planned and compelling exhibit.

Very moving museum. I really found the set-up for the museum thought-provoking. Do watch the video at the beginning which poses the question *What would you do if invaded?" Would you Adapt, Collaborate or Resist? The exhibit information, in Dutch and English, walked you through the WWII timeline. I found it very worthwhile and a wonderful adjunct to a visit to the Anne Frank Huis. I recommend doing this one first for background. It is not as crowded as Anne Frank Huis, thus you have more time to contemplate and absorb the exhibits. A fairly small museum, it felt like just the right size as it is a very emotional journey. I spent between 2.5 and 3 hours here.I walked to the museum from the Centraal Station and although I had a map, I managed to overshoot the entrance. The nice folks down the street at what I believe was the entrance to the zoo pointed me in the right direction.

A bit out of the center and worth it!. We probably would not have gone were it not for the rave reviews of a friend, and I am so glad we did. This museum is not just facts and dates It conveys a real sense of how people interpreted the events preceding and during the war, how they felt, why they did what they did.

Reality check for liberals. What did you do during whatever war you lived through? These folks risked their lives and sometimes paid with their lives. Secret messages, hiding messages, the role of propaganda, the importance of radios - so much information to absorb! Counterfeit ration cards were needed so that hidden Jews could be fed. Coffee and other substitutes were made. This is a must see and a companion to the Anne Frank House. Please go.

Great Window into Dutch Experience. Really well organized, lots of excellent narratives and first hand experience of the Dutch citizens under Nazi occupation. Unique details od daily life for Dutch people and a window into how this has shaped current civilization.A little hard to find, near the zoo. Museum pass works here.

Very interesting. Me and my daughter spent more than 3 hours in this museum, very well laid out and very clear signs in both English and Dutch. We had the audio guide but didn't use it after the first few times. I found it very interesting to read about the war from the Dutch point of view. There was a special exhibit on evacuation of children - and also liked the Indonesian exhibit.We got free entry with our Museumkaart (60 euros for 1 year but worth it if you are visiting a few Amsterdam Museums).

A hidden gem. The resistance museum tells the story of how The Netherlands coped during WW2. The Museum is brilliantly put together and packed with information in both Dutch and English. There is also an Audio guide available in several other languages. The Museum is small but because of the amount of information in it it takes at least 2 hours to fully enjoy the visit. Tickets are €10 Or part of the Holland pass. Well worth a visit.

Best Museum. This is a must for all to see as it depicts exactly what occurred during those terrible years when Nazi Germany occupied Holland.Its not fiction it's the truth where family members just disappeared off the face of the earth and what those who managed to hide achieved to disrupt the occupation by these evil persons.Unbelievable the displays and records that are shown.

Interesting museum. My husband and I spent at least 2 hours in this museum. It was a very moving experience. Entrance fee per adult is 10 Euro and you get a free audio guide. Highly recommend this museum.

Excellent museum for all. The museum is only 10 Euros for an adult, good value compared to others. It is essentially the story of the Netherlands during the second world war. Written information is in both Dutch and English. There was also an audio guide which greatly enhanced the visit. The museum is complemented by audio and visual exhibits and makes you think about the difficulty the dutch people faced during the war. The question 'Adapt, collaborate or resist?' is asked throughout. There is a 'junior' part of the museum - this shows the war from the point of view of different children where their families are in different circumstances - e.g. a jewish family, a resisting family, a dutch nazi family etc. Whilst primarily aimed at children (and was being used by school groups when we arrived), the museum staff told us it was very popular with adults and well worth looking at. (We do not have children ourselves). They were right. It is at the back of the main museum, and well worth the detour from the main route for 45 mins. If you have kids, take them to this part first!

Interesting museum, well worth it.. I really enjoyed this museum, the displays and descriptions were excellent. I also thought it was good value compared to the generally expensive museums in Amsterdam.

Worthwhile museum to visit. I found the Resistance Museum to be very interesting. There was a free audio guide available, however I did not use it. The exhibits were all in both Dutch and English, so I was able to easily make my way through the museum without the guide. Having known little about the Dutch resistance during World War II before going to the museum, I learned a lot. It is definitely a museum for someone interested in history. I did find the museum a bit difficult to find, however. We were staying near the Rijksmuseum, and it was about a 30 minute walk.

Excellent. It took us ages to actually find the museum but we were certainly glad we did find it.It is great value for money at €10 admission and we spent a most enjoyable two and a half hours.There is a great little section called the junior exhibition aimed at younger children and was beautifully done.This museum is highly recommended.

Don't miss this. This is an excellent museum. The staff are friendly and very helpful and the audio guides are free. However, I found that I didn't need the guide as the exhibits are clearly labelled in English as well as Dutch. I wish I could have spent more time here and will definitely visit again.
