The exhibition shows the clear dilemma for the Dutch residents after their country was invaded. Adjust, Collaborate or Resist?
Outstanding and very informative. Very informative and if anything, understated the horrors of the war. Lots of documents and pictures to demonstrate what it was like.

Should be on everyone's list. Thanks to previous Tripadvisor reviews we went to the Junior section with our eleven year old first. The adults for just as much out of this section of the museum as our child. It helped that she had studied Anne Frank a lot and WW2 a little and that we had been to the Anne Frank museum. It also very clearly demonstrated why children and adults joined the Dutch Nazi party. I have yet to come across a better children's museum. Interactive, informative and thought provoking. The questions asked throughout the museum and in the evaluation enable a lot of discussion. The importance of this museum was summed up by my daughter in her evaluation ... It should have a travelling exhibition to Sydney, Australia and beyond.I also think the Anne Frank museum and the resistance museum should encourage visits to each other - the two complement and enhance each other.

Worth a visit. Very interesting museum - goes well with visit to Ann Frank's house. Visit the children's section as it is very well thought out and held the kids interest for well over an hour. Easy to get to on a tram from the station but only about 40 minute walk from there too.

A Powerful Reminder Of A difficult Past. If you are interested in WW2 Europe then the Verzetsmuseum is a must see. It is a very well laid-out series of exhibits, linking events and reminding visitors that there was a solid core of resistance in Holland durig the war. There is a very well put together section on the horrendous treatment of the Jewish population there, but also some uplifting segments on efforts to help them under what were the most difficult of situations.After just over two hours there, I was left with an admiration for the Dutch people in how they coped with occupation and congratulate the curators on a high quality representation of a defining time in European history.

Very good but one issue. This was a very interesting museum in an old building near the Amstel part of Amsterdam. There are many displays and photographs. It is a fascinating account of people who created resistence in many different forms. It gave explanations for people who didn't resist and people who collaborated. I believe it was this museum where you were able to follow the lives of several people who survived the war. The disappointing thing at the end for me as a Canadian was that the museum gives credit to countries who helped liberate Holland. I know Canada made a significant contribution but we were not really recognized amongst the other countries. The Museum decided to use the Canadian flag at the time of WWII which was the Red Ensign but it can only be identified as Canadian by the shield on the flag since many British Commonwealth countries used and continue to use the Ensign. I explained this to the people at the museum who said many Canadians had commented about this but that their curator had researched this thoroughly - clearly she hadn't and they need to put an identifiable Canadian flag along with the other countries - unless of course they don't feel our efforts were worth it.

Highly rated for you history buffs - Lots to read. This is one of those little known museums that is very enjoyable because you are not rushed by a crowd. The Museumkaart covers the cost of admission so as always I advise you use that. While this was not in my top 5 to visit, it did make the 2nd full day of museum-hopping. This has really great, personal-level information and some neat, little-known tid-bits from this period of history. It was very interesting to see how the Dutch dealt very differently than other nations when they were overrun by the Nazi's. The layout is a little confusing, but stick with it and you'll figure it out. There is Soooo much to read (and most all of it is translated into English) that it will take you quite a few hours to get through it all. I would set aside a whole morning or afternoon for this one or if you just want to skim-read you can probably get through in an hour. BTW - it is right across from the zoo, so if there are little ones that wouldn't really want to read about the resistance in Holland, you can split up and conquer (although there is a children's section to this museum, but I didn't partake so I cannot review it).Overall, a good thing to do.

Very insightful! Fun museum. . Absolutely loved our visit here. Gives a great snapshot of what it was like in the country before and during WW2. Gives a good picture of the different perspectives of the German occupation and the main dilemmas for different groups of people. Don't be fooled by the small scale - there is heaps of information. My wife and I aren't big museum people but loved this visit - spent about 2 hours here.

Definitley Worth a Visit. Great place to see Amsterdam and Holland's perspective on their part in WW2. A very professional and comprehensive perspective from the Dutch point of view. There are many exhibitions to see and interactions to take part in. 10euro is a fair price and you get a coffee or 2 in the coffee shop next door. Well worth a visit.
Interesting. A good place to visit for a couple of hours. Lots of information with regards to the resistance during the War.Entry price is reasonable at 10 Euro each
Great display of the movement. A very through and personal view of the resistance movement in Amsterdam and the countryside during WWII.
awesome. So many artifacts to see. it was incredible . Pictures were allowed. There was no line/wait to get in. Allow about 2 hrs to see the exhbits

Excellent calm museum without too many tourists. Many Amsterdam museums have big queues. Not here. It was busy without being too full of people and we managed to spend as much time as we wanted in a calm environment learning about the war from the Dutch perspective and life in Holland for Jews and others.

Very good museum, the kids section is the best.. This museum is very informative, but the childrens museum is fantastic, also for adults. It is hands on and gives you an idea what life was like for children in WW2. It is a small museum. Teens will love it too!

Take your time - worth it. In this museum, they use short movies, audio tapes and more interactive stuff to teach you about World War II and everything that happend around it. Definitely worth a look if you're interested in this part of history. There is also another exhibition (Dutch East Indies) and a junior part.

Great little museum. I thought the museum handled the Nazi occupation is a very thought provoking and sensitive way, with lots of little personal insights. If you're looking for the junior museum, you need to go through much of the main one to get there. We took our 9 year old son and by the time we got to the junior section, which was beautifully presented (incorporating the stories of 4 different children still alive today), he felt that he'd pretty much had enough...

Excellent museum, though time-consuming. This is a very specific interest, but if wartime resistance holds a mystique for you, you'll be in heaven. Very well done displays and short movies, and there's an interactive children's section, too. Just across the street from the zoo, and very close to the Hermitage Museum.
Solid and well laid out. This museum was well laid out. We spent about 1.5 hours working our way through the museum. It was worth a visit.

Don't miss this museum. Pick up a headphone (available in many languages).The museum is very moving. The museum is in chronilogical order that starts in 1930 to 1950.With authentic objects, photographs, document films it tells the story of people who lived through that horrific period. Tells of how people helped others into hiding, learn about underground newspaper, ways in which people had to communicate to each other.I never knew about this museum until someone on my tour told me about it. And she never knew about it until someone on this same tour told her.It is out of the way from the main tourist area of Amsterdam. I did a lot of walking exploring lot of area but you might want to check into taking a tram or subway.There was a lot to take in from this museum. I may have felt overwhelmed. Should I return to Amsterdam, I'll definitely visit this museum again.

Amazing Review of WWII History in Amsterdam. The museum is laid out well, and easy to follow on your own (guide not needed). Headphones available in many languages for each display. I learned a lot about the Resistance Movement in Amsterdam as well as some WWII information that I did not know, and found it fascinating. What those people went through during those years!! If you like history, I strongly recommend visiting this museum. It is eye-opening.

very moving experience. Terrific museum focusing entirely on the harrowing, World War II era in the Netherlands (there was also a great special exhibit on the Japanese war against and occupation of Indonesia, which was a Dutch colony at the time). Very friendly and helpful staff, fascinating information; and it was so absorbing that I spent three and a half hours there without once realizing how much time had passed. The only complaint I have is that for some reason, some of the displays are behind very narrow windows, making them difficult to look at.

Don't miss it!. The displays are FABULOUS: covers a lot of elements of how the politics, culture and society were impacted by the fall to the Nazis in just 5 days! The conflicting reactions from sympathizers to resistance, various political parties, changes in everyday life... all is shown there with small room displays and a FREE audioguide. The Special exhibit on The Hunger Winter is fantastic and emotional showing how children were sent to the farms so they could have food. There is also a special display for children showing the impact from the point of view of 4 kids. FABULOUS.
Great. Worth the money and friendly staff. The presentation of information was of the right level and the audio guides were great.

Disappointing presentation of important information.. For some reason many exhibits are visible only through narrow openings through which one has to squint. The information panels are helpfully all bilingual Dutch/English but are too small to read comfortably. Our overall impression is therefore one of disappointment in valuable material inadequately presented. A shame.

One of the best museums I have visited. Myself and a friend arrived in Amsterdam on a very early flight so had half a day before the rest of our party arrived. We decided to head across to this museum as our first port of call as neither of us knew much about the resistance movement in the Netherlands and as we had luggage with us we didn't want to spend a lot of time traipsing across the city. This is genuinely one of the best museums I have ever visited (and I do love museums) with the staff being some of the friendliest I have ever encountered. Upon our arrival they allowed my friend and I to store our luggage and seemed really thrilled that the museum had been our first port of call. Upon leaving they also assisted us with finding the right tram to get us to our apartment which we were renting. The museum tells it's story using real life narratives of individuals who experienced the war from all sides and does not hold back. It explains the war truthfully, using propaganda items, photos, videos and sound recordings, enabling you to understand the complexity of the situation and the difficult decisions normal citizens were forced to make. Areas around the museum are thematically and chronologically organised and the way everything was written (English and Dutch) myself and my friend (who are in our mid twenties) felt compelled to read everything.Amsterdam is a great choice for a city break however with so many sights this museum could easily not make the list but I would highly recommend it doing so. If you are interested in World War II and are thinking of visiting Anne Frank's house then visiting the museum before hand really sets the scene.

No Punches Pulled History. We visited this museum with our eleven-year-old son, who didn't have a moment of boredom in either the adult or children's sections of the museum.The adult's section is presented in Dutch and English. Displays of papers and artifacts are next to multimedia displays explaining and detailing the events in the Netherlands during World War II. Particularly moving to me was the display showing copies of the last letters flung from the Jewish deportation trains in desperation. This display is a 3D display, and when one can almost see the letters fluttering to the ground as the train pulls away. Throughout the displays are pictures of members of the Dutch Resistance and the activities they participated in during the occupation. This really made the history seem personal.The children's section of the museum was mainly in Dutch, but fully interactive. Language barrier aside, my son (and my husband, if I'm being honest. I'm actually not sure which one of them was more fascinated by the presentation) spent a very long time going through each of the houses of different real Dutch children - the child of a Dutch resistance member, a Nazi sympathizer, a Jewish child, and a child of a family trying to survive without becoming too engaged in either side - and studying their stories. This museum was a fantastic site to visit, with so much to learn about the WWII era. It was well worth the three hours we spent visiting.

Comprehensive coverage of a troubled period in history. The Nazi occupation of the Netherlands was dark period in the country's history and is a divisive topic to this day. This museum takes its time to explain all stages of the occupation from invasion to liberation and beyond. It uses audio-visual guides and short film clips to accompany the many texts and transcripts of period time accounts. The display looks a bit small and underwhelming when you enter but you soon realise the extent of the layout. Many artifacts are displayed throughout to add interest as you work your way around. Although I knew a certain amount about this period prior to my visit I felt this museum gave me a much better understanding of it and I would definitely recommend it. In fact, for anyone planning to visit the Anne Frank House the Resistance Museum is an excellent companion attraction.

Very interesting. How each country dealt with the Nazis always interests me. This museum was no exception. It was full of interesting information and artifacts. It tells the story of many who died resisting the Nazis or helping Jews escape. My only complaint is the museum is rather difficult to follow in order of exhibits, and sometimes there are big jumps in time or events. Still, don't miss this museum if WW2 and Nazi resistance interests you.

Calculate a few hours for this visit. This is quite an informative museum, you get an audio guide as well as there are lots of information written inside of the museum. The texts are written in Dutch and English, but the audio guide offers more languages such as German, French and Englisch +++. It is a museum with a quite good variety of short movie clips, pictures, and objects from the war. I'd surely recommend this museum as a part of your city programme in Amsterdam! It is not to miss, you'll regret it. We spent around 4 hours here, because it is so well informed and we wanted to inform ourself as much as possible when we once visit it.

Outstanding. We went with an open mind to this museum and were totally fascinated. It illustrates how the Dutch people as a whole resisted and survived the German occupation during WW2. Particularly interesting was the special exhibition about the city children who were evacuated to the countryside in the famine times towards the end of the war. 2 small suggestions to make this an EVEN better experience: 1. To appreciate the absolutely prodigious amount on display, the possibility perhaps of a return visit on the same ticket, 2.. A few more resting places would be welcome for those of us who are 'getting on a bit'.

Amazing experience. A top Amsterdam site.. We allotted about 2 hours for this museum and regretted that we didn't save more time for it. Make sure you get the free audio tour, a crucial part to the museum. Although there is a lot to read and listen to, the curators have made it all so compelling and interesting. Above all, even adults should go to the children's part. They have you follow the lives of several different children through the War, from a Jewish girl to a Nazi activist. As a historian, I would quibble with a few of the accounts, but that doesn't mar the overall experience. The only regret is that all the books in the too small shop were in Dutch. Along with the Jewish museum (and the zoo, across the street from the Resistance Museum), this made my Amsterdam trip very special.

A great place to explain "the resistance" to children. There are at least five museums in Amsterdam that purport to focus heavily on the resistance, but this one has the clearest focus. It's low tech and relies heavily on 1980s technology, but its documentation of the unfolding of the resistance is thorough. Audio guides allow the viewer to experience actual audio footage from the period in Dutch (German in some cases, but with English translations). The experience was very powerful. A separate area for children takes them through the lives of four tweens from the period of the resistance and shows how their families responded to the changes differently, and then how this affected their lives after the war. It brings the realities of making political decisions into a stark perspective.

Impressive in both content and presentation. The museum looks small from the outside but packs an amazing number of displays into the space it has. I really liked that most of the material was either written contemporaneously with events, such as letters or diaries, or recorded recollection by people who were there as children. Attention to the mundane details, whether in Amsterdam or in internment camps, kept the focus on the human experience, not just the political/military. Inclusion of events in Indonesia very interesting. The only unpleasant part was the amount of noise made by several large school groups. Most of it was relevant to seeing the museum (teachers talking loud enough for all to hear, students getting excited about an exhibit, etc.) but because the exhibits are so compactly arranged the noise was amplified and became quite overwhelmng at times.
Interesting. Interesting but somewhat confusing in layout. Lots of fascinating information but a bit maze like. Four of us went there and all had the same view.

Interesting but missing the work done to help people escaping from other countries. Many people escaping from other European countries found passage through The Netherlands - we did not find this part of the resistance covered in this museum at all. Rather this museum covers only the resistance which helped Dutch people who needed to be hidden from the Nazis or others who would have turned them in. It covers this area quite thoroughly and is of interest but of limited interest to us.

Informative, great value museum. This great museum gives you a great insight into the development of the Dutch resistance during WW2.The museum starts by setting the scene the regarding the economic situation in Europe before WW2 which added to the rise in fascist movements including the Nazis.As well as showing the resistance effort the museum doesn't shy away from the fact that there was collaboration and cooperation with the Nazis and this delicate relationship is explored very subtle and subjectively.There is a huge amount of original artefacts and photos on display. All displays are in English and dutch and there is a multi language audio tour available that is free.

The inventive Dutch take the initiative against oppression. The museum tells the story of how the invading force slowly managed to whittle away every little bit of goodwill in a population that at first wanted to remain neutral. They had reckoned without the Dutch sense of fairness, however, and gradually brought out the finest humanity and a sense of ingenuity in the population of the time. Courage and invention, good organisational and technical skills, and a willingness to live with ambiguity all played their part in this moving drama. Riveting! And displayed in a way that all ages can appreciate. Once one is past the fairly surly reception, one is lost in the story...

Lots of information but no real story. The exhibit was very informative about what happened but really did not engage me with the story of the people who were affected. It was to much like a visual history lesson trying to get over the whole story rather than allowing the visitor to discover facts themselves. The lay out was good and the temporary exhibition was excellent but we left feeling like we hadn't really engaged with the struggle of Amsterdam but knew a lot about it.
Nice. If you want to know more about the war and the people who been against it, this is the place you have to be. The name says it all.

must must see. This is the second time we have been here but as the first was in 2006 there has been a few changes although the theme is just the same. AS a BRit I cannot decide how I would have felt in 1940 if my country had been over ran.....remember we would not have known certain big issues.

Fantastic Find!. A great museum showing what life was like for the Dutch during the outbreak of World War 2. There's a lot of reading involved however there is also a fantastic kids section which has loads of practical games for the children and adults to be involved in.We walked from the centre and it did seem quite far but I'm sure there will be buses/trams that will go that way. It's right across from the zoo.Everyone in our party were impressed and we'd liked to have stayed longer but we only had two days in the city so we had to try and fit in as much as possible.

Better than the Anne Frank House. This incredible museum is not as well known as it should be, and tells the stories of hundreds of ordinary people in an extraordinary time. Having studied WWII at length, there were still many things I had never heard of including the tram strikes in occupied Amsterdam, how hard the Nazis tried to get the Dutch to join into their political mindset, the work of the university students, the pressure in the schools, so many ways in which this time effected the people in this country. The thing I liked best is how much we got to hear of people in their own words. It was profoundly moving and challenging.

We owe it to our ancestors to visit this place... Emotional and very interesting look into the resistance movement during get the war. Heartbreaking and informative. Suitable for families and adults alike.
Interesting. Really enjoyed this museum that portrays life under occupation and what locals experienced to survive.

Nice museum, not heavily trafficked, a unique space.. This is a small museum off the beaten path. It contains an overview of the resistance movement in Amsterdam during World War II and many staged examples showing how information was passed. Well worth the visit.

Framing the pointed question: what would you do?. This museum frames the question very well: if you were a Christian in Amsterdam in 1942, how would you have responded to the Nazi occupation? It's an uncomfortable question and you find yourself relating to the archetypical characters who take different approaches. At times it was difficult to follow the sequences, and the audio didn't always match up to the displays. A bit more organization and maybe a bag of breadcrumbs to lead the way would make this a world class museum.

An inside look into Nederlands during the war. I really learned about the Nederlands role and suffering during the war. I also got great insight into what happened in Indonesia and Dutch colonies during wartime. Went there after the Artis Zoo. If you love history this is a must for you.
Autumn visit. Welcoming museum staff and good facilities including lockers and free information handsets. Very interesting and thought provoking.

Very memorable visit. This is one of the most interesting museums I have been to in a while, and one of the highlights of my Amsterdam trip. It is also a nice contrast to the art museums. As others have written, there is a lot of information presented. I recommend using the free audio guide as it helps focus the visit. You always have the option to pause the audio guide and spend more time on any exhibit. I highly recommend visiting the children's museum even if you are visiting without a child. This allows you to experience what life was like during the Nazi occupation, from the eyes of four different children. This turned out to be one of the best parts of the museum. Of note, this part of the museum is only narrated in Dutch, but the audio guide provides a very good translation. Overall, I found this to be a very worthwhile museum.
Small but informative. Small museum full of great information. They offer free English audio guides to use if you don't speak Dutch. Friendly staff.
Very moving and educational. It is a very good complement to a visit to the Anne frank house as it gives the larger context within which her story occurs.

As a history buff (WWII specifically) this was amazing!. I love to travel and see things that not everyone visits. Plus, I love learning, 1930s and 1940s are my era of choice, so seeing a first hand account of what the Dutch Resistance did to fend off the invasion of the Nazis. The artifacts and the personal accounts that are documented were beautifully presented and the audio tour was a nice guide through it all.

Thought Provoking. There is a lot of information in this museum with free audio commentary. It really puts you into the position of a person faced with the options of how to survive a Nazi occupation.I think there is too much information if you are planning on reading everything as we spent about 3 hours there and didn't read the Dutch East India section as it felt we had taken in enough information.There was a temporary exhibition with real life experiences of Dutch children during the war, their starvation and evacuation. We had no idea how much the Dutch had suffered during the Second World War.A must see, but you may want to dip in and out of the information rather than trying to read it all as it is tiring to take it all in.

Got headache, too much information. This museum has a lot of information and lack of space. The lay out is too tight, I mean there is not so many space between one subject to another. They fill all the space with information. You really need 3 hours at least to work it out into your head. I love the Junior department. You'll understand better than reading all those information. It's worth visit if you want to know what happened in Amsterdam in WW II. Besides the permanent exposition, there is also other periodical exposition and at this moment is "Naar de Boeren".
Fascinating!. This place really made us think what would we have done if faced with the same situation. Very informative and very moving. We were here 3 hours and it is well worth a visit.

Cool perspective. The museum was really great! Probably my favourite museum in Amsterdam! I spent a good 3 hours there! They ahd a cool exhibit about Indonesian life during WWII. Added an interesting perspective of history Westerners unfortunately don't always get the opportunity to hear.

Great Museum Covering NAZI OCCUPATION. I wanted to visit on my first trip to Amsterdam some years ago, but ran out of time. This museum does a great job conveying the difficulties ordinary people had under the occupation. There are significant sites in the surrounding neighborhood concerning the occupation. After visting the museum, we did a one hour self-guided walk covering the sites. The museum sells an inexpensive booklet for such a self-guided walk.

Surprised. We visited here after spending a number of hours at the zoo. I wish we'd done this museum on a separate day as there was so much information to glean, it was difficult to absorb it all having exhausted ourselves outdoors. It was incredibly interesting to see the war from a different country's perspective and I was surprised at how much I enjoyed this attraction. Lots of interactive displays and audio, plus a special area of the museum is dedicated to children. Would recommend.

A perfect compliment to your visit to Anne Frank house and no queuing.. Set within the old Jewish quarter a more detailed history of the local resistance in Amsterdam to the Nazis in WW2.Civil disobedience and strikes in reaction to the worsening treatment and restrictions on the Jewish population and later the defeated Dutch army. Excellent displays and make use of the free audio guides. Temporary display (November 2014) including video diaries of people who were children in WW2. Very enthusiastic local staff who were taking teenage school groups around. Puts the Anne Frank story into a far better local context.

I have mixed views on this place.. I was a bit surprised to see this place, myself being a student of military history,and my father fought in Holland in WWII.The Dutch "gave up" their Jewish citizens to the Nazis and also sent a lot of volunteers to the German army units in WWII. Not a lot to see really, give it a miss.

Honest treatment of wartime Netherlands. We had family in the resistance, so wanted to see how they told the stories. They were very honest about the hardships, and how some resisted but others collaborated. The special exhibit on the hunger winter hit home, since some family members lived through that. Excellent, worth a visit. Easy access by tram, and reasonably priced.

Very moving experience. I would suggest that every American spend some time and effort familiarizing themselves with the events and people of WW2. So much sadness, so much horror, so much evil, so much death... and yet, so many heroes to honor. In the midst of the tragedy there were many people who were willing to and who did die for the right reasons and this museum honors many of them. You should make time to go. It's more important that many other things Amsterdam has to offer.... I only wish there were even more stories at the museum.

Great information but a bit much. There is so much great information that is very interesting. The only difficult thing is actually reading it all. About halfway through of trying to listen to the audio and read everything we were a bit overwhelmed.

The occupation museum. An interesting museum, but I was expecting more focus on the Dutch resistance movement. The audio guide was a bit disappointing as it repeated the information that was on the boards. The temporary exhibition on the evacuation of children to the countryside due to food shortages was very interesting and engaging.

very interesting. Was told of this museum by my son. I visited with 3 girl friends we all thought the museum was well presented and very thought provoking. Thought we would be there for about an hour! 2.5 hours later we had information overload but hadn't finished the museum. I Will go back to finish it.

Great for Children too. Normally we would be cautious having young children visit a holocaust museum, but the Resistance Museum had a section specifically for children. We felt the museum was very successful in having us feel the debate the people of Holland had. Hero or safety or the family. Makes one wonder what we would choose. Well done!

A real gem!. My Husband chose to visit here on our recent trip to Amsterdam and he chose a wonderful place. Such an informative and extensive museum, excellent audio tour! Facilities are very good, lockers, toilets and a cafe. We spent a couple of hours here but could have doubled it easily. Excellent value for money and well worth a visit.

Interesting Visit. We enjoyed our visit to this museum, but it wasn't our favourite... I do feel bad saying that though because it was informative and well-organized. For some reason I just felt like it was perhaps missing something? Either way, we were glad we went. It can be quite a hike though depending on where you're located in the city (not very central).

Surprisingly informative and enjoyable.. This museum is extremely effective at providing detailed insight regarding the German occupation of The Netherlands during WWII, from the perspective of the Dutch people. The many conflicts regarding whether to resist and how to do so are portrayed through various images, documents, videos and re-creation of the environment. For instance, unique Items such as a small Christmas tree fabricated out of bandages and medication wrappings by a resistance prisoner while in solitary confinement after he'd been shot give a valuable perspective to the prison cell exhibit. The overall transition from uneasy co-existence to outright acrimony is depicted in the same gradual but highly crescendoed manner as it probably developed. This is quite an interactive exhibit, so it would be of interest to children, though some of the topics may be excessively macabre. The (free) audio tour in this museum is particularly well-designed, as you simply hold your device to one of many (30+?) labeled 'docking' locations as you enter any given exhibit or area, and the corresponding description begins automatically. You can then choose additional details on the topic by selecting various buttons on the device. As with most of the WWII resistance museums I have seen in various cities, you can sense the pride of the people in their desire to emphasize the sacrifices made by their citizens and their significant role in helping defeat the occupiers despite a fairly quick initial surrender, which is really the most valuable aspect of this experience. The location, about a twenty-minute walk or so from Dam Square, is well-worth it. Easy to combine with a visit to the Rembrandt House, which is a mere 10 minute walk.

Wonderful museum- very moving. This museum is not amongst the most famous in Amsterdam but should be on everyone's list. It details the events and atrocities that occurred during the nazi occupation. The layout and style of the exhibits make you feel that you are witnessing hidden and personal events and the testimony from individuals is very moving. A sobering and worthwhile visit.

Very good. A very interesting museum, there is almost too much to read and take in!The museum provides a detailed insight into the lives of the Dutch people during WW2 and their struggles with the occupying Germans.There are plenty of interesting artefacts to see, the highlight for me buying the often poorly forged identification papers.The audio guide is good and is available in English.Definitely worth an hour or so of your time while in Amsterdam.
Interesting history in a static display. The museum is a timeline of the occupation starting in 1940. It features the relics and artifacts from those who lived in the city. A few film clips.
For those who like history . This is a very interesting museum. The multimedia part is amazing a lot of interesting history about world war 2. The kids place is touching.

Fascinating Dutch history. My understanding of what happened to the Dutch people during the Second World War was sketchy, but after visiting the Anne Frank house I was interested to find out more about life under the Nazis. We cycled to the Resistance Museum from the Jordaan area and it was well worth the trip.The museum is an inspiring testament to the Dutch people under occupation. The stories of heroism and bravery were very moving, from their hiding of the Jews to their strikes and underground newspapers.The many letters, photographs and artefacts made this recent history come alive. It was often distressing. Highly recommended for all visitors to Amsterdam.
Great little museum - well worth visiting!. Really enjoyed this museum - lots to see and very interesting and informative - learnt a lot about Amsterdam during the war.

Very good value for money. We went here with our teenage children as the queue for the Anne Frank museum was too long. This is an excellent museum which gives a really good overview of the war in the Netherlands. It cost us 20 eu for the whole family and this included the 'talking guide'. Very well described and with lots of 'people' stories to bring it to life. It is opposite the zoo and took just under half an hour to walk there from the station - but it was a great walk and worth doing. I would say this takes about 1 hour and 30 minutes but you could probably stay a little longer. Visited with our two teenage children and we all really enjoyed it!

Well worth a visit. if you're sick of the queues at the Ann Frank house,and even if you're not, then this is well worth a visit. It was not at all crowded on the Saturday I was there and the displays which were in both Dutch and English were easy to understand and engaging. The story of the growing resistance to Nazi occupation was soberly and credibly told and the various actors - collaborators and resistance were fairly described. Not a particularly lavish or high tech museum but probably the better for it. Good for an hour or so.

Moving Experience. If you are interested in anything to do with the Second World War and the ingenuity displayed by the Dutch in their resistance to the Nazi regime then this is the place for you. Although it is slightly outside the centre of Amsterdam it is well worth the effort.

Worth a visit for recent historical events. This museum is situated a short tram ride on the number 9 from Dam Square and well worth the effort. It gives a very comprehensive history of the role of the Dutch Resistance with many photos and personal accounts.

Great History Museum!. If you're a WW2 buff, then this museum is for you. Starting at the beginning of the war and moving on to the restoration, this museum offers a lot of information that was unknown to me, including a lot on how the Nazis infiltrated the government peacefully and how the resistance teams covertly deterred the Nazi invasion. The most interesting element, and one that is often overlooked, is their display on the East Indies and the role Dutch colonization played during the war. The history books tend to overlook the "non-white" aspect of WW2, and the museum's display on the islander position before and after the war is a must-see.They also offer a free audio tour, so take it!

Compelling WWII history!. After spending several days wandering the streets of Amsterdam, it was instructive to be reminded and informed in detail about what life was like under the Germans from 1940-45. This museum gives you both the big picture, but also a lot of individual stories which make the history come alive. The introductory film is excellent, the labels are all in English as well as Dutch and there is a free audio guide which is also available in an English version. The museum space is small and the feel of it may seem dated, but it is a powerful story we all should know. Their location is out from the center of things across from the zoo, but reachable by tram.

Deeply Moving, Important, Be Sure to Visit. One sunny day in May of 1940, a perfect day for lunch outside or a walk in the park, the German Air Force bombed the Dutch city of Rotterdam. Then they said, "Surrender or we'll bomb the rest of your cities." This is the story of what happened - the ugly and cruel, as well as the brave and humane. You will be moved by this museum, and you will see the city of Amsterdam in a new way, one that will deepen your appreciation for what its people, buildings, and beautiful canals have witnessed. The belief of some groups in each society that they are so right that they can - even must - impose their will on everyone exists today as it always has. It's a sturdy and pernicious weed. Visit this museum to be reminded of what can happen when it is set loose. Believe it or not, you will be glad you did.

Very educational and well worth a visit. We intended to visit the probably more famous Anne Frank House during our quick visit to Amsterdam, but were directed here instead by our innkeeper. There is alot of information in a small space, and all the exhibits are in Dutch and English. There's also no waiting to get in! Audio guides are available. We had to drag ourselves away due to time constraints, but learned a great deal about the Dutch Resistance in a short period of time. A short tram ride away from Central Station, and near the zoo.

Accessible and revelatory. Apart from the higgledy-piggledy layout, this museum was absolutely fascinating on many levels, and well worth the entrance fee.As a self confessed enthusiast about all things World War II, i was desperate to see how the Dutch had undermined and resisted against their occupiers, and i wasn't disappointed. There were some lovely displays and some great personal stories, most intriguing of which was that of Gerrit Van Der Veen and his family. The smaller offshoot section about The Dutch East India Company and the consequence of uprising of the local Indonesian population was also extremely interesting.There is a lot of information here, but it is presented in an easy, accessible manner, and shows to remind us of the impact of the Dutch underground community pulling together against tyranny.
Very informative. Lots, and lots of information and well presented. I ended up here longer than I thought I would. Was most intrigued about their country's reclaimed land.

Informative but dry. Overall the museum was informative, but it lacked the personal story aspect of those in hiding. The listening tour was helpful and there were many pictures and articles. I would recommend it if you're in the area.

Ask your self a question then ask someone.. Not what I was expecting. We called in on a wet and cold morning with the hope of gaining a little info and passing some time. Over 2 hours latter we were still here. Even my 18 year old daughter got in to it And for some one with no interest in history meant it had to be good. Shows the life's of real Dutch people during the war years and their decisions to coraborate with the invading fourced or to fight back in way possible. Gives a really good insight also in to the winter of starvation at gone end of the war where children were evacuated to the country side or face starvation. This brought the real horrors home along with the kindness of the country people in a real time of need.

Fascinating & sobering. There are many museums in Amsterdam that have similar counterparts around the world. This museum, however, is distinctly Dutch, telling the stories of individuals during the Nazi occupation of Amsterdam. Very well presented in timeline form. Watch the short introductory film before going into the exhibit hall. Museum was chilly. Wear a sweater!

Definitely visit. If you enjoy history this is a must see. I did not know much about the Dutch resistance, but after 2 hours in this museum feel very educated on the subject. Overall, interesting material to read and view, as well as many personal stories of brave individuals.

Put yourself in their shoes. How would you resist ? What options were available to you and your family and consequences. Multimedia, use of visuals and stage helps you connect with this difficult historical period.
Very educational. It was thoroughly educational and entertaining and its quite a big museum. Took a while to finish. Worth a visit if you are interested in history
A must see museum.. An informative history of a very difficult and dangerous time for the Dutch people and needs to be visited to appreciate the ordeals they went through. Brave people.

Not everyone was a hero. This is a fabulous museum. You could visit here time and again and not absorb all of it. The best aspect of the museum is that it doesn't portray all the Dutch as being heroes. You must watch the introductory film (in Dutch with English subtitles) that lays out the theme, "Adjust, Collaborate, Resist" which resonates throughout the museum. Not everyone was able or willing to help resist the Nazi occupation, and this museum shows what choices real people had to make depending on their circumstances. The exhibits cover a vast array of reactions by the residents of Amsterdam when their world was turned upside down.

Not What I Expected. The museum is interesting in its portrayal of the Dutch to the Nazi occupation. It focused mainly on the low key obstruction tactics rather than direct confrontations. There were some moving stories related to the persecution and the rescue of (some of ) holland's Jews. I had expected more on armed resistance, but maybe there wasn't much......

Excellent little museum. Visited this with my 17 year old son. It is a little 'old school' in terms of presentation but very interesting and very well done. We spent over 2 hours in the place. Staff were excellent, really friendly and helpful.Strongly recommended!

Informative displays showing a human perspective. This was a well-considered, balanced insight into the Dutch response to Nazi occupation, demonstrating motivations for and consequences of the range of Dutch responses. At times moving, this was the most compelling of the museums I visited, with the most powerful human element. Give 2 hours minimum to read all the captions and examine the displays quite quickly. Anything less and you'll have to miss out on quite a lot; choosing what to miss is a tricky decision!

Honest and enlightening. A little off the general tourist track means that even with a big event on at the time of my visit it was a little crowded but not enough to hamper my enjoyment of the place. The audio guide is a must, there is so much additional information available to those who are interested and it is well structured - the museum is too if you are paying attention to the 'story' that is being told, to the casual wanderer it may be a little less so.The information presented is unflinching and honest, none more so perhaps than the section on the colonies at the end of the tour, but at various points it challenges the visitor to put themselves in the position that was faced at the time, do you protect your family or risk all. The choices are presented in what I felt was a non-judgemental way leaving the visitor to make their own mind up.As with many museums there is an enforced locker for large bags which is ideal in so many ways, I can put mine away and enjoy the visit and no bumping of others, the deposit being returned when you are finished with the locker. A great place and as I visited here before the obligatory visit to Anne Franks house I felt much more informed on the events around the war era in the Netherlands than I may otherwise have been.

Small but you'll need a couple of hours.. A very special museum showing an extremely difficult time in Amsterdam. Well laid out with clear English information. Leaves you, of course, with the question - What would I do? You need to take the tram - but try to get there - even if you only have an hour.

potential but a bit of a mess. The museum holds a huge amount of important information . However. maybe because of its small physical space - it is set up in a very confusing matter, hard to follow and very noisy (from the audio exhibits) . Its a shame as it is an important subject to learn about
Brilliant!. A great museum without advertisement. There were a lot of informative display about the Dutch and how they were suffered during the WW2.

Good Museum. I went here today as soon as I got to Amsterdam. The Museum is small but it has a lot of valuable information about how much the Dutch suffered during WWII. This Musuem has props such as suitcases of those who suffered as well as helmets of those who resisted and even weapons. The museum will take you a good hour to an hour and a half to get thru it all. I highly recommend it for anyone interested in WWII to visit this museum.

Fantastic Museum. This museum is not well advertised but is definitely worth going to see! The museum has an odd layout which is not always the easiest to follow but the information provided is fantastic. While we were there, there was an additional exhibition about the children's transport during the occupation. This exhibition was informative, well planned out and something that stays with you! If in Amsterdam you must see this!

Well done museum. This museum is very well done with good English commentary, though sometimes repetitive. I especially liked the special exhibit where you can see and hear videos about what is was like after the war, when there was almost no food available and the children from the Waterland area north of Amsterdam were taken to foster homes where they could be fed and nursed back to health. Their stories and journeys were very interesting.

Learn a little about the Dutch People. A small but well built up museum that give a little perspectine into the Dutch society, people, living etc during the Nazi' occupation period in the Netherland. It' s far from being the museum of the Resistance ( when one know'sa little about it).

Compelling, sobering, educational. The museum posts the dilemmas faced by the Dutch when their country was invaded by the Germans: acceptance and go on with life, collaborate with the new regime or resistance. It educates on what society was like before the Germans, how people reacted differently during the 5 year occupancy, and how brutal the Germans were not only to the Jews but also to the Dutch who were appalled at what was happening to their friends and neighbors.

A great exhibit and a pleasant surprise. I traveled here recently with my mom, who is in her mid-eighties. Most of our knowledge of Dutch resistance was pretty limited (people who helped the Frank family, etc.) This place was filled with terrific exhibits that put the entire Dutch Resistance movement into context and also strives to examine the alternatives of capitulating to the invaders as well as being complicit with them as a means of survival. There is also a great facet of the museum that deals with Dutch resistance in the Pacific Theater, to which I had never given much thought.We wound up spending far more time than we had originally thought/planned. It was one of the highlights of our recent trip to Amsterdam.

My favorite museum in Amsterdam. If you want to learn what it was like to be in Amsterdam during WW2 you will get an overall history plus individual stories in this museum. Would you have adapted, joined or resisted the Germans? That's the question they all had to face. You will get to see what it was like for many on all sides of this question. Anne Frank's diary was only about the story of a few, now see more stories that stir your emotions as well.

We really enjoyed this. interesting museum that gives a lot of background information about Amsterdam in the war.Do use the free audio guide which is very helpful.Wonderfull fascinating exhibition. Learned so much - great combining of photos, film, music etc.'

Great Exhibit. A Must See. I had learned about WWII in textbooks, but attending this museum offered much more depth. The impact to the Netherlands and its residents was astonishing. A profound reality that both sickens and inspires. The only constructive criticism would be that the audio didn't always match the exhibit. At times you had to step back, or around, to tie the audio to the visuals.

We expected a bit more.. The museum gives the visitor a very broad look at what happened and why but it seems to have missed the mark for us Canadian visitors. We expected that they would have more stories of what people did to fight the Germans. It's worth visiting but it's not the best museum we've ever seen. See my review of the Amsterdam City Museum.

Thorough history of WWII Netherlands. Using the word thorough does not accurately describe how in depth this museum explores this period. While I am very familiar with this time period, I was unaware of what this nation went through during this time. The museum was wonderful with lots of interactive exhibits and a fascinating area dedicated to first person accounts of the hunger winter.
Great historical vision. Had a really wonderful visit-- the museum is so well done and gives you a real perspective on the people and issues of the day.

Fascinating Museum. This is one museum not to be missed on a visit to Amsterdam, make sure you set aside at least two hours to walk round and get the full story of not just the Dutch resistance during WW2 but also the collaborators as well. The entire period is captured from invasion to liberation and there is an additional section on the Dutch East Indies and how they dealt with the Japanese invasion.

Very well laid out museum. We visited recently expecting to kill an hour but spent almost two and a half! For someone who knew relatively little about how the Dutch survived the occupation during the war it was a real eye opener. The whole story from the invasion right thru the war years to liberation was unfolded as you walked thru the exhibits. We even visited the young persons section which was fortunately devoid of schools visits whilst we were there and I must admit we all enjoyed the interactive exhibits despite none of us being under 19! A very well presented museum. telling a vital story. Well worth a couple of hours of your time.

Fascinating stories about heroic people. This museum is not large but holds fascinating displays and stories of the way the Dutch defied their Nazi occupations. The displays tell stories and exhibits show some of the ingenious ways the resistance smuggled good, information or people. It is a must for anyone with an interest in not only war but in the way normal people sacrifice themselves for the good of others.

Much more than the Resistance. A must see museum to give a thorough understanding of what the Netherlands faced and suffered during World War 2. Very clear general narrative and superb detail in photos, film and artefacts. Very moving in parts. An ideal complement to a visit to Anne Frank Huis or if that is too busy a great alternative.
Informative. I knew little about the Resistance movement in Holland before this visit...glad we went...lots to learn about this country's stand against the Nazi's,etc...recommended!

Proud heritage of a country occupied. Simple and straightforward approach to curation. Tells a story about the nation and about how people responded to an occupation that started after only 10 days of conflict. Focus on young teenagers excellent. English language information across all areas. Exhibition about Japanese occupation of the East Indies very interesting. Multiracial resistance to tyranny noted.

Resistance the Dutch way. Very cool museum. We had been looking for some place to buy WW2 memorabilia without success. It's all in this museum. The layout is a little confusing and if you are not careful you could miss parts. Not a lot of fighting depicted. The Dutch resisted by having strikes. I recommend this museum to everyone.

Essential tourist attraction!. This has got to be one of the best museums in Amsterdam and no tourist should leave without seeing this! Very interesting and informative account of the occupation and how this impacted on people and their everyday lives, with so many pictures and detailed information on display that you should not be surprised to spend a few hours here.
The Dutch did not like the Nazis. A well laid out museum with plenty to see. You get a free head set, ask them how to use it. The story's re well put together

Very informative. This museum is tucked away across from the Amsterdam Zoo. It is a self guided tour and all the information on the placards are in Dutch and English. There are a lot of artifacts and displays to go through. It explains how life was before the German Invasion and then how life was after. The Dutch had to choose whether they would try to resist the Germans and there were many ways they did. The hardest part was when the Germans started deporting the Jews and thousands helped hide the Jews in their homes. It helped that we had already seen Anne Frank's house before we went through this museum

A thought provoking, inspiring, emotional "must see". If tyrants took over your country what would you do? Collaborate, try and ignore it, run away or fight it? I guess we all have an established idea of what we would do. After visiting this wonderful museum I'm no longer so confident about how easy it would be to make that decision.Other reviewers have observed that you need at least a couple of hours to set aside for this place. I had anticipated a quick one hour whizz around, but the story this museum tells will quickly stop you in your tracks. We were there for well over two hours.Don't miss the Junior Section. This is where the lives of four very different children face the decisions and hardship that wartime occupation brought. Interactive activities and experiences bring it all to life. Sometimes in heartbreaking ways. This museum doesn't suffer from the queues and hustle of other museums in Amsterdam.We used our Museumkart for free entry and afterwards enjoyed a refreshing alfresco beer in the adjoining cafe.

The best surprise of our trip. An absolute "MUST SEE.". This was the biggest positive surprise of our trip to Europe. What an incredible museum and an absolute must see for anyone travelling to Amsterdam. This relatively small, introspective and thought provoking museum was enthralling to our group of 2 adults and 3 teenagers. After 2 hours we had already voted this our favourite stop, then we discovered their new section called "Junior." So interesting and thoughtful. This museum deserves a higher rating that 5/5. The free audio guide was excellent, so that everyone can move at their own pace.Make sure to buy the Museum Card and use it here. If you plan to visit Anne Frank's house, you must see The Dutch resistance museum as well. I would suggest you visit here first. I would set aside 3 hours. Our absolutely highest recommendation for adults and teenagers.

Very well done, educuational and interesting. The name really doesn't tell the whole story of this wonderful, densely packed museum of the Netherlands during the War. You must go here, and you must give yourself a lot of time to take it all in. This is one of the world's best little museums, and a true gem when it comes to understanding WWII.

my favorite and so much more than resistance focus. This was one of my favorite museums to visit while in the city. I spent more than 4 hrs here, taking a break for lunch at the cafe next door. There is a free audio guide that comes with the ticket, and is one of the museums you can use your museumkart with. The displays are so interactive and visually appealing. This is so much more than the focus on the resistance. You will read and learn about the different mindsets of the various religious, political parties, civic groups, and social classes during the period of 40-45. It explains what the general mindset was of each group: resist, collaborate, comply. There is also a wonderfully done exhibit that focuses on the Dutch that were interred in the prisoner camps in the East Indies during the Japanese occupation of this area once they joined the war. The last area focuses on liberation. Lots of interactive displays, personal accounts, and items from the period 40-45. Original broadcasts of announcement of invasion, sermons from the pulpit of both a Catholic and Protestant church. I could go on and on but if you love history, this is not a museum to miss! It is in the same area of the Portugese Synagogue, Jewish Historical Museum, and just around the corner from the Jewish Theater(Hollande Schwouberg). The building itself is across the street from the Artis Zoo, and the front of the building is yellow. Trams 9 and 14 serve this area.
Worth a quick visit. The museum isn't very large. It gave an in-depth history of world war II and the role of the dutch- pro and con the nazi movement. The museum was free with the Iamsterdam card.

Dark period in Dutch history. Very detailed exhibit about the Dutch reaction to the Nazi occupation. The audio guide is very informative; however, it isn't always clear which order to view the exhibits.

Too little time!!!. Be aware that you need at least two hours to view/tour this museum. Unfortunately we did not realize this nor did we realize that it closes at 5:00pm......we only had 3/4 not an hour as we got list trying to find it!! It is NOT listed in the "Top Attractions" which I cannot understand, as the little we saw of it was fascinating, albeit sad and disturbing. What a brave nation.

Fantastic museum!. One of the best museums dedicated to the resistance during WWII. Lots of artifacts, pictures and interesting information. One of the upsides is the fact that it isn't too crowded, like Anne Frank's or Van Gogh's.If you like this theme, you should not miss this museum!

A difficult Subject. A museum that has presented such a difficult subject in a very 'tasteful' way. Each exhibit fully explained to the many different Nationalities and beliefs of visitors. The personal accounts are so beautifully documented in a very reverent way, and can only tug at the heartstrings of any visitor. There was a lot to take in, and with not much time I did not use the audio available, but quickly grasped the direction of the 'message' of this museum. The choices of all Dutch individuals at this time under such oppression. I did not feel it was a museum dedicated to 'Resistance Organisation' but to ordinary civilians living in the Netherlands during WW11.The exhibits of the Dutch Colony resistance movements was something I had not thought of or knew about. So many brave people.I did watch the film up stairs which was most enlightening without being too graphic.

I expected more from this museum. The Resistance Museum, much like the Anne Frank House, is a combination of individual stories, multimedia and authentic exhibits describing life in the Netherlands during WWII occupation. Detailed history lesson that asks you what would you do during this time. The museum is repetitive after an hour. The main layout of the museum is confusing and I found myself wandering and wondering if I missed some of the exhibits. An audio guide is available free of charge, but the front desk person told me I didn't need it because the exhibits are in Dutch and English. I spent 2-3 hours there. A group of teenagers entered the museum at the same time as I did and they were quickly gone.

Geoff n yinnys review. by far the greatest collections of world war 2 German against the jews.Letters and printing machines secret rooms and videos, you have to see how the jews hid from the germans and the dobbers thinking they where good.Staff excellent and very helpful, go and see for yourselfs opp the zoo.

An innovative account of a harrowing period in Dutch history. The museum uses a great mixture of media to describe life in the Netherlands during the Second World War.It was an aspect of the Second World War that neither of us was familiar with before, but after several hours here we have a much fuller understanding.

Excellent!. If you really take your time and read all the explanations of the exhibition (I think we were there for about two and a half hours), this place really takes you through the dutch occupation and resistance history! While there isn't much on actual display, this is still a very interesting place that fascinated us.

Revealing but not all. I find it difficult to criticise as it was all about a nation that suffered from a Nazi occupation, their resistance and also about their collaborators. The audio guide was useful and easy to use but there was also a lot of reading and many of the exhibits were of little value. I found no mention of the fiasco involving 50 or more spies, many of whom were Dutch that we Brits parachuted into Holland over a period of about 2 years. Each was captured on their arrival and most were killed.

So interesting and the content was vast. I spent around 4 hours at this Museum and still didnt have enough time, it really was interesting and so well laid out and engaging for visitors.If I ever return to Amsterdam I would certainly visit it again.

So much information. A massive amount of information and so good for people who do not know how the Dutch suffered.I would just like to see the audio points numbered so that you get them in the correct order.A really worthwhile visit

worth a visit. we visited this museum, after visiting the zoo across the road, and it was interesting. put into perspective of what the dutch people went through and the efforts of the resistance. part of our history that not everyone knows about with regards to the dutch, but very interesting and worth a visit

Must see!. Incredibly interesting and I have to admit, I enjoyed it more than the Rijksmuseum. Very well done and informative focusing on the Second World War. This was the best museum we visited in Amsterdam. It was not busy too which was great after fighting the crowds at the Van Gogh museum. Highly recommend it!

A little disappointing. We were a little disappointed with the rather low number of actual 'resistance exhibits' which was the main reason for our visit. One of the themes was the problem the Dutch people had with choosing whether to collaborate with their German occupiers and the political battles this caused.The hardships the Dutch people suffered during WW11 was well documented. The dreadful plight of the Jewish people living in the city at the time of the invasion was nothing short of heart rending and very upsetting but well worth remembrance.In short if you expect to leave your visit uplifted by tales of heroics of the resistance you may like me be rather disappointed, we left feeling quite upset. However if you are capable of absorbing the museum content with less emotion than ourselves I think it is well worth the visit, you will be moved and you will be reminded that we must never allow such inhumanity to man to be tolerated again in this world.

Very Good to Excellent. A great compliment to Anne Frank House broadens picture in an objective way showing why some Dutch collarobrted , some reseisted and some "neutral" etc great history well de with personl interivies, nice displays and not crowded so you can really take your time-a xtra attraction is the Dutch Onnian part post WWW2 Really a grat little useum if you are "into" this hstory and how things can happen etc. You can do highlights in an hour if you want to rush but really worth the in depth of two to three, at least we found it so.

Informative and a good alternative to the busy Anne Frank house museum. Fair price to enter which included free audio guide that really made the difference helping you understand what everyone went through. Plenty of English info on the displays too. Takes you through the years of the war until the end from the locals point of view. Well worth a visit. Not far from no 14 tram route.

Great Museum. This fascinating museum tells the story of the Nazi occupation of Holland and has exhibits of interest for the WWII buff as well as the casual visitor who likes history. The museum chronicles with videos, exhibits, life size dioramas and pictures, the experience of ordinary Dutch citizens during that time. It is easy to tour and has English translations. I found especially interesting the exhibit on the experience of the Dutch in the Pacific theater especially the old Dutch East Indies, today's Indonesia. This is a topic often ignored in many western histories of the War in the Pacific. Close by are other locations of interest to WWII buffs including the theater which was converted by the Nazis into a transit camp for the removal of Dutch Jews. Nearby is also the Auschwitz Memorial. This museum is well worth a visit.

Great details. This little museum provides much detail on the behavior of the Dutch during the war and how they were the only country to strike in opposition to the Nazis. It tells of the hardships the Dutch went through and how they tried to circumvent their oppressors.

Interesting Museum; Difficult Layout. I have a Military History Degree and I also visit more than my share of museums. Moreover, I have worked in a few, as well. Given that, my expectations of museums that must convey historically accurate information, displays and artifacts in a cohesive, consistent and - most critical - an intuitive flow are very high. Considering all that - let me touch on the positives of this museum: 1. It is a very full museum. The artifacts, information and historically detailed material found in this musuem is mind-blowing. Truly, this is a treasure of one of the most important resistance movements in all of WWII. They should be most proud. 2. They offer interactive exhibits to attract the young. I can't express how wonderful and welcome this is; especially those traveling with kids that may/may not find themselves interested in the topics. Thus, the interactivity was fun for both our teen and ourselves. 3. The staff is amazing. Truly. They are very helpful. 4. The cost, while a bit steep, is worth it; solely for the bounty that is present within. The reason for the "average" rating could partially be our fault. We had only two hours for the visit; so we likely didn't give it justice; however - for a one-level museum, one hour should be plenty. The challenge that I had was the flow and the signage. While the signs were in English, there was no logical flow of time, truly, to the exhibits. They wind around and, they chronologically jump around as well. While I am sure not intended, that is the outcome. It is a blessing and a curse when you have so much access to so much history and so many artifacts. The blessing is that you have a wealth of detail to tell the story of the Dutch resistance. The curse is that you have SO MUCH and quantity may detract from the quality. I feel that is what happened here. By all means, do visit this museum. DO take the time to watch the quick 7-minute film at the entrance as that provides the foundation. And, if you can, spend several hours here. It is worth it as there is so much to see. If you are a true historian, you will respect the museum for that. If you are looking for a quick hit museum to get a little bit of knowledge; this may be overwhelming. If that is your goal - I highly recommend just touring the kids exhibit. It touches on the key facts and brings the interactive element to it to keep it paced and interesting. Overall, I give this an "Average Plus" or a "Very Good Minus".

Very nice museum that tells a lot more about the Netherlands role during WWII. This is a hidden gem of a museum! Spent over an hour there walking through the displays and listening and watching old movies about how the Dutch dealt with the German occupation before/during WWII.

Interesting find. We were fascinated by this different museum and grateful we were able to visit. It is well organized and gives insight into a subject not usually touched upon when WWII discussed. In a world that focuses on man's inhumanity to man, it is a reminder that decency and courage exist if we care to look.

Moving and informative experience with a great children's area.. This museum had a wealth of material about the Dutch experience of the Nazi occupation. It started by asking the visitor to think about the experience of occupation and the ways one might react to this then led us through how both individuals and the nation did face the war. The small junior section was wonderful and focused on real people bringing their stories to life by recreating their war time rooms. The Vertzetsmuseum museum is well worth a visit.

Problems of conscience. A very interesting display with lots of detail about the German occupation and the problems of conscience it imposed on Dutch citizens Of course, it is always the politician's view which goes along the lines of "if I don't collaborate, then someone even worse will, and so I am taking a realistic and patriotic approach". . It is always worthwhile to remember that it was long after the D-Day landings that the Netherlands became "liberated".  I was particularly intrigued by the short section on the Dutch East Indies, which I had almost forgotten that it had been conquered by the Japanese, although I am very familiar with what happened in Singapore.I was also amazed to hear the theme tune of the famous "BBC Sports Report" radio show for many years being played as the theme for some sort of German sports propaganda film.

a good overview. This museum gave a very good overview into the what the Dutch experienced during the Nazi invasion and occupation. It's not that big, but was packed with information. Since we couldn't get into the Anne Frank house due to the lines, we did this instead and I'm glad we did.

A museum that really informs. If you're a fan of museums which just pile up material, you probably won't like this. Despite this though, the museum has a very strong informative mission and uses its stuff to actually build up an argument. As such it is much more informative and enjoyable than would otherwise be the case. Despite its name, most of the museum focusses on life under the occupation, rather than resistance per se. There's also an interesting exhibition on the Dutch East Indies during the war.It's easily accessible from the Central Station by tram, "Artis" being the correct stop.

Much more than we expected. From the outside you can walk right by this museum. I thought it would be interesting and would take about an hour. I was right about it being very interesting but it was very extensive and we spent over two hours and could have stayed longer. If you are interested in WW2 history this is very worthwhile.
Some very amazing stories by some very young children. It was great seeing how the dutch people survived the nazi invasion & how they fought back & how they survived
Wonderful museum do not miss.. Strong presentation, important history, audio complement as you go through museum. Across from zoo. Well worth time and cost.
Museum. A beautiful museum filled with history. This museum is about the resistance to the German army during the war years.

Surprisingly good. Very informative in telling the background to the people of Amsterdam and their initial reaction to German occupation, and their eventual courage in resisting and trying to keep their own identity, their outrage at the injustice being done to the Jews culminating in the Dutch putting their own lives at risk to help them. It poses a thought provoking question of moral dilemma v. self preservation.
museum. a interesting insight into life in Holland during WW2. varied displays but some titles quite difficult to read through poor lighting or positioning.
Lots of interesting info!. Good value for money, lots to see and read all for only 8€ each.Well worth the walk a little out of the centre.

Moving, detailed, and well presented. A great place to learn about WWII and one of my all time favourite museums.. The greatest thing I did in Amsterdam was visit this museum. It is one of the best I have been to anywhere in the world.The museum looks small once you get to the main section, but there is so much information packed into the exhibits that it takes some time just to see the WWII part (there's also a section on the Dutch East Indies I didn't have time for). The presentation of information is just as impressive as the volume. The progression is easy to follow and thoughtfully arranged, and the descriptions are to the point and centered around a recurring theme that asks the poignant question of "Collaborate, adapt, or resist?" The subject matter is covered thoroughly, so no matter what aspects of WWII you're interested in, there's a section here for you. The audio guide is free and is one of the more useful ones I've come across, so I recommend taking it.I was particularly moved by the paintings done while in hiding by Heinz Geiringer, a young man murdered in a concentration camp who would have become Anne Frank's step-brother after her father re-married to his mother post-war. Some of his paintings were full of hope and longing for freedom, while others were full of despair. If a picture is worth 1,000 words, it's heartbreaking that these are not famous as Anne's diary. The paintings are not displayed all together with one in the children's museum, where you can learn more about Heinz. It's just as interesting for adults.On top of all this, the reception staff were most friendly and there's no giant lineup!Anne Frank's house may be the most famous WWII related place to go in Amsterdam, but if you want to really learn about the Dutch involvement in the war, history lovers will find themselves much more satisfied here.

Interesting. Interesting museum about the resistance that happened in Amsterdam during WW2. Lots to read about, we probably should have visited before we went to Anne frank. But very well done and lots to read about.
Very moving. This is a relatively small museum but it is worth the effort. Allow at least an hour to have time to take the bulk of it in

Collaborate, adapt, or resist?. Extremely thought provoking museum, built around the 3 options of collaborate, adapt or resist. I never appreciated just how many Dutch families went into hiding during WW2 to escape concentration or labour camps in Germany.It sets the scene for Dutch life in the 1930s, and the occupation of the country during the early 40s. The exhibition about the Vught concentration camp is particularly poignant.

Hidden away little gem. I am a massive history fan especially when it comes to the war so this was a must do on our list. It's out of the main city area and opposite the zoo.A very reasonable priced exhibition with a lot of detail put into it. You can have an audio tour from free which you scan at certain points to hear more information. I definitely recommend to anyone fascinated by the Netherlands in the second world war.

A Worthwhile Place to Visit. Almost directly across from the zoo, the Dutch Resistance Museum is a must see. Although it will never be the most popular museum in Amsterdam, the displays are excellent (and in both Dutch and English). The museum well informs visitors about the trauma of the German occupation and how it affected Dutch life. There is nothing “gruesome” or disturbing in the museum, but young children are unlikely to find the museum of interest because of the amount of reading. Nonetheless, this should not deter visitors from this informative and well-designed museum.

Interesting. Another thought provoking museum Showing how people helped one another and those persecuted. I did find it interesting but expected more tales of the heroism of the people involved in the resistance. There were a lot of artefacts which was good but I did leave feeling as though I wanted more info. Staff at reception lovely and it's convenient for cafés nearby.

Disturbing and important to visit. The layout of the museum is very well done. Although it isn't very large it gives a very comprehensive and disturbing view of what happened to the citizens of the Netherlands and the atrocities perpetrated on them and especially the Jewish residents.
