It is a good way to learn about this period in history and know valid reasons why we should never let history repeat itself

Excellent Museum. An interesting museum leading you through the Dutch attitudes and perspectives in WWII. It is a lot of reading but well worth it. There is also free WiFi if you need to take a break.

Excellent. Did not realise how mu,ch the people in occupied holland/Netherlands fought to maintain their beliefs in equality and diversity. Loved the story/ reality of trying to get beliefs across in. Times when the message you wanted to share were controversial.
fantastic experience. fantastic experience... I decided to go there when i read the excellent reviews and it was totally worth it. A very emotional and strong experience

Very impactful. This museum was great. There was a TON to look at and many stories to read. It covered different aspects of the Resistance and really gave an understanding of what it was like during that time.

A hidden gem that takes you into the reality of occupied Amsterdam. We went there with the family that included us adults and a 14, 11 and 8 year old. The latter 3 iPhone junkies are a bit of a risk in a museum but oddly enough they were interested once there as they do a great job providing a museum space for the juniors. The museum itself is well laid out and an interesting glimpse into the lives of those who lived through the occupation. The focus remains on the people, and not the occupiers, and this was great. To get here is a wee tram ride from Dam square, just go in the right direction :) You head East and get off near the zoo and walk about 5 minutes. It is well worth it, you won't be disappointed.

Thought provoking visit. A must see. Starts with a short film - make sure you see this as it asks a very thought provoking question that will help you on your way round. Very well laid out and very clean. The staff are very friendly and helpful and the audio tour is excellent. It is hard to conjure up in your mind how it would be to live in a military occupation - this museum shows you with no holds barred. Sad but worth a visit.

Interesting experience, giving the story behind the resistance movement. This museum is set into distinct areas of life in general in Holland immediately before the war, the events that led to the founding of the resistance and some of the acts of the resistance during the occupation and the liberation giving some personal stories along the way. Whilst it was very good and both interesting and at times quite shocking, I was a little disappointed not to learn more about actual members of the resistance and the operations which they carried out. It would also have been interesting to learn more about how the Nazi's infiltrated the resistance and the damage that this caused. The visiting exhibit on children of the holocaust is very saddening and along with some of the exhibits in the permanent exhibition give you an education into the human tragedy that the occupation brought to the people of Holland and the other occupied countries. The newly opened education centre is also well worth a visit for anyone with children with it's interactive experiences and personal recollections from people who were children during the occupation being enlightening for young minds.

Amazing, detailed, and unique insights. Wow! The most fascinating museum we saw in Amsterdam. The museum takes you through the journeys of the country, its towns, and the individuals involved. We spent several hours walking through the museum captivated. The audio tour was excellent. Make sure to read all the extra bits throughout the museum - they tell unforgettable stories of individual efforts during the war. If you go to one museum in Amsterdam, let it be this one.

Easy to spend 2+ hours. Very well organized and kept up museum. Audio is a available in English as well as half of the signs. Netherlands history during WWII, amazing and sad. The temporary exhibit, the children at The children's camp was touching and a historical account.Overall it was a historical find, but a bit over whelming.Kids may get bored, there is many signs to read.

Thought provoking. A very interesting museum which explores the reality of military occupation. Visited with children 7 and 9 years old. Junior part of museum is aimed at children and brilliantly presents life in a Nazi control land country. Highly recommended to visit but do accept the offer of the audio guides as the junior museum is not labelled in English (note to museum - you should fix this omission for the benefit of foreign visitors who otherwise may miss out on the experience). Apart from the labelling this is a five star attraction.

Accept, resist or collaborate- what would you do?. The Verzetsmuseum or Dutch Resistance museum should not be overshadowed by the other great museums Amsterdam has to offer. During the long German occupation of the Netherlands, each person had to choose how to react to the actions of the occupying force. This museum does an excellent job showing the visitor the decisions the Dutch faced as they watched the fate of their Jewish and other neighbors. Excellent explanations in English but pick up the free audio pod catcher at the desk for more background. Well suited for children as well. The museum is across the street from the Amsterdam Zoo and may be difficult to locate. Plan for a 2 hr visit. Your ticket gives a 2 for 1 coffee at the local coffeehouse.

Makes you think!. Despite the driving rain we walked to this site, I'm glad we did! Thought provoking especially as to what the word resistance means! If you visit please allow yourself time to take it all in. The question we asked all the way back to our hotel was - what would we have done! A sobering and thought provoking museum. On a practical note the signage outside is smallish so be aware its across the road from Amsterdam Zoo.
Timely and moving.... IN this time of rising right wing politics in Europe we must never forget to fight fascism anywhere and everywhere!

Well worth a visit.. We took our 11yr old son to this museum this weekend and stayed for several hours, deeply engrossed and a lot richer for our experience. The museum is well laid out, although we were encouraged to follow the 'footsteps' to the Kinder Museum section and thus accidentally did the museum backwards. Many of the displays and items of interest are 'hidden' in furniture or viewed through 'spy' holes to further enhance the feelings of secrecy. There was a temporary exhibition of the horrendous removal and subsequent murder of the cities children and I defy anyone to visit and not be moved. The museum is based on personal accounts of life leading up to and during the occupation rather than a totally collective representation and the children's section also reflects this with the personal experiences of children from different sections of the population-Jewish, resistance, collaborators. It was an especially difficult period in the history of the city and we came away hoping that we would never have to ask ourselves the same questions or be confronted with the same difficulties in our lives. The accompanying book is in Dutch and English (as was the whole exhibition with free audio guides) and is a fascinating read.

Interesting insight to resistance movement. Shows dilemma of collaborating or resisting the Nazi occupiers during WWII. It brought the occupation to a personal level as to how the Dutch survived during occupation. Interesting first person accounts made this time real for the museum goer.
Very interesting!!. Definitely worth a visit, if you are a WWII history buff and want to learn more about the Netherland's involvement during the war.

Very informative and very moving. I found this museum very informative and very moving. It had the right balance between the stories if different groups of people and different periods during the war itself. I also found the questions ("Strike?" "Adapt, Collaborate or Resist?") very confronting, which I feel is an important part of museums covering such material. It was worth the entrance fee; if you look for the little discount cards hotels and hostels sometimes have, you can find a coupon for a free postcard from the gift shop. The only downside for me was that the layout was somewhat confusing and I had to double back a lot to see things I had missed. Everything is written in English so I declined an audio guide but it might well add to the experience and it's included so I would go for it!
Very nice museum!!. Really enjoyed this museum!! Very interesting story told in a nice way with pictures, videos and you could also listen to a private audio!! Do not miss this visit!!

Must see. Very well laid out and presented. The free audio guide is essential to get the most out of the displays, and the way they work allows you to progress through the museum at your own pace. We were told to expect to take an hour and a half, but before we knew it nearly four hours had passed.

A very well put together museum!. My fellow travelers and I had been to Amsterdam before and were looking for something a little off the beaten track (have done the Rijksmuseum, Anne Franks house, Rembrant and Van Gogh museums) and something good for a rainy day as we were having. This museum turned out to be a wonderful little gem and we spent 2 hours, despite its moderate size. It helps to have an interest in history and or WW2 history, but everyone in our group of 4 enjoyed themselves. The exhibits are extremely interactive and there is a great mix of individual stories and general history. There were also a lot of genuine artifacts that really added to the overall presentation. I would highly recommend this museum!
Amsterdam Resistance Museum. Not what was initially expected but well worth a visit. Display was professionally put together and very informative. Just across the road from the zoo.

Do not miss this museum. What a great little museum! The audio tour is free, and does a great job of telling the story of Dutch life during WWII, from the early days of the Nazi occupation to liberation. It's done roughly chronologically, with side areas that explore specific topics in a bit more depth, so you can really understand how and why the resistance came to be. The theme of the museum is to ask you what would do in the same circumstances: adapt, collaborate, or resist. The area for kids is the probably the single best kid-specific exhibition I have ever seen anywhere in the world. I'd actually recommend that even adults without kids do it, as I found it fascinating. The exhibit tells the story of four different (real life) kids who all experienced the war from vary different perspectives: a Jew who went into hiding and was ultimately caught and sent to the camps, a girl whose father was a Nazi collaborator, a boy whose father was in the Resistance, (and I've forgotten now what the 4th was!). Each one has a separate area and you discover the story of what happened to them during the war as you go through a little display. Then at the end, there's a room with video screens where they are playing clips of interviews with the four real life people, now fairly elderly, and they explain why they wanted to tell their stories, what they remember about the war, etc. It's really amazing and very moving.Also, this is easily combined with a visit to the zoo (Artis) which is directly across the street. And there's a good burger place on the same street, and an ice cream place. So it's easy to convince the kids to go to a museum that they might think they won't be interested (though they will be once they get there) with the promise of a burger, ice cream, and a trip to the zoo.

The most interesting & commanding museum in Amsterdam. We saw the Rijksmuseum, the Stedelijk, Van Gogh, Hermitage, and Anne Frank museums, but none of them really delivered an experience as cohesive as the one the Verzetsmuseum provided. I think this is partially due to the specific nature of the museum itself - naturally, it relied on many written artifacts and personal accounts of stressful and dangerous times - so it gave a very personal perspective that really allowed you to step into the shoes of the Dutch resistance. Though it wasn't as high tech, I still liked it the best.There was one moment where I watched film taken by a Jewish father of his two daughters growing up, and I just couldn't help but see myself and my sister reflected in their antics (eating cherries, chasing each other, play-fighting). Paired with the sad narrative of their deportation as their neighbors watched helplessly, that one artifact brought the experience into a realistic frame for me. It's something I'll remember for a very long time.Although it may be on the side, Rick Steves gives it a 2-triangle rating of importance, and it doesn't seem to be very crowded most of the time. Plus audioguides are free. Definitely give this a look if you're in the area or have free time.

Loved this museum. This was a great find in Amsterdam, and a must for history buffs as it told the story of the German occupation of the Netherlands. It also took the time to provide lots for the younger children.
nice museum. Very well organize museum, It is worth visiting this place when you are in Amsterdam, you can use audio or read the information to understand it easily.
What life was like when.... Moving record of life under Nazi occupation, giving a profound feeling of ho things got worse and worse for the Dutch as the war dragged on.

Good overview of German occupation and Dutch resistance. This is a well organized museum with a combination of written, audio, and video information presented. It takes about 1.5-2 hours to go through. Make sure to ask for the audio guide at the start, and don't miss the bit at the end about the war impact on the former Dutch East Indies.

Worth a visit. An interesting and thought provoking museum, well worth visiting. Not as high tech as some if Amsterdam's other museums but very well put together in a timeline which really helps you understand the Dutch resistance.

A 'must visit' for Amsterdam. So pleased we decided to include this on our recent visit to Amsterdam. Really informative and provided an excellent insight into how another country dealt with the challenges of the Second World War. Reasonably priced and all information both in Dutch and English though make sure you ask for the free audio track. Need to allow three hours to wander around to make the most of your visit.

So much information, too little time. As with any museum, you need a lot of time to truly appreciate all that is shown. We gave it our best shot and are glad we could read and see all that many of the Dutch people did to resist the Nazis oppression of Jewish and other peoples. Well done.

Great !. Very comprehensive exhibition which moved chronologically through the challenging occupation of The Netherlands by the nazis. Only complaint would be that there was a lot of info to take in but that is hardly a complaint! There was a good variation of presentation styles; video clips, radio excerpts, newspaper clippings etc very interesting!

Confronting, educational and humbling. Its one thing to learn about the war from Australia, but being in a city that was directly effected and listening and learning about the details leading up to and during the war was very serial. Glad I visited.

Hard going. There is a lot of conent and a heck of a lot of reading. Some interesting threads running through it but, unsurprisingly, rather depressing and stark. If it's a nice sumnny day go over the road to the zoo.
What a story. Please do not miss this museum. So much information regarding the resistance effort in The Netherlands during WWII. Be prepared to be moved to tears. Such a sad time in history.

Study of Amsterdam in WW2. Traces Amsterdam through the Second World War. In Dutch and English. Just follow the displays with pictures, newspaper articles, letters, recordings, artifacts, etc. Allow several hours to study it all. A good use for your museum card.
Incredible. A great museum but not much know. The presentation, display and interpretation is very, very good. You learn a lot with your visit. Do not miss it.

Very Informative. Went here today after Anne Frank House. Enjoyed both of these places from a learning and history perspective. The museum was very well done and we spent about two hours but could have spent more time. Really enjoyed learning about how the locals struggled with the Nazi occupation and did what they could to help. It gave you a good idea of changing view points on the occupation and every day life during the war. Ran out of time (closes at 5pm) to hear the different stories about four children's struggles. Will have to go back! Definitely get the free hand held recording device. The plaques are in Dutch and English but the hand-held recordings give you more insight. A must see if you like history (and really a hidden gem of an attraction).

Interesting Point of View. Starts with a great introdctory movie that provides you a great points of view on WW2 circumstances. It's a small museum but has lots of interesting short videos and would take about 2 hours to finish. If you take the tram coming from centraal, exit at the front of the tram and turn left on the cross street in front.

One of the highlights of our stay!. Extremely well-done museum, with lots of information, and personal accounts of WWII that not only engage your brain, but touch your heart. Very, very impressed. For anyone that has interest in WWII, this is a must! We arrived about 2 hours prior to closing, but wish we had 3 hours!

Very informative, lots of reading required. This is a good museum for adults, and those who don't mind reading the many written info panels throughout the museum. Not for kids under 16. Tip - Use the free audio guide. Learned lots about the Dutch involvement in WWII.

Excellent!. Took the tram to this museum (get off at Artis stop), and walked a block or 2 to museum. It is exceptionally well done and well worth the couple hours to visit. The museum does a great job at giving you an understanding of the complexities faced by everyday people at the outset of WW II after the invasion by the Nazi's. It seems simple today to think that we would all "resist" the invasion, but real people having to make a decision in the here and now had to choose between resisting, collaborating, or complying, with often deadly consequences.

Terrific museum!. We were pleasantly surprised by this museum. It took us over two hours to complete the tour and it provides a significant amount of data on the Dutch experience in WWII. The audio guide was excellent and the exhibits well laid out and informative. Their coverage of the Jewish population during the war was great.
Very interesting and informative. No Q.... Interesting displays and very helpful staff, All on one level for access purposes. Audio description/languages available.

Low Profile Museum; a bit dated, but the subject matter important. as a family we are very interested in this subject so were keen to see and read about occupation during the second world war (being from the UK we only hear about life here).but it is not a high profile museum. we had to hunt it out - our taxi driver had never heard of it! by todays standards it is quite dated, and i fear needs a bit of investment to move the offer into the 21st century and i also fear there is less interest in the younger generation. so i hope this museum does not get overlooked as others profess. perhaps it should try and liase with the Anne Frank museum; after all many of the issues overlap.do try and go. it is a fascinating part of recent history

Very informative and well presented.. We used the audio guide which gives you a lot of information. The information is presented very well, to help you relate to what is being described. It was very educational. There are very sad parts, but there are also lots of parts where you are proud of how "resistant" the Dutch were.

Asks questions of yourself. Excellent exhibition of like in occupied Holland and asks the visitor would you collaborate, resist or just get along. No matter how bad fighting on May seem it will never be as bad as the consequences of surrender. The Dutch suffered terribly in the winter of 44-45 and had they known what was coming back in May 40 would they have surrendered so readily.

Highly recommend this, especially if you cant get into the Anne Frank house. What can I say? Ive been to plenty of museums in my lifetime like most folks but Ive also worked in some as well. This was one of the most informative well put together museums I have ever visited. While the one drawback is a lack of English subtitles for the visual exhibits, the audio in ENglish helps a lot. The most fascinating aspect of this museum is at the end where you go through the Junior resistance exhibit. WOW. You find yourself able to travel through those difficult times with 5 young Dutch kids. You can pick who you travel with. I happened to choose the little Jewish girl. Again, like I said in the title, if you cannot get into the Anne Frank house then you need to go here. The little girl was a neighbor of Anne Frank's family and her story is truly remarkable. In addition, to the exhibits there is a room at the top of the museum where there is a small library and tables where one can sit and do some research. I was truly amazed with this place.

Fascinating. This was a very interesting museum, one of the best we went to in Amsterdam; there's a good mix of video, audio and text, and a fair degree of interactivity. We didn't visit the kids section, but it's also really good that they have one. Well worth a visit.
Better than expected. Didn't know what to expect from this museum but it was very interesting tour of the nazi occupation of holland and how they responded. Audio guards are provided for free.

Do not miss!. An extremely well laid out exposition of the barbarity of WW2. Great for adults and kids and lots of interactive activities. Exhibits are clearly signed in Dutch and English, and the audio is very instructive. The staff are very helpful and the chocolate cake in the café next door is something else.

Not what we expected. We skipped many of the bigger art museums because we're history buffs, interested in WWII history, so this seemed like it would be right up our alley. It took us forever to find because the tram system we used to get there was very confusing! (If you go, get off at whatever stop is nearest to the zoo and walk, it's on the same street). We were expecting a comprehensive exhibit about the organized Dutch resistance during Nazi occupation. We did not find it. The introductory video shows 4 different people and how they responded to the occupation, and promises that the museum will show you the various choices that people made regarding resisting the regime. It doesn't. It's a disorganized, not-very-well-laid out exhibit that gives the impression that there really WASN'T any kind of organized resistance. Worth seeing if you have some time to kill but overall disappointing. Don't go out of your way to see this unless WWII history is your thing.

Thought-provoking museum. Best museum to visit - well laid out with loads of personal stories and displays. Harrowing and moving in equal measures. Particularly liked the children's area - following the fate of several different youngsters throughout the occupation.

DUTCH RESISTANCE & MORE. Top tour charting the world war two years through The Occupation of the Nazi's, encompassing the Resistance movement & the suffering at large of the Dutch people. A point that had never before crossed my mind is explained how the people in the Dutch Colony's fared under the Occupation of the Japanese & the aftermath of world war 2 & the handing back of the Colony's to the respective people & the repatriation of those people back to Holland.located in the same street as The Artis Zoo, nicely adjacent to a tram stop!

Good Museum. Gave great history of what happened to the Dutch people during the 2 world war. Cab driver said i was his first tourist in a few years to ask to go there. Don't know why, but made me feel good to go see what only the local people are going to see. I say its a must see even more than the art stuff.

Maybe my favorite museum?. Fantastic museum. Excellent history. Full disclosure: I teach social sciences. The layout of the museum is great and offers interesting insight into why the Dutch try to be so currently open-minded. No audio guide necessary.

Very interesting!. I really enjoyed the personal stories of individuals that were involved or affected by the Resistance movement in the Netherlands during WWII. We were there over 2 hours. Well worth the time and cost!

Lots of reading, very insightful. Fantastic look at how WW2 effected the Dutch with various artefacts and stories mainly from the prospective of inhabitants of Amsterdam. There is lots of reading involved to make the most of the trip, and I wouldn't recommend taking children. It's good value for money. Free WiFi throughout.

A. This museum was well laid out and well marked. Everything was labeled and well displayed. The whole experience gave a thorough understanding of what life was like for the people living in Amsterdam. A visit in conjunction with the Anne Frank House gives a complete picture of the time period.
Great insight. Taking you through the stages of WW2 and the rise of the resistance movement & the awful conflict faced by the Dutch where their support lay; the invaders or the resistance movement.

little gem. This was one of the best things we did in Amsterdam , it was very interesting and educational and even though we were adults we loved the children's section Don't miss it right across from the zoo but much better and really easy to get to on the tram
Great adjunct to Anne frank house. We learned a lot about life in Holland during WWII from this museum. Great for adults and older teens but maybe not so much for the under 15 crowd.

informative and moving. we had a bit of trouble finding this museum. it is right across from the zoo but needs a better sign along the street. once found it was worth the visit. it is mostly photos, memorabilia and text in small boxes along the walls. shows a good cross section of history of this period. I would have liked more places to sit down and rest. the stories were very moving. you have to lock up your back pack so be prepared.
A different perspective. Certainly gives a good idea of what life was like under occupation, thought provoking and looked at all the options open to the dutch

Wonderful exhibits. This was a wonderful opportunity to get grounded in what transpired in the Netherlands during WWII. The exhibits are well presented. Lockers are available to stow your gear so you can walk around unencumbered. Bathroom was very clean. Highly recommended.

Adapt, collaborate or resist?. This wasn't an amazing museum but was definitely worth a visit, raising questions about the choices people make when their country is occupied. There was a little too much text for me - and too much of a division between the adult museum and the children's museum. The latter was fantastic for kids but I would have preferred it mixed in with the rest of it. Some of the artefacts and photographs were amazing, my favourite part of the museum - like the small piece of paper with the tiny code and the paper hidden inside a wristwatch. The material relating to the Jewish population and what happened to them was very sobering and eerie.

If you want a flavour of WW2, this museum informs big time. This museum was added to our day almost as an after thought, given that it required a bit of a walk away from the center of Amsterdam. It is across from the city zoo. This is a relatively small museum that provides much information and gives the visitor a strong sense of Amsterdam during the warWW2. It outlines the history of occupation, the decimation of the Jewish population, and the bravery of those individuals who fought the occupation and tried to help their fellow citizens. It is provocative because it asks the visitors to imagine whether they would have been resistors or collaborators. Information is provided in different formats that maintains the visitors interest. English descriptions are available.

An must-see addition for your things to do. The main attractions (Van Gogh, Rijks and Annr Frank) were far too busy that day, so we opted for the less busy but as equally fascinating Dutch Resistance Museum. There is a lot of information to read alongside accounts of people's experiences under Nazi occupation but gives you a sense of how the Dutch felt and what they were subjected to. The children's exhibit is just as fascinating for adults, giving you a story into four children's experiences as a Jew, collaborator, etc and the conclusion of their lives. There is also an interesting section of the Dutch involvement helping the Indonesians who were under Japanese occupation. For those wanting another insight into Dutch history and those who have an interest in WWII history - this museum is a must.

Brilliant. If you are a history buff or just want to get a feel for the identity of the people...this is a must see. Strikingly thought provoking museum, offers up an engaging experience. Balanced in its approach and interactive, this really does provide a unique insight into the character of the Dutch spirit - their sacrifice, courage and inventiveness.

Emotional and Involving. The museum immerses you in the details of 1930's and 1940's pre-war and occupation Netherlands. There are many different interactive displays that draw you in and help you feel what it was like to be there. The fates of the Jewish people are especially challenging. By the end, I felt a little bit like the man who couldn't really celebrate the end of the war, because he was too emotionally spent. I spent a full two hours and listened to nearly everything on the audio guide.

Moving. We had decided to visit this museum rather than Anne Frank before we set off on our trip, mainly because of the excellent reviews, and the fact we did not fancy queuing for Anne Frank Museum.We bought tickets for this as part of the Hop On Hop Off Bus Tour, so saved money on the ticket and also saved money on Bus Tour as we purchased a combi.We arrived before it opened, and so went for breakfast. Don't go to the cafe next door, the waitress there was very blunt when we asked for food. Despte menus being on the table she told us they did not serve food until 11. Walk to end of the street and there is a large cafe with outside seating. Very friendly and great food.Anyway, back to the museum. The staff were very friendly and polite as they checked us in. We took the audio tour and went around clicking our device and listening to what happened. It was a very moving exhibition explaining the plight of the Jews during the war, and very sad in parts.It took about an hour to walk around and see everything, but well worth every minute. Definitely recommend it! Very Moving

A gem.. This museum is on the way to being perfect in regard to the way it totally involves the visitor. Having lived in Amsterdam for 40 years and considering myself pretty much aware of it's history I was amazed by all I learned from my visit here. The visit, I should add, that was quite unscheduled, we wee supposed to be going to Artis, the Amsterdam Zoo, across the road!

topic that every country should examine. Very interesting. Not a museum with a lot of artifacts but one that sets you thinking. How does one cope with a formerly friendly neighbor who does a hostile take over. In day to day life what do you do. Thought it gave a reasonable take on the subject. Adapt, Collaborate or Resist. I think the title has a bit of revisionist history attached. In the mirror people tend to remember resistance more than the day to day Adapt that the overwhelming number of people did as in every country.

Definitely worth a visit!. A total gem of a museum. We allowed 1.5 hours for our visit and were still there after 3 hours as it was just so interesting and engrossing. Well presented, well curated and well laid out, this is definitely worth a visit. The current extra exhibition on those taken to the concentration camps was unbearably sad and so well done - simple, understated and all the more powerful for that. Do not miss this!

Interesting place, lots of media. More an occupation museum. I wasn't quite sure what resistance was undertaken, but still an interesting 1.5 hours. Closes at 5. The audio guide was easy to use and interesting, but you don't need one.

Interesting but could be better!. We were given a audio guide which helped but there were also English translations as well as Dutch! Very moving and lots of artefacts, films, letters and personal stories which really helped you to empathise! I thought it would have been better to direct you by numbers which way to go, as there were different ways to traverse through the museum, but overall very thought provoking!

Great to visit before Anne Frank Huis. The museum does a great job of posing the question to you - what would you do if your country was occupied? It comes to focus mainly on those who chose resistance. Definitely do the audio tour - we found that all the audio tours we used in Amsterdam were excellent and very helpful. This is a must do if you are visiting the Anne Frank Huis. The two together will give you a more comprehensive picture of that time.

Very educational. The 'regular' part of the museum is a bit static, but definitely interesting. There's plenty to see and it paints a very clear picture of the second World War. The museum is off the beaten path, but for history enthusiasts a must visit. Especially the kid's section is gorgeous and fresh. I loved the presentation and how interactive it was. Even as an adult, I spent most of my time there, exploring every last inch of each little 'house'. Definitely recommended.

Amazing. this is a great museum providing an excellent companion to the Anne Frank house..plan on 90 minutes to walk through the experiences of the Dutch people during World War II...we all (probably) would like to think we would resist the Nazi occupation.. the decision is not so easy at the time.. this museum shows all the alternatives.. will make you think and you will be touched

Excellent Experience. Every nation wants to tell their own story their own particular way and the European phenomenon of "resistance museums" is so exception. As a student of history, the Resistance Museum was very interesting. The audio tour (included in the visit) is very interactive and all the primary source material is presented in interesting and interactive ways; very creative.

You need at least two hours here, possibly three.. It is somewhat difficult to find but it was worth the effort. The Dutch people were asked to keep diaries of their experiences during the war, and here you get to learn what it was like to be occupied by the German forces.

Tolerance Even Here. The Resistance Museum captured my attention for over three hours. Whether collaborating, hiding, resisting, or just trying to stay alive...the stories and truths are compelling and the pictures and personal items are touching, many tragic. I spent over an hour in the special exhibition about the children's transports and read every narrative. The entire space was quiet, sobering, and still making it easy to really feel the enormity of both WWII's braveries and horrors.
Dutch courage. This museum gives you an understanding of the resilience and bravery of the 'ordinary' Dutch citizen during the war. Well worth the visit.

Very Interesting. From my hotel, we took a tram to Central Station and then took a bus which dropped us off close to the museum. The zoo is also located nearby so you could visit both on the same day. The museum depicts the struggles the Dutch people endured during the occupation by the Nazis. A must see when in Amsterdam.

Powerful stuff. This is opposite the zoo and I'm glad we went in here first as we needed some light relief afterwards.It provided a fascinating insight into Dutch life from the 30's through the war years and just beyond. The temporary exhibition Where have all the children gone had me in bits. It was heartbreaking to read personal testimonies but I'm still glad I went.

Thought provoking and moving. I visited a week ago with my 16 year old son who is interested in history. I personally learned a lot about the backgroud to the resistance and the occupation of the Netherlands. For my son it was also a good place to visit before going to the Anne Frank Huis - it put the visit in context for him. His discussions about it since make me realise the museum had a big affect on his thinking. Some criticisms have been about everyting being in Dutch but the museum has obviously addressed this and information is also in English now and very accessible. In addition there are free audio guides although we opted not to use these. Well worth a visit.

Very moving! . I have always been fascinated with the resistance movements in Europe during WWII, so this museum was at the top of my must-see list in Amsterdam. I was not disappointed! The free audioguide is an excellent companion to the museum, which is packed with artifacts and first-hand accounts of resistance in Amsterdam. Be sure to take the time to read the placards and explore the interactive displays. The entire museum takes several hours to see if you do the whole thing. An excellent exhibition!

Very extensive and detailed.. The museum covers the immediate pre-war years, the invasion, the occupation, the transportation of Jews, forced labor, and the efforts at resistance to the hungry winter and the Allied liberation. It is based on objects, oral history in videos, newspaper cuttings, posters, and documents from these times. There is also a slight reference at the end to the Dutch East Indies occupied by the Japanese.

well worth visting. very good telling you lots about the resistance to the war and shows you lots of what went on really sad in places when you go in the childrens room with all the names on the wall well worth the vist

Thought provoking. The lady at the desk said it would take about an hour to go round this museum, but we found it so interesting we stayed almost 3 hours. Make sure you asked for the translation headsets in your language (they are free) for extra information as well as the notices on the walls which are both in English and Dutch. The overall theme of museum was how the people felt and coped at the time of occupation so gave you a lot of food for thought of what you would have done in the same situation - bearing in mind no-one really knew about the concentration camps etc - Hindsight is a wonderful thing! We really enjoyed our visit here and would go again. The only "negative" aspect was a wonderful area showing how the children coped at time of war - but unfortunately all the information was only in Dutch! A shame as there was a lot of interaction to keep children amused and interested.

Fascinating. I thought before I visited that the museum was solely about resistance to the war. In fact it poses the question of what would you do in a similar situation and shows some who collaborated as well as those who resisted which made it all the more thought provoking for me. The museum is well set up for children. It also has information about what was happening in Dutch colonies during the war. A must see museum!

Lots of information. This museum had so much stuff to look at and read. I loved the videos they made. The best part was that they would demonstrate realistic examples for certain scenarios. So interesting and lots to learn here!
this is a must. a small museum near the zoo, but its really good. factual and interactive it has a real story to tell

Inspring and interesting. A little hard to find - doesn't stand out on the street but worth the hunt. A great insight into Amsterdam before and during the war. A slightly confusing layout. The section on the Dutch in Indonesia was particulrly interesting

Even more informative than the Anne Frank House!. I LOVE this museum! It is very informative, and a very well done museum. The children's exhibit is also very well done, so if you have children, please take them here! I went during the time between King's Day and Liberation Day, so I felt like I understood the culture a lot better after visiting this museum. It provided a lot of useful context to better understand other museums like the Anne Frank House. This museum was still very emotionally moving, and it did not have a huge line like the Anne Frank House. There is no line to get in, and a lot more material to go through, so I would recommend a couple hours for a visit! Definitely worth it if you want to learn something about Dutch history and better understand the city you are visiting!

Mixed feelings.... Lots and lots and lots of reading. But by three quarters of way through, both my husband and I just couldn't read any more through mental tiredness, and so we missed how it all ended up (but guess liberation was the end of the story!) We felt very tired when we left, after around 2-3 hours. However, it is all quite interesting and we learned a lot. Just far too much to read and take in, and some of layout quite confusing.It starts by telling you how occupation started and how demonstrations began and how the resistance came into being. However I felt disappointed in the sometimes trivial information presented as "resistance" i.e. just thoughts written down by someone who didn't want the Germans in their country, but couldn't do anything about it.There was no real substance as to what the resistance really was as an organised body and how they operated. For instance, I would like to have known about spies and their work and what the resistance really accomplished underground, but it was more an exhibition of people trying to demonstrate but being clamped down on, and the church openly trying to encourage people from the pulpit to take in Jews, and individual people that did so. If you can call that "resistance", well, I guess its all about what resistance really means.There was a large room about the Jewish children and 3 massive walls of photos and missing photos of the children from Amsterdam who died, although the list is not complete (Anne Frank is not on the list for some reason but didn't have time to find out why). I found this section unnecessary and should maybe have been in a Jewish museum, because it really had nothing to do with the resistance but more to do with Nazi evils. I would like to have seen a room about spies and what they did. I found the room about the children very sad, but nothing to do with the resistance, so why is it there?There was a section about how radio transmitters were banned and how individuals hid them under floorboards or made their own in defiance. Not sure if this really comes under "resistance" or personal "disobedience", but it was all interesting how they were put together.There was a large section on how the poplace co-operated with the Nazis out of necessity by going and working in Germany as there was little other choice, and that they were basically slave labour. All the reasons were given by individuals as to why they compromised. Although interesting, it was really nothing to do with the resistance at all.So, overall an informative museum but with a lot of unnecessary fillers which were time consuming and because of this, it was an anti-climax at the end, when we didnt read about how it all ended up. All in all there is nothing much about what the resistance accomplished to thwart the Nazi machine during the occupation. It was more to do with defiance of the spirit through lack of co-operation.

Historically significant. We enjoyed he Dutch resistance museum very much. We had know at the Netherlands was occupied during WWII but it was interesting to hear about the plight of the people at that time, as well as the resistance movement in Indonesia during and after the war. There were many English signs to read and an audio guide. The only drawback was the ample amounts of schoolchildren visiting when we were there. It is nice that they learn the history and very important but they were not respectful to the tone of the museum. It took away from the sombre atmosphere and the importance of the message.

Fascinating tour for all ages. This is a fascinating tour for adults and children alike. Allow plenty of time to explore and take the free audio tour. It is definitely a good place to visit after you see the Anne Frank house. Loved it!

Involves a lot of reading but worth the visit. This museum covers not only the activities of the Dutch resistance but also touches on those who collaborated with the Germans and those who felt too afraid to get involved. It hugely informative but has a lot of information to read. Personally I feel this museum could be better laid out but don't reject it based on that. I dispensed with some of the exhibits as my feet and back we're quite sore near the end. However, my discomfort pales in comparison to what the ordinary Dutch people endured during the occupation. This museum is a little off the main area and nowhere near the other museums but we'll worth the visit.

must see. This took some finding, big tip it is opposite the front entrance to the zoo, catch the tram to Artis. A really good reflection of what happened in Amsterdam during the second world wart, very good value

Wish we had more time to spend here. As a WWII obsessor, I could have spend hours in this museum. There is so much to learn, do, and see here that you'll want to spend at least an hour or two exploring. We decided not to go for the audio guide, but it seemed like there was more information on the guide explaining some of the artifacts left over from the war. You can either begin with the WWII section of the museum or the history of the Dutch royal family. We only managed to see the WWII part, which begins even before the German invasion, and takes you through the Nazi occupation of Holland right up until liberation. There are some fantastic personal stories both of heroes fighting in the resistance but also of collaborators who felt they had no other choice. Absolutely essential for any visit to Amsterdam.

Definitely don't miss this!. A friend recommended that I go see this, and I'm so glad she did. It takes you along a narrow winding route as the Netherlands descends into worse and worse aspects of Nazi occupation, with real-life stories of courage and resistance, right up to the moment of liberation. Best of all, it constantly challenges you to think -- what would you have done?
Well worth a visit. We made use of our Museumcard and were pleased we visited this museum it gave us an insight into the deprivation and resilience of the dutch people during WW2

Fascinating. Extremely interesting look at the heroes of a horrific chapter in history--the resistance fighters who put their life on the line to fight the Nazis. I suggest going here first thing in the morning when you are fresh and energetic as there is so much to read and see. Consider an audio tour as well--some of the explanation plaques are difficult to read.

Salutary but should be compulsory. There is a great deal packed into this museum and it gives a very authentic view of life in The Netherlands during the Nazi occupation.There is a preliminary film which lays the foundation for the rest of the experience, primarily the options open to every Dutch individual (unless you were Jewish) - collaborate, adapt or resist. Most of the rest of the exhibits are static but nonetheless, full of impact. Much of information is written in English as well as Dutch.The exhibits cover the social conditions contributing to the rise of fascism in Europe together with a vivid picture of life under a brutal regime. It also illustrates the bravery and stoicism of the Dutch people.Many of the stories are harrowing and cause one to wonder whether it could happen again. Sadly, I suspect it could.Everyone should visit this museum and thank their lucky stars they didn't live through it.
lots to see. thought we would take a look & ended up spending hours there! So much to read & see. Very good value as not expensive entrance fee.

impressive museum. Impressive museum about the Dutch resistance during WWII. It gives you insight information about how the Dutch handled the war that seems them fit: acceptance, collaboration or resistance. The different point of views from these Dutch people makes this museum very informative.I also appreciated the seperate youth division of this museum. Here 4 children (adults now who has survived the terrible war) tell you about their lives and choices made during WWII; from being a Jewish girl to help the German as part of the NSB Youth. Very interesting.This museum makes you aware that it's too easy to judge others of the choices they made, if you haven't been part of the WWII yourself.I definitely recommend visiting it. Anne Frank museum is more famous. But this museum completes it.I have spent 4 hours in here. It was much bigger than I expected.

Better than the Anne Frank Museum. This tranquil and moving museum offers as much information and poignant evidence as the Anne Frank Museum but without the queues. A beautifully curated collection which contextualises the ambivalent Dutch experience of the Nazi invasion. It is not afraid to confront the difficulties of the historical evidence of Dutch collaboration as well as the heroism of Dutch Resistance. There are some very moving personal stories and some harrowing accounts of transportation and separation.A must if you visit Amsterdam.

Well Worth The Time. This museum is a great tribute to those who fought with the Dutch Resistance. It has an excellent display of artifacts and informative story boards telling the tales of individual Hollanders. It is well organized and allows for easy navigation. Outstanding presentation of the Dutch in the second World War.

So, Oma's stories were all true!. Having been raised on another continent (Africa) by my immigrant family, I grew up listening to stories about occupied Netherlands and the hardships during WWII. How they went hungry, ate tulip bulbs, listened to a radio hidden under floor boards and of Opa arriving with a horse cart with food stolen from the German army. How Opa disappeared for weeks on end and that he ended up in surviving incarceration in Buchenwald.During my third visit to Amsterdam I decided that this museum was a must-do on my list. I am so glad that I did go. All the stories, which used to be fiction, became real. They DID experience all that I was told, the NSB-ers were despised and Opa was a very rebellious young Hollander indeed. Very brave, too! I could picture him as a young man, in stead of the tall old man I knew, who grew more frail and forgetful, but still growing flowers and vegetables in Africa.I can recommend it for anyone interested in the lives of those in occupied Holland, and especially for descendants of those who lived through the ordeals during that time. The story is told and the memory remains....

If you're into WWII you have to visit it. The museum is well organized with a lot to read and observe. I advise you to get the multimedia tour. The whole museum gives you a very good view of how Netherlands lived during the WWII and the nazi occupation.

Good account and questioning of the other side of war - enemy occupation!. Slightly misleading name as this museum is not really just about the resistance as we know it ie espionage, but rather what is was like for the Dutch population living under German occupation during 1941-5. Lots of text to read, but largely in good English ( a pity some of the original documents were not translated eg newspaper headlines)- much of it from personal accounts. Also lots of contemporary film clips, including 'soft' Nazi propaganda. Strong on the treatment of the 1000,000 Dutch Jews, and various mass strikes and uprisings, yet also good use of questioning : how would you have reacted to a similar situation? Knuckled down, rebelled, or actively resisted the Nazis' rule? There is a short film upstairs that gives a brief chronology and starts the questioning- see it first. There is a Junior museum at the rear but not sure if this is in English too. Allow 2-2.5 hours visit.

Excellent presentation of difficult subject. History of Holland during the Nazi occupation told in personalized stories as well as general outlines. Describes the difficult choices of flight, hiding, collaboration, resistance, or doing nothing faced by individuals. Special attention to the plight of Jews and the Holocaust in the country. Also a special area for current school kids to better understand what happened. Finally, there's even a section about the Japanese conquest of the Dutch East Indies and how Indonesia finally achieved independence in 1949. Well written signage in Dutch and English make this a memorable visit.

very interesting. good insight into the Dutch's struggle during WWII. There is an abundance of information, allow plenty of time to complete. Maybe best to do first thing in the morning, as we found it quite tiring taking in so many facts.

Small museum but makes a big impact!. They have done a fine job of portraying life in the Netherlands leading up to and during the Nazi invasion/occupation. The displays and content draw you in at a personal level, challenging you to imagine the difficult choices and bravery of the Dutch during this terrible time in their history.

Must See. For the true Amsterdam experience, you must live in Holland before, during and after the Nazi occupation. If you spend a couple of hours here, you will leave with some of this experience; the horror, the courage, the frustration, the hope, the perseverence, the difficult decisions and the sacrifices of hundreds of people. Here are well-documented life stories that you may find incredible, inspiring or hard to understand yet the stories are real and reflect the greater story of human survival.

Small but interesting. This museum was included on our iAmsterdam card, but we would have gone there anyway. I had no idea how much the Dutch suffered during the Second World War, and how much they tried to resist the Nazis. Explanations were in English and Dutch, a little small occasionally, but well laid out. Very moving and interesting.

Fascinating and well-organised. This is a very well-organised museum that takes a slightly different approach to WWII-era history. The focus on the subtle and more revolutionary ways that the Dutch resisted the Nazi occupation is absolutely fascinating. As a non-Dutch speaker it would have been helpful if the printed items (such as wartime posters or newspapers) could have been translated as I was sometimes left really curious about certain parts of the exhibit, but not speaking Dutch is certainly my own fault! Highly recommended museum.

So interesting!. This is a well done museum experience, explaining the Holocaust and occupation by the Nazis in the Netherlands. Lots of information and was one of our favorite museums of our visit to Amsterdam! For anyone interested in WWII or the Holocaust, this is a must!!

Understanding History. This modern, well laid out museum looks at Holland in the lead up to WWII, the rise of the NSB, following onto the period of occupation (1940 to 1945).The main points are covered like the general strike of 1941 and other strikes that followed; what it was like to be under occupation, the Royal family in exile, the implementation of the deportation of Jews, the resistance and how these organisations evolved. Many people’s views and stories are displayed along with individual photographs, archival photos, ID cards and papers and items that showed what it was like to be an occupied country or part of the resistance movement. The display culminates with liberation, and the outcome for Holland. There is also a small section on the Dutch colonial Empire and WWII in Java. Here thousand of Dutch men fought against Japan.I found this museum very interesting. The stories that are told on the boards are very honest and very human. Some stories made me smile at a person’s defiance or tenacity; others brought tears to my eyes. Always reminding me how fortunate I am never to have lived through a war, while applauding the courage of those who stood up for their beliefs, and in some cases risked their lives for unknown “someone”. For the betterment of our world stories like these need to be told. To add another layer, visit to the Hollandsche Schouwburg Memorial, down the street and around the corner on Plantage Middenlaan. This was the Jewish deportation depot to the death camps. Across the road is a small plaque that identifies the Jewish children’s nursery.Entry Cost E8.00, free with Museumkaart.Photography allowed; no flash.Visit time: allow about 2 hours or more to see all exhibits. If you just want to have a condensed overview without all the side rooms, probably allow about an hour or so.

Full of Sadness. Hard to give such a sad story a 5 rating as I did leave feeling sad, but also incredibly grateful for the life I have and with the hope we have learned something from that terrible time and with admiration for the brave souks who fought the good fight. Audio program helps I believe. Well thought out museum that has you thinking.

A reminder of what was paid for freedom. A superb museum that documents and narrates the story of Dutch resistance against the Nazis regime. Inspiring! (Most information is also in English as well as Dutch.)

Fantastic children's museum. My 13 yr old son really wanted to go and I'm so pleased we did. The children's museum section, was one of the most engaging, interactive and immersive museums I have been to. You need to ask for a translating gadget as you go in, as we had to go back for one later. Go in to the children's bit first, then do the other sections, just to make sure you have given yourself plenty of time to explore all the integrative drawers, pictures, suitcases etc.
Waste of time and money. It could be part if Anne frank house, its almost at all an interactive museum.I was disappointed,and I think that just through away 8 euros

Very moving.. I had heard that the Dutch had a rough time during WWII, but seeing the specific stories and the artifacts made it clear that this was a very tough neighborhood, and the surviving Dutch were very tough or very lucky.

Great museum. We visited this museum on our last day in Amsterdam. It wasn't our first choice to visit this museum, but was surprised by how many good reviews it has received so we gave it a try. The price was very reasonable and came with free audio description which was good as most the the displays were in Dutch. We gained a wealth of knowledge on the Dutch resistance and left feeling like we had learnt something new. The displays were very moving and made you value the life we live today.

Powerful Museum. The museum is a glance back to the time when the country took part in the resistance movement during the German Invasion and the museum has a rather vivid picture of the time. The displays are powerful and touching. You also get to know about a whole lot of personal details of the people of that time and the things they had to suffer and see on a daily basis. The museum is also good on the interactive quotient and making the visit worthwhile. The museum can be accessed via tram too since it has a stop for the museum.
small but reflective. good english transltions quiet environment neat the zoo more about the occupation than the resistance

The courageous must never be forgotten. This museum is dedicated to the Dutch resistance and their courage against the Nazi invaders of their country, but it also gives an account of the hardship suffered by Dutch nationals during WWII. It was an educational experience for those of us who did not live through that period, stimulating an appreciation of the cost of standing up to the oppressor. The children's section of the museum was very good, especially the mock up house interior showing how people hid to avoid capture and the harsh realities of discrimination. Anyone interested in the history of WWII should visit. Allow at least 2 hours. Entrance is almost opposite the Amsterdam Zoo.

You will find it opposite the Zoo entrance. My father went into Holland from the Normandy Beaches, 3rd Canadian Division he told of the atrocities and starving that he saw in Holland and what good work rgw Resistance Movement done.

Good for children but sadly lacking some key parts of history. First, let me start by saying what I thought was good about this museum. It did a really good job detailing life under the occupation during WWII. Having grandparents who lived through this and having read a significant amount about Holland and WWII, much of this was very accurate. I found this part very interesting. The best part of the museum was the children's section. My son spent a significant amount of time in that section, and even as an adult, I found it quite interesting. This section didn't romanticize the Dutch that everyone resisted, but showed the children how different people made different choices. The fault I have with the museum comes at the end, when they have an exhibition on the liberation of Holland. Canada is rarely made mention of, although they were the army who freed most of the Netherlands. The D-day landings were described as only the Americans and British. The Canadians, despite taking one of the five beaches, were not mentioned. The current Canadian flag is not displayed, although the old flag is (most people don't even know this is the Canadian flag though). When I spoke to one of the staff about this, she said that since Canada fought as part of the Commonwealth, it was lumped together with the British. When I mentioned to her that Canada in fact fought during WW2 with its own army and that the First and Second Canadian Army liberated most of the Netherlands, she said that since Canada was a part of the Commonwealth, they were not mentioned as an independent country. I found this quite offensive to the sacrifices of the more than 7600 Canadian soldiers who died liberating the Netherlands, and to the many more soldiers who lived with horrific memories of that time. Most Dutch people are very grateful for the Canadians who sacrificed to free their country, but the person at the museum was quite unyielding. While Canada is a part of the Commonwealth, they declared war as an independent country, not because they were compelled to by Britain.

Well worth doing. Out of town, but taxis happy to take you there. Well worth a visit, very interesting, very moving. Directions round museum could be better but it does work (go right on entry!). Cafe next door also good and you get one drink free after your visit.
So much information. This is a place to visit more than once. You can't possibly take it all in at one time. There is excellent information here.

Thoughtful and compelling. If you are into WWII history this is a wonderful museum that really tries to take a deeper look into what happened in Netherlands at that time. English signage, easy to find by tram and included in the Museum Pass.

Poor layout, not at all engaging. I have visited many different museums all over Europe regarding the WW1 and WW2 (to include The Warsaw Uprising Museum in Warsaw, The Great Patriotic War Museum in Kiev etc) so I had been very much looking forward to this one.My own opinion was that it was very poor, I felt the layout was pretty terrible and the way the information and items exhibited awful (you have to looked through small windows and in many can't properly see some of the items or descriptions.I didn't enjoy it and felt my time could have been better spent at one of the other museums in the city.The pros however were that it is in English as well as Dutch and it was very easy to find and get to on the tram.

Important to remember. . .. This museum presents the situation of the Netherlands and Amsterdam during the resistance. The section of the children´s camps and their separation from their families is especially moving. There was a small, temporary exhibit in the lobby about the "Memoria Historica" in Spain (the problems of finding burial sites of victims of the Spanish Civil War) in Spain.

A must for history lovers. Although the museum hours were not the most convenient (11:00-17:00), I loved this museum. The museum entrance is free with the Iamsterdam card and also offers free audioguides (whether or not you have a card). The museum was very interactice and had so much information that my friend and I visited who at 3:30 in the afternoon didn't feel like we had enough time to thouroughly explore the museum before it closed at 5:00. The exhibit takes you through the history of the war as told from the Dutch perspective with general facts of the war and resistance in the Netherlands and snippets of personal accounts from Dutch and Jewish people living in Holland as well. I love history and have been to many museums that explore WWII history, but this museum was unique in that it offered a different, more specific perspective. The museum surpassed my expectations and I only wish I had more time to pass there!

Moving. Lots of great facts and information about WW2, particularly the involvement of the Netherlands and the hardship of the Jews. Definitely worth a visit. Only downside is that the majority of their artefacts are just replicas. Can be done quickly in an hour or less, but allow more time if you have it. It is very interesting and you will want to take more time in order to pay your respects.

Do not miss this museum. This is, without a doubt, the best museum I have ever been to. It was so well done and well presented. It brought you back to those days and made you really feel what it was like to be both Dutch and Jewish. The special exhibit on the childrens concentration camp was so more moving than anything I have seen. Do not miss this museum. Fabulous!

Superb and very Educational. We visited here as a family as our son is just learning about WW2 at school, We spent hours in here walking around looking at the various displays, all the descriptions are in Dutch and English and the audio tour (free of charge) is a must, point it at the contact point and you get an English walk through of the area you are in, we all thoroughly loved this museum and is a very good use of a few hours

Poorly Laid Out. This was my second visit to the Dutch Resistance Museum (first visit in Jan '13).The free audio guide is quite good and goes into more detail than the displays and there is quite a lot of information to take in.Some of the displays are quite poignant, especially the ones that talk about the families and children being deported to the work/death camps.Having said that though, this museum is so terribly laid out that it makes trying to make sense of it a bloody hard task. When you enter there is a cinema on the left but there are no signs to point it out and the staff at the desk fail to tell you about it. When you enter the museum there are a few red arrows on the ground that point you in the right direction to begin with but then just stop so you are left aimlessly wandering around jumping from the start of the war to the liberation. It wasn't just me that thought this - a few couples that I talked to thought the same. Why not just carry on with the arrows on the floor throughout the whole exhibit?This COULD be a great museum but it is so poorly laid out that it ruins it.

A full and engaging museum. I highly recommend that anyone with an interest in WWII history visits this museum, it wonderfully lays out the extent of the resistance movement; and what daily life was like, in Holland under the Nazi occupation. The free audio tour included with entry (€8 - fantastic value), is not strictly necessary for Dutch and English speakers, as the display signs are in those languages but I recommend taking a set as you can both read and listen in the museum at your own pace.There is also an excellent separate section of the movement about the Dutch resistance against the Japanese militants in the Dutch East Indies/Indonesia.I was very impressed by the integrity of the museum, which displayed details of events and individuals opinions "as they happened" and without any sort of bias or spin.N.B. All of the street signs to the museum are in Dutch, so look out for the Verzetsmuseum

Historical museum that gives meaning to what happened in Holland during WWII. Small museum across the street from the Amsterdam Zoo. Gives realistic audiovisual history of the monstrous time of the Nazi occupation of Holland, and how people responded to this cruel time. Not for kids under 16. (My opinion). It's the other side to the Anne Frank story.

history museum with an important story. This museum does a great job of telling the story of what happened in Holland during the war -- and the agonizing choice between collaboration and resistance. They have a good collection of artifacts, and the audio guide is one of the best I've heard in a history museum.If you can't get into the Anne Frank museum on your trip to Amsterdam, this museum is a good second choice.

A moving experience. Be prepared to be moved by the stories you will learn here. The audio guides are free, and worth taking along on your visit. It is all very well set out, with clear explanations in both Dutch and English. There is a large variety of historical items, photos and documents, presented in different ways. Although small in area, it is very intense in the amount of information presented. Very clearly shows how difficult it must have been to live under the occupation.

Worth visiting. The 20 reviews prior to mine describe all the various facets of a visit to this well-planned museum. The thought-provoking central idea of what can individuals living under an occupation do - collaborate, ignore, or resist - is the thread of the museum. Currently there is a heart-rendering special exhibition on the mass transit of Jewish children and their mothers and some fathers from here to Auschwitz on June 6-7, 1943, where they were all exterminated upon their arrival.

An excellent understanding of world war Holland. We have been in Amsterdam 10days and thought we had run out of attractions that interested us. We decided to walk to this Museum after reading good reviews on Tripadvisor and we were not disappointed. The museum was well laid out and an audio guide was included as part of the 8 euro admission price. The exhibits were well-curated and provided an excellent set of resources including poignant letters and forged documents. There was also a section on Indonesia and how the Dutch were affected there. It made you realise what a resilient people the Dutch are to survive what they went through.

Well worth a visit. Make sure you allow a couple of hours to fully appreciate this gem of a museum (sadly we didn't!). The free audio tours are great but make sure you ask for one as we weren't originally offered one at reception.

An unexpected gem. Went here as we were particularly interested in the period. Thought it was one of the best parts of our visit, really though provoking and interesting even if you are not that into history. Give it a try, you won't be disappointed.

not to be missed!. this museum gives you the feeling of what it was like to live in Amsterdam during WW11! The building was actually used as the first stop in the deportment process, and the current streetcar across the street figures prominently in the history.

Irresistable. A sad but inspiring presentation of Dutch resilience and courage. Despite danger and the threat of death so many took huge risks to stand up for their rights and protect the Dutch people.The story is told with multi media enriched real life exhibits which pull at one's emotions.I was impressed to see so many children with their parents reliving the lives of four of the survivors from different backgrounds. The Junior exhibit is thoughtfully constructed.

A real sleeper. Tremendous museum I'd never even known about in previous visits. An incisive view of life under the Nazis and its cost to the population. Superb educational experience. Right opposite the zoo. A slice of history not available elsewhere and the objects, visual displays, and information displayed add up to an unforgettable experience.

Superb find. For some reason this wasn't in our Lonely Planet pocket guide to Amsterdam but we saw it on one of our maps and thought we would check it out. It was a little out of the way from most of the attractions but only a 10 minute ride by tram from the city centre. The Museum offers great information on the 2nd world war from a Dutch point of view. As part of your entrance fee which was about 13 Euros, you get headphones that can be activated at certain points offering you a better experience. Worth a visit if you like or love your History.

Very confused. The audio tour only repeats what the information signs give. Unfortunately the switches that activate each element are small, difficult to find and not in the same place in each section which means that you spend as much time trying to find out how to get the info as you do listening to it. There wasn't quite as much information as we had expected and the confused layout didn't help understanding. We doubt we'd go again and would only recommend it if you've seen everything else in Amsterdam you'd like to see - it's not a priority (which is a pity as it should be a fascinating topic.)

Very well done museum, gives insight.. Very well done museum on a very difficult time for the Dutch people. Well laid out, thought provoking, easy to get to by tram. This coupled with the visit to the Anne Frank Huis provides some perspective on what occurred in Amsterdam during WW II, Would suggest getting the audio guide as if you do not language may be an issue.

Thought provoking. A well laid out and interesting museum, with text explanations in Dutch and English. Very moving to hear the stories of some of the people and an insight into the terrible suffering and of the resilience and courage of the Dutch people during WW2.

Powerful and extremely well done.. The museum posits several questions - without offering judgement. What would you have done under the same circumstances faced by the local populations with the growing presence of the Nazis: Ignore, Resist, SupportVarious real life scenarios were presented, with the real life choices made by the people being profiled. Important museum to visit.

WWII History - The Dutch Experience. Well set out, good audio guide. Probably too much information for most people. If you have a particular interest in this period of history you will be stimulated by a visit this museum.
Most enlightening. This is a thought provoking place to visit. It is very well done and provides all sorts of examples and details of what it was like to be in Holland during the Second World War.

Well worth the visit. I am an American living in Denmark. My sister is the family historian and I never paid much attention to family history -- until a recent driving vacation through Germany, Luxembourg, Belgium, and the Netherlands. Lots of highlights and a few low ones. Among the best of the highlights was the Dutch Resistance Museum in Amsterdam. I will admit that much of my family background is Dutch and Belgian, but in a few hour trip to this museum really impressed on me the courage of many ordinary Dutch citizens during WWII. The "junior" or youth part of the museum was perhaps the most interesting because it is highly interactive and informative, highlighting the lives of four real Dutch youth from four very different family backgrounds and ideological backgrounds. The museum is at some level overwhelming because there is so much written (both Dutch and English) and audio (Dutch and English) information that can be processed. So many displays that nicely flow. We spent probably three hours at the museum and could have spent much longer. It is an easy walk from the central train station, is adjacent to the Jewish quarter, across the street from a zoo and botanical garden ... very easy to spend a day in a contained area. Also, we found Amsterdam fairly high-priced by US standards - about average by Danish standards -- but this museum was reasonably priced. If you want to eat before or afterwards, be prepared for a bit of a walk -- that was probably the drawback.

A highlight of our trip - recommend.. This really is an excellent museum. Considering the relatively small area it occupies, they have managed to squeeze so much into this place but there isn't a sense of things being crammed in. The exhibits are well presented in Dutch and English and touch on some quite powerful subjects around the occupation of the Netherlands and the Dutch colonies during WW2. There are lots of physical artefacts to support the written exhibits; for example, a crystal radio design that was developed by a young resistance member and a baby pram with a handgun hidden in the cot. These add depth to the accounts of the other exhibits and make for a well rounded, well informed, and at times quite saddening experience. You can pay extra for an audio guide, but if you're travelling on a budget it is still a great experience without one - we didn't bother and still took a lot away from it.This museum really made us think about an area of the Second World War which is rarely taught in history in British schools, and gave us a huge respect for the people of the Netherlands and a real appreciation of the freedoms of modern life that we enjoy daily. Thought provoking, powerful, and well presented. You can get in here for free with an i-amsterdam card but if you don't have one it's still worth paying the admission fee (which at €8 for an adult is pretty good value given the prices of other places) to get into one of the best museums I've ever visited. A must see for a trip to Amsterdam.

Very good but ....... This museum is well worth a visit. See several reviews. Sad, poignant but not horror! You come away shaking your head at how futile war is.... I admire the Dutch people for the stance they took. Unfortunately they were 'duped' by propaganda and victims of their own naivety. All very pertinent to this exhibition. It was encouraging to see how good can overcome evil. My gripe with the museum was the background noise. I could barely hear the audio with the sound effects from other parts - I pointed this out to one of the staff @ reception. She advised it's part of the exhibition - but for me it was far too loud! It took away from what could otherwise have been a totally absorbing experience. TIP: Avoid when school tours are in progress. (For obvious reasons - 30 / 40 kids scurrying about). Have a coffee or two & let them go ahead. But don't let it put you off. Amsterdam has so many places to visit / this one will have a lasting impression.

Visit. I enjoyed the layout and the presentation. Plenty of room to wander. The only downer was that the staff had to provide a large number of audio units to visiting children so the adults who paid full price miss out. Doesn't seem right

Excellent museum.
