We really enjoyed a couple of hours at the Resistance Museum, which was very informative and interesting.The staff at reception were really great and friendly - and we made use of the excellent audio guide.Only my youngest daughter made it to the Children's exhibition which has just won a national award, but she said that it was a fantastic addition to the whole museum - even featuring a replica of Anne Frank's house.With so much else to do in Amsterdam, we were delighted to have spent the time at this museum.Excellent !!!

Informative. This museum is very interesting as it covers the Dutch resistance to nazi Germany during 1940-1945. The museum has a free audio tour & while small in size has loads of information. We went to the maritime museum & then walked over to the verzetsmuseum - a short walk. We used our museumkaart to get in. Entrance is located opposite artis zoo.

Interesting. The museum is a great museum, they have so much they want to share....and there is literally too much information. I felt that it was scattered and disjointed. I love museums and in particular, I love WWII museums and exhibits. They have so much information at this museum, that it really could be something great, if it were organized and displayed better. It was almost as if they took every piece they had collected and decided that it had to ALL be displayed at the same time. Some of the displays were also difficult to read and see as they were deep shadow boxes, and flush to the wall making it difficult to read the pieces they placed on the sides of the boxes. All that said, had I been prepared for the presentation and load of info, I think I would have enjoyed it more.

Well-presented exhibits about Dutch life during World War 2. The Verzetsmuseum is just located across the Artis Zoo and is an excellent companion piece to the Anne Frank House. It features impressively presented multimedia exhibits about Dutch life before, during and after the Second World War. Descriptions and annotations of the displays have English translations and if that isn't enough, your 8 Euro entrance (for adults) comes with a free podcatcher for audio descriptions. The museum covers the plight of Jews, Dutch collaborators, resistance fighters and even a special exhibit on the Dutch East Indies (now Indonesia) and its fight against Japan. But what really stands out are the deeply-moving temporary exhibition of the Children's Camp, where pictures of children shipped from the Netherlands who died in the camp are posted on the walls; and the truly excellent Junior section of the museum which follows the tales of four children (and others) during and after the war. The displays are interactive and adults will surely learn a lot from this section, since the subject and presentation is far from "kiddie" or sanitized.You can easily connect a visit from Anne Frank to the Verzetsmuseum (or vice versa) by riding Tram 14, getting off at Artis and a short walk to the Resistance Museum itself. There are a lot of cafes around the area in case you need a meal afterwards.

Interesting museum. As a child of Holocaust refugees, I am always interested in learning more about how the people of Europe coped with the horror of Hitler. We all know the story of Anne Frank, but this museum shows how much of Holland worked against the Third Reich. Very poignant vignettes of a variety of people - young and old - and how they responded to the occupation. Panels are in English and Dutch. My only negative comment is that the lighting is low, and the font size is small, so after a while I had to leave because my eyes had gotten too tired to continue.

Moving and very well set out.. The museum is described in English as being about the Dutch resistance, but it is also very much about how the people suffered during the war and as such is a very moving experience, particularly the 'Junior' room. This is incredibly sad, with its walls filled with the names and photographs of children - some only months old - who perished in the holocaust.The museum is set out in a very interesting way, with very comprehensive explanations about each section in English as well as Dutch. There is nothing 'stuffy' about it. Film footage from the time is used, as well as many artefacts. It certainly gives food for thought as well as being nteresting and educational.

Shouldn't be Missed!. This museum tells the little known story of the Dutch people's activities during WW II to try to protect their Jewish citizens from the actions of the Nazis. Very well presented and extremely informative.
Excellent. The museau it's very complete, the attention excellent, you have audiotour for free in different languages.

Excellent Museum. Amazing amount of information, and extremely moving. The museum is well presented and clearly signposted. We were very glad we visited this museum and it is well worth adding to your list.

Provides a good insight into the experience of the Dutch during WWII. This museum outlines the situation in the Netherlands leading up to WWII and the living conditions during that time. Lots of interactive displays and commemerations without being soul destroying.

very educational. We expected to be here for an hour but stayed 3 hours and if we had more time would of stayed longer. The exhibits made you think as to what you would do. Clearly there were many Dutch citizens at great risk to themselves and family resisted the Nazis. It is a great compliment to the Ann Frank house. I did not appreciate that Ann Frank's experience was duplicated by many others in Amsterdam.

Moving Beyond Words. This museum, located across the street from the zoo and only about a 10 minute walk from the flea market, isa in depth study of an occupied country. This museum is very well set up beginning with the occupation of The Netherlands to the Liberation. It tells the story of collaborators, resistance workers, and the plight of the Jews in Amsterdam.We must never forget the sacrifices people made to stand up for what they believed in.

Interesting museum for all ages. Explore a little known topic of WWII - the Dutch resistance.Get the audio guide for the full experience. The junior section gives the stories of actual children who lived through it and is well worth a detour for the adults as well. One tip - the tour isn't over with liberation so don't miss the post war section

Poignant and moving museum brings history to life. The museum uses an audio tour to guide you around a very moving subject and since I last went has added an area telling the stories of children during the occupation which is interactive and fascinating for adults with an interest in history as well as children. My husband and I found some areas quite disturbing but that is the point. don't forget what has happened in the past use that knowledge to prevent a repeat. This museum certainly achieves that goal.

BRAVERY REMEMBERED. For only 6 euros this fascinating museum is a must to visit whilst in Amsterdam.It is hard to believe how much the Dutch suffered during WW2 and this is evidenced in the excellent presentation at the museum. The free hand held audio set talked you through very clearly.In the adjoining cafe Plancius we enjoyed a lovely coffee whilst having a rest during our visit and you could return for a second cup free.Very sad revelations in this museum but so pleased to have made the visit.
So interesting. A cheap but fascinating museum with lots of interesting details about the occupation of Holland in WW2. The audio tours were very good and added to it.

Well worth a visit. Superb children's section, novel, interactive and informative of the sensitive subject. The adult section is also very informative across a broad spectrum on the socio-political situation and history of the times. Well illustrated, not overly detailed. The audio program on the hand held devices did not really contribute anything extra though it was free. A thoroughly worthwhile and enjoyable visit which helped me to better understand what my father and his family went through.
thought provoking. a very comprehensive museum that tells the story of the Dutch peoples resistance against the nazi regime during the second world war

Not much to resist here. The displays were informative but not terribly interesting. It seems the museum is labouring to offer a resistance story that really isn't there. The main lesson from this museum is that the Dutch did very little resisting and successfully eliminated the majority of their Jewish population under Nazi rule. Not exactly covering themselves in glory during one of Europe's darkest periods. At least their quick surrender and compliance meant the beautiful city of Amsterdam went unscathed by the war and remains a lovely city to visit.

Insights into extreme culture clashes. “Resistance” is a misnomer. At its most obvious level, the museum is about various ways, including collaboration, that Dutch citizens dealt with the Nazi occupation; joining the Resistance was only one way. The museum includes a significant and disturbing segment on responses in the Dutch East Indies to Japanese occupation. (All information is in English as well as Dutch, and it’s touching, troubling and impressive. There is a single set of stairs to an area I found of minimal interest; I think some kind of elevator/lift is present, which I think was for wheelchairs. I didn't notice whether stroller parking exists.)I only accidentally wandered into the East Indies part of the exhibition—when you enter the overall museum, you can turn left into this section (without yet clearly knowing what’s there) or right into what seems the larger, main flow of the museum. When, after turning right and navigating the larger and powerful account of Holland’s years under the Nazis, I finally turned into the Asian section and realized what it was about, I was struck by the darker side of Dutch wartime and postwar history—the terrible irony that once free of the Nazis, and once the Japanese were driven from the East Indies, the Dutch government spent four years trying to hold onto its Asian colony in ways that were not always different from what the Nazis and Japanese had done. One of the effects of the Japanese occupation was to breed an anti-colonialist resistance movement, headed by the not-so-enlightened Sukarno, to ANY occupation, Japanese OR Dutch.Beyond their historically and geographically local themes, the Nazi and Japanese occupations say something much more universal about the variety of ways in which human beings deal with their lives being turned upside-down. (There may even be a parallel to the Kubler-Ross 5-stages-of-mourning.) There’s certainly denial. For some there’s acceptance, for others a desire to benefit from the occupation, for others resistance. Most people, presumably want to protect themselves and their loved ones without fully knuckling under to the occupier. We most admire the active resisters, but I suspect we’re all tempted to less dramatic and less admirable responses when we confront the daily, seemingly endless challenges to our previous assumptions about life. The larger world is full of parallel examples. In the short run, there are places like Egypt, the Ukraine, the Crimea—places vivid in our recent memories as potential locations of reversal in the midst of new norms. In the longer run, we might think of North Korea and its decades-long fate with no apparent end in sight, or interactions between Israelis and Palestinians, or nations like India or Ireland with internal religious conflict, or nations in today’s world where millions of slaves continue to exist.And we might reflect on how these lessons, to the extent we can understand them, tell us about our own behavior on either end (are there only two?) of issues like how a national or local government should treat immigrants (especially during hard economic times) or marginalization of groups with behavior we consider fundamentally different from our own “norm” (for example, people with different sexual proclivities). I encourage readers to come up with their own examples, and, as you move through this museum, to project yourselves into what it would be like to be part of a group different from your own self-identification.

A must see if you are interested in WWII. Great museum telling the story of the Dutch during WWII. Headsets are included in admission, giving a good overview of exhibits. Temporary exhibit while I was there on Children's concentration camp was quite moving.

Ominous. Very good and informative museum. It looks a bit boring when you first go inside, but once you start browsing the exhibits chronologically, it mesmerises you. To see how it all happened, in the run-up to the war, as well as during the German occupation.No big, visually impressive exhibits, but a lot of very ominous documents and small items, with some funny ones to lighten the mood every now and again. The audio exhibits were also very interesting.A must visit for anyone interested in the history of World War II.I'd say you need about three or four hours to really see and hear everything, but if you are pressed for time, you could do it in an hour, but you'd have to skip quite a bit.

visit. the onoy detraction [and a considerable one] is this can be very confusing in terms of sequence. there are no numbers or arrows and the exhibitd are often roundabout. So. You may walk thryu only to find out--wait--already saw that. And, probablly missed something to boot. But, shouldnt be missed.

Great museum. Looks small from the outside but once inside it is like a Tardis. Great exhibits which bring home what it must have been like for the Dutch during the occupation. Good newsreel footage and artefacts. Spent about 2 hours there but would have like to have spent more time there but we had to get to the airport to travel home. Recommended if you are into information relating to that era

Very imformative. We really enjoyed the resistance museum and would definetly recommend other people to go there. It gives a lot of insight into what it was like live in Nazi occupied Netherlands. You get a free audio guide which you should really get.admission prices: Adults: € 8,-, Children 0-6: Free, Children 7-15: € 4,50You can get free admission with a iAmsterdam card or Museumkaart.Its quite a small museum but they have packed in loads the only downside is that there is no cafe which we would appreciated as our feet ache at the end of it so I think we would have stayed longer if we could have taken a break.

Great Value. We visited this museum not expecting much. this was so informative, we ended up missing allot due to having to leave for the airport. Give yourself at least 3 hours to take everything in. Very sobering and upsetting at times, but it is places like this that keep the memories and make us never forget those that perished.Well worth a visit, excellent value for money.

Excellent museum with a lovely setup. The museum itself is not very big, but offers extensive information on how ordinary Dutch citizens resisted Nazism. The whole setup is quite imaginative, and the entrance is free if you get the I Am Amsterdam card. Another 'plus' is that it is right opposite the Amsterdam zoo, so you can combine these two attractions and spend a great afternoon.

Informative and moving. This is a very interesting museum, with a lot of interactive figures and descriptions of the german Nazi era in Amsterdam and the Netherlands and the resistance movements. Beside all those reports, photos and videos of these terrible atrocities there are many memorabilia of the daily life.Actually there is a temporary exhibition: "They’ve taken all the children away”, it tells about the 1300 jewish children who have been billeted in the Vught concentration camp first and then brought to the Sobidor death camp. Very touching and moving!
Lot of reading. New exhibition about childrens transport, horrific to imagine. Was well set up with audio feeds which brought it to life.

Well coupled with Anne Frank House.. I really enjoyed the Resistance Museum. It was good to have an insight into the experiences of the Dutch people during the occupation and was a good place to visit after Anne Franks house as it was more general. It gives a good timeline of events and is easy to navigate. It does however seem like it could benefit from a bit of extra funding as it is a lot of written text and not much else, so I could have read the information from home. Also some exhibits only had information in Dutch. Still very enjoyable and worth spending a couple of hours there.
Brilliant after anne frank house. Really enjoyed reading all the personal experiences of Dutch people during the war. Very interesting and shocking

Interesting and good value for money. A really nice museum, we found it very interesting and thought it was good value for money. We got a headset as part of the entry which is a nice touch and offers additional information to the displays. Only downside was the lack of baby changing facilities as we had a 7 month old baby with us but this was not unusual in Amsterdam.

Interesting Place. This museum tells us what Holland had to endure during the war..One learns much as you walk through the exhibits. We were not given a listening device. I think we missed a lot by not having one. Do get one..

Brilliant Museum. We visited the Verzetsmuseum the day after visiting Anne Frank's House, so were already feeling a little emotional. This museum gave informative and comprehensive accounts of the lives of Dutch people under Nazi occupation; their resilience and suffering. Much of the content was extremely moving and tragic, especially that concerning the Jewish community including children. We spent several hours here, but wished we could have spent longer - it certainly warrants the largest part of a day. Highly recommended, everyone should visit as a tribute to these courageous people.

Very moving. A very moving museum, illustrating a difficult part of recent Dutch history.The museum illustrates the awfulness of Nazi occupation and the plight of the Jews ( and others) The transportation of the children is particularly harrowing This should be a compulsory visit, if only to prevent this situation from ever happening again.

Wonderful museum. I visited this museum in conjunction with a visit to the Anne Frank house. The museum (opposite the zoo) was wonderfully appointed, interesting and informative. As you'd expect, some of the information was deeply moving and upsetting but it is important that these sad stories are told. Spent a good couple of hours there, could have been more, but I had other places to visit. Bought a brilliant pamphlet whilst there for a euro that details the main sights of resistance in Amsterdam. A must see whilst in Amsterdam.
In Depth Museum. WE enjoyed the in depth information given from both sides of the Nazi Invasion -those Dutch who supported them and the Resistance- a top priority to see when in Amsterdam

Must be seen, before or after the Anne Frank House. This was such a good museum, really capturing the horror of the Nazi occupation in the Netherlands, and the reaction of the Dutch people to this. It works on very simple stories, which throw you into the lives and experiences of the everyday, and encourages you to confront your own thoughts about fascism and the abuse of power.
Perfectly complements Anne Frank House. Great exhibition of how the Dutch resisted the Germans as a nation during WW2. We spent over a hour but could have spent longer as so much to read

Worth a visit. A good layout and easy to follow the exhibition around. Very thought provoking ad reminds us of the horrors of the war.A short walk from here you will find a lovely windmill to see, a rarity in Amsterdam

BETTER THEN ANN FRANK MUSEUM!!. me and my friend went on the off chance to the museum after seeing it on the Amsterdam map for the afternoon. The museum was just like any other with interactive videos and recordings, thought provoking history and an amazing display of war history!! We spend over an hour in the museum and enjoyed it immensely without the busy crowds or need to rush to the end. Excellent value for money and helpful staff!!!

Well organized and lively displays- thought provoking. We went to the Verzetsmuseum through the 'Iamsterdam' card, as it was a tram ride away from central square. This also meant we had no entry fee to pay too.The staff were very helpful, and like most Dutch people, spoke excellent English. There's also a flea market nearby which is worth a gander.The museum has quite long opening hours and I was pleased to see it wasn't excessively busy. There is a huge amount of information and a whole variety of displays to absorb here, we could have spent twice as long as we did. The museum chronicles the history of Dutch colonialism through to the Nazi occupation of 1940-45.I very much valued my time here, the display about the Jewish families and children sent to concentration camps was particularly thought provoking and extremely moving.
A little resistance. Well laid out museum which benefits from the free issue headphones. Not much resistance more of a history of the Dutch people's dilemma and treatment under the Nazi occupation.
A gem. Excellent - we enjoyed this the most. Opposite the zoo. Tells story of 4 different Dutch people pre and post WW2. Very moving.

A real education and very much worth a visit. Unfortunately, we arrived at the museum just an hour before it closed for the day. It's extremely well organized and we could have spent twice as long there. The museum not only gives a lot of information about the Dutch Resistance, but also about the experience of the Dutch during World War II. This is a "must see".

You like history...come here!. The Dutch Resistance Museum (Dutch: Verzetsmuseum) is located in the Plantage neighbourhood in Amsterdam.The Dutch Resistance Museum, chosen as the best historical museum of the Netherlands[citation needed], tells the story of the Dutch people in World War II. From 14 May 1940 to 5 May 1945, the Netherlands were occupied by Nazi Germany.

Perfect museum for Dutch invasion era. More informative when compared to Anne Frank's house. Numerous visuals and papers dating back are presented in the museum. Upkeeping is also very good. All items are in perfect condition regarding their age.

Stirring Exhibits. This museum was located across the street from the zoo; public transportation made this museum very accessible. The exhibits, which included "tools" of the resistance, using everyday items including baby strollers was interesting.Letters and photos were a haunting reminder of the brave people who were fighting a very important underground war.
Great Follow-Up. Great follow-up to the Anne Frank House. While many go to Amsterdam for the art museums the history museums also have a lot to offer.

A fantastic museum to gain insight into mans inhumanity but also hope. One of the best museums we have seen for young and old to see the resistance to Nazi Germany. Still impossible to comprehend but vital the message is never forgotten.

Be prepared fpr an emotional trip.. Take the 9 tram from Central station and get off at the Zoo - strangely called Plantage - it is the next stop after the Botanical gardens. The Museum is just opposite the Zoo entrance and next to the Café Plancius. Eight Euros seems very reasonable for such a well laid out history of resistance and triumph in WWII. Most of the exhibits have a recorded commentary and two presses on the button will generally change it from Dutch to English. There is an explanation in English on all exhibits but the typeface is small and some are dimly lit making them hard to read. Don't miss the cinema set in the middle where a German film and contemporary newsreels are shown. Having passed the end of the war turn into the War in the Far East where all Dutch citizens living in the overseas territories had a very rough time. Go early as this is not a suitable museum for crowds as all exhibits are in small windows and need individual attention.

A museum with a difference. The displays were interesting. They told you the life of the various Dutch resistance people and how some of them gave up their lifes etc. Good displays. Slightly expensive to go in. We caught a canal bus down there and then visited it.

Well worth a Visit. Lots to see, amazing artifacts and great history of the Amsterdam population in Nazi Occupied Europe. From the hiding places to mini radios, secret messages and other great information

Enlightening. A previous reviewer complained that nothing was in english. After having visited the museum, I can't help wondering if they went to a different place! Absolutely EVERYTHING is clearly outlined in both Dutch and English. For other languages you are given free audio equipment.This museum took you on a journey through the war years from the perspective of the average dutch citizen. It was about much more than the resistance, it was about how the Netherlands coped with Nazi occupation. Admirably, it did not shy away from detailing the less heroic aspects either,explaining about collaborators and even the dutch peoples less than admirable actions as Colonial occupiers in the East Indies.If you have time to do more than the Rijksmuseum and Van Gogh museum this is definiately worth putting on your list.Just get a tram or bus to the zoo and it is on the opposite side of the road to the main entrance.

Well worth visiting. This was very well laid out, informative and engaging. The English text and audio guides were very clear. Well worth a visit for a good understanding of how the war affected Dutch lives. The cafe next door looks promising, but service was really slow and we were overcharged! I did query the bill and get a refund. Unfortunately this meant we didn't have time to go back and see the children's part of the museum which had looked interesting.

Interesting but layout was confusing.. The Verzetsmuseum went all out with the technology--there is a very good free audio guide and many of the exhibits are interactive. However, there was no clear guide as to which exhibits to follow, and I ended up seeing a lot of them out of chronological order, which was very confusing. Overall, a good visit. (Free with Iamsterdam card)

Very nice museum. Just like most of the museums in Amsterdam this one is top notch. Everything is in English and Dutch so you can enjoy all of the exhibits. The tour begins with a short film that asks the question "would you collaborate, adjust or resist" the germans. The exhibits give a good account from beginning of the german occupation to the liberation by the Allies. Well worth the modest entry fee.

Disappointing as could be very informative. Many of the exhibits have only Dutch information, many are very difficult to see as you need to peer through small openings and there is far too much reading required. This is a shame as this could be a great museum if it was rethought and redesigned. However, there are interesting exhibits within the poorly thought out displays. The children's section was good for that age although much was not captioned in English.
Very interesting.. This is just opposite the zoo in Amsterdam.Very informative and all translated in English .The layout was so well planned and the information touched our hearts.

Well worth a trip, fantastic.. This Museum is generally not quoted as a 'must see' in the guidebooks, but this really is well worth a trip.. It provides an interesting and very moving insight into the Dutch Resistance during the war. If you are interested/enjoyed the Anne Frank house then this is certainly worth a visit for an hour or two. The are some nice cafes and the zoo nearby to make it worth the trip out. Great value too, far cheaper than the other mainstream museums.
Wonderful. Very interesting the staff were very nice it was a very interactive museum my husband really enjoyed the history of the resistance movement
very poignant. very poignant and thought provoking. included in Iamsterdam card almost next door to the Zoo. Interesting to view it from another nation's viewpoint

Makes you think. This museum brought to life the reality of the war. I went with my university age son because my husband had told us it was good. He could not go again because it was too emotional for him(he is Dutch). His father had been a part of the resistance. We had heard a few stories but got a much better understanding of what happened. It was very interesting and informative to read the real accounts of why people reacted the way they did. You will need a couple of hours to go through the place. It is very emotionally draining so be prepared for that. Even if you are not a history or WWII buff (and I am not) it was absolutely fascinating.

An eye opener. I last learnt about the Second World War when I was a teenager at school. This museum proved to be a really eye opener as to what life in occupied Europe was like under Nazi control. Earmark at least 2 hours to spend in this museum... It is packed with information that will leave you with a far better understanding of how the Nazi's took control of Holland and how the Dutch people responded.The curators have tried to make the exhibits as interactive as possible but be prepared for a lot of reading to truly appreciate this museum. The museum is slightly off the beaten path but well within walking distance from the centre of Amsterdam.

perhaps the best historical museum ever. An interesting perspective about the Dutch Resistance, beginning with banking and importance of moving money, then on to how the Nazis began gathering information on Dutch citizens, and slowly began to use the information against them.Some of the interactive exhibits (there are many) force one to think about how you might respond to similar pressure from a government - pressure to self-identify race, religion, business, assets and inform on your friends. We found the museum thought provoking, especially considering today's police states and constant government surveillance.

What would you have done?. This museum, which is a little bit outside of the centre, poses the question "what would you have done?" during the Nazi occupation of the Netherlands. It presents personal tales of victims, survivors and average people in order to facilitate understanding of what happened and why. The written information is in English and Dutch but there is a free audioguide which is available in many different languages. This museum was very interesting and informative. Any interest in WW2 and this is a perfect stop.

Stories of Unbelievable Courage and Cowardice. The museum recreates the atmosphere of the streets of Amsterdam during the German Occupation of WWII, contextualizing the many stories of individual courage and cowardice. It brings home the horrors of war. Also just opened a Children's Museum of the Resistance--a daunting project beautifully done.

We've been to several Resistance museums. This is the best. BY FAR!!. We've been to resistance museums in Paris, Rome, Bologna, other places. This is the best. By far. What a superb experience. Far more than a history of the Resistance, it's a history of the Dutch experience during WWII. I'm an art historian and this is one of the best designed museum experiences I have ever had. Just superb. Don't miss the Kid's Museum. Even if you don't bring kids, it's an interesting walk-through. Great combination of hands-on experiences and timelines. WOW.

Thought provoking. Definitely not your usual WWII museum. Difficult and controversial subject matter, handled very delicately. Lot's to read (the audio guide is helpful to speed this up) but well worth the tram ride to get there. Included with the Holland Pass.

One of the most interesting museums ever. This museum is one of the most unique we have ever visited. The exhibits are wonderful, from the drop off points where spies left messages to the door one might have to approach for sanctuary. The exhibit on the starving time was one of the most evocative I have ever seen.

Well worth a visit. A great museum which has a "warts and all" look at how the Dutch people coped with occupation during World War 2. Some excellent audio visual displays and some of the personal stories really make you think about the decisions you would have made yourself, and demonstrate how easy it was to suddenly find you had collaborated with no real intention of doing so - and how difficult, and the personal sacrafices involved in resisting the occupation either actively or even passively.All the storyboards and audiovideo are available in English, and if it's quiet you can get round and see everything in a couple of hours.There is also a very interesting section on what the end of the war meant for the Dutch Empire, with the Dutch finding themselves in the role of the oppressor and facing resistance movements of their own.This was a surprise highlight of our visit, and I would recommend it to anyone with a couple of hours to spare on their trip.

very informative, thought-provoking. As others have noted, a lot of information and reading (although the audio guide which is free with admission enables you to basically skip the reading) -- but really interesting. Gives a real sense of the evolution of the war in the Netherlands, and the complicated choices facing people.
A must. So interesting. You can spend all day there or just an hour. Go at your own speed. You can go and have lunch or a coffee as there is readmission the same day.
Beyond Eye-opening. Heart breaking, educational, informative and very hands on. It is well worth the tram ride. The curators have done a brilliant job in presenting a very delicate subject matter.

Great educational experience!. While visiting Amsterdam, make sure to leave time for the Dutch Resistance Museum. A great audio-visual presentation takes you on a tour of the history of occupied Holland during the Second World War. A real education and well-balanced as well. Don't miss the Hollandsche Schouwburg nearby, the point of deportation for Amsterdam's Jews and a small museum.

Good for youths. Although there is a good deal of reading at the exhibits, they all have an English section, and the whole museum is aimed at making you think what you would have done...go along, cooperate, or resist.

History of the resistance in WWII. They recently added a section for children which sounds thoughtful. The rest of the museum does a tasteful job of showing and explaining the history of life in Amsterdam during WWII.
a bit of history easy to locate by zoo. Well laid out easy to follow. Gives you insight into the lives of locals before and after the second world war.

Interesting museum. This museum was in a part of Amsterdam I had not visited before. Lots going on there. The museum itself was a different aspect of war - how the Dutch stood up to the nazis and helped Jewish neighbours. Lots of individual stories

Thought Provoking and Worth A Visit. Firstly, there is a free locker, cloakroom, toilets and Audio Tour - that is definitely a 'must'. Unusual to get anything free in Amsterdam. The Museum is very good but some of the exhibits are difficult to see, we felt they should be clearer in the show cases. Some of the labels are too low to see. The restaurant is not one we felt comfortable in just to have a coffee or snack - it looked like people were dressed for dinner and we walked into the centre for a coffee after our visit. Having said those few negative things it IS worth a visit and the staff are very helpful. I am not sure we learnt much about the Dutch people and wonder if a few 'real' stories from people who lived through it would have been good also, actual interviews and speaking their own words. Museums like this should be encouraged and it's marvellous for the children to learn about the war, their section is excellent.

A bit out of the way, but worth the trip .... A rather small museum dedicated to the resistance movement in Holland during the Second World War. Many artifacts and descriptions on the everyday lives of those who tried to stand up to the Third Reich. Interesting to visit this long with the Jewish Heritage Musuem which is close by. These are both included as free with the purchase of the IAmsterdam Card.

Very interesting museum. This museum has and excellent and informative audio tour which if included in the ticket at no extra charge. However allow plenty of time if you want to listen to everything, we would recommend at least 2 hours, we ran out of time as it we had to leave in order to catch our plane. There is a lot of information with interesting and varied displays, some multimedia, and hardly a mention of Anne Frank so it complements the Anne Frank Museum very well. Slightly off the beaten track unless you are going to the zoo but well worth it.

Thought Provoking. Museum is well designed with a very thought provoking presentation of artifacts and information from the WWII occupation of Amsterdam. The presentation of information was laid out in a way to really draw the visitor into the war-time experience of a citizen of The Netherlands. I'd recommend going here prior to visiting the Anne Frank house, it's a perfect bit of context for the Anne Frank experience.

Not the greatest. Not wanting to be disrespectful to the heroes, but this museum was not what everyone made it out to be. There is alot of reading, and not enough visuals. Could have been just as educating by surfing the internet.
An emotional trip in the past. If one remembers the second world war in The Netherlands, this is a step back in history. Those who resisted saved a lot of people and I am one of them

Lots to read!. A bit out of the way and newly opened so not all locals are aware of where it is but basically head for the zoo and the museum is about another 100 yards further on. Lots to see and even more to read! We didn't manage to read everything that was there as became too tired with all the reading.Really good to hear from an historian about Amsterdam during the war! Good restaurant on site and excellent toilet facilities. My only negative was I felt hat there should be chairs around the museum for those of us t need occasional rest breaks.

Are you interested in WWII history? Then this is a must see!. This museum is a great focused subject matter, and it covers the story from beginning to end very thoroughly. I would recommend seeing this museum before the Anne Frank house so that you have more background on the resistance before going to an even more focused subject-matter. If I have any comment on something to improve for this museum, it would be to improve the English titles on the displays. I can speak Dutch, so I was able to read more of the original signage, documentation, and personal letters. But the English titles on some of the displays did nothing to get to the detail of what was displayed, so I feel that I got a lot more out of it than your average tourist would. That's what I think some of the other reviews mean by the "simplicity" of the museum. Overall, I would highly recommend this museum to anyone visiting Amsterdam. I live in the Netherlands, and this museum is going on my "must see" list for visitors!

Collaboration or Resistance, a very insightful museum a . The Verzetsmuseum is an interactive museum that captures the life of Dutch citizens during World War 2 in an impressive manner. The museum takes you from 1930 till the end of the war and shows the different choices people made during this period of time. I definitely recommend this museum if you're interested in World War 2 or want to learn more about the daily life of people between 1930 and 1950. If you take your time, visiting the museum will take between 3 and 4 hours.

Well worth a trip, but make sure you have 2 hours!. I noticed that this was a 'new ish' museum and not too far away from my hotel. I felt I owed it to the people who led the resistance to visit it and I was not dissappointed. I took the audio tour which was about 90 minutes long and felt I got much more out of the exhibits than just reading the plaques. The downside of the museum was the layout was not so straight forward, but nothing major, I just had to back track a bit.the upside, was a lot of work had gone into it, they had different types of displays, and very informative. I was really glad I went. However you if you do the audio tour and press all the options (as I did) it will take you 90 minutes plus. So make sure you are not in a hurry.

great place to visit full of knowledge. excellent this is how museums should be , not expensive and guys you can spend a day there ,the local streets have the jewish connection to and make sure you buy a little book called persecution and resistance in Amsterdam ,it tells you around the streets local and what happened . and its only 50p .... the aushwitz memorial near to ....

A Highlight Of Our Vacation. This museum tells the story of brave people fighting tyranny. These are people who should never be forgotten. It also was balanced in showing that not everyone fought the Nazi curse, which is a plus.

Excellent Museum. The museum has a great combination of audio and visual experiences the gives you a great view of the resistance as well as the Nazi collaborators. It takes about an hour and the exhibits give a great view of the time period and what the Dutch went through during the Nazi occupation.

Very moving and interesting. This is a fascinating place, with an excellent audio guide. It tells the story of the occupation in picture and personal story, with lots of fascinating information which brings it all to life. Very well worth visiting.

The Resistance Museum. Be ready to read a lot! This museum is filled with information about Amsterdam during the Nazi occupation. It's a bit out of the way, but there is a canal boat stop about 10 minutes walk away.My husband is a World War II history expert and he enjoyed it but didn't feel he learned anything new. If you are very educated about the subject you may be a bit let down.It's a great museum and tribute and a wonderful place to learn if you are not already educated on the subject.
Very interesting. This was very interesting exhibits well thought out and displayed. Fascinating to see how 'normal' people put up the fight!

If your in amsterdam its a must see. We were late to a dinner and they were closing in an hour so we didn't have much time, but what we did see was great. Its filled with WWII history and holocaust artifacts. I plan to go back next time to get more time to see everything

Some good info but dogmatic. Some good eyewitness accounts of the era of occupation of the Netherlands but the dogmatic and simplistic approach makes you wonder whether this museum was made for children only or also for thinking adults.

Interesting & interactive for a museum. This was a great museum & not characteristic of your normal museum. A little out from the centre of the city via tram, it is quite near the zoo & also if you need a coffee/snack I’d recommend the café which is immediately to the left of entrance in the same building [can’t recall name]. It details the plight of Amsterdam locals during the Nazi occupation of WW2 & how various groups decided to adapt [go about life as usual], resist [blatantly or with underground newspapers etc] or those that would essentially collaborate with Nazis but actually plot ways to rebel or not have their culture changed overly. There was a good timeline set out of the haves and have nots & divisions in Dutch society even prior to the Nazi invasion. The experience portrayed of the Jewish citizens & their gradual outcast descending into violence was very vivid & films & interactive displays also show this well, with many anecdotes from citizens at the time. I’m not a natural museum lover but I found this really interesting & interesting to see the how Dutch were loyal to each other, supportive or often indifferent to Jewish suffering, & indeed, harsh & violent post WW2 to fellow citizens they perceived as traitors & Nazi aligned. I do not regret attending. Great perspective on the suffering resilience & cleverness of people during wartime & if you think you’re having a bad day, think again I suppose
A good insight to the plight of the Dutch people. We'll documented chronologically and very different to what I was expecting. Well worth visiting, audio tour is free.

Good way to learn about the resistance.. The museum does a good job of covering aspects of the Nazi occupation of The Netherlands, and the various responses from the Dutch. It covers the armed resistance, capitulation, and those who just tried to get by. There is a lot of memorabilia from the time, posters, newspapers, personal papers. Some earlier posts complain about the lack of English, but I would disagree. All museum information signs are in both Dutch and English. There is also an English audio tour that is very informative. The original documents/posters are in Dutch of course, but I don't see that as a negative.There are sections dedicated to various political parties, religious institution response to the occupation, counterfeiting of documents and more. There is also an interesting room dedicated to WWII and the reaction of the Dutch West Indies, which is something I never thought of.You can take Tram 9 from Amsterdam Central Station, to the Plantage Kerklaan stop, about a ten minute ride. It is fairly easy to find, directly across from the entrance of Artis, the Amsterdam Zoo. The cost for an adult is 8 euro, and that includes the audio tour. It does accept the museum card.If you are interested in WWII, especially topics not often covered in main stream books, this is worth your time. Allow about two hours.

Thought provoking and interesting. This museum was not well advertised and we only went to get value from our museum card. However we were soooo glad we did go. Very thought provoking and well presented. Would recommend a visit

Impressive. Can't say I enjoyed the museum as it's not a happy museum. But I did like to see, read and watch all the material that they gathered. It's nicely done, very diverse. Amazing what the resistance did and has suffered, and has saved so many lives. Went with my son, that doesn't read Dutch, so he missed a bit of the letters that were on display. Pls do visit this museum and on it's way you can also visit the Portuguese Synagogue but do bring warm clothes, the temperature in the museum is a bit low. They have a section for younger kids, but that is only in Dutch.

Hard to find but worth the visit. It is not well advertised in Amsterdam so know in advance how to get there. But if you really want to learn about life in the Netherlands during World War II, this is the place to go! The museum is a very good balance of fact and personal histories, without either being apologetic or boastful. It left us with a lot of questions of how WE might act if we were occupied by foreign forces. Very thought provoking.

Enlightening and poignant. My father was a tank gunner in WW II and served in The Netherlands, so I found this museum very enlightening and poignant. We in North America find it hard to believe that ordinary people would risk, and in many cases, lose their lives for what they believed in. I loved the ingenuity and was appalled how we sometimes treat our brothers. Well worth the money. One thing - they don't take Canadian VISA or debit cards - cash only.

Interesting and thought-provoking. We went there as we just happened to walk past it, and we couldn't have been more pleased about our spontaneous decision. It was well laid out, put everything at a human level (lots of different people's personal experiences) and was generally informative about Holland's experiences during WW2, such as the 'hunger winter' which I really didn't know enough about before. We spent about two hours there and could have spent longer.

Takes you back in time. This museum was so much better than I expected. It has personal touch which takes you back in time and you will share people´s lives during your visit. Their audio guide system is great. It´s very easy to use and you don´t have to spend extra time with it trying to find right chapter if you have missed one or two.
A GOOD AFTERNOON.. A fascinating experience, I,ve always been interested in how the Dutch coped with German occupation.Well laid out, uncrowded, time to reflect on recent history.

Definitely worth a visit. Well priced. Interesting stories about Nazi occupation and how the Dutch dealt with it. Even covers Indonesia's occupation by the Japanese in WW2. Could do with more places to sit and read, there's so much to absorb and alot of standing/crouching to read it.

Very informative. I think this museum is probably aimed at children but well worth a visit by everyone. Lots of audio descriptions & real life accounts from ordinary people which are quite moving. Well laid out, extremely interesting.

Helps you understand the experience of the Dutch nation in WW2. We expected this to be broadly similar to similar museums that we have visited in France, but it stands head and shoulders above the rest.It is a small city centre museum but it uses the available space well and makes a real impact. Audio guides were available but we found them uneccessary as loads of information was displayed in both Dutch and English.The story which is told is that of how a neutral country was suppressed in a few days by a the might of a militarily-superior neighbour.This is a warts-and-all story which explains how some people embraced the new regime, how most simply acquiesced, but also how others tried to make things difficult for the Germans. I learned about a food-shrtage which caused mass starvation, and how ordinary Dutch people were transported on trains in their thousands to work as forced-labourers in Germany.I found myself imagining what life in England would have been like if Hitlers Operation Sea Lion had been successful !The visit was well worth the effort of finding it You are not allowed to take bags into the museum but they provide free lockersAdmission is free if you have an "I Amsterdam card"

Very worth while. It's off the beaten track but an important reminder of bitter times. Probably not for a two or three day first trip to Amsterdam but we found it compelling on this our sixth visit to the city.

Great storytelling in this small museum. The museum is well put together and easy to follow the story of the war years through from the German occupation to liberation. Wonderful collection of exhibits but what makes it slightly different is the way it tells individual's stories and experiences. Very sympathetically presented without being overly dramatic. Very enjoyable and thought provoking visit. Can be done in around 2 to 2.5 hours.

Very Interactive Little Museum. Really worthwhile visit if you are a history/war buff. Exhibits really bring it all to life. Well worth seeing even if you think you have been on museum overload with all the large museums. This one is a gem.

LOTS of information - could it be too much?. Can a museum have too much information??? Well this one might. It is significantly based on following a path through history and reading about the resistance movement during World War II - in painstaking detail! If that's your thing, go for it. If not, you will get as much value out of reading the Wikipedia page on the Dutch resistance.

Underpublicised gem. Good museum on the Dutch experiences in World War 2 with a pervasive moral question 'when is it better to accommodate to an occupier, to collaborate or to offer resistance?' Excellent audioguide - as it's free take one !The questions stop becoming explicit in the small section on Indonesia (Dutch East Indies) in and around World War 2 ... Were the occupiers there now the Japanese or the Dutch ?

Gives you a feel for the times. Unflinching look at Nazi occupation with first-hand accounts as well as visuals and artifacts that let you appreciate the challenges of daily life, the terror and the stakes associated with resistance.

Humbling and sobering. Worth it.. The Resistance Museum does a very good job putting a human face to the Nazi occupation of The Netherlands and always asks the question: should they have collaborated? adapted? resisted? What would you do faced with the same circumstances?You see the faces and stories of real Dutch citizens who were faced with that choice. It is easy to throw stones from a historical distance at the collaborators or those who simply adapted, but the museum does a very good job of presenting their stories and rationale as well. Physically, the museum is a winding path with windows (metaphorically and literally) into individuals' lives and choices, as well as short alleys that follow a particular story. Stories are told through artifacts, photos, writings, flip-boards, and video.At the end of the day, you are left with a sense of the scope and horror of the occupation, perhaps a desire to go hug the ones you love and make sure they are safe, and a deep appreciation of life in a time and place where you are not in danger of being killed because of your convictions or the circumstance of your birth.This is not really a light-hearted museum, but it is worth the time if you feel you should understand history.We would suggest allocating at least 3 hours.

Interesting display about grim chapter. This museum was well set out and very informative. The exhibition effectively personalised the experience for the viewer by posing ethical question about how you would react to the nazi occupation: collaborate, resist, adjust. The English signage was very good, as the free audio tour (although the audio tour didn't add much to the signage). Our visit pre-dated the new kids exhibition, but there was still enough to occupy our 8 year old for 2 hours.

A bit basic. Found the displays a bit basic and in actual fact learnt that dutch resistance was minimal and as this is what the museum was supposed to be about was left wondering where this museum sits. Not really worth the $8 euros entry fee.

Very interesting value for money.. I have been here twice now and there was more to see the first time ,but still lots to see. Lots of things for children to see and do. It costs 8€ each adult but good value?When you come out just cross the road for the Artis zoo.

Resistance Museum, Amsterdam. Was a last day, quick choice and what a surprise treat it was! The museum was so very well done with movie, photos, audio, history, stories, displays. It is located across from the Zoo. Highly recommend, enthralling.

Do not go gentle into that good night.. At first you think, what harm can it do to register. Why shouldn't I say what religion my grandparents were? I've got nothing to hide, nothing to be ashamed of. I'm a good citizen. Then, more swiftly than you'd think, you can't work, can't get a job, can't marry the one who loves you, can't eat, can't stay, can't live. When you stick up for someone, you get their punishment, only worse. Divide and rule.This museum is important, the message is important, the parallels are important. Think, be aware, be afraid, but most of all be brave. Resist!
Thought provoking. Found this museum by chance and spent a rushed visit as we got there about an hour and a half from closing time. Very interesting exhibits - would like to have had a longer visit.

Good overview of WW2 in Amsterdam. This is a bit tricky to find on the tram, but just look for the main zoo entrance. It's across the street in a very non-descript house.Great overview of WW2 in Amsterdam. Good visuals. Very limited hours it seemed. Great as part of tourist pass.
A hidden gem. 8 euros to go in and well worth it. You could spend hours here. A great exhibition and a wonderful coffee bar just next door

Small but interesting.. This is a small but well-done museum that traces the rise and fall of the Nazi's, both German and home-grown. A student of history and World War II in particular, there were a lot of things that were new to me, like how the Dutch were able to keep their bicycles running without rubber.

for history buffs. We spent 2+ hours reviewing the war years and the Action of the Resistance and the reaction of the Dutch to the Japanese in their Colonies. Having done some reading on THE RESISTANCE in various occupied countries, I found this museum very worthwhile.

Don't miss it. I am glad I took time to visit this wonderful historical museum. Everything from the nice staff at the ticket office, to the clear and informative audio guide that was provided without extra cost made my visit a memorable experience. I visited Anne Frank House a few days ago, and this museum serves as an ideal complement. The museum was not busy in the afternoon and I was able to get close to see all exhibits in a leisurely pace.

Well-presented and sobering. The Nazi occupation of the Netherlands is obviously a difficult and emotional subject, but this museum presents its information interestingly, clearly and in a refreshingly honest way. There's enough material here to keep your attention for many hours, but I also think it's possible to get a general grasp of the exhibits in 60-90 minutes.This is not a fun subject, but I think the the perspective one gains from visiting makes it a must-see. You may need a drink or two afterwards, but you'll be better for the experience. Highly recommended.

Very moving and thought provoking. This museum easily invited one into the lives of the people of Holland during the occupation. It presented information in a lively and not prejudicial manner. We found ourselves amazed that two and half hours had passed without our notice.

Much more here than in the Anne Frank House. A very interesting, small museum about the Nazi period in the Netherlands, that foreign visitors, in general, hardly know. It hosts many objects and documents, with comprehensive descriptions, most of them bilingual. It explains quite well the ambiguous relationships between the Nazi governments and the "Dutch cousins" at the beginning, evolving into an open military occupation afterwards, focusing on the different expressions of the resistance movement in the Country and its repression.Although with lower emotional impact, it gives to the visitor a much more comprehensive picture of WWII Netherlands than the very popular Anne Frank House.There is a lot to read, so take your time to visit it properly. I would suggest to dedicate to it 3 hours to fully enjoy it.

Disapponted. Having read great reviews, perhaps my expectations were perhaps to high. It is largely a read, at least for English visitors, of war time in Netherlands and I suspect understated Dutch Resistance work.
Actually we walked there from our central hotel and the walk through charming streets made it worthwhile.

An Honest Look at their History. I was quite impressed with the way the Dutch have looked very honestly at their role in WWII. This museum admits that three different paths were taken at that time - collaboration, acceptance, resistance. The bravery of the men and women who resisted is so very fascinating. As a fan of WWII spy novels, I loved viewing the objects and reading the true stories of those who resisted.
A must see. Should be compulsory for all still in school... A superb place with a powerful message... The Dutch, and especially Jews, really did suffer i... a very sobering experience that

Dutch Resistance Museum. Excellent museum. I found out about this museum through Trip Adviser and decided to visit it after reading other people's reviews. So glad I did as it was well worth it. Shows the history of the Dutch Resistance and the plight of the Jews during WW2. I recommend visiting this museum prior to visiting the Ann Frank House. You cannot buy tickets anywhere other than at the museum as it is not advertised through the hotels or the main touring companies in Amsterdam, which is a shame really as many tourists will miss out on this gem if they don't know about Trip Adviser. I went on a Saturday afternoon and there was no que and not many people inside. A well kept delightful secret but more people should know about it. Go and enjoy, it cost 8 euros. Request a free talking recording and allow at least 90 mins to cover it all.

Not to be missed!. Even if you do not like history, this museum should be visited to understand the ordeal caused by the Nazis. I visited during a school day. There were several children present but all went well because I was prepare to slow down or accelerate (and return on your steps to continue) the visit to avoid the commotion.

Worth a visit - but perhaps more English translations needed.. This is a very interesting little museum, about the Netherlands' wartime history. It gives a very good picture of life in wartime, occupied Holland, with all its wartime photographs. A lot of hard work must have gone into collecting everything and putting it all together.Unfortunately for English speakers, most of the exhibits (posters, leaflets, newspaper clippings) and their accompanying description-board are written in Dutch, with only summaries of the main ones translated into English. I would have derived a lot more from its wonderful display, if only I had been able to understand more of it. Sometimes, the significance of some exhibits "Went over my head" a bit. Still, it was interesting and very well laid out.It not quite as easy to reach and find as some of the big city-centre places, which are right on tram-routes. If you have a walking difficulty, this might mean walking a little bit further than you find comfortable; but it's nice when you get there. There's a nice, welcoming, pavement cafe just outside the door.

Very well presented, memorable. Certainly this type of subject matter is sobering, and the subject may not interest everyone, but this museum is well worth visiting.So much information, in a well ordered and accessible format. I wish I had had more time there, could have used more than the two hours we spent there, reading and listening to everything. It was enough time for my boyfriend to read everything (fast reader).

Like Being There. Of the ten museums I visited while in the Netherlands, this is the one that I remember. It fairly illustrates the dilemma faced by the city's residents in the face of Hitler's occupation, explaining how insidious his start was, the role of tradition and church in deciding which side to take. Also the fact that Amsterdam had just gone through a major recession so conditions were ripe for joining the German movement. Also interesting that Anne Frank's house was just one of thousands in the city.

Understated yet one of the best attractions in Amsterdam. Some time to kill with over 20 attractions to plump for and we chose this one and not sorry we did. Very reasonable entrance fee and exhibits throughout in English and Dutch explaining the struggles the Dutch people went through in their homeland during the war. I am keen on history and still learned a lot about this period in Dutch history. "V"

Important for WWII perspective. We were planning on three days in Normandy later on in our trip, and found this museum to be an excellent way to understand the Netherlands role in WWII. Walked away with a terrific understanding of the Dutch resistance.

BEST MUSEUM IN AMSTERDAM. If your going to be in amsterdam, i think this is the one thing you MUST make sure you do!! I cannot rate this museum highly enough. understated and not very well known but absolutly fantastic, i personally preffered it to anne franks house and van gogh museum! could easily spend 3 hours looking through this truly inspiring museum. It is exremely interactive which makes it interesting at all times and is only 8 euros with a free multimedia tour (would definatly reccomend having the multimedia!)

Outstanding!. I had a great time in Anne Frank's Museum, but I considered Resistance Museum THE museum of Amsterdam. It is filled with artifacts from the WWII. Most of the seem to be real, other are reproductions. There are some sections in which the era is fully recreated, posters from Nazi propaganda, movies playing, weapons, documents, etc. The museum can be totally finished in about two to three hours, but reading the complete history would take you longer. You won't be disappointed.

VERY SOBERING MUSEUM, A MUST SEE!. This is an outsdanding museum about the abuses of the Dutch by the Nazis' It covers the ground on the courageous soles who resisted the persecution efforts of the Nazis. The exhibits are compelling and outline the efforts of Amsterdam citizens to limit the carnage during wwii of people of jewish faith. Over 60,000 people in Amsterdam were killed in consecration camps. There were courageous people in Amsterdam who hid the targeted people even at potential risk to their own lives.

Worth a Stop. Not a very big museum, but worth a look. The museum gives the visitor the opportunity to examine the Resistances' efforts to fight the Nazis during World War II. Easy to follow interior design with information presented using various methods such posters, dioramas, video, and sound. Across the street from the zoo. Easy to get to using the tram system or about a fifteen minutes walk from Rembrandt Plein . Accessible for wheelchairs and there are toilets in the lobby.

Very good and interesting - specialized interest. A smallish museum - I walked past it without realizing it first time round! Of huge interest if you're into European politics, Dutch social commentary etc, around WW2 times. Lots to read and see. The artefacts are real and make one's visit entirely genuine and 'of that period'. It's a serious place but there are touches of humour and of course one is surrounded by the heart-warming and inspirational stories of 'the resistance'. An important tourist stop off in order to understand the Dutch people better. A must see for anyone with an interest/passion for WW2 history.

Broadly appealing. This museum is free on the Museumkaart and definitely worth seeing. The audio guide was free and very helpful. What I appreciated most were the many varied personal stories of Dutch people during the war, and the choices they made. Reading their stories and viewing pictures and displays was memorable, and would appeal to all visitors, not just history buffs. The museum does lack some detail about how the Dutch resistance movement worked, and it does get difficult to focus after awhile because many of the stories are upsetting, but it's a valuable and worthwhile experience nonetheless. The neighbourhood it's located it also made for a nice walk.

Good history/accessible. We found the museum to be well planned and managed for a small museum. However, as per the subject it was depressing. We were forced to go next door and eat pancakes to recover.wheelchairtravel99

Great for young people. This tells the story of WWII through the eyes of the Dutch and is very much geared to be educational and appealing to younger people and children who may not have much or any background about this period of European history. Outstanding visit!

A 'must' for those interested in history and politics. I enjoyed my visit but needed more of a map to get the very best from it. Very good exhibits (interesting maps, letters, explanations and items) with excellent explanations from which I learned a lot about the Dutch and wartime - much of which I was unaware.........Very helpful staff at the front of house, photos possible so long as you do not use flash and treat others with courtesy, refreshments available. I thought that it would be good to take young people here to show them that politics can sometimes make life's choices difficult. Explanations in Dutch were fantastic. Some super extracts and interactive radio. More seats, improved map with suggested route would be great. Recommended.

What would you do?. Possibly the best museum we visited in Amsterdam. The initial plan had been to visit the zoo but it was raining and the Resistance Museum was opposite so we gave it a go. The introductory video and stories dotted around the museum helped give a real feel of what it would have been like to live in Nazi occupied Amsterdam. It focussed far more on individuals and their lives than great political gestures which made it much more interesting.Collaborate? Adjust? Resist? The main theme running through the museum was the choice that everyone living in Amsterdam had to make. It really makes you think about what you would do in their shoes.

Thoroughly recommended. Allow plenty of time - there is a lot to take in! The best thing about the museum is that it makes no bones about the fact that not ALL Dutch citizens were members of the Resistance - "adapt, collaborate or resist?" is the theme of the museum.

More information, no lines, on Amsterdam Card, engaging for children, consider over Anne Frank Museum. I found this an excellent museum on WWII in Amsterdam and the Netherlands. They will soon be opening a new children's area in the future. But even what they have now for adults was quite interesting and held all of our interest including 12 year olds.The museum covered life in Amsterdam under the Nazi's. There were photographs, videos and objects. It was put together in a way where a number of stories and issues were raised.At the end there was also information on the effect WWII had on overseas territories such as Indonesia.I would highly recommend this if you have the Amsterdam card. It is across the street from the botanical garden and zoo, and a couple of tram stops from the Rembrandt Museum and Jewish Museum- so you can put a nice tour together and hit many museums.We also visited the Anne Frank Museum and I would recommend the Resistance Museum over the Anne Frank museum given cost, lines and the general information/experience.

An EXCELLENT learning experience!. Really great for all ages. Well done and truly a part of history that should not ever be forgotten, but remembered for what needs to be. The staff is knowledgeable and the museum is a must see!

Disappointing. Long walk to this small museum. Woman at the front desk was obviously unhappy with her job and aside from taking our money, did not even offer up a greeting to us, let alone any information on the museum. Large group of school aged kids attended at the same time which made it sometimes hard to concentrate or move around. Before walking out, it was very noticeable that there was not a single Canadian flag hung with all the other nation's flags. I am aware that Canada adopted the maple leaf flag in '65 but considering it was Canada that liberated the Netherlands, not to recognize this, I left scratching my head.

Museum of a difficult time in history. Went to this museum right after visiting the Anne Frank House and got a nice perspective on the Dutch people and how they tried to show strength against the Nazi takeover and how some helped the Jews stay out of the concentration camps. Found the museum to be quite informative, but also about repetitive. would have been nice to follow individuals during this time and see how their story unfolds instead of just glimpses of various people during a difficult time. A child's section is opening within the year and think is important to have a museum like this on a child's level. Was worth the visit.

Not to forget!. This is a small but important museum in Amsterdam. The most impressive exhibit I visited was called 'One thread a day', pens and paper were not allowed in prison or camps but needles were easy to smuggle in and messages were embroidered in and out.

Moving experience. Interactive, carefully paced, beautifully displayed museum about the Dutch resistance in WW2. A learning experience, for sure. They're building a new children's annex to make the history relevant for younger generations. Well done.

Powerful and Real Stories. This museum was very thorough and informative. The displays were varied and included some interactive experiences. What I really appreciated was the numerous personal stories that were shared throughout the museum. Reading the testimonies of the Dutch people during WWII was very powerful. I came away from the museum informed and inspired.

Hugely informative. We spent 3 hours there and could have stayed longer, but they were closing. So many personal tales and the 3 questions posed are very thought provoking. This museum should be better advertised and known.

Gives you a strong sense of Holland during WWII. This is not a super sophisticated museum. The displays are simple, historial artifacts and the commentary sometimes goes beyond simple to simplistic (Hitler bad, House of Orange good). But still, I know more now than I did before about the war and the resistence, and it is an important insight into the culture of the country now.

An engaging museum.. I can fully understand why this has been recognised as a key attraction in Amsterdam.
The combination of film clips, artefacts and commentary used to explore the question of Adapt, Resist, or Collaborate? shows empathy for the dilemma faced by ordinary citizens in extreme circumstances.
I would highly recommend a visit.

Interesting Museum. Definitely worth a visit as gives insight into the complex decisions the locals had to make when Germany invaded. Makes one consider what they would have done in those days - resisted or complied...

Expensive for families ..... We arrived at the museum looking forward to a visit. Unlike Anne frank house there was no queue, no sign of any other visitors. We were a family of four but were not allowed a family ticket because my sons were not young enough. We could not get a group discount either and when we were told we would have to pay extra to put our bags in lockers when we wanted to keep them with us, I'm afraid it just seemed too expensive for us to go in.I expect it was very interesting inside and i would very much have liked my teenage son to learn what the resistance was and about the heroes in it, but we felt it was hard for one family to spend this amount (more than Anne frank house when you have to pay to leave bags).Very disappointed.

very expensive for what it was. Its a long walk to the resistance museum as its not near any tram stops. Easy to find, follow the signs for Artis zoo. Its around 8 Euros each. The museum is full of some very basic but some very interesting information. Was told on the way in that everything is translated into English, however, when in there found that a lot was not.There is a lovely restaurant attached to the museum, great value food and lovely staff.

Amsterdam's Resistance Museum. This in not your usual venue.One must appreciate and understand the resistance to oppression whenever/where ever it occurs. This history of the Dutch during World War II is but one example of what happens to a (previously) FREE nation taken over by an oppressive nation (in this case, Nazi Germany).It is a good reminder of what people must do to resist such a totally unwanted and illegal occupation by another country (or group of people) and the (undesirable) experiences some had. It also identified some that went along with the tyranny and what later happened to them.It shows just how easily FREEDOM can slip away and the intense and significant efforts employed to reattain it. This was one fabulous expose' of true HISTORY; clearly reality; and not some progressive trying to reshape what really happened!One of my most memorable venues of my 5-week visit to Northern Europe!
Well worth a visit. A very informative and well designed museum which effectively represents the very difficult time endured by the city during the War

Innovative and thought provoking. I had visited this museum during my past visit, and had really left myself with too little time ( only one hour) this visit. Very innovative displays, although a little confusing at time to get the right linear pathway. Intriguing topic and interesting to see the evolution of the movement and the feelings of the Dutch people over the course of the war. Highly recommend.
So crowded unable to study and take in some wonderful art.. Lovely building, got tickets and got in quickly, but far too many people allowed in and we couldn't stand back and take in some lovely art.

Far better than Anne Frank House.. Bring cash as they don't like to make change and don't have a machine that works...that is the only bad thing about this place. It is great and you can either skim over or go indepth and read every last word. It gives you a view of not just the Dutch in Holland but you also get to see what happens to the Dutch in the East Indies as well....Soon they will also open a children's experience that they have a preview of that was very well done to give kid's a view of the war. It is well done from photos to stories and timelines. Very well done, good price, no lines, not crowded but well worth it. It is also very convenient to the zoo right across the street. If you have limited time...we would choose this place over the Anne Frank house for experience, history and value. We did Ann Frank the next day and all thought that this museum was far better experience.

Less is more. If like me, you can go into autopilot in huge museums and galleries that are rammed with tourists, this is a great, easily-digested alternative. It's more like an exhibition than a museum, with a decent audio tour that takes you through the beginning, middle and end of the Dutch WW2 experience, so you come away feeling you have been engaged and educated. I think it would work really well with children BEFORE a visit to Anne Frank's house: going from the general to the very personal would be very powerful.Only very minor criticism is that towards the end, the sequencing of the exhibits is less clear but that certainly didn't distract from a very good overall experience.

Not much resistance here. It got off to a good start asking the question "what would you do?" Resist or collaborate?
However despite the numerous audio-visual displays it seemed to lack sufficient examples of people who were in the resistance and what they did. It was all a bit low key.
One for a wet day in Amsterdam I feel.

Well organized. We were a bit disappointed with the museum. It is good in that the displays go in chronological order and really outline the history of WW2 in Holland, but disappointing in that the actual section on the Resistance was smaller than expected and didn't have as many "spy" type artifacts as we expected. Still, an interesting experience.

Don't miss this. Lots of the displays include documents in Dutch and there is no translation, so take the audio-tour if possible. You need to leave bags in a locker before entering, so have a 2 euro coin with you which you get returned on leaving.

It's about more than "Dutch Resistance". I am sure that the curators thought long and hard about their title for this museum but don't be put off. It is not just about the resistance to Nazi occupation over the years 1941-45. It is, in fact, a very balanced account of the three choices available to the people of this neutral country when they were overrun in 1939: collaborate, accept or resist. What would you do? It contains some stark mementos of that dark time. Particularly poignant are the hand-written notes dropped from the trains of transportation and the final words smuggled from the cells of those condemned to death. Take the free audio guide, particularly if you are English-speaking. Some of trigger points and the material described were a little difficult to locate.
