Most of the text is bilingual but the catalogue of films running when I visited were incomprehensible to me, but it was fascinating nonetheless.Requires 2-3 hours to do it justice.

A bit of history that was covered very well. The Dutch attitudes doing the war and how individuals acted is something that needs a lot of explanation and the Museum does a great job. Worth more than Anne Frank House in understanding what happened in many areas and circumstances. Well documented and presented. The Audio Guide is essential.But must read all the descriptions and listen to the stoties.

A Must see in Amsterdam. While this is not located right in the core along with many other attractions, it definitely should not be missed. It looks at the different aspects of the Dutch Resistance during WWII and the issues the people faced. There is a recommended pattern to go through the museum (chronologically), however there are many different presentations (movies, poster boards, information boxes). It begins with a history before the war of the Netherlands and explains the different types of people ie. Socialists, Liberals etc. Then it goes into the war arriving in the Netherlands and the different resistance movements that began. They had different little shadow boxes with real peoples stories in how they personally resisted the Nazis. I found those quite informative. Overall the Museum has lots to see and if you want to fully experience it, expect to spend several hours here (we spent probably 3-4hrs and didn't ever realize it was that long until we left). It's too bad this Museum is not in the museum centre of town as people are unlikely to stumble across it. We made it the end of our Jewish Quarter Walk (Rembrandt House, Jewish Historical Museum, Synagogue) and felt it an appropriate end to the day. So make sure you plan it into your trip.

Very informative. Very unassuming museum, quite small but really worth a visit. Fascinating accounts of life in Amsterdam during the war and how the Dutch resistance stood firm against the Nazis. Even though there are English descriptions get the audio too as that way you miss nothing. Lovely museum, not overcrowded at all (visited Sunday morning) easy to see all exhibits. Audio is free.

A "Must-See" in Amsterdam. Don't leave Amsterdam without seeing this phenomenal museum! I was always told, growing up, that the Dutch had fiercely resisted the Nazi occupation during the Second World War, but I never understood their commitment and intensity until I visited this museum. It is a "must-see".There is no apologist feeling here, as one gets when visiting a French museum about the war. The Dutch were NOT collaborators, and this museum tells their stories. Very interesting exhibits. Get the audio boxes (which I think are free).

A great way to spend the afternoon. The museum is easy to get to by tram-just get off by the Zoo. Once inside the exhibits are well laid out and informative. I was most surprised what desperate straits the Dutch were in by the end of the war. The displays on Mussert and the Dutch Nazis are particuarly eye opening. It is a good way to spend an afternoon. The cafe attached to the museum is brilliant-very cheap, lovely decor and great service.
Fascinating. Well worth a visit.... Doesnt look like much from the outside... but a real treat inside. Our party learnt a lot. The audio tour was brilliant too.

very moving and well organized museum. We got so much out of our visit to the Dutch resistance museum. We learned a lot about the dutch people that we did not know before and their resistance to the harsh cruelty during the holocaust. `it was surreal to know that the jews were sent to the theatre just around the corner. `it was also very interesting to learn about the dutch indian people as we definitely did not know too much about their status during the war and their influences here. This was all very informative and again, well presented. We almost didn't visit the museum because they apparently do not take visa and we had no euro upon arriving. Since we were getting ready to head back to the US, we did not want to use the cash machine...as luck has it, another vendor accidentally over charged our card and gave us the difference back in Euro which ended up being just enough for us to visit the museum...would have been sad to miss this one. `it may be off the beaten path but well worth a visit..especially if you will be seeing the Jewish museum and portuguese synagogue.
Really interesting. I actually found this more moving than Anne Franks house. It was so interesting, probably wouldn't take youngsters though as masses to read. Great VFM!

Very interesting! Allow 2 hours. Cool musuem, full of information of which isn't hugely publicised about the time of occupation in Amsterdam. A massive willingness to help and defend, a must see. Captions are in English but you definetly don't get the full story, I would reccomend an audio guide.

Definitely worth the visit. Yes, it's a little bit out of the way, but it is very interesting. I'm not quite sure which museum the people who say there's not much to see, nor very much English, because we found plenty to see, and there was so much English that we got a little tired of reading. We did not get the Audio Guide. It may have enhanced the experience, but I do not see that it is an absolute necessity. The information was presented in a very organized manner, and really showed what life was like in occupied Holland. The museum signage specifically states that it does not seek to show what it was like for every single person, but highlights a good number of individual stories. You can't go wrong for such a low admission price...8 euro (25% discount with Holland Pass)

Excellent and informative. Museum is off the beaten path, but it gives an informative and interesting history of the Dutch resistance movement, with lots of artifacts from the period. The museum is air conditioned which was important when we went and it has a pleasant cafe. The zoo is just over the road.

Collaborate, do nothing or Resist. The Resistance Museum explains that those were the choices each individual had to make during the occupation by Germany in WWII. Very detailed exhibition with plenty of exhibits that asks the visitor questions of "What would they have done?" Get Museumkaart

Food for Thought.. This should be on the list for every traveller to Amsterdam, particularly now that the generation who actually lived through such dark times is beginning to disappear. This really brings alive the difficulties of living in an occupied country in the Second World War. This is another Museum which repays visiting several times, to really take in all the detail of the exhibits. There is certainly too much to think about on just a single visit.

almost a must see. The Dutch have a very interesting history and a very cosmopolitan scope of their history. This museum illustrates the conflicts between resistors and collaborators during WWII, but also deals well with the conflicted attitude to independence of the Dutch colonies in the aftermath of WWII in Asia. New museum, well designed, well stocked, worth a few hours

Easy to miss on the street, but unforgetable after going in. The museum offered an English audio guide included with the entrance price. The theme of the museum is "what would you have done" and gives thought provoking questions about how you would have responded to the things the Dutch were dealing with. It is interactive but give yourself a couple hours if you plan on doing it. I loved WW2 museums and this provided a different perspective on the war.

Learnt a lot. We previously knew very little about this topic, so it was very interesting to learn about the resistance by the people in the Netherlands during WW2, and also the impact of the war on the people and the counrty.

Second time- Fascinating and Though Provoking. I went to this museum last year with my mom and wanted to bring my children and husband with me. I think the balance of helping people understand how the Dutch people both resisted and were drawn into the Nazi invasion and perspective.
worldwar II information. It is quite a small museum, dedicated to the Dutch resistance during the second worldwar. Nicely done, with some movies on displays.

A Little Hard to Find. A lot of good information, but not quite as powerful of an impact as I anticipated it would be. After spending a while trying to find this museum, I was a little disappointed on how small it was,

Very moving and interesting.. I absolutely loved this museum. It is a very well done example of what happened to the Netherlands during the period of German occupation. To be honest I got more out of this then the Anne Frank house. The displays are interactive well documented in several languages including English. There is also a very good cafe located here.

Very informative and heartfelt. The museum is very special and a must for anyone who is interested in people and how ordinary lives were affected by the war. Very clever design and use of film at the beginning to explain how you might have reacted during this difficult time in history. Very moving. And very informative. Having been to the Anne frank house as well it was the next step to be able to understand what was happening outside whilst the Jews were in hiding in the occupation.

Hard Choices, Explained Well. Imagine the happy little world you've always known and counted on is gone in an instant. The Germans bomb a nearby city and start rounding up your friends, neighbors and co-workers. Your Royal family flees to England. What would you do? This museum lets you experience what all kinds of people in the Netherlands faced when all of this happened to them. Do you keep your head down? Sell out your Jewish neighbors for 7.50 guilders apiece to the Nazis? Or, do you rebel in any way you can to send a message of resistance? Thousands did the latter and this museum shows you how through newsreels, photos, radio newscasts and people's own voices. A wonderful, eye-opening experience that will leave you looking at people from the Netherlands with new found respect for the difficult choices they had to make.

Interesting and very informative. Only found out about this museum from reading other reviews - it is not well publicised - but it is well worth a visit. Take a 14 tram to Plantage Kerklaan (entrance is opposite the zoo entrance). €8 entrance. Gives loads of information, artefacts and pictures about how the Dutch coped with invasion during the War. There is a lot to read (though you can get audio as well) and sometimes the writing is very small to read. As an adult it was fascinating but I think children would find it boring.

Definitely a must-do in Amsterdam! Honest, uplifting and interesting!. This museum is a must-see! It is well organized an curated - it is one of the most dynamic and interesting layouts I've seen in a museum like this. It is so interesting to learn about the brave and humane side of the civilian and political resistance to nazi efforts during the Second World War. In context of seein other sights and museums about this time, it is comforting and uplifting to know there was a movement against the nazis even amongst the barbarity and inhumanity of those who supporting nazi reign. It was honest about the Dutch history and efforts, showing both their courage and cowardice in the face of German occupation. It was defnately among the top museums we've seen in Amsterdam and even Europe for that matter.

Excellent, interactive museum!. This museum is so informative and well done. It gives you the perspectives from various viewpoints of the Dutch Resistance from 1940 - 1945. We spent a good 2 1/2 hours here. Highly recommended.
Excellent. We visited this before the Anne Frank Museum and it showed the humanity shown by many Dutch people during WW2. It was really good and was close to the hotel we stayed in.

Disappointing - not what I expected. It was an interesting couple of hours, but it really concentrated on people's experiences in the occupation and not the role of the Dutch Resistance, sabotage, etc.

Disappointing after the reviews. We'd heard so much about this museum and after our visits to the Oorlogs Museum in Arnhem and Airborne Museum Hartenstein`in Oosterbbek we were really looking forward to it. We all like to grade the museums and this one scored a 4/10 compared to the 10/10 of the two previously mentioned. Our boys (9&10) could not really get interested in this one. Seems geared more for native adults. If you have a busy schedule and limited time I'd suggest skipping this museum in favor of the Rijksmuseum or Scheepvaart Museum (Maritime).

Best of its type. We really enjoyed this museum. Second visit to the city in two years and the tram trip got us to a different part of town as well. GREAT exhibits, but also different ways of telling about the time period from different perspectives in very personal ways. Learned and continued on through the exhibit out of curiosity. There is a good place to eat nearby , Cafe Koojse, about 2 blocks to your right as you face the museum. It sits on the corner of Plantage Middenlaan #37, and Plantage Kerklaan. All are close to the tram stop. We are senior couple but the restaurant and museum would be good for families as well.

Surprisingly interesting. This museum is quite small, yet contains approx. 2 hours of viewing. Very well set out. A bit boring for children (although a specific children one is currently being constructed). Great attraction *****

Great little museum. Great, small museum about the Dutch resistance movement during WWii. A ton of information. Very interesting to learn about WWII from this perspective. It's not really geared for kids, but my 1 year old and 2 year old were happy just pushing buttons. Allow 1-2 hours. Right next to the zoo, but a good walk from the central area of Amsterdam.

Life Changing Experience. We spent a large portion of our brief stay in Amsterdam visiting the Verzetsmuseum and we really found ourselves asking a lot of questions about our Dutch family history that we were never told, and had never before thought to ask. We really enjoyed this museum, and only regret that we do not speak Dutch - though much of the content was in both Dutch and English, there were many pieces of memorabilia (e.g. newspaper clippings, letters written by people in the resistance) that would have enriched the experience even more were we able to read them. Plan for several hours of quiet, reflective time here. Very powerful stuff.

Outstanding Insights. The Resistance Museum is great for those keen on understanding more about Amsterdam's modern history and it's resistance to Nazi occupation. It shows how Holland was divided in Catholics, Protestants, Socialists and Jews most of whom vehemently opposed the Nazi's. It chronicles the prelude to occupation, the Nazi claims to this "Aryan Nation" and how the Dutch organised mass protests, direct action and the sheltering of Jewish Refugees. It culminates with the liberation of the Netherlands by the Allied forces and has a small section exploring the role of the Dutch Colonies during the Second World War. It's mainly text based with little in the way of interactive displays but it's all of good quality and the displays are very well presented. The staff are very friendly here and struck up conversation when entering, would recommend and revisit. Also provided are deposit lockers. Photography is allowed

A fantastic museum. This museum was a little hard to find (expected bigger sign out the front) but it opens up inside like the Tardis. There is no charge if entering with the 'I amsterdam' card, and they have lockers to put your bags in whilst you enter the museum. There is plenty of video, photographs and information to lead you through the Dutch experience during WWII. There was many things I didn't know, and some very interesting pieces in their displays. This was worth the effort of finding it (just across the road from the Zoo entrance), and easy to spend a couple of hours here.
A Moving Experience. This was a moving experience looking at and reading about the German Occupation.Very well put together, well worth a visit.
Very Moving and Informative. I learnt so much about how strong resistance was in Holland. I loved seeing all of the artefacts such as the ID cards, and of course, the yellow stars of David.

Worth a visit. The museum was very well set-up with lots of information so there is quite a lot to read. Would recommend a visit if you are a history fan...takes around 2-3 hours but more time if you want to read details

Nice place, needs better signage. took a while to find, but for WWII buffs, it opened doorways to a different part of the war. It showed that The Netherlands have the courage to reveal that the Nazi occupation has left many scars behind.

A true sense of history. This compact museum gives a true sense of what it must have been like to live under nazi rule in World War Two...a must see for all...far less crowded than the Anne frank museum and far more informative

Very interesting. The meseum tells the story of the resistance movement in German occupied Holland in WW2. It asks some searching questions about about the role of the Dutch in relation to the persecution of the Jews. Interesting and thought provoking.

Well put together and informative. We started with an audio-visual film about a few characters who were caught up in the war. Lots of information, with English translations, picture boards and audio stories. Covers the Dutch colonial history and the war in Asia as well as what was happening in Europe. Nice café bar and bistro beside it.

Informative. If you ever wondered what the Dutch did during the Second World War, this describes it in detail. This museum is packed with historical objects from the time period. It describes how the Nazis slowly turned up the pressure on the Jews and how the Dutch reacted. The final straw was when the Nazis ordered all able-bodied Dutch to work in Germany's war factories.
Good history lesson. The museum is small, but has lots of good information and stories about the WWII era. Audio-guide is included. Lockers for your stuff are free.

Make this museum your #1 Choice!. Absolutely powerful and comprehensive museum of resistance efforts during WWII. The design, displays, audio, video and the building itself are beyond any criticism. I came out of there with a greater understanding of what life was like during occupation - and the types of choices people were forced to make. For example, there were many people who went into hiding during the occupation and many others who risked their lives daily to keep them safe. If you only have time to do one museum in Amsterdam, I would encourage you to make this your choice. It is an easy tram ride to get there and the facilities are top-notch. The reviewer below from Bangor ME gives a much more eloquent and detailed description. All I can say is I was deeply moved by the exhibits and think you will be, too. Hope this review was helpful ... please click yes if it was!

Excellent accounting of the Dutch experience in WWII. This museum provides a remarkably well-presented picture of the experience of the Netherlands and its colonies in the era surrounding WWII. The primary source materials in the exhibits, the audio guides, and the very layout are all excellent. A very moving experience, and one that you can grapple with at your own pace and in your own way. I went alone initially and spent 90 minutes there, and took my husband back a few days later, thinking it might not be terribly interesting a second time around, but I found that the second visit was perhaps even more compelling than the first because there's so much to see and learn that I was able to take more in during the follow-up trip.

Modern museum wi mixed media off beaten track. We went here free with our museum card. Ask for the audio tour it's free if that's your thing. The displays were very well done with a variety of shapes and sizes everything in English!! Even a display inside of desk drawers you pull out. Push a doorbell to hear voices, etc. took us about an hour or so to get through. Find it opposite the zoo entrance tram 14. There is a coffee shop next door you get coffee discount with your ticket withth free wifi. We learned a lot as the Dutch changed their attitude toward the Germans and the Germans started being more strong armed as well. Not much else over that way except rembrandts house is on the way at another stop.
a good follow up to the anne frank house. a much more interesting way to learn history than from a text book. very interesting, moving, and well presented

I am glad that I went. The museum did a great job explaining what happened to the Jews, the Dutch and the Dutch in Indonesia during WWII. I enjoy history and this museum explain what happened in the Netherlands in a fair manner.

Wonderful and Thought Provoking. I first visited the Verztsmuseum in 1990, when it was housed in the middle of a residential area, and, I seem to remember, all in Dutch and Spanish (neither of which I speak) but nevertheless, it was fabulous! I was a little concerned it might have changed, and not for the better, but I needn't have worried' if anything, it was even better!Because we were on a bit of a schedule, we only spent two hours in the museum, but could have easily spent a lot longer. The ground floor focuses on the occupation of Holland during the Second World War, and the persecution of the Dutch Jews. The first floor (which we did not visit) focuses on the Dutch East Indies (I think).The exhibitions are well laid out, the testimonies moving and informative, and the whole museum is spotlessly clean. Audio guides are available, but we didn't use them. I'm just so glad the move and refurbishment haven't affected the museum, as I had such positive memories. I'm sure it won't be be another 23 years before I go back!

Not to be missed. We've been to Amsterdam a number of times before, and I don't know why we had not previously gone to this museum. The content is spectacular and the documentation, audio, and visual impact are extremely well-done. Following the whole chronology of the Netherlands during WW II, the material went way beyond what I'd expected to be the narrower focus on Dutch resistance. There was a tremendous amount of social and cultural context, as well as documentation (written and audio) of historical events. Given the relatively small space, this is also one of the best laid out and presented museums I think I've ever visited. A bonus was a special exhibition on the experiences of the Dutch and local people during Japanese occupation in the Dutch East Indies during the war, with a brief followup of post-war events as the Netherlands tried to hold onto its colonial status there as Indonesia fought for its independence. (I think may Americans forget, or do not know, that the Netherlands was once a major colonial power in the world, a perhaps not so sterling chapter in the country's history.) As other posters have said, I think the museum offers something for people of all ages, and is a "must see" for anyone with an interest in history.

Loved this museum,very informative.. I really enjoyed seeing all the letters and actual pictures of the people who had a part in that horrendous period of history,made it feel real and not just a page in a history book.

Very interesting. We spent an entire morning here, and learned lots about the resistance movement in the 2nd WW. The displays are authentic and videos, photos and recordings all add to that authenticity. Thank you for providing information in English!!!

Can bring you to tears. Some of the stories told in this museum can bring you to tears. This is especially true of the brave Christians who hid Jews during World War II. You are forced to decide whether you would have the courage and fortitude to follow the example of those who risked their lives, and in many cases, gave their lives to bring freedom back to Holland. You have to admire the sacrifices they made to try to get rid of the Germans.

Informative, enlightening and very moving. A beautifully laid-out museum with very detailed displays many consisting of documents and artefacts dating back to the Nazi Occupation of the Netherlands. Highly recommended for anyone interested in 20th-century history,

Tough but great. Frits time I'd been here when in Amsterdam. We were all pretty tired from walking and museums, so did not expect to be up to engage much. In fact, we were gripped from the beginning, my 15 yr old daughter off on her own,, husband too, and we would hook up and pull each other to exhibits we had been fascinated by. Not easy, but one of our top picks.

Well worth the entrance fee. Really interesting look into war life in Amsterdam. I wouldnt class this as a must-see attraction but great location as it just opposite the zoo. The audio tour was included in our entrance fee and I'd definitely recommend it as it gave a more detailed insight than the displays. The free stools were welcome to. As someone who is more interested in History than art I'd definitely recommend this to people with a similar view. Get your 2nd coffee free was a welcome inclusion with the ticket to. However this is a per person offer so cant be used between two people.

Sobering and Uplifting. This museum is the best museum I've ever been to. You get your audio guide and then tumble into the world as the Nazi Empire was beginning to take shape. This is a great museum for all ages. The multi-media presentations, the memorabilia, the actual newspapers, news reports, movie reels are astounding! You really get into the sobering aspects of what slowly was happening in Europe that exploded into Dutch society. The heartbreaking decisions that ordinary people had to make-- to live "normally" under the Nazi regime, or to clandestinely fight the Third Reich in the hopes that the Nazis would be driven out. The firsthand accounts of the Dutch, both Christians and Jews, and their plight and how they had to deal with their circumstances on a daily basis until the final Allied victory.Be sure you are rested and you give yourself plenty of time to see this museum. You may actually need to go back two days to be able to absorb all the exhibits.

Amsterdam WWII outside while Ann Frank was inside. A really fine exposition of the lives of Dutch resistance against the Nazis. It finishes up with the same time in Dutch colonies, especially Indonesia. Very well done

Interesting Museum. A very interesting museum telling a difficult story. Lots of artefacts and plenty of audio visual displays. Most of the displays have an English translation with them. Certainly worth a visit if in the area and it's opposite the Zoo so not hard to miss.

Don't Resist a Visit to this Museum. This is a don't miss museum. It chronicles in film, photograph, and artifacts the Nazi persecution of the people of Amsterdam particularly the Jewish people and the efforts of the brave residents who acted to resist the Nazis including the successes and consequences of their actions. This is a high quality presentation and well worth the time. History has a habit of repeating itself if we do not learn from it - this museum offers a lot to learn.

History of Dutch Resistance. This museum details the Dutch Resistance movement during WWII. They have a lot of interesting artifacts on display, such as a baby buggy used to hide guns as well as many other things.The history is told very well and you come away with a good understanding of what life in the Netherlands was like during this time period.

Poignant. This is a very comprehensive museum, telling of the lead up to the German Occupation and posing the important question - what would you do?aquiesce, collaborate or oppose.Very imaginative and informative displays, well laid out.

The good in people shines through the horror. Really was inspired by this museum. In amongst the heart-wrenching, disgusting, frightening story of the Nazi occupation of the Netherlands, and the Holocaust, was the story of how many, many, many people from all walks of life found ways to resist, fight back, escape, help and hide others and generally be their best human selves. It gave me a spark of hope in these dire times- when things get really bad, the good in people does rise. One lesson I took from it was the need to always teach critical thinking and to question authority from a young age (or learn it as an older person, whatever) - the extent to which the rather conformist, trusting-in-goodness Dutch (including some Jews) went along with the Nazis (who were clever in their manipulativeness) at the start of the occupation was interesting. This exhibit is well-organised, there are English interpretations and audio guides available, and the staff are friendly and helpful. Overall it does the job it sets out to do- tells the story of the Dutch resistance, and invites you to think about how you would respond.

Thought Provoking but Lacking Detail. No lines to get in are great, but the ticket cost to enter is a little expensive. Audio guide is free (refundable deposit) and worth getting.Whilst the display is well set up and gave some case histories of different people living in Amsterdam during the war, it lacked specific details of exactly how the resistance worked I.e. what did they do to be resistant?It was thought provoking, but just lacked a bit of depth.

Interesting. If you are at all interested in war history you should definitely visit this museum. The entrance fee wasn't too bad (€8) and almost everything have information in English. I was there for 1.5 hours but wished I could have stayed for at least 45 more minutes. The only thing I lacked was some translations of the original newspapers etc. in the museum. It existed for some but not for as many I as would have liked.

Interesting visit. Fascinating, educational & yet harrowing insight into life under occupation.Located a bit off the tourist route from the centre of Amsterdam, but certainly worth a visit to understand how people lived & survived, in what was an extremely challenging time in the City's history.

well worth a visit.. Imaginatively designed and displayed this tells the story of the Dutch during the resistance, both good and bad.
Very moving and well worth a visit.

Very Intresting but the Introductionary video Ruined my Day. This Museum is a very interesting one . It is very nicely laid out and had loads of things to read and see . The story of Dutch Occupation is a very interesting one . The Down side comes to their poor excuse for an educational film. I went to to upper section to watch it and am confronted with a disgusting man wearing a bandanna presenting the film . I have a degree in Education and Love history this mans clothing was totally unacceptable for the topic he pissed me off so much I had to leave and he ruined the whole experience for me . What do these people think they are doing really makes me feel like do they care about history at all !!!!!!!

Excellent!. It was time well spent - a bit off the beaten path but it is nice to get away from the touristy areas. The displays were excellent and gave me a different view of the country in war, and the extremes the citizens went to, to protect their own. If you only have time for one museum and an interest in the war, this is it.

Out of the way but worth the trip. This museum, off the beaten museum path (it's out next door to the Zoo, not too far from Rembrandt plaza), is very worthwhile. The resistance is a big part of the Dutch experience, and it turns out to have been a very complex phenomenon. An appealing quality of the Dutch is their honesty about their history, and that infuses this museum too, with tales of informants and collaborators mixed in with the stories of heroism. If you don't want to make the 30-40 minute walk from the Center, take the 9 Tram. This is an excellent value-added experience on your Museumkaart.

War history. Historical museum about the Dutch resistance during the war. Has a lot of authentic material and information and the exhibition is quite easy to follow forward in the correct order (you may wish to take the audio guide to get more info) and each and every sign and info is printed also in English. The story focuses quite much on people involved and I perhaps would have hoped more about the "big picture".We combined this with the visit to the zoo as they were in the same area, and those two made nearly a full day's worth of program. If you are interested of the war era then this should be on your list - but not so sure if this is an area that has a wide general interest.

Better than I thought!. Was already enticed by the reviews and found it to be much more interesting than I imagined it to be! Be patient as it does take time to read through but well worth taking in, a lot of 'artefacts' as well as the interactive side. Well worth the €9!

Fascinating. What would you do? This museum was started by former members of the Dutch resistance out of concern for the rise of Neo-Nazi groups in the 1980's. Gives a real sense of the time, and the choices people made. How do you deal with an evil occupier? Big, futile gesture or many small insults? Be sure to buy a Museumkaart.
a bit of a hidden gem. This is so worth it! Right across the street from the zoo. I hope they will collaborate and do some version of the exhibit about what happened at the zoo in WWII.
Interesting museum for WWII buffs. Small museum with detailed pictorial history of German occupation of Netherlands. Provides information not familiar to many people.

Educational and informative about the Dutch in WWII.. Most enjoyable two hurs. Exhibit is explained in both Dutch and English.....lots of information about the struggles against the Nazis and how difficult life was for the Dutch. Only 8 Euroand that includes a interpretive audio if you wish to use it.
Well worth the visit. A great collection of information, great to give you an idea of how life was in those dark times. Well worth the couple of hours.

An honest view of Dutch resistance. A well balanced view of Dutch resistance during the Second World War. Everything is translated to English except for actual artefacts (news papers, letters and the like)

Profound!. This museum shows the courage of people under occupation. I enjoyed the exhibits that discussed who cooperated with the Nazis & who did not. The stroller with a gun stashed away was the most striking part. It's important to remember that the Nazi occupation could not have worked as long as it did if there was not some cooperation from the locals. This was more interesting than the Anne Frank house in my opinion.

Another view of the Netherlands in World War II. The museum presents a picture of what choices the Dutch had to collaborate or resist the German occupation. It does not condemn one side or the other, but lays out the situation and results

The Underground is alive in A'Dam. It was an intimate and insightful exhibition on the people of Amsterdam during the Nazi Occupation. The different facets of the occupation are represented in a maze-like exhibition that mirrors the complexity and confusion of Amsterdam's social sects and their relationships. It's a lot of reading, absorbing, and self-motivated connecting-the-dots, but the stories of heroism rising from tragedy are inspiring and keep you engaged. My favorite parts were the installments depicting the espionage tactics the resistance used. There is real microfilm and trap doors preserved for viewing.The museum tried hard to make the exhibit interactive, but the sensitive nature of the artifacts and the limited resources make this difficult to achieve. It's not for the whole family as of right now, but they will be opening a children's wing soon. Not sure what that might include.Worth the trip and worth the time (again, this was included in the price of the Iamsterdam card)! Plus, if location is everything, it's right next to the Zoo! Fun for all!

Good background from the Nazi occupation. Not much about the radio communication from the Resistance to England. A very comprehensive coverage of the Jewish situation and the deportations. Although most is in Dutch we found the essentials has English translations.

Worthwhile Undertaking. Very new museum addressing a difficult subject. The exhibits are scattered about to allow for easier crowd absorption, but looses some of the focus along the way. Still, hard to understand what life was like at that time in that place without personalized exhibits. Recommended.
resistance museum. excellent presentation. chronological. well organized. very informative. a lot of information we had not seen previously. good background material

a museum we all need to visit. the audio guide is excellent - as many of the visual information boards are not translated into languages other than Dutch. If you are a wooss like me, take some tissues, as some of the stories are heartwrenching. Sad that students from all over Europe aren't taken here to read what can happen when good people are subverted and divided. Wonderful that their stories have been saved and shared. Glad we went

Very Interesting. We learnt a lot of what went on in Holland during the second world war.Done in a very interesting easy to follow way,with many old photos , letters and short films as you wander around the museum which is opposite the entrance to Amsterdam Zoo !!

Makes you think.... Sometimes its hard to visualize what the people went through during the 2nd World War. This museum brings it to life in a way no other museum does. We make it a point to visit these museums so we dont forget what happens when intolerance and ignorance run rampant and this place is among the best at accomplishing this. They tell the story of all the groups that were affected, not only Jews but the people that were their friends, people that were not intolerant, other groups that were marginalized too but didnt receive as much press as the Jews. Even though is Amsterdam, this museum doesnt focus on Anne Frank. She is just but one of the many that were victims during that time and it showcases all those other cases that were just as heartbreaking as hers.

Worth Learning. This is a wonderful little museum away from all the noise of Amsterdam. We walked from our hotel and that in itself was pleasant. So much history about a part of the war that often isn't discussed in America. We are history buffs so we were really moved by the experience. Bought some fascinating reads.

Very well done.. Amsterdam has a unique perspective on surviving the war, and you'll learn all about it here. I would recommend grabbing an English audio guide, but it's not entirely necessary. I would say this is a key part of any trip to Amsterdam. We were only there for a day and a half, but you really should squeeze it in.
Very Interesting Museum. Well displayed and very moving. You will need some tissues as you read the harrowing events the people of Amsterdam had to endure!

Fascinating history. I hadn't known much about the occupation of the Netherlands, but WWII had become a theme of the vacation museums. This ties in well with the Anne Frank house and really shows the personal stories and war events that are presented through many documents, audio clips, and other media, including a thorough audioguide. Took me 2.5 hours to look at everything pretty closely.

One of the best museums in Amsterdam. Although not so well known as, for instance, Anne Frank House or the Rijksmuseum, the Verzets Museum is one of the best and most interesting places in Amsterdam for anyone interested in Dutch culture, and the history of the Netherlands. It tells the story of the rise of Nazi-ism in the Netherlands, and then the Nazi occupation, year by year, and of course the story of the local resistance to that occupation -- little known even to many Dutch people. I recommend the museum to all my visitors here in Amsterdam, and without exception, all who go come away inspired and enthralled.

Very Interesting. This museum gave as a broader perspective of the Nazi occupation of the Netherlands. Previously I had always viewed that horrible period of history from the perspective of the Jews without consideration how it affected other people and nations. This museum gave a chronological account of the events from 1940 to1945 and definitely broaden my understanding of that period of history. We went to the Anne Frank House the following day and our visit to The Resistance Museum made that experience all the more better!

Resistance Museum. This also was insightful as to the actions and suffering of the people during the war.It was well laid out and it portraid and you will need substantial amount of time to view the whole museum .

Powerful education on the Nazi Occupation and the Dutch Resistance. This museum offers a powerful and detailed historical account of the Nazi occupation of the Netherlands and the efforts that brave Dutch citizens took to forestall or counteract the Nazi atrocities. The story is portrayed in chronological order so that you can better understand the course of events. At first, life went on more or less as usual, even though the queen had taken refuge in England, but gradually and horrifically, the Nazis imposed more and more restrictions on the people in general, but especially on the Jews. There are numerous personal stories of the efforts, large and small, to cope with or fight the oppressors. Display cases contain personal memorabilia and accounts of individual actions that had been taken. The fate of the individuals was provided. Many of the people in the resistance movement were killed. This museum was a fascinating education on this time in history and an excellent adjunct to a visit to the Anne Frank House.

Very interesting. Did not realise there was an audio tour! This would've made our visit better, as I could see that I was missing out a part of the story. Apart from this - very well laid out, with a huge amount of information and personal stories which made it more interesting, and very real. Would recommend - give 3 hours, to be safe.

One of the best. I actually thought this was one of the best museums we went to. It flowed in a chronological order, was thought-provoking (constantly asking what you would do - endorse, accept, or resist) and covered the subject very thoroughly. I actually learned more here about the persecution of Jews by the Nazis than in the Jewish Museum down the road. Highly recommended.

A lot to take in but worth it. The museum covers in great detail many of factors that played a part in the situation of the Dutch people leading up to and during the Second World War. At times there really is a lot to take in.Many of the captions/descriptions do have English text too, but they only cover part of the story being told. There is a free audio tour available, but as others have said you might not be told about this. This was not mentioned to us when we bought our tickets & instead inquired with the other staff member handing them out (thanks to a tip from here warning of the tour). The audio tour gives far more information & access to background & information or stories. Depending how much information you read & take in I'd probably say you want 1-2 hours to visit.

A lot to read, mostly in English. Plenty to read about wartime in Amsterdam. Focuses heavily on the moral dilemma about hiding the Jewish population. Wish it had been more in depth about how this was actually done.

Informative and interesting. If you have any interest in the second world war and especially intrigued by how a country survives under occupation this is a good place to spend some time. There are stories here of heroism; of reluctant 'heroes'; of compromise and then straightforward collaboration. It is a series of exhibits which try to capture the varied daily experiences of Dutch people and Amsterdammers in particular. The agonising decisions of those who reluctantly co-operated to attempt to ameliorate the worst excesses of Nazi occupation and the way in which the occupiers gradually became punitive. There were heart rending stories and overall it was a couple of hours well spent. Yes, there are some difficulties with translation if you have no Dutch (or for that matter, German) - but there are sufficient English language translations to make it clear what is going on, in fact most of the exhibits have adequate translations. The staff were helpful and there is to be a children's museum opening later in the year. Perhaps not a 'must' but well worth the time ...

Important to visit . Very easy to access by tram, this museum is located opposite the entrance to the zoo. It seems quite new and very well kept. Entry is a reasonable price and includes your second coffee free at the cafe next door. To learn of the plight of the Resistance during WW2 this museum is very informative yet it doesnt overload with heavy information. It is quite interactive and would allow at least 1.5-2 hours if you are to take the time to read all the information.

Interesting Material. This museum does a good job of explaining the difficulties ordinary citizens faced in day to day life under the Nazis. Resistance came in many forms, and several of them are highlighted here. The museum has a nice flow to it, with little side areas detailing the personal stories of some of the local folks. It's worth the visit, give it two to three hours. The 9 or 14 tram to Plantage Kerklaan, then about a 5 minute walk.
Well worth a visit. Very interesting. This is a good museum to visit. We have now been twice. It is historically a must if you appreciate Amsterdam's history.

Very interesting!. I would agree with some of the other reviews that the staff was rude and unhelpful, but the museum is worth the effort. We bought our tickets and entered the museum not realizing that there were few English explanations. The staff didn't mention that they had a gizmo that would give you English explanations. If we hadn't asked some one inside the museum, we never would have known. It would have been a 10 minute visit if we didn't have the gizmo, but with all the explanations we really enjoyed it. The exhibit was from the perspective of the average person....do they join the Nazi movement just to get along, do they try to stay under the radar, or do they actively resist? There were many examples of what different people did. I kept trying to think about what I would have done given what was at stake. I really enjoyed it, but customer service is nonexistent....although, this was the only place in Amsterdam that people were not friendly or helpful. It's a hike to get to the museum, but we thought it was worth it.

POOR QUALITY GRAPHICS-HEART WRENCHING REMINDERS.. Was quite disappointed with the layout of the Verzetsmuseum. The whole 'exhibition' was in my opinion spoiled by the poor quality graphics. The massive enlargement of old black and white photographs were naturally very fuzzy, this ended up giving me a headache due to my eyes constantly trying to focus on the pictures on the walls and panels. The exhibits on show were I have to say memorable, from the 'bits and pieces' bicycle to the heart wrenching (translated) letters written during a hellish time of cruelty and mass murder beyond comprehension, in Europe's history.Suggest a bit of computer enhancement for graphic displays. If interested in history in the raw form, a must.

a very well laid out museum. Just across the road from the zoo on the #5 tram line. You could spend a whole day here if you're a history buff, especially world war II of course. Lots of interactive exhibits as it tells the story of pre war Netherlands, the invasion and liberation through three standpoints. Adapt, Resist or Collaborate. Excellent value for money too.

Very interesting. We were surprised and amazed by this museum. It was so informative.
One downside was that they did not mention Canada at all regarding the liberation of Amsterdam.

Very interesting and education. Excellent museum with free audioguides. The audioguides make you slow down and examine the artifacts in the museum. Lots to learn about the Dutch Resistance here with plenty of anecdotes.

Small but worthwhile museum. A museum dedicated to the dark days of Amsterdam & the Netherlands under Nazi occupation. Many artifacts and some video and audio. Very interesting for history buffs. A little off the beaten path, located near the Zoo.

Very interesting and value for money.. This was perhaps a slightly unusual choice for a couple in their mid twenties (as was made quite obvious by everybody else touring the museum) but we found the excursion to be very informative and interesting, with lots of attention to detail. It's just by the zoo so you could combine a visit, but be aware that they don't accept all types of cards (i.e. visa is a nono which surprised us a bit).For the price (8 euros) it was a long visit of about two hours, spent reading and watching various things, tracking Jewish history until the modern day. I would not recommend this museum for children for that reason - it relied heavily upon reading and would probably be very boring to a child, although they are opening a children's area, so perhaps it will become more exciting for younger generations.

First museum we visited during our Amsterdam stay and one of the best. We found the staff very helpful. All the exhibits are explained in both Dutch and English. The introductory video is not to be missed.This facility is in a nice neighborhood with a lot of old buildings and a neat canal bridge right down the street. We could have spent more time than we did to fully explore.The exhibits are very well done and this place tells a story that needs to be remembered for all time.

Telling an untold story of WW2. This is an excellent "little" (although seemingly growing with a forthcoming addition of a Children's Museum) place that tells the story of a somewhat largely untold one of WW2. Yes, large parts of the displays are in Dutch - recovered letters, newspapers, posters, propaganda leaflets etc - but the accompanying English descriptions on the walls/displays is enough to give you a complete account of the story. Allow for 60-90 minutes to fully absorb the exhibits.

Good for a rainy afternoon. I'm a student of WWII history, so this was right up my alley. The museum is mostly various diaramas depicting life in Holland before, during and just after the war. There are few actual historic items on display, most are reproductions of letters, papers, posters, photos and identification cards of the times. The exhibits are presented in both Dutch and English, so language was not a problem. I enjoyed reading the text of each exhibit, but I can see that if it isn't a subject you're interested in it may be a bit boring.

Fascinating Insights. A fascinating and involving museum giving a context to the wartime experiences of The Netherlands - the good, the bad, and the ugly. Refreshingly honest, and often deeply moving - did make you wonder, "What If"? What if it had been my country, my town, my family - what would I have done?

Thought provoking for adults. If you are interested in history, this is a really good museum, although would suggest largely for adults or older children. (A children's annex is in construction but is not yet open). The subject matter of the museum is wider than what you would imagine as the resistance movement, it encompasses the resistance of the population as a whole......the strikes by workers, the ways in which those in civil service positions tried to make things more difficult for the occupies, as well as workers working that little bit slower.The subject matter is quite emotionally draining (including letters thrown out of the cattle trucks as people were deported to the camps) and you can come out of the museum at any point and go into the nice and quite reasonably priced cafe attached......and then go back in.

Well presented but dry. Although the content was well laid out and there was a podcatcher (audio that responded to "pods" on the walls), there was a lot to read and the narrator on the podcatcher did not make the content "live". The theme is how ordinary Dutch people chose to adapt, collaborate or resist the Nazi occupation, rather than stories of the Dutch Resistance. We took the Blue Line "hop on hop off" canal boat to the Maritime Museum and did not find signs to the museum until we were fairly close, by which time we had walked the long way round to get there.

Disappointed. I was looking forward to visiting this place and went there with my mother, sister and 17 year old son. On queuing to pay I noticed there was an elderly American guy and his wife in front of us and I was a bit shocked at how rude and dismissive one of the staff was to him when he was asking about an audio guide in English. The same short haired woman served us and gave us short shrift too with no information at all.There is a lot to see here and and while there is some English writing an English audio guide would have been useful. At the end we noticed the Indonesian bit and the upstairs film which the lady at the reception made no mention of.I left feeling disappointed..

Well Organized Account of Resistance. Ineresting Account in English and Dutch...of Hitler's rise and fall and how it affected the Dutch government and people. On a side street so easy to walk by without noticing museum. Close to zoo

Disappointing Museum. The reviews were excellent so we decided to visit this museum while in Amsterdam and found it disappointing. While some things were in English, others were not which was frustrating. The organization was confusing. And, though there were some wonderful tidbits, for some reason we weren't deeply moved by the material as we expected to be. A wonderful idea that fell flat in execution.

Shows you only need a few to start a movement. From the U.S. I did not know about the Dutch Resistance during WW2. This museum does have a lot of information and provides an audio tour. The only dislike I have is the layout as it is a bit confusing on which order you should view displays. This really is minor as the wealth and detail of information is amazing.

A fascinating museum. The museum presents in a non-judgemental manner the choices faced by Dutch people during the Nazi occupation; to collaborate, to adapt or to resist. I found it fascinating yet challenging. The exhibits were of a good quality and were presented in the Dutch and English languages. A recommended visit.

Very educational. Well presented information in English as well as Dutch. Made us all think about the resistance movement during the war and how brave they all were. Well worth visiting, but you need a good 1.5 to 2 hours to do it justice.

Interesting and informative. We have always been interested about how people coped during the war and this gave us a different view, that of the Dutch and the battles they faced during occupation. Good exhibition on the Indonesian links as well. Lovely guys on the desk, very friendly and welcoming.

Fantastic. We visited this museum prior to an evening visit to the Frank House. We spent several hours in the museum (8 and 9 years old) and were moved by some of the stories we heard, really well worth a trip with a fantastic number of exhibits.

Something different and very interesting. This tells of a wonderful story of the underground resistance fights of Holland during World War II. It is very well presented and we learnt a lot from the stories told. Well worth a visit for a change not another church of not another art museum:)
Very moving. A very thought provoking museum. Lots of really interesting information but layout is a little confusing at times. Well worth a visit.

Interesting information about Amsterdam during the nazi invasion. Overall it was detailed oversight of what happened when hitlers crew arrived in the 'dam. Quite the bit of reading but very interesting ! This would suit the patient older generation or those with an interest in WW2 history.

A canny look at Dutch Resistance. I went there in part because a friend's parents were decorated aft the war for their role in the Resistance, but the more I have the more I have found that those in the resistance may have been rather a minority. This Museum was highly evocative, was extraordinarily laid out, and clearly presented the cases for collaborate, accept OR resist 'which would you have done'?' My admiration for my friends' parents bloomed hugely.

Very Informative and Moving. I visited the Resistance Museum after seeing the Anne Frank House and found it to be an extremely informative and moving experience. I learned a great deal about a part of World War II history I previously hadn't known about and the exhibit kept me interested and well informed. There was a free audio guide provided (mine did not work but I did not end up replacing it as I found the plaques and information available sufficient) and the whole museum took me probably 3 hours to go through. I did read everything and look closely at each exhibition so you could probably do it in less depending on how much depth you wanted.The tram number 9 takes you close to this museum. Get off at the stop for Artis (ask the tram driver) and then walk down the hill from the tram stop. It is pretty much opposite and a little further down the road than the Artis itself. The weekend I went it was Museum Weekend so only €1 to get in but I did not check to see how much it normally costs. Either way, it is worth a visit.

Loved it. One of the best museums I've been to. Loved it. Me and my partner spent about 3 hours in there, we read every single artifact! The people on the desk were very friendly and helpful also. Toilets easy accesible also.

Very informative. I was very impressed by the Verzetsmuseum - a clear journey through Dutch WWII history from 1940 until 1945. Most of the exhibits have labels in both English and Dutch, and the storyboards give just the right amount of information. Probably not suitable for under-12s.

confusing. It isn't easy to find this museum and sadly we arrived with only 1 hour to closing so had to rush. All the English audio guides were in use and despite English being spoken almost everywhere in Amsterdam it is in short supply in this museum. The lay out was rather confusing to us but we did enjoy it and to see pictures and read what ordinary people went through was an eyeopener.

Alot to read but worthwhile. Very friendly/helpful reception staff who directed us to the lockers as bags need to be left (2 Euro but is returned).All exhibits behind the wooden doors (where the museum really starts) have an English translation and you follow the boards around from 1940 through to 1945. My 12 yr old son was kept interested, though they are building a version for children - one room is open but is all in Dutch.We were here for a few hours - lots of photographs, a few interactive exhibits (such as magnifying glass to look at forged ID cards vs. real). Very good value for money and a moving experience.
Not in English. Rude staff, not in English, not much to see, glad it was free on our Iamsterdam card.We didn't enjoy it and stayed for about 5 minutes, as we couldn't understand anything.

Great and Informative. This place was highly recommended to us by friends. It is 8 euros for entry and it includes an audio guide in English or Dutch. They have set up this exhibit in cubicles or tiny rooms around the interior, each depicting the story of what the Dutch Jews endured from 1940 to 1944 during Hitler's reign. Then there are other exhibits in the center; again, each display showing authentic documents, newspaper articles, notes, objects, maps--all telling various stories of what went on in Holland at the time. The most interesting story was about how the Dutch themselves were torn into two factions: those who sided with the Nazis, and those who formed a resistance union and stood up to the atrocities. Of the 140,000 Jews who lived in Holland at the time, only 18,000 remained at the end of the war. Very moving, the audio stories are enlightening. I felt that I was experiencing the suffering and all that went on through the exhibits.

Excellent Information with Interactive experience. I love museums like this, they take you on a journey of information and interactive experience, you learn without studying... you just flow and feel what it was all about. I don't want to spoil and tell you what happens, go and you will not be dissapointed..

Excellent experience.. This museum is across from the entrance for the Artis Zoo, so easily combines with that activity if you're so inclined. I loved the way this museum is arranged - the displays are creative, and draw you in. At the display of an actual house door and stoop, you stand and ring the bell. Then you hear recorded voices (in your chosen language) telling you why they have to turn you away. It is easy to imagine that you're terrified of being discovered and have nowhere to go. For many of the exhibits, you are peeking inside windows to see them, which gives you an added sense of the fear that must have gripped this nation. There are desk drawers and cabinets you can open to see documents or artifacts - which this little museum has a treasure trove of. There are actual notes thrown from transport trains, ration cards, a baby carriage with false bottom to accommodate the hidden transport of grenades and guns. Tiny notes written in code, wristwatches with hidden compartments, real and false passports for you to inspect and decide which are real. This is a very interactive museum. Most household items are shown in a natural setting. Many, many interesting things to look at - German helmets made into bedpans, printing presses used to produce illegal resistance newspapers, etc. No worries if you only speak English - everything is translated. I've been to many holocaust museums and for me, this little gem was the best of all. It really gave you a sense of what Holland was like under the Nazis. Good for children - there are so many things you can touch.

Informative. At the beginning you are told that you can "resist, collude or get along". There were told many stories of people who colluded with the enemy, some who resisted, and some who just adjusted and got along day by day. It takes a few hours to really see it all.

Small but interesting. This is a worthwhile addition to the Amsterdam museum scene, created in response to rise of right-wing groups. It is intended to remind people that many of Dutch initially thought that the Nazi takeover was relatively benevolent and they were slow to wake to its horrors. An interesting and frightening story, well told. Better for teenagers rather than small children.
Worth a visit. It was very interesting and most definatley worth a visit. However visit was tarnished by large groups of school children who thought they were in a play ground.

Fascinating. Very interesting, have never seen or heard of so much of a country being a part of a resistance movement. Having lived in the Netherlands for 13 months, the questions raised in the museum are still pertinent for today. Adapt, Collaborate or Resist. What roll does society have to protect and speak out for the minority and the less powerful? Been to many WWII memorials here so this was very fascinating.
Amsterdfam during World War II. Excellent museum. Very moving stories and exhibits. Situated opposite the Artis Zoo and easy to get to.

A lot of interesting info but a bit dry.. There's lots of information about the resistance during World War 2. There are lots of images and objects and it's laid out well, however to know what they are you have to read a LOT.I found the map of jewish homes in Amsterdam to be especially chilling, and it was interesting to find out about the Dutch experiences in the Far East - a part of WW2 that, as a Brit, we don't learn much about.It's €8 but you do get a free coffee at the cafe next door.If history is your thing then check it out, if not I'd maybe give it a miss.

Much Better Than Expected. The perspective is not from a military point of view, but from a civilian point of view. When we were there there were a number of school groups there as well. Very well done.

This is a slice of life you don't see too often.. My wife & I visited this sobering museum on Saturday March 16, 2013. It was a cold and dreary day which nicely match the subject matter of this entire museum. Once again, audio guides are strongly suggest and even though all the signage is in English & Dutch, there is so much more given on these audio guides-well worth the extra couple of euros. The museum is well laid out and easy to follow with lots of stops to listen to recordings, view pictures and articles on display. The entire floor plan is level and goes in chronological order by date. Plan to come when it opens at 11 AM because you'll need all that time to go through it all.

Nice museum tour. The artwork on display was superb. I never appreciated art until I spent some time really examinging the paintings and learning about each piece and artist. The Rembrandt's will amaze you when you are 6 feet from them.

A must see while in Amsterdam, a true story very well told.. We visited this museum while in Amsterdam. Although we arrived at 4:15 pm and they close at 5:00 we stayed anyway. We are so glad we did. It is laid out very well and easy to navigate. It chronicles the time leading up to, during and after the Nazi's captured, brutalized and tried to break the Dutch people. It uses documents and original artifacts to tell the sometimes confusing story of a people that choose not to fight and die for their freedom and lost it. It lays out how the Jewish people were targeted by Hitler's regime for ridicule, torture and death. It offers a compelling case for sticking together and fighting for our freedoms. In the end the Dutch resistance stayed in the fight and welcomed the Allied troops as they fought and died for freedom for all. A true, eye opening and sober story worth learning about.

A significant story well told. This is a brilliant museum and would strongly recommend to anyone with an interest in history or modern Dutch culture.A difficult subject is handled by using the theme 'Adapt, Resist, or Collaborate?'Great historical materials, great telling of experiences through individual stories.Intended only to be in there for 30 minutes and spent all afternoon there!Easy access via tram - got the #9 from outside the central station.Would like to see extra exhibitions on the German perspective and from those deported.A real must-see in Amsterdam

Give yourself at least two hours. It was really interesting to learn more about the resistance movements and the reactions of the Dutch to the second world war but there is a LOT to take in - it'll take at least two hours. Very interactive.

Aircrew Review. The Resistance Museum is small but very well done. Our concierge suggested 1 to 1&1/2 hours was needed to tour it. Well, yes and no! I only budgeted 1&1/2 hours and unfortunately felt hurried through the museum. I think one of the biggest short-comings of the museum is that I do not speak or read Dutch! I wish I did! The exhibits are very interesting. Some are originals and others reproductions. I just wish i had been able to read and understand them. Posters. Newspapers. Personal letters. Radio broadcasts. So, although small, I do not think this is one to rush through.From the Central Station, take tram #9 to the Plantage Kerklaan stop. From the Dam, tram #14. The museum ticket costs ~8 euros. That includes admission and a free audio guide as well as a free SECOND cup of coffee at the adjacent coffee shop.
Disappointed.. Not sure exactly what we expected but it wasn't what we got.The exhibits are good but not as interactive a we were looking for.

Choices, choices - what a choice!!. Very polite reception staff, they understood my basic dutch and explained that most of the exhibition was in dutch but was captioned in English. We started with two videos by two elderly gentlemen who had been in the forced labour camps. They explained they had a choice. Collaborate with the germans or be sent to the labour camps, if they tried to hide, the germans would hurt their families and they would still be sent to the labour camps. After being in the labour camps when it was all over they were shunned by their old neighbours because they had collaborated. What a choice! The museum is a chronological story over a number years and has personal stories of what happened to people during this time.It demonstrates another dimension to the second world war that we don't know about because we are not taught about it.There are stories about the resistance and spies (real ones) and what they did during the warThere are some humourous tales but you have to find them. A very informative museum and well worth the time

Interesting museum about the Second World War in The Netherlands. More interesting than Anne Frankhouse, impressive and very good to get the ambiance of those days, cheap and no queues, it's opposite to the eentrance of the zoo

Great Piece of History. I was in the resistance museum with one of my children it was very educational for him and myself. It is humbling to learn the sacrifices of the people of Amsterdam and the Netherlands during WW II. There are many interesting exhibits and lots of explanations of them. It is easy to reach and a good museum to spend a morning at.

Very interesting, learned a lot. We found out about this museum by chance but it was well worth the trip as it really opened our eyes to the experiences of ordinary people living under occupation - especially interesting was the section about the Japanese occupation of what was then the Dutch East Indies and the aftermath of this. Very poignant accounts from real people and a testament to the bravery of many.

Piece of History little known - A MUST to visit. MUST go to learn about a piece of history little known by most.Quiet area, do take the free audio tour which is included in the admission fee, allow about 2 hours; nice cafe/bar adjacent to use before & after your visit.

Good value, deserves a 3.5. While The Resistance Museum is quite informative I found the overall experience fairly dull. There are very few interactive exhibits and much of the information was rather boringly presented. Like some of the other reviews point out this museum is geared more towards locals than tourists. Being of partial Dutch heritage myself and interested in this period of Dutch history I was a little disappointed as I expected to enjoy my visit a little more.

Worth making the trip. This little museum may possibly be lost behind the fame of the Anne Frank House but it's worth the trek. It tells the stories of the brave men and women who fought for freedom under Nazi occupation. The stories of ordinary Dutch men and women who couldn't bear to see what was happening to their Jewish friends and the museum gives accounts of such remarkable individuals.
Excellent. Provided an excellent overview of the questions and issues the residents faced. Audio tour was simple to use and informative. Highly recommend.

Very well thought out.. This is very well worth visiting. The audio guide is easy to use and each piece of commentary is informative without being over-long. It is possible to listen to more information if you are interested in a particular area, or you can move on at your own pace and leave some things out, though I doubt whether you would want to. Each general point is given a personal touch by the inclusion of a personal story, which makes the story more forceful. The items on display have been carefully selected and many were obviously saved and kept for many years to act as a testament to what happened during the war. There is an interesting section on Dutch colonial power at the end, and the museum is also expanding to include a children's section.

Very interesting. Although it is a little bit out of the way I thought this attraction was good value for money, friendly staff, and very educational. Worth a visit for sure! Lots of items to look at and little rooms for children to explore. You could also reward them with a trip to the zoo which is just across the road.

Visit. Well worth a visit, currently being expanded. Liked the way that it showed how the general population were affected by the occupation. Would have liked more information on the actual resistance.

Well worth a visit. This is a very interesting museum with lots of individual stories which makes the war years more real to the visitor. You find out how ordinary Dutch people dealt with the occupation (good and bad) and you learn a lot about different attitudes and beliefs in the Netherlands at that time and also after the war. Particularly to those few who returned from the concentration camps or forced labour in Germany.

Good samples of the war. We made it after the very nice WW2 Walking Tour with Peter Schaapman, http://historywalks.eu/ which we do recommend as well. Once visiting we see how it was tough to survive a war in an small city.

if you are in to history well worth a visit. This is what is good about Amsterdam the variety of places there are to visit, this museum really brought to light how much the Netherlands suffered during and after D Day, I learnt so much. It takes a good 2 hours to get around everything.

A good museum to visit. Well-laid out and well presented. You will learn about the 5-year German occupation of the Netherlands during WW2. I did not know much about this topic but came away more knowledgeable.Dutch society prior to the war is explained, life, attitudes and beliefs during are examined as well as after.As previous reviewers have mentioned the museum is very interactive. Allow at least 2 hours to visit properly.

Take your time.. This is a very interesting museum dealing with WW2. There is alot to see and as much to read, so I wouldnt go if you are in a rush or have small children. Very informative and interesting.

informative. this is great museum so much information and done in such a way that it never becomes boring we spent 2 hours enjoying every minute its laid out into cul de sacs each one telling a different story we certainly learnt quite a lot of things which we were previouly unaware

Wicked awesome!. One of our favorite museums in Europe. Honestly. It was very interactive and informative... and we LOVED the special exhibit on the personalized quilts made by prisoners in concentration camps. Surprisingly engaging two and a half hours of our time.

interesting museum. I took the tram out from amsterdam centraal station and it is located opposite the zoo. spent about 2 hours here. I thought it was very interesting on what happened in Holland during the War. found the area where the Dutch were trying to hold onto Indonesia during the end of the year. worth a visit. there is a locker there before you enter the museum area to put your bag away if you want to

The font used for displays. It was very hard to read the fabulous displays information because of the type of font used. Otherwise, it was an impressive collection of photographs and artifacts, and I would like to return.

An experience more recommendable for Dutch rather than foreign visitors. A glimpse of the history, interesting to see school children having probably their history lesson in the museum, for better understanding of their history. But targeting mostly Dutch visitors, not very friendly with foreigners in terms of explanations

interesting story of Dutch resistance movement. small well laid out informative museum detailing the history and development of the resistance to occupying forces in WW2 Good audio tour in English included in the price if admission (E8) Takes about 2 hrs to do . New development of children's museum extension underway.

Interesting museum. More biased towards the awful treatment of the Jewish communities in Amsterdam by the Germans in WW2 rather than active resistance movement. Museum layout a bit muddled and it wasn't until we left that we found a tiny floor plan printed on reverse of ticket! Most exhibits provided with English translation (except for wall display along entrance corridor). A number of display cases force you look through tiny cut-out openings we we thought was daft as it was pointless and made viewing difficult. Important to have this sort of museum but could be greatly improved.

What Would You Do If the Bad Guys Conquered your Country?. The jack booted Nazi thugs invaded and took over Holland in WWII. It wasn't a fair fight for little Holland and the museum will tell you all about that. But the central theme and question is, "What would YOU do if the bad guys conquered your country?" The Dutch answer to that question is this unflinching and critical review of the Dutch by the Dutch in the form of this fascinating museum.The Germans dissolved the legitimate government, crushed the labor unions, sent Dutch youth into forced labor in Germany, rounded up the Jews and the homosexuals and sent them off to concentration camps, looted the food supplies and even melted down their church bells to make war materials. The Gestapo arrested, tortured and killed Dutch citizens for even small acts of resistance.Some Dutch resisted in every way possible. And gave their lives for it. Some enthusiastically collaborated with the Nazis. And paid a price for it later. Some kept their heads down and tried to wait it out. Others passively resisted, or hid fugitives in their homes and businesses. This museum tells all of those stories and is a Dutch national exploration, sometimes heroic, sometimes not, of the ways in which people reacted to their occupation and brutal subjugation. My wife and I spent 3 very absorbing hours in this museum. We learned a lot. The Dutch are determined not to forget this episode in their history and the rest of us shouldn't either.
Great historical exhibit. Great exhibit for travelers interested in WWII history. We really enjoyed the artifacts and learned a lot from the museum.

very interesting. a nice museum very informative with lots to learn, information given in English also. learnt lots more of how many Dutch people suffered during the war years.. nice displays .. very clean . a lovely coffee shop restaurant next door accessed from the museum.. you could visit this and also the zoo which is almost opposite if touring this area of Amsterdam

Really interesting, great overview of history. The Verzetsmuseum is definitely a place for any history buff, WWII enthusiast, or visitor fascinated by the resistance movements of the war. It really gives perspective on how very difficult times were and there is also a very interesting exhibition about the invasion of Indonesia.

Great way to while away an hour or two.. Only found this by chance but what a great place to visit. It provided the background and reasoning behind what I had previously thought to be somewhat illogical decisions and actions. Great way to while away an hour or two.

Worth the Trip. A very worthwhile visit. It was interesting for me further understand this aspect of WWII. Also, to see the coordinated effort and techniques the resistance took to fight. If this the slightest bit interesting to you, I would make the visit.
