Living history. The way this museum is set out feels a little disorganised. This gave me a real experience of what it must have been like during the period of resistance. There is very informative background on the build up to the resistance movement. Many of the exhibits are interactive and the way the little windows are arranged means you have to make an effort to get all the information provided. I can see that this might put people off, but for me it gave a sense of the concealment and secrecy that the resistance movement must have experienced. It let me share in their discomfort and danger a little. There is so much history here that I will ahve to go back for a second visit.

Excellent museum. Very informative museum - I now feel that I have a far greater understanding of how civilians in the Netherlands fared during WW 2. Would recommend this museum to anyone visiting Amsterdam

Very interesting museum. We visited the museum on the final day of our trip and we were rather tired. However the museum was so good that we didn't notice how tired we were. The material was interesting and enlightening. I would recommend to anyone with an interest in WW2 history or even to those who don't. It was also very reasonably priced.

Very moving. I was pleasantly surprised with the quality of the museum. All exhibits were explained in English and there was even a great audio guide. You always hear about Anne Frank, but this museum helps you understand the hardships and risks the other non-Jewish residents of the Netherlands went through.

Mesmerized. I found out about this museum by accident and unless you are looking for it you won't find. Once there - I was completely enthralled and mesmerized! It took over 2 hours and I still feel as if I missed things. The only thing I would caution is we did the Anne Frank House in the early morning and then this.......It was A LOT TO TAKE IN in one day. A must stop though while in Amsterdam!!!

Well organised, thorough and eye-opening. Really opened my eyes to what the war-time experience was like for the non-Jews in Holland who formed the Dutch Resistance. Definitely get a "podcatch" audio device, which has multiple stations throughout the museum where you can listen to recordings which sums up the some of the information in the displays. The museum is very well-organised with a fairly set route through the displays (chronological) which I really liked as I always feel like I'm missing something when I'm at museums if I don't check every nook and cranny! It took about 2 hours to get through all the displays thoroughly, though that could be cut down to 60-90 minutes if you skipped over some of the details. Highly recommended on a visit to Amsterdam!

Interesting but a little overwhelming. There are so many exhibits and so much information provided in this museum that it can be a little overwhelming. It does however provide a comprehensive look at what life was like in the Netherlands during the Nazi occupation. You are left to draw your own conclusions about how different people coped during that difficult period of history.

Very informative. We were interested in this having visited Anne Frank's House, thinking more people than just that family must have gone into hiding during WWII. This excellent museum provided us with information about the resistance movement in the Netherlands, those in hiding (thousands of them) and an insight into living under the Nazis in an occupied country. There are English translations and subtitles, and so much information to take in, we were there for hours. They are also building a children's museum which will be open next year.

Glossy show with no story. This museum does not do justice to the Dutch Resistance. It is well laid out with good looking, though hard to see at times, exhibits but they barely scratch the surface. Some attempts are made at storytelling but I never felt like learned anything I could later share with someone else.

Worth While Visit. We visited the Resistence Museum during our trip in August 2012; Had been meaning to visit previously but is is a little out of the main tourist areas that we frequent (it is right accross the road from the entrance to the zoo and also near the botanical gardens though) so left it until we were planning to visit that area for other attractions to - we went en route to the Brewery Ij.There are lots of facts and original 'artifacts' and one could spend many hours reading an studying or an hour or less if just looking over the stuff. There is an accessible loo, and all the museum was easy to access in my wheelchair, and my carer got a reduced rate for pushing me.All in all, a good few hours and very enlightening into the lives of normal Dutch people at an horrific point in time.

Not much resistance to show.... The museum is well planned, with good walk ability.Unfortunately, there is not much of a resistance story to show to the visitors. If you have a museumkaart it might be worthwhile a visit. One hour is enough.

Interesting displays. My family was in Rotterdam during the war and this exhibition gave me an insight into what life was like in occupied Holland. The exhibition gave details of event leading up to the start of the invasion and the separation of the Jews from the rest of the Dutch. Very emotional visit

Very enlightening. Well worth a visit if this period of history interests you. A very detailed account of the resistance during the occupation and how the locals coped and dealt with the occupiers. Be warned that there is a huge amount of information available and after 2 hours we had only done around 60%.worth a visit if this period of history interests you.

Excellent museum, with enthralling first-person tales. I thought this was a fantastic museum, which told the story of the Netherlands during the World War II in an engrossing way. It included many first-person accounts of life during the occupation, with lots of good photos and packed full of information. Definitely recommend this.

A true reflection of history. This museum shows the tough times that the Dutch people went through in WW2. I found this very informative as it showed the timeline of the invasion and the victory. It helped me understand quite how much the Dutch people resisted the Nazi occupation. This was a very good trip.

another picture of an awful time.. very interesting. In reading the reviews, I think some have mistaken this for a WW museum, but the focus is on the Resistance. For travellers from abroad, I thought this was incredibly interesting. There are many individual stories, pictures, and artifacts. It's a small museum - but it wasn't crowded - highly recommended to capture yet another piece of this awful period in history.. there is a very minimal entrance fee (always support museums!!)..I think it's right across from the zoo (I'm against these, so we didnt go) but if you are planning your day there are a few other things to visit in the area and many restaurants around.

Sadly disappointing experience. There were many great Dutch resistance fighters during the war, but none of these peoples stories were exhibited. It is really just an overview of life in the Netherlands under the Nazis, and not a very interesting one at that, alas...

A worthwhile hour. An interesting museum with a good deal of focus on the treatment of Jews in the Netherlands. The displays were well laid out and the interactive display windows were well thought out.

very moving. this is well worth a visit to understand what the Dutch went through during the War. Very moving and haunting what happened to the Jews, too unreal to believe. many of the notices were in english which was very helpful and interesting

Interesting, Informative but not what I'd expected entirely. It may have just been my expectation but the museum wasn't exactly what I expected. What I expected was that their would be a lot of stories, exhibits and little known facts about the individuals who resisted the Nazi domination in Amsterdam during WWII. I did get some of that, but there weren't quite as many individual stories of heroism and daring that I'd expected. Moreso...and this isn't a bad thing at all, I came away from the museum with a better understanding of how the Dutch people came to capitulate to the Nazis. The process of domination was really well documented in this museum, and I could understand how people at first didn't realize what was happening, and how soon they were really trapped in a situation that they could either submit to or resist. The museum covered the policies that were established by the Germans to document, and track the people in the city...and how those that resisted early on were punished as examples. There were a few stories of individual acts of heroism and risk, but also a fair amount of space & time is devoted to the establishment of underground newspapers and really HOW the Germans established their domination. One issue I took with the museum is that it was all about how the Jews were persecuted...there was no mention whatsoever about the gays, the gypsies, the intelligensia and others that were also discriminated against and sent to camps. In a way, I felt that the museum presentation was less about Dutch resistance, but more about how the invasion and domination was implemented, and then oh, by the way, here are some stories of people who resisted and how. Perhaps this is even better than what I had expected, from an educational and understanding perspective, but it was a little different than I had expected. I'd also like to add that though the information was awesome, I found the layout a little confusing and distracting. Its a little like a maze & you're supposed to flow through it, but there were times I wasn't sure if I was supposed to go down this aisle or that next. I will also add that the woman at the front desk was a little surly, and not very welcoming. I entered with a large party (9), and this seemed to overwhelm her a little bit & she was really concerned about making sure everyone paid. We had every intention of paying, but she was kind of tense about it. I don't know if I'd go again, but I sure do want to learn more about the brave Dutch who risked their lives to oppose the Nazis.

Excellent museum and another WWII perspective. We loved this. Not a large museum, and you can easily do in an hour if you read everything. But very well laid out, lots of exhibits, artifacts, documents, movies, and history. It is laid out in a chronological sequence and it flows nicely. I have heard lots of American and British perspectives on the war, but it was refreshing to get the view from the "inside" of what it is like being occupied and how much is possible to do for resistance. I enjoyed that they posed many ethics questions to think about, do you resist, adapt, or hide? And how they presented real life stories from people that had to grapple with extremely difficult decisions in that regard. We had this as a lower priority on our trip, but I would put it at the top because of how well done it was.

interesting. this was an interesting and highly informative museum. this museum takes you through the stages of the war in Amsterdam with a lot of information by people who experienced the war against jews first hand. must visit if you're interested in war facts

A must for WWII buffs!. Everyone knows about the French Resistance, but you don't hear much about the Dutch Resistance. You should. Their efforts during WWII were just as heroic and effective. This museum walks you thru a history timeline beginning just before the war and up to liberation. There are excellent exhibits of their equipment, their stories, and their sacrifices. Also covered is the lesser known resistance efforts in SE Asia in those Dutch colonies. The day we were there there was a school tour going on and that made it hard to see everything, but it was really an astounding experience. I'd like to go back sometime. We used our Museumkart pass to get in for free...get one of those passes if you are going to a few of the Amsterdam museums, it will pay for itself in no time!
Everyone should visit!. We must not forget the atrocities committed in this war. This museum can be digested in an hour, but will be remembered for a lifetime.

Excellent museum. My husband and I are WWII history buffs so we try to hit as many related sites as we can when in Europe. This did not disappoint. As Americans we don't really get to see history from the point of view of an occupied population. This was a very thought provoking museum and unlike any I have experienced. It really does provide and interesting perspective on the war.

right across the Zoo. The resistance museum is quite nice, it's located across the Amsterdam Zoo. I first visited the zoo and then the museum. The museum is included in the I Amsterdam card (as the zoo and most other museum in Amsterdam). Being Belgian I did not learn a lot of new historic facts but the focus how the Dutch people tried to survive (sometimes working together with the Germans and sometimes trying to sabotage them) explains quite well how hard it was to survive during the 2e WW. The displays provide a very good explanation of the life during these 4 years of war. I left wondering if the collaboratiors just tried to feed their children and may not have being this horrible as most of us think they were.

Marvellous museum well worth a visit. This museum is a little out of the way and we weren't expecting much. We were wrong! The displays are first rate and ver extensive. There is lots of video, and the whole museum gives a great insight into lifer in Holland before during and after the war. Not to be missed! Suitable I suspect, for 10 or 11 year olds and up.

Conform or conspire?. The museum expanded my understanding of the word 'resistance' and forced me to think how I would possibly react under similar circumstances. The human dimension, against the backdrop of huge political and military upheavals, was the museum's greatrest plus.
The Resistance, but not as Renee knew it.. Quite an interesting place to visit, although the treatment was a little simplistic. At least we didn't have to queue around the block to get in.

An education. I learned a lot about the Resistance movement in Amsterdam during WWII. There was so much I had never known, and so many people that sacrificed their lives fighting against the Nazis. This is a great experience for history buffs, but also for anyone interested in learning about the human spirit and what good people are willing to do.

Sorrow part of the history. Even though none of the Amsterdamers wanna remember the sorrow incidents that marks the mutual dislenience of the people of this lovely city. It was remarkable to recall that part of the history as well.

Moving. I would watch the film upstairs before you walk room because you will ask your self more questions. You can buy a walking guide at Ann Franks house for €0:50 which shows you all about what happened and where. Well worth the walk from Ann Franks to the resistance museum before you go in
a good stop if you are interested n WWII info. Husband is has strong interest in WWII.We liked seeing the artifacts and hearing the descriptions. small museum in a nice spot.

Very Good, Very Interesting. Accross from the zoo, this museum presents how Holland dealt with the German invasion of WWII. Well done, with interesting, interactive exhibits. There also was a second section, smaller but very interesting discussing the war and post-war experience in Holland's Indonesian colonies.

One of the best of its kind!. This is one of the best Resistance museums I have been to, it takes at least two and a half hours to go round and everything is in English as well!Everything from the start to the finish , down to the different religious groups opinions are included.It also takes into account the Japanese side of the war as well.
Marvelous find. Took us over two hours to get through this museum. Very well done. Gave a perspective we hadn't heard about before

An importanr story. The Dutch military couldn't confront the Nazis, but the people of Amsterdam fought back in many ways. The museum tells the story of Dutch resistance through personal experiences with many artifacts, documents and individual histories.
Lots to read, not much to see. Worth a visit if you speak Dutch (I don't) and had relatives killed in WW2 (I did). Lots of posters to read, not many exhibits

Definitely a must see!. Amazing museum. Me and my dutch boyfriend went once but didn't have enough time to see all of it, so we went back a second time (and stayed until it closed). The museum isn't big space-wise but we spent a lot more time here than anywhere else, there were so many details, so many stories presented in a way that let you understand what happened chronologically but from a human point of view. I even asked my boyfriend to translate things that were in dutch like newspapers and handwritten letters. Really worth a visit if you're into european and/or dutch history!!

Second only to Anne Frank's House. Although Anne Frank's House was a highlight for us (don't forget to make reservations in advance for the Anne Frank House), we thoroughly enjoyed the Resistance Museum. We learned so much more about the Netherlands during WWI, the Nazi occupation and the impact to the everyday citizens of the Netherlands. We enjoyed it so much, we stayed until closing. A can't miss attraction!

Hidden Gem in Amsterdam. Friends told us not to miss this museum and we went here after touring the Anne Frank House in the morning. It tells the story of those brave Dutch who resisted the Nazi occupation of their country. What heroes they were. I loved the way the museum was laid out in chronological order and the audio guide let us move through it at our own pace. After almost 2 hours I got through the main part of the exhibit but was emotionally exhausted - yet so thankful for those who were part of the movement. Don't miss this wonderful museum.
A look back at the past. We sauntered around this museum in a couple of hours and that is all that you'll need. It is a bit off the beaten track but worth finding if you like this sort of stuff.

For WWII history buffs. If you are interested in WWII history, the Verzetsmuseum is worth a visit. While the museum is small, it has a very good collection of resistance artifacts from different parts of the Dutch empire.There are English translations for almost everything inside.Note: The museum only takes cash payments.

Very informative. A not so much visited museum. We went in the morning, prior to our visit to Anne Frank's house and they complemented each other well. It told the story of how the Amsterdam people resisted the Nazi takeover and how they tried to rescue or hide the Jewish people to protect them from deportation.
do not miss. This was one of the best museums of this nature we've ever been in. Gives one a real sense of the times pre, during and post WWII. We spent over 21/2 hours there. Well displayed, superb.

Very interesting and informative. Had read before visiting Amsterdam that this museum was highly rated, nice to say i agree wholeheartedly. The audio guide included in the entrance fee was an added bonus. Staff very friendly and well laid out exhibition. Only one niggle was the interruption caused by a party of school kids milling around looking for answer to some sort of questionnaire they had been set. Would not normally be a problem but it is quite small but don't let that put you off make sure you pay a visit. Some very interesting displays including on the Holocaust and how the spies operated - fascinating.
Okay - expected more. In area so decided to pop in. Museum has some interesting artifacts but nothing spectacular. Located across entrance to zoo.

Interesting museum. This one is well worth a visit as it tells the tales of what life must have been like during the occupation. Thought-provoking and whilst quite a grim subject to examine, worth devoting the time to visiting.

Some interesting items invoking the WWII era. Contained some interesting items invoking the WWII era which I found interesting but given the cost of entry it is probably only really considered worthwhile to people who want to learn more about how the war years affected Amsterdam and the Netherlands.
very interesting. We visited on our first day in Amsterdam. I thought this museum had alot of interesting information and was a nice compliment to visiting the Ann Frank House later in our trip.

Terrific look at tough subject. Extraordinary multimedia presentation of a difficult period of Dutch history, including everyday life under Nazi occupation as well as collaboration and resistance activities as such. In addition to its content, this is an excellent example of what a modern historical museum can be.

Very informative. Free entrance with I Amsterdam card with free audio. Staff friendly and extremely helpful. Learnt a lot about the Dutch resistance movement during the war. Plenty of exhibits and took about 1.5 hours but could take a lot longer if you were to read everything.
Recommended for all ages

A positive surprise. Our visit was at the instigation of our boys (18 & 21), but proved an unexpected success. The museum is very well laid out in Dutch and English and provides a remarkable insight into the less well known Dutch resistance. Definintely worth a visit, allow 1.5 hours.

Different. This museum takes an interesting and different take on WWII than any museums I'd been to before. It tells the story of so many people who tried to sabotage the Nazis and help people get out. They were unsuccessful of course, but it's interesting to learn about. The museum's set up was confusing for me, but that wasn't a big deal. Just meander through, take everything in, and then have a conversation about what you think you would do, and why you think people did what they did at that time. The museum is in a nice, quiet location, yet it's easily walkable to center city. Or there's a tram that stops right by it too. There are a couple of nice cafes right outside too.
Excellent history of the Dutch resistance. The exhibit is quite large and gives a personal perspective of what went on in Amsterdam during World War II.

Social history of WW2. Gives a very good insight into the lives and choices ordinary people made during WW2 - by the use of various media and narratives weaving ordinary people's stories - of resistance & collaboration in some cases - against a narrative background of the Nazi occupation.

Small museum, lots of history. This is not an entertaining museum, but it is very interesting. There are many letters, newspaper clippings, photos, and items that tell the story of the Dutch resistance during WWII.

Informative, great museum for all ages!. Actual visit date: February 2011.We didn't know much about The resistance museum before we went, but as we left we had a great understanding of the resistance.There's lots of activities to do as you walk round and plenty to see!Not too much information piled onto you at once its all distributed evenly and easy to understand.Well worth a visit!
a big museum. very good collection of items of all the masters, on 3 floors but at 14 euros i think a bit steep!! but don,t let me put you off a vist.

Interesting. More like a 3.5 Rating. The small museum was interesting in that it showed the development of how things changed in The Netherlands and the Resistance began before and during World War II. It was not a large Museum and won't take up a lot of time, but worth the look see.

Very interesting. In the UK, we get a lot of information about WW2 from the pov of a country being attacked, and working to free others. This museum offers a different view, of a country that had been invaded and was trying to come to terms with this.The museum leads you through the wartime years with exhibits ordered sensibly and presented well. Well worth visiting.

Real insight. We love our history of WWII but this gave a very different perspective of a nation under occupation. Loads of papers, photos, wartime day to day belongings and household goods with audio recollections as well. Worth a trip.

A Good Perspective on Dutch Culture. The museum is nicely laid out telling the story of the German invasion and the political and social conflicts it resurrected, which led to the formation of the Duth Resistance movement. See this before you visit the Anne Frank Huis.

Never Forget. This museum posed the question, "What would you have done?" It showed how various groups of people in the Netherlands responded (or didn't) to German takeover. It's hard to imagine until you see and ponder what this museum offers.

A moving and educational experience.. A litle of the beaten track, but well worth tracking it down. It had an excellent historical exhibit of the Netherlands just before and during World War II. The display was well laid out and was very personal in that it included personal belongings and the words of participants. It was very moving and informational. While very educational its probably not the best for children - due to the amount of reading and lack of a lot of interaction in the exhibits. We went with a couple of our Dutch friends and they, too, found it thought provoking as well as informative.

Resistance Museum. It's near the Zoo!!! I say that because no one understand the term Resistance Museum. If you do the A F museum, you have to do this. You can walk it from Central Station in 15 mins.

Educational and Intense. This museum was not close to our hotel which was near the train station. It was a bit of walk, but we used the canal boats on the return trip which was lovely. There is a significant amount of information that is not in English. You do however, get the feeling of what it must have been like at that time in history. The exhibits are somewhat interactive in a way that involves all of your senses. We only had an hour to tour the museum. It really deserves 2-3 hours. There are lockers for your belongings. They do charge 2 Euros, but it is refunded when you open it to get your items. The area the museum is located in was very quiet and away from the normal tourist haunts and really lovely.

A very well presented museum on the history of Netharlands during WWII. Amsterdams Verzetsmuseum offers perfect presentations of the events and the resistance movements during WWII in Amsterdam. There are lots of interactive stories, a lot number of documents from these dates and informative installations. Although a bit far from the center, the museum can easily be reached by tram 9 from Central Station or tram 14 from the Dam square, and this attraction is free for I Amsterdam card holders.
Not worth the vist. The staff was unfriendly.Seemed like they were only there to take your money. Not well organized, Charged 2EU for locker. Would have liked a tour guide to explain.

Educational and Moving!. Spent 3 hours in this museum off the beaten track but easily walkable from central Amsterdam. We visited this museum after visiting Anne Frank House. This museum complemented Anne Frank House and provided so much history and information about the resistance movement in Amsterdam. We never realized how active this resistance movement was during WW II. The display of needlepoint and embroidery done by women resistors while imprisoned was very moving. An important museum in Amsterdam.
The history of WW11. This is an amazing museum, well contructed to give the viewer an authentic and sobering view of Holland under the Germans in WW11. I encourage everyone to see this.

Learnt so much. I spent ages looking for this then on my way back from the zoo one day I just stumbled across it. It was pretty late in the day so I didn't get to spend as much time as I would have like there.There is so much information about the Dutch Resistance, pictures and exhibits. A must for anyone with an interest in WWll
really interesting. I had no idea of the role of Holland in the war, or Hitler's affection for the Dutch people and his plans. Very interesting.

Excellent. Not too many people come to Amsterdam to discover the tragedy of WWII Amsterdam, but this museum is defintely worth a visit. Truly amazing presnetation of the city during this time. It's well organized with excellent displays and information. Highly reccomended.

Emphasis on treatment of Jews as well as WWII resistance. This museum is not easy to find because the numbering is confusing, but it is well curated and worth the search. One needs several hours to do it justice.
Eye opening tour. This is a very interesting place to visit and would recommend it for a brief look at the more recent history of Amsterdam

opposite the Artis zoo. The museum is set directly opposite the Artis zoo.It is well laid out and information is in English and Dutch.8euro admission.Worth a visit if you are interested in war time Holland.

A Gem to visit. Did this on my visit in April 2012. A fascinating place to visit giving a feel for how life was during the war. There was a good range of information going into detail about how the ordinary people of Amsterdam coped with the war and their resistance methods used.
So worth visiting if interested in history

Large amount of first hand experience. Interesting museum well laid out with a large amount of detail from many individuals and artefacts to go with their stories. The museum follows the chronology of the war allowing you to understand the decisions that were being faced, and the descriptions were in both Dutch and English throughout. But two criticisms, firstly a lot of the writing was very small and angled making it quite hard to read. Secondly, although very descriptive of life in Amsterdam at the time, the actual stories of the resistance and their impact was not, but rather subsumed into the mass of detail. You could come away thinking that all the resistance did was print some leaflets, strike and provide hiding and escape routes whilst waiting for the liberation, very little about any direct actions.

Fascinating and harrowing at the same time. This was not as down and sorrowful as some of the other museums, but it was very insightful and brilliant to learn so much about the Dutch Resistance. It was hard to learn about just how many were captured and what thier fate was, but still some very inspiring and though-provoking stories.

Well Worth a Visit. The museum is slightly off the beaten track (opposite the Zoo) but well worth a visit. The information is very well presented and the story is an absolutely fascinating and absorbing one concerning little discussed and a not very well known period of Dutch history. Well worth it.

Very good museum. This museum was very interesting. I enjoyed the layout of the museum as well. It's very touching to read about and view primary sources of the people who lived and/or died during this time period.

Very Worthwhile!. The Resistance Museum is often overlooked by tourists, who choose to visit the Anne Frank House instead - such a shame! While the Anne Frank House is undoubtedly a must-see, the Resistance Museum provides a far broader a general overview of wartime Netherlands.It is filled with anecdotes and stories from the war, and has a great collection of posters, letters and other memorabilia of the underground resistance movement against Nazi Germany. The information is cleverly laid out in chronological order, and very much brings this part of history alive.Just €8 for the full ticket price, and worth every one!
Don't miss this one!. I think this museum gets skipped, but it was so informative and a visit to it rounds out the trip to the Anne Frank house

Great little collection. The Dutch resistance is not something which springs to mind when I think of WWII, it certainly doesn't get a lot of exposure. This exhibit adds another dimension to the usual stories of Nazi's and the Normandy landings.
Excellent. Short wait time to get in. Displays were informative. There is a large collection of art here, much more than I expected, and it was a pleasure to visit.

A very informative museum. Wanted to know the "other stories" about the war, and this museum tells it beautifully. If you are interested, then it will not disappoint.
Excellently laid out and informative, and the bonus was that even in the middle of August it was not overcrowded.

Touching!. This museum has mainly paperwork artifacts (photo's, newspapers, forged documents, Jewish star, etc., etc.,) with signs displayed in Dutch and English explaining what you are seeing. There are also some audio displays with pictures that light up. Overall a very touching display and documentation of the Dutch occupation and resistance. Like most Dutch establishments, the building doesn't have any big signs out front and is a little tricky to see, basically across the street from the zoo.

Depressing. You feel the war.. Very glad I visited these museum. You can feel the tension of war and all the things Dutch (and other) people had to suffer. Documented by life stories of Dutch people during the war. It may give a bit a depressing feeling. Spend about two hours overthere. Certainly worth a visit!

An unexpected and amazing place. Wouldn't have gone here, if it weren't for the trip already arranged for the students in the group we were travelling with. So glad we did go, though--what a thought-provoking place. The way the musuem was arranged is great, and the questions they ask the visitors to ask of themselves is a terrific way to draw you into the exhibits and really make you think, not just observe second-hand without much thought or emotion involved. Very, very well-done and very well worth your time.

Interesting guide to Dutch Resistance. With everything in English as well as Dutch, great museum to wander round and take in the fight the Dutch put up against the Germans. It seemed quite 'warts and all'; where there were 'failings' as the Dutch would see it, they were acknowledged too and the reasons why the NS party had at least some support in the Netherlands was approached with openness and fairness to the people who didn't have our historic perspective. I found the individual one page stories of people that were thematically linked to the displays un-put-down-able; these were ordinary people put into sometimes horrific circumstances. Definitely worth an hour or two of your time in Amsterdam and well away from the horrific city centre.

Unbiased view of a very complex period. I was moved by the Dutch Resistance Museum and surprised how genuinely interested I became in learning about the events, circumstances,and decisions each and every person needed to make. With every decision came repercussions and more decisions to be made. The museum does an excellent job of giving an unbiased glimpse into the life and times of the Dutch people during the German occupation. Lots of reading in English or Dutch but pictures, documents, film clips. and actual items involve all your senses. The everyday life of the citizens becomes real and the personal stories (a must read) make it all too real. The very short stories are not all noble ones but stories of the average person. The personal insights gained from these stories and the well documented and chronological museum helped me understand the complexity of the circumstances of that time. More importantly, the museum made me think and question what I would feel and do in similiar circumstances.

Resistance Museum- A Must See!. We have visited other resistance musuems, but this one is so superior and far more comprehensive. The layout is easy to self guide, and the artifacts and information is interesting and diverse. It takes approximately one hour or so to complete, your tickets allows you to leave and re-enter for that day.Definately worth the price of admission, and if you are interested in the history of Amsterdam/Holland during the 30's ~40's, you will enjoy this well constructed collection of the Resistance.

How the Dutch Kept Their Culture. This museum is the story of how, despite incredible horrors that the Germans visited upon any who dissented from the terror-filled occupation, a moral people with a strong self of culture, can band together to save their culture. The museum documents in paper, artifacts, news reels and every day items how the Dutch resisted and worked against the Germans, staying one step ahead. Printing presses used to prepare forged documents saved scores of thousands of lives. A baby carriage, modified to carry weapons among the resistance, is presented and demonstrates how many Dutch joined the movement despite the executions and imprisonments they faced.A great important story and museum that leaves you saying thank you to the Dutch for their part in the defeat of the Nazis in WWII. Located just across from the Zoo in a lovely neighborhood.

Worth a look for those interested in the WWII era. This is a small museum but done very well. The general experience of the Dutch during the war was represented as well as different groups and how they were affected by the Nazi occupation.

A perfect combo with the Anne Frank House. This was my favorite museum experience in Amsterdam by far -- and that includes the Anne Frank House (nevertheless a fascinating site), the Van Gogh Museum, and the Rijksmuseum -- all of which were fabulous in their own right.Why? Because this museum provides an intimate, uncrowded, cleverly and sensitively mounted display of the range of forms of resistance that ordinary Dutch citizens displayed toward Nazi occupation during World War II. Full of authentic period artifacts and ephemera from the period, it's an engaging exhibit that, while making the visitor wish she understood Dutch, provides more than adequate information in English for a speaker of that language to appreciate and interact with the materials on display.My cousin and I visited the Dutch Resistance Museum after we went to the Anne Frank House, and in some ways I think it would have beeb better to flip that order. Either way, however, both are must-sees for those interested in the human dimensions of World War II.Don't miss it!

Very well done. The Dutch Resistance Museum was one of my favorite attractions in Amsterdam. It was a wonderful balance of personal stories, interactive exhibits, and historical information. The explanations are all in Dutch & English and the whole thing was very well done. I left feeling like I had a much better sense of what the war was like in Holland, and how blessed I am to be living where and when I do. If you are interested in the history of Holland and the unique way that the people supported one another, this museum is a great way to do that.

Small accessible museum. Our family went to this interesting museum after the van gogh museum line was way too long. We found it to be extremely interesting and well done. There was a short temporary exhibit that was also very good. Nearly all of the exhibit signs were in English along with the Dutch. We recommend this museum for those who enjoy history and want to escape the crowds at the big destinations.

Worth a look. Full of historical tales,pictures and remnants well worth a 2 hour visit,or however long you got. Be warned they will not let you take a bag in but they do have,small free lockers i e you get your coin back,2 euro I think it was

Would have been much better if I spoke Dutch. It was quite an interesting museum and some of it was captioned in English. It would have been much better if the personal documents and effects had been translated into English as it was quite frustrating to only understand the main caption and not the more subtle details. Found I had looked at everything in under 45 mins. Worth a visit if you're interested in WW2, like me.

A Must See. A wonderful museum, particularly when seen in combination with the Anne Frank House. Lots of ephemera and artifacts from life under the Nazis. Especially fascinating were the tiny radio receivers camouflaged in matchboxes! As previously noted, heavy on the text but very well presented. Don't try to rush through but allow a good couple of hours. Little kids would be bored but I can imagine anyone 12 or older with an interest in the subject would be fine. Easy to get to on the tram, it's right by the zoo. Don't miss it!

Very personal history. This museum is slightly off the usual tourist track and is much quieter than most of the other museums we visited. It is included in the IAmsterdam card. It is a great museum. I particularly liked the individual stories of some of the people involved - some incredibly brave, some very sad but all very interesting. it's not a modern museum with all sorts of interactive exhibits but if you've got a bit of patience then it's an unexpected gem.

Highlight of Amsterdam. I spent 3 hours here and likely would have spent more had the Museum not been about to close for the day. Anyone who has any love for history will appreciate the visual displays and explanations - all in English and Dutch. You definitely will come away from this with a greater appreciation for what the Dutch citizens and the country as a whole experienced during WWII and the resistence they put up.

Interesting and Informative. This a nice little museum with many artefacts relating to the second world war. The content is a little text heavy as there's LOADS of reading but other than that I found it quite enjoyable.

Interesting History. We visited the museum more due to the weather to start and were amazed at the amount of history that we learned about. I liked the layout of the exhibits and how much information was provided by the simplicity of the exhibits. I was also amazed to see/hear the issues that were experienced prior/during/after World War 2 by the Netherlands but also in their Asian colonies. As the exhibits were in Dutch and English we had no problems and I did notice a couple with audio units so the museum may offer them for other languages. Overall an informative 2 hours.

A Big Part of the History of Amsterdam. My daughter and I visited the Resistance Museum last week, and our experience there was excellent. The museum is much quieter than the tourist-clogged Van Gogh and others--there were very few people there. The museum is fascinating, and the story of the Dutch Resistance during World War II was full of impressive information I never knew. There were many short films and lots of exhibits and memorabilia. I loved it and would recommend it to anyone visiting Amsterdam.
A must see. Liked how the museum was sequenced and very personal with inidvidual stories.Not crowded and we could take our time.

Fantastic museum. We went to this museum as it had been mentioned on Trip Advisor but hadn't been reviewed in my travel book. I would highly recommend this as a 'must do'. The exhibits are in Dutch and English and give both a comprehensive and personal view of occupied Holland. It was fascinating to see how the ordinary Dutch people mounted subtle and obvious forms of resistance, as well as those who actively joined the resistance movement. I would highly recommend this museum, especially in conjunction with the Anne Frank House. The entrance was €8 per adult.
Thoughtful museum. Worth visiting if you have the time, although there's nothing amazing here. Great history however. Makes one think of what one would do in a similar situation.

Somewhat interesting. We went there because it was free with the Amsterdam City card & it is across the strret from the zoo which we had visited. It is very well done with a great deal to read if you have the time. much of it may be of more interest to Dutch citizens.
Stories of the occupation. Brought home history - suffering and eventual success in resisting occupation. Quite busy, with it being high season. Will return for an off-season visit.

A wonderful surprise. Imagine you're living in occupied Holland during WW II. You far-sighted enough to know that the Nazis will be defeated and courageous enough to stash away evidence of Nazi crimes and acts of resistance and bravery by Dutch citizens. Fast forward to today. It's all on display in this well designed museum, including the not so glorious (indeed, atrocious) history of Holland's occupation of Indonesia until the 1950's. But that's the Dutch: they tell it like it is, in extraordinary detail. Only "problem:" is that all of the informational displays is in Dutch; no English. But we were still able to make sense of it. And tours are available.

Not to be missed!. Very informative museum detailing what Amsterdam went through during World War II. They have a lot of personal artifacts and exhibits detailing the events. Definitely worth the visit, there is so much information here about the Dutch Resistance! It took us almost 2 hours to see everything, I never expected it to be so interesting. Worth every penny of the 8 euro price to get in. They don't take credit cards so you need to be aware of that and bring cash. The museum is right across the street from the zoo in a yellow building next to a cafe. We walked right by it at first thinking it was just an office building.

Very interesting museum, superbly curated. This is a fascinating and very well curated museum about the resistance of the Dutch (and Dutch East Indies) people during the Nazi occupation. It told the stories of the people who suffered during this time from a number of perspectives - the Jews, the resistance fighters, the collaborators, the soldiers, and so on. Definitely well worth a visit.

I personally liked it. Looking at the exhibits, stories and photos I realise how lucky I am to live in a free country and never experiencing war. There were many hero resistance fighters during WW2 in Amsterdam. I really admired their courage.
Fantastic museum. Excellent museum to develop a true understanding of life in Amsterdam during WW2. Fascinating.
Awesome place. This combined with Anne Frank House really tell you about what WWII was like for the dutch people.

Fantastic little museum off the normal beaten path. It's across from the Amsterdam Zoo, and we only heard about it on our last day in Amsterdam but decided to give it a shot. We're glad we did. It's laid out very well, so you can skip through it and easily see all the big picture parts, or go into each side room for more information when you want. The history was very well presented, with just the right amount of text (informative, but not a wall of text you get tired of reading). It really explored what the resistance went through during the war, which you would probably never hear of otherwise. Everyone at the museum was nice, and the facilities are all new and quite clean. It's a bit out of the normal sight-seeing area, but still a short tram ride and not hard to find at all. Highly recommended.
sad sad sad. beautifully presented and everything in English too.

Eye Opening. It was excellent in explaining the thoughts and actions of the Dutch people during the German occupation. The people were of all ages, from all walks of life. Some were collaborators, some were in the resistance and some took a passive stance. The vast majority of the information was not in English and the English was often hard to read because of placement.

eye opener. this museum is near the zoo so definatly take the tram as its bit of trek. the museum is a little gem it has so many first hand experience of the occupation and the subsequent forced deportation of jews and workers that it feels that you are there well worth two hours of your time to pay your respects to the departed
Educational and Thought Provoking. Not to be missed museum. A little out of the way but worth a look along with the Ship museum.
Please go if you are in Amsterdam for cultural reasons. A very poignant place to visit. Fascinating and informative.

Very informative. I had read on a forum that this museum was the most interesting museum in the Netherlands. I must agree that for me it was educational and thought provoking. I ended up spending more time there than I anticipated. I would absolutely recommend it especially for those of us not old enough to remember the war and its attrocities. There were plenty of English explanations. The only thing I think would make it better would be directional arrows or maybe even footprints to ensure you're following the timeline. Make sure you watch the film on the left hand side of the hall as you enter the museum. I was the only one in there but I felt it prepared me for the museum and its theme.
Very good story to be told. It gave you a view as to how such a thing can happen bit by bit with great pictures and stories

Interesting and moving. I can't fathom why a person commented below that there was very little in English. Absolutely every text panel was in Dutch and English. True the original letters and documents were in Dutch, but of course they would be. There is a lot to read at this museum. It is almost all reading, but I find that enjoyable.

Seen one seen them all?. This has the potential to be a really good museum, but there was too much information crammed into quite a small place. I normally find War museums really interesting, but I felt that this was a bit 'samey' to alot that I have already been to. It was good to see the proaganda which was shown to the dutch and read little extracts from personal profiles and indepth information on certain families. I can't really complain as we got in for free with the I AMSTERDAM card, otherwise I may have been a little disappointed.

Resistance Museum. This one is a bit off the beaten track, but a beautful walk, nevertheless. It's a small museum dedicated to giving visitors a quite moving, realistic experience about being in Amsterdam during WWII and particularly the efforts (and incredible risks and hardships) of those in the resistance and those friendly to it.

Very little English. No audio tour and very little English - disappointing unless you are personally involved (e.g. Dutch Jewish forefathers). The original propoganda movie which was shown to Dutch people during WW2, could have been interesting, but it wasn't working! Not worth the trouble to get there.

A different view of the war.... My wife and I visited this museum in late June and were both pleasantly surprised at this unique look at a part of WWII history neither of us knew anything about. I am a history buff but came away astonished at how little I knew about the Dutch resistance movement during the war. My wife, on the other hand, doesn't really study or like history, but surprisingly, enjoyed this museum with it's many artifacts, documents, and detailed displays. The cost was 8 € each for the entrance fee but we both agreed that it was worth it.A unique museum for anyone who has even a passing interest in World War II history.

A lot to take in.. This museum is extremely interesting. It is not very big, but once you start looking at the exhibit, time will just slip away. We started walking through the exhibit and the next thing you knew 2 hours had gone by. It is sobering as some one else posted but it is also well done and balanced. If you are a WWII enthusiast, this is a must.One note: they do not take U.S. credit cards, so bring cash!

Sobering. The museum documents the resistance movement in Holland in WWII and the ways Dutch citizens protected their Jewish neighbors. Most of the exhibits are in Dutch, however, so I felt I missed out on a lot of the details.

It should be titled "The Lack of Resistance Museum". The Christians residents of Amsterdam completely rolled over to the Nazis' will. For whatever reason, they completely played along in one of the worst examples humanity has ever demonstrated. What a sorry example of man kind's treatment of his fellow man. The museum is okay but doesn't reveal the dramatic true and horrible story that ensued as clearly as it should.

Thought provoking. This museum takes a difficult subject and presents it in a very balanced way. It is harrowing to see some of the pictures and read/hear from those who were involved but necessary, I feel, so as not to lose the past. I left the museum with a far better understanding of everyone involved on all sides.
A lot of information about the resistance. I liked Anne Frank House better. But, this was nice too.

If you are in to the 2nd world war, its awesome!. Very good museum. Good info about the situation in Holland before, during and after the 2nd world war. Also for people who are not very fiamiliar with 2nd world war history.My girlfriend is not in to 2nd world war history at all and she found it interesting as well.

Worth going. Worth going to although like so many of Amsterdam's sights, it is a reminder of the continent's shady past. So much to see and everything is in English. Spent 2 hrs there and great cafe next door!

Incredible. I have been to the Dutch Resistance Museum at least 3 teams and I still leave each time surprised how much I loved it and confident it is my favorite historical museum in the world. The museum does an incredible job of both articulating the historical big picture of what the occupation and war was like in the Netherlands, while weaving it with incredible stories of heroism. The museum is both heartbreaking and fulfilling, and any museum-goer's trip to Amsterdam without a visit would be a serious mistake.

Let us not forget how others suffered. This is a museum that I wanted to see. As an American who was a child during WWII, I wanted to understand why the German Nazis were so cruel to the Dutch who are very similar in ancestry. The museum makes every effort to show objectively what happened to the Dutch people. My wife and I had planned to visit for an hour but ended staying for near 3 hours. The restaurant Plancius and Cafe Koosje are excellent places for lunch. We ate outside at the Plancius, right next to the museum, and really enjoyed it.

Please don't miss this.. Everyone goes to Anne Franks House but this is the rest of the story. Well laid out and easy to follow. Plenty of English translations and commentaries. A bit of a trek outside the main area but tram 9 goes past the end of the road

Do Visit If You Can. A most unexpectedly fascinating experience. Much is made of the amount of collaberation with the Nazis in all occupied countries, and here is an excellent series of displays of what went on in The Netherlands from the start to the finish of its occupation.A pretty balanced account of what people do when faced with an utterly miserable situation made slightly better by working with an occupying power. That many showed bravery is beyond doubt, but the nagging feeling that it must have been so easy to turn a blind eye is always present. The overwhelming question is:- should leaders retain power in order to try to mitigate excesses or simply resign and hand over to Nazi sympathisers?It takes a very brave person to decide to retain some local power whilst being denounced as a puppet of the occupying regime. Cannot leave this Museum without more questions in ones mind than answers.

More important to locals. The museum is set out like a series of streets, and is mostly graphical, but with some artifacts and audiovisual content. It tells the story of the WWII invasion, collaboration, resistance, and finally liberation from the Germans. Whereas many museums are at least bilingual, this will require at least a smattering of Dutch to get the most out of it. You can use your iAmsterdam card to get in.

Eye opening. I knew there was a Dutch resistance against the Nazi's, but had no idea of the extent to which the Dutch resisted the unlawful occupation and the mass killings of innocent people that took place as a result. It was certainly an Eye Opening exhibit, but allow at least 2 - 3 hours. It is hard to find as the signage is quite small. But look for it across from the zoo, next to an attached cafe.
Inspiring!. If you've visited the Anne Frank House, this would be a good place to visit afterwards - to get a good perspective of what was going on during the time of hiding for the Jews during WWII.
Thought provoking exhibition. A really good history and exhibition of Amsterdam during the Second World War - also very thought provoking about what happened and how people reacted.
Well worth a visit. Don't miss seeing this one. Very moving and well set out

Well done, lots to see, great for WW2 and history buffs. We stayed here for 1-1/2 hrs (and rushed through) but really you need at least 4 since there is so much to see. The museum is extremely well done and the relics are abundant and fascinating. They even had a little movie theater section showing original propaganda films. The stories and history are very well told through the exhibits, many which contain real footage. It's a definite must-see if you are interested in history or WW2. And the price is a bargain for the amount of material presented and the top-notch, first-class presentation.
A must for history buffs!. It was easy to explore and definitely added to my understanding of history.

More interaction needed. Ok. Not bad value at €8 pp.Slightly hindered by the audio tour sets which werent working. Although cards were written up in English I felt I was missing something. Bit of a trek but if you're headed to zoo or Aquarium worth a stop. Not much for kids.
worth the visit. Interesting, I liked that there were storries behind most names and historical events. Definatly worth visiting
An insight into history.. Lots to read & absorb. Audio guide excellent. School children visiting need to be more quiet & respectful to the subject on which the museum is based.

A very good visit. We really enjoyed our visit we found it not well advertised and quite hard to find we went for a couple of hours and ended up there for about 4 hours very interesting time just flew it was excellent

Great little museum!. It really tells the story of WW2 resistance in a chronological and thorough manner without being overwhelming. Lots of different points of view, and a wonderful walk-through. Highly recommended, and enjoyed the walk there from Damrak through the city.

Worth a visit. A little off the beaten track (located next to the zoo and not so overtly advertised) this museum was lower key but still fascinating. Like a visit to Anne Frank's house it was sobering but very informative. A little more difficult to navigate the museum but geared to English speaking visitors. We could have spent even longer there than we did but after an hour and a half we had to move on. Free entry with the i amsterdam card. Otherwise 7.50 euros which is amazing value.

Should be on everyone's list. From the outside it looked small but wow, when we went inside it just kept going - an amazing amount of really interesting material. We spent hours there and were so interested we forgot about lunch. With inlaws who lived through this period of history in the Netherlands, it gave so much information as to what they endured and in a really interesting format - memorabilia, interviews, letters (not all in Dutch), photographs. It also covered the fact that Holland went from being the occupier of the Dutch East Indies to being the occupied, by the Japanese. A large venue and even though there was a group of school children there at the same time we were able to see everything.
Great historical museum. Easy to see, lots of history about Amsterdam and the war. Try and see, you will not be sorry.Grammy Sharon

Near Artis zoo, but something to visit. Most in Dutch (what I remember). How did people resist. Would i dare to resist? How ro resist in a war? How to life in this war? Find all kind of questions in this museum.
On regular base with extra expo.
Odd layout, but good museum.. Amazing and interesting! Layout is odd and random, but museum and information is fabulous!

One of the best. I gained a new understanding of Amsterdam during the war. The timeline, displays, layout, colors and text all evoke an appreciation for how the occupation and the Dutch reaction evolved during the five year period. The variety of Dutch responses is evoked through the stories of different people and the places shown in the photos and video are all around you as you leave - adding to the impact. Well worth several hours.
The Resistance Museum. It was interesting. Pretty easy to get thru and still learn more about the Resistance. Great pub next door as well. :)
Eye opener. We thoroughly enjoyed this experience when we eventually found it. It is opposite the main gate to the zoo.

OK, but a bit dated. The subject was, I think, more interesting than the museum. The interactive style was similar to the Holocaust museum in DC, but the layout was a bit random. I thought it was more effective in illustrating the persecution of Jews than in building an image of a resistance movement. Some really thought-provoking material, but lacking depth, and the attempts to create an interactive multimedia type display are pretty outdated. An interesting visit, but a bit overrated.

Interesting and thought provoking. A salutory experience as we found ourselves wondering how we would have responded in that situation. We had not realised the extent of the Resistance in Holland and how many people were hidden and helped by ordinary citizens. A fascinating museumHowever I found the print difficult to read on some of the displays and higher contrast captions would have helped.

A masterpiece of a museum. I absolutely loved this museum. I might even say it was the best museum I have ever visited. I thought the exhibit did a good job of providing context for the second world war and what eventually happened in the Netherlands. I loved the layout and how it was also a representation itself of the main themes of the exhibitions. Many artifacts, historical documents, photographs, and sound recordings are on display and I loved how these were organized into montages for the difference time periods and themes. I loved how the exhibit provided both objective, general information about the events of the war as well as individual stories and memoirs that were used to convey the realities of the time. Can't say enough wonderful things about this museum. Needless to say, I would highly recommend it!!
not as insightful as hoped. some good excerpts but overall hoped for a bit more from this attraction

Excellent museum, could be my favourite. Not on all the maps, but not far from the maritime museum. Definitely worth a visit. We bought a museum card, which cost 45 euros, and then all visits were free, and you could bypass most of the queue's, biggest queues were van gogh and Rijksmuseum. You cannot bypass the queue at Anne Frank house.

Amsterdam during wartime. This museum tells how the Dutch coped during the occupation. The exhibits follow a timeline which showed the escalation of rules restricting everyday living. There is also a display of needlework carried out by those imprisoned in camps which was deeply touching. If you visit the Anne Frank house, include this as well, it's worth it.

Only superficial view on Dutch resistance.... In fact, I had expected so many things about this museum, but unfortunately even it is a well organized museum, it just gives a superficial view on Dutch resistance against Nazi Germany. For instance huge strikes and their role against discrimination and sending concentration camps of Jewish people are mentioned very little. Anyway, if you read something about Dutch history and politics before you go, it will provide an assistance for your readings...
Thought provoking and educational. S0 much information. It was a good follow on from the Anne Frank museum

Excellent, thoughtful museum. Great small museum with a moving display about the Dutch resistance and war experience. Explained clearly the dilemmas and hardships faced by people living in Amsterdam at the time. Well worth a visit, we thought it was much more illuminating and worthwhile than Anne Frank's House (if you wanted to choose just one).

Very good museum. We had not planned a visit to this particular museum but the weather was really bad so we decided to add it to out trip. i am glad we did. It is not a large place but I found it really informative. You must ensure you take the time to fully read all of the information as it builds a fascinating picture of what life was like in Amsterdam during World War 2. Very thought provoking.

A Great Value Learning Experience. My wife & I visited here on the 03rd June when it was very wet & cold outside! ..... and spent a very enjoyable 2 hours reading all the displays. My wife isnt into History but she found the museum very interesting.Whilst a lot of the experiences of those living in Europe under the occupation of the Nazis have been well documented, less so those of those living in the Dutch East Indies (Indonesia) ...so it was great to learn about that part of the conflict.For only 8 Euros, it was well worth the entrance fee.
Enlightening. Seemed to be a fair and balanced history of the politcial forces and changes that occurred from occupation by the Gremans to liberation by the Canadians.

Informative. The Resistance Museum showed me how close ties were with the British and Dutch during the war. I saw artefacts that showed the resistance efforts by the Dutch and how the Nazi regime forced its way into the Netherlands. The museum opens your eyes as to how people show hope even when faced with what seem like impossible circumstances.

Great museum. I have discovered this museum once I accompanied some students there and since then I have been back many times: it's very modern and the displays are very creative and there are a lot of authentic reperts of the period of the resistance to the Germans. A lot to learn!

Interesting but not user friendly. We visited the Resistance Museum in May 2012. The information was interesting and comprehensive. However, the layout of the museum was confusing, and the displays were strange and difficult to see: many were presented through small windows, and you have to strain your neck and eyes to see the items or text on display. A significant amount of information was also presented only in one language, Dutch. Considering the cost of the entrance fee, we were a bit disappointed. But overall we would go again.

Enriching. I came here alone, spent around 40 minutes learning about the Dutch Resistance during WW2.
Lots of interactive stuff, mainly in Dutch, so I couldn't understand, but all the explanations were also in English so it was great.
For anybody who likes to research the war theme, or just curious.

Out of the ordinary. Not many people discover this museum near the zoo. But if you have any interest in WWII it is well worth a visit. Much of the museum is taken up with pictures that were taken without the knowledge of the Germans. You also get a good feeling for the slow but steady change in views of the ordinary Dutch people from 1941 (accepting with Germans) to outright revolt (1945).

Needs funding. While the people working here are very helpful and the place has a nice location, it's too small and it feel like it can do with a bit of funding. Living in London Im used to not having to pay (just donate) to get into museums, so when I paid €8 a head I expected a great visit. the intro video seem really outdated and cheesy and the whole experience while informative it felt short of details of how the resistance operated.
Excellent museum. This museums was well organized, and very thorough- I would definitely recommend for anyone with an interest in WWII.

An exceptional small museum. The Verzetsmuseum focusses on the life in the Netherlands, paricularly resistance to Nazi occupation, during World War Two. The display languages are Dutch and English and the story is told through film, photographs, radio excerpts and documents and artefacts from the time. The museum is exceptionally well designed and the displays are informative and imaginatively presented. I was absorbed for more than two hours and regretted that an appointment caused me to leave before completing the whole journey through the displays. I will be back.
Good learning experience. This museum really gives you a good feeling for what went on in Holland during WWII. No punches pulled.

Don't miss this!. Our hotel staff dismissed this as somewhat of a "minor" museum but my husband and I spent several hours there and were touched and impressed by it. I learned a great deal about the Dutch and the Jewish residents during WWII. There were photos, films, various objects from that time and all were interesting. I was most touched by the museum's display of embroidery made by women who were in camps and who used this craft to pass time, help keep hope alive and give to others.
Must see. It is a sad but compelling story that is shared. Gave us more respect for the dutch when we saw how they fought back during the war. Excellent items to view from the time also.

"Expand your understanding of WWII in The Netherlands". This unheralded museum near the Zoo is much more than "merely" a Resistance Museum. It is designed to make visitors consider what THEY would have done, faced with the choices the Nazis forced on the Dutch. Loaded with personal artifacts and stories, it is thought-provoking and moving. And it has a great little cafe attached!

An eye opener. This museum tells of the great Strength, resolve and bravery of many Dutch people involved in the resistance. I cannot recommend it enough. Everyone should visit this at least once on a visit to Amsterdam.

Extremely informative, personal,and in depth look at the World War II years in the Netherlands. This museum is very informative and has some interesting exhibits. The key to an enjoyable visit is to get the audio guide. The staff members seemed very unwilling to hand them out (even though they are included in the price of admission) but we persisted and our group of four all agreed at the end of the tour that the audio guide really made our visit worthwhile. This is a nice accompaniment to the Anne Frank house as this museum tells the story of how German occupation affected life for the Dutch people as a whole and how the Dutch people responded. Very interesting and definitely worth a visit. just be persistent and make sure you get the audio guide. I gave four out of five stars because the staff was rude and the layout if the museum a bit confusing.

A bit of revisionist history, but worthwhile museum.... This museum, located in the Plancius Building, (near the zoo, which was forbidden to Jews during the German occupation), has 2 permanent and 5 temporary exhibits on various historical themes per year. It has recreated streets and large photos that try to recreate the war years in Holland. There are letters, photos and film fragments that give small stories to the horrible backdrop of German occupation. I had the honor to meet a man in his 70s who was hidden as a 4 year old, who was grateful, but more honest about the percentages and numbers of real resistance, especially during the first 3 years of the war. His father and siblings were in hiding at another location, but were betrayed by Dutch neighbors and were sent to the death camps...only his mother survived the war. He, and many historians, feel that The Netherlands, France, et al...highly exaggerate the numbers and percentages of real resistance to the Germans and genuine help for their Jewish neighbors. Holland had one of the highest rates of Jewish selection, interment and murder of most European countries...even though it had a long history of tolerance for centuries. Many, many Dutch were nazi sympathizers or simply ignored what was happening to their Jewish neighbors...shame. There were true Dutch heros who resisted, hid Jews and did deeds above and beyond the call of normal citizens...but, not the high numbers eluded to...

Best most informative museum of our trip!!. 8 euros entry, well worth the cheap cost though, very clean place, very clean toilets, quiet area of city opposite the Artis Zoo, secure lockers for bags with refundable 2 euro coin, can take photos without the flash on too.This place is a little hidden treasure and well worth a visit after visiting the Anne Frank Huis (house) it was very informative and moving all the same and helps to put things into perspective along the way.
Worthwhile. A well set out tour through the occupation of the Netherlands. Good audio guide, although clunky to use at first.

well worth the visit. I really liked the Resistance Museum. I've seen others like it, but the curators have really used the period materials well to tell the history of the period about 1936 to 1950 centering on WW 2. The visuals are simple yet very powerful and bring a strong sense of the privations felt by the Dutch with special emphasis on the WW 2 Dutch Jewish experience as well as the Dutch East Indies late colonial period. It'll take you 30 minutes to one hour but if you like history - this is the place to see.

Brilliant. It was fascinating yet very sad what the Dutch and Jewish people experienced from 1940-1945. It gave us a unique perspective on how people responded differently to the German invasion. I highly recommend it.

Don't miss this gem. We hit up this museum expecting to just spend an hour and ended up spending 3-4. It is well put together and really gave you a feeling of what life was like during the Nazi occupation. All the displays had English descriptions though all the personal items like letters are obviously in Dutch. They had a great display of embroidery done by Dutch jews in concentration camps which was quite moving. All in all a great and moving museum and a testament to the Dutch peoples courage during WWII.
Well Done Museum. Most Dutch museums are excellent, and this one is too. It's small but you leave with a strong sense of what the war was like for the Dutch in the Netherlands and in Indonesia

Well worth a visit. Despite a bit of difficulty following the flow of the museum, it was well worth our time. The personal stories (snippets though they are) offer direct insight into the psyche of real people struggling in a difficult time period. The museum tries very hard not to censure or approve any one point of view, but to present a range. Well done.

Well done despite some painful exhibits. The power of this museum is in the combination of small stories of individual struggles and the context of the big picture of the occupation. The chronological pathway through the museum is a bit complicated but you can double back. There are many photos and artifacts of daily life during the occupation. It does not overly glorify the resistance effort at the expense of a parallel narrative of collaboration. Some exhibits are heart-wrenching. Overall it seems very objective. There was a special exhibit of needlework done by women who were captive of the japanese in the far east. It is very interesting.
Fascinating. Much more interesting and informative that the Anne Frank House.
Very informative. Excellent museum for anyone interested in Holland during WWII.

An Excellent Resistance Museum. This museum, through an amazing collection of artifacts, tells the story of the Dutch Resistance during WWII. It gives plenty of context to understand the circumstances of the German invasion of Holland, how the resistance developed, and what it did. I have visited several resistance museums in Europe, and this is one of the most well done ones.

A don't miss. We rented the head phones (an actor did the narration) and after all these years we still learned a lot. This is a museum not to be missed. We ordered our tickets on line, very easy, well worth avoiding the line.

Quirky, informative. The museum was both harder to navigate and more interesting than I expected from the guidebooks. Keeping a timeline straight in the little off-shoot rooms was a challenge, but I very much enjoyed the personal stories. My only disappointment was that I expected more on the non-violent resistance movement, and I learned very little about that.
good little museum. However, I had read most of the information on their site before going. It was new to hubby, though.

New and Significant. This comparative newcomer is well-planned within a tight budget. Marvel over the Dutch response to the Nazis. And don't fail to check out tram line #9 in front of the neighboring Schowberg (ask anyone) where the Dutch bundled the Jewish babies in the Nazi orphanage holding facility under their arms and using the tram as cover ran with them to the next stop and safety!
Good Laugh. it's just one of those places you visit in the Dam
Informative. I'm a WW2 & Military History buff, so I found it particularly interesting and informative, but this is a place that will have something for everyone, from children to casual visitors.

Informative and interesting. We were pleasently surprised by this museum, we found it very interesting and informative.It was sad in places and warm in others. The exhibits were well laid out and the cafe next door served tasty sandwiches!

Insightful and memorable. History cones to life in this very interesting and interactive museum. Pity much of the information is in Dutch, but as this is a very visual museum, it still leaves a lasting impression of what life must have been like during the occupation.

Interesting snapshot of part of Amsterdam's past. The Resistance Museum presents a great overview of the Dutch experience of Nazi occupation during WWII. Well presented exhibits, with lots of interesting artefacts (microfilms, forgery tools for documents, etc) and personal anecdotes of 1930's-1940's Amsterdam.

Resistance Museum well worth a visit. It's fascinating to learn that the Dutch had a strong and effective organization opposing the Nazis. Although obviously the most famous Dutch Jews were the Frank family, many other Jews actually survived the war in hiding.
Very interesting. Liekd the artifacts and personal stories of survivors

Off the Well Worn Tourist Path and Well Worth It. We originally put aside 1 hour for this museum yet when we left 3 1/2 hours later we felt as if we just lived through all the history that we viewed and read. I am always thrilled to learn things about which I had no idea and this museum supplied more than its share. Simply incredible and a bit draining from an emotional standpoint as well. Do not rush through the exhibits (which is sometimes hard to follow as they twist and turn and are hidden in every nook and cranny of the museum's space) and make sure to watch the videos. Since it is not full of tourists you are free to let it all seep in and when you leave you can maintain that feeling by walking through some very quiet residential areas.
Excellent Museum - well worth a visit. It tells of the time of German occupation in WWII. Good photographs and exhibits. Dutch / English explanationsHelpfull staff."Least we forget"

A Very Moving Learning Experience. This is an incredibly moving museum which personalizes the story of the Dutch resistance so one can understand what it meant for the individuals involved. Thh home movies of Jews in the Amsterdam ghetto were very effective because it humanized the victims. Well worth the 1.5 hours I spent there. It is soemthing I will never forget.

An Amsterdam Highlight. This museum was on our "list" for our days in Amsterdam, and it was one of the high points of our visit. The Anne Frank House gets the press and the crowds, but this museum gets to the real core of the events of the 1930s and 40s.
