It has so much more information and a wealth of the historic events, as well as poignant and impressive stories. It would be very easy to spend 2 hours or more here if you read everything. It's a great exhibit of the ability of humans to be incredibly cruel, and the astounding strength and determination of people who are confronted with that evil. An absolute must for anyone with the slightest interest in the history of WW II and the Holocaust! The entry fee is free with the Museumkaart.

A wonderful surprise! A must for those interested in WW2.. I had never heard of this museum until I checked the tripadvisor site when I had a free afternoon in Amsterdam. It turned out to be one of the highlights of our trip. It was easy to take a tram from the Rijksmuseum and then walk a bit (and we found a delicious cafe, Kosje, on a nearby corner). What looks like a small museum from the street is actually quite large, and includes an enormous number of artifacts from the war years. The displays date to 1998-9, I believe, and are not particularly modern looking. But they are well arranged, setting the scene in the Netherlands in the 30s, then moving on through developments during the war years. Throughout, the viewer is nudged to think what you would do in response to each German action: adjust, resist, or collaborate. It is sometimes painful, often provocative, and definitely worth a visit. A big help: the labels are all in English as well as Dutch.
Good museum. I enjoyed my time at this museum and it gave me more insight into Dutch resistance in the war (against the Germans and the Japanese.)

Fascinating. We actually visited May 2010. Our travel agency suggested we do this museum with a tour guide which was not necessary. Everything was clearly explained in English and was very easy to navigate. Incredibly informative and well worth the visit. We felt our tour guide rushed us thru the museum and we weren't able to spend as much time as we would have liked with each section. We would do this again- independently!

Excellent museum, interesting and imaginative layout. Interesting and educational. A great way to spend a spare hour or two. Some fascinating exhibits, especially the then and now photographs of the city.

Well done, good addition to your Amsterdam trip. If you're interested in WW2, this is a great museum to visit. They pack a lot of information into a relatively small space. It was a nice complement to the Anne Frank house and some of the bigger art museum options. This included on the I amsterdam card
A great insight into a terrible time. A nice museum, hidden away from the crowds showing what the city and country put up with during WWII along with how they fought.

Don't miss this. A quite remarkable small museum. A bit like the tardis - seems tiny from the outside but is a decent size inside. I was absolutely in awe of the exhibits and information. I simply cannot imagine living through those times. It seems so awful. The embroideries done by female prisoners are simply stunning. I urge you to go visit this museum if in Amsterdam. It's just off a tram route and easy to get to.and the restaurant next door is wonderful.

A must see. A well worth while museum that gives a balanced and interesting look at how the Dutch people handled the German occupation in the second world war. Is very good to do this before you visit Ann Franks house as it puts that eperience in its context. Spend about 1-2 hours there. Good cafes close by for lunch etc. Opposite the zoo.

Small Museum with a great theme. I liked the name and the work of this museum. All I would say was that it was “worth a visit” if you have time or stay in Amsterdam for a few days. Very educational for both old and young. A good lesson to learn about war, its impact, and how people survived during wartime.
Worth the stop. The exhibits had English and Dutch. It was interesting to learn about the Dutch fighters in Asia.
Excellent mueseum. One of the best museums I visiting in Amsterdam for history/flow of museum
Cool museum. Great stories about how the Dutch resisted the Nazis during WWII. Right across from Artis Zoo. Visit both places for a pleasant afternoon of sightseeing.
Very informative. HIGHLY recommend visiting - very interesting if you have interest in learning more about WW2 and netherlands' role

Interesting part of WWII History. I have been to many different sites dealing with WWII history in different countries (Germany, France, England, Latvia etc.) and each has their own story to tell and each has it's own story to be remembered. This museum is exactly for that. It is put together quite well and really gives a feel to the struggle the Dutch people went through and really shows how much they tried (and in some ways succeeded) to hold onto their own culture and heritage. The stories of people risking their own lives and those of their families to try and help others (Jewish and non-Jewish) make you realize that even in the face of terrible circumstances people can still do the right thing. The only thing that left me with a weird feeling was the last portion of the museum when it was dealing with the liberation there was no mention of the Canadian soldiers who were the main forces who liberated the country when the majority of the Allied forces were making their way to Germany / Berlin. As a Canadian I am extremely proud of the veterans who fought in this war. There were UK (which is probably where we were lumped into), French, even Russian flags but not a Canadian flag. Of course this is not what the museum is about but when many Dutch people consider the Canadians as the ones who finally freed them German occupation you would think a flag in that museum would not be too much of a gesture. There is a monument to the Canadian soldiers elsewhere in Amsterdam so the Canadians sacrifice is recognized but I think it should also be mentioned at this museum too.

Lots of information about life during occupation.. It wasn't just about hiding Jews. The Dutch love their royal family and found creative ways to get by during the war and to impede the occupation. There is a ton of information in this museum, and while most of it has English translations, it helps to be able to read the Dutch. You get a really good feel for what it was like to live in an occupied country.

A moving experience. A fascinating museum, small, but well worth a visit just to discover the bravery of the Dutch people and the lengths they went to, to protect the Jewish people. The photographs in the entrance hall were particularly poignant.

Very educational and informative. I have visited the Holocaust museum in Washington D.C. and this gives a different perspective to the time that serves as a great reminder of what can go wrong, but also what can go right when people stand up for what they believe in.

Good museum - as much about occupation as resistance. The museum is well worth seeking out. It has a great array of historical documents which are described in English and Dutch. The context setting of Dutch society before the war helps to explain the actions that took place during the war years. The museum does a great job of explaining the impact of the war on individuals and what it was like to be occupied by a foreign power. It felt like a very honest account of how difficult it was for individuals to pick sides and decide how much to resist. The museum is probably more suited to adults and older teenagers. There's not a lot of interaction for younger children who would not read the descriptors. Very vivid and informative but perhaps not for the whole family.

Fascinating!. A fascinating afternoon was sent looking and learning about the Resistance movement in the Netherlands, people who were so brave and selfless in their actions. The stories of the people of Amsterdam was upsetting but yet uplifting in the attitude shown towards the Nazis; combined with a visit on Saturday to the Anne Frank Huis, our weekend has left us with a huge sense of gratitude towards those who appeared fearless in defending and maintaining the freedom that we all enjoy today.Also at the moment, there is a further extra exhibition of embroideries done by women prisoners during the war, some moving stories to be told and incredibly intricate handiwork.

A fascinating insight into war-time Holland. The collection of artefacts and stories told through this exhibit literally transports you back to the period itself. It was incredibly humbling and a great privilege to see the things you hear about from the war but never think you'll see, such as the illegal newspapers in circulation, secret papers revealing written code, and sewing by female prisoners.I would definitely recommend a visit; I learnt a lot and it's practically opposite Artis Zoo so you can go to two totally different attractions in one day!

A monster of a small museum. Included in the I Amsterdam card this "small" museum is located very near the Zoo. All the Dutch experience of the German occupation, from passive acceptance to outright hostility, can be seen here in imaginative exhibits using photographs, real objects, sound, and film. A whole semester of history is packed into this relatively small space and is done in such an exciting way that you are compelled to read more.

Very Interesting. We loved this museum and learned a lot about Amsterdam during the Second World War. I had to keep moving my wife on or she would have spent all day there. The museum is very close to the zoo which we visited after.

Definitely learned something new here. Anyone who says they knew about the dutch resistance to the Nazis before visiting this museum is either Dutch or lying to you. I for one knew nothing and was very happy to visit and inform myself. The museum has a slightly confusing layout, but everything is also stated in english. A great learning experience!

Good place to visit to set the scene for Anne Frank's house. This exhibition was very interesting and thought provoking. There is an explanation in English at nearly all displays and the witness first hand accounts are also translated into English. We had an hour and half before it closed and just fitted everything in but ideally allow 2 hours-longer if you can read the old documents in Dutch! The museum is geared towards educating older children with thought provoking displays-flip boards and some interactive buttons. My 11 year old daughter was completely engrossed as she moved around.
great place. It is worth a trip here. We combined it with the Jewish historical museum and the Portuguese Synogogue.. They are a short tram ride away

another way of seeing things. just 20 m away from the artis royal zoo, this is also a must visit place in amsterdam. everything is presented in an unique stile, very interactive with the visitor, things are well explained, and you feel you transfer yourself in the action. try it

Really worth a visit if you are interested in WW2. It provides a great overview on what happened in Holland in the war, with stories and interactive displays. Good for older kids and adults alike. The zoo is just opposite for a bit of light relief afterwards!

pleasantly suprised. We ended up at this museum by chance; it rained the day we were going to rent bikes, and we needed to stay warm and dry. In most of the guidebooks, this museum is not listed as one of the must-see's of Amsterdam. However, for anyone with an even moderate interest in the history of WWII in Europe, really should go. Not only is the information interesting; it is laid out in very interactive style, heavy on multi-media. Everything is in English and easy to follow. They display remarkable artifacts from all phases of the war in the Netherlands and tie in personal stories of people who experienced the war. Very sobering and educational. We ended up spending about 4 hours there, glued to the exhibits; whereas we spent only about an hour each at the Van Gogh and Rijks.

do not miss this.. i found this a very interesting museum which gave a great insight into the occupation of Amsterdam and the determination and heroism of the dutch people during those dark days. i was even lucky enough to be guided round by an ex resistance veteran, a great honour.
Great. we only had 50 mins when we went in but it was really good would liked to of had longer words can not describe how good it was just depends on if you like museums

Informative. Museum was full of a school class while I was there which rather spoiled it. However found it covered the subject well with most things translated into English. Certainly I left a lot better informed than when I went in.

Best Museum in Amsterdam. Wonderful museum dedicated to the people of Amsterdam who fought against the Nazi invasion. There are lots of visual displays and you really need 2-3hrs to take your time and read everything.Must see when in Amsterdam !!

So moving - find time to visit. I imagine it would b easy to overlook this museum as it is a little further out of the centre and it does not have the same fame as Ann Frank - but it moved us four adults so much we just walked around in silence at times trying to comprehend what people went through - I for one will never forget some of the things I read here. The Dutch should be so proud of their ancestors

Best Museum I saw in Europe. We visited the museum about three o'clock on a rainy afternoon. The staff warned us it was closing at four thirty, but we thought there was enough time to walk around. There was not, the displays were thoguht provoking and utterly compelling. This attraction (and the Pegasus Bridge) were the high points of the Netherlands for me.

Must see!. This was my favourite museum in Amsterdam. I spent about three to four hours here, giving due attentions to all the amazing artefacts.They are stories which must be told, and never forgotten. It was not all that long ago and this museum will open your eyes and invite you into a very real world that over-produced, over-stylised Hollywood movies can never do justice to portray.Highlights were the women's embroidery, weapons, tiny coded messages, and any letters that were narrated. So much to see here.Many tourists do not put this on their list of places to see - put it near the top of yours. It is close to the zoo, easy to reach by tram.

Fantastic. Recommended by hotel we were staying at and glad they did otherwise we would have missed an amazing museum. Gave a very good account of what it was like under enemy occupation and the history of the resistance. There are many accounts of some very brave people who stood up to oppression, some paying the ultimate penalty.

not in to art but was good. as title says not that in to art but enjoyed visiting this place. We were on honeymoon so thought better see the sights so we did. the lines were massive to get in. But we had the i am amsterdam card that took us all the way to the front.

A small but very worthwhile museum. We've been to Amsterdam many times and have visited the major museums on multiple occasions, so we wanted to visit smaller museums the last time. This museum has quite an interesting exhibit and we thought it was very informative & well-done. I also recommend a (smallish) book about the museum that's sold in the bookstore; it's beautifully-illustrated.(We were actually there in May of *2010*, but there's no mechanism for indicating previous years).
Dutch Fighters. Loved the museums statement "resist, collaborate or go along with"Loved some of the resistance stories

Worth a visit to Amsterdam all on its own. This is a totally riveting, meticulously assembled, well presented, and deeply moving exhibition on life in the Netherlands during the occupation. We would recommend it unreservedly.

A moving experience. This is a small museum dedicated to explaining the resistance to fascist occupation. Tales of individual heroism and acts of defiance are set against broader historical explanations. A must for understanding those terrible times still within memory.

Very interesting. We went here the day before Anne frank Museum, and i am glad i did. This tells you lots of information about the war which you might not learn at Anne franks huis. Very well set out very good
Very good! Impressive building!. Very good with loads of things to see, again go early in the morning to beat the crowds
Thought Provoking. You don't hear much about the Dutch resistance - so this was an interesting walk through history. Its a little bit slow at the beginning, but persevere.

Thought provoking. There is a lot of information to read but the museum is laid out really well in a logical order. Information is delivered with photos and personal accounts of individuals roles in the resistance. This really made us think for days after we visited. Unbelievable that all this went on less than 100 years ago.

Adds to the experience. After visiting the Anne Frank and becoming more aware of the plight of the Jews in Amsterdam, i wanted to know about the people that helped the Jews avoid the concentration camps. The museum is mostly in Dutch, so one has to read the handout in English. Do read the stories of the babies that were saved and how heartwrenching it must have been for the mothers to give up their children with the hopes of saving them.
Interesting reminder of difficult times. It is quite small but it is an invaluable reminder of troubled times which should never be forgotten.

insight. I know every country writes it's own history. If what you see here is true, the Dutch opposed the Nazi regime every step of the way. Lots of informative photos and write ups enlighten the visitor as to how much suffering took place, and how it carried on to the war in the East. It's worth the visit.
Worth finding. Just out of the centre, but worth the walk.Very well laid out, very moving

Excellent. We spent a whole afternoon in this museum - there was so much information to see / read / hear. We felt that as these people had often given their lives for the resistance cause the least we could do was read their stories etc. It was interestingly exhibited too... some things you had to peer through 'windows' and around corners to see properly, other things were almost interactive - you could tune in the radio to hear different things, listen to the stories of the individuals as you turned the pages of their photo album etc.A visit is highly recommended
Dutch resistance mueseum. A very comprehensive insight into the occcupation of amsterdam by german forces lot of reading and audio visuals good to visit

Not cheap but worth it.. Was hoping more than the philips wing would be open by now. Quite an expensive visit but it's worth paying for the audio tour, 'lively' version (a more informal talk through of the major works), to get more out of it.

Worth a visit if you are interested in history. Very helpful receptionists. Fascinating insight into what happened in Holland during The Second World War. Many individual accounts which made it real and a wonderful exhibition of embroidery made by women prisoners under very difficult circumstances. Not much on the actual Resistance Movement though. Allow plenty of time for the visit.

Very informative, not cheap!. Brilliant if you want to understand Amsterdam fully and would recommend visiting at the beginning of your break as it pieces a lot of history and landmarks together, shame its 10 euros entry

True stories placed in context. Loads of impressive stories from a dark period. What I really liked is that everything is placed in context. It is not just a collection of paraphernalia, but it is very well explained. Visitors get a good impression about the time and how people from Amsterdam and the Netherlands behaved (which wasn't always that brave) and tried to survive. It also raises the question: what would I have done...
A WW 2 buff must visit. If you enjoy history and World War II then this is a must in Amsterdam

Good place to learn more. The location is a bit remote, but worth seeking out. It is not crowded at all, so is a welcome relief from other tourist sites. I love learning more about the WW2 era, so this was perfect for me. Gave a good sense of place for the Netherlands during the period.
Great Museum. This museum is is well planned out and really captures the Dutch Resistance Movement. I highly recommend it.
Fantastic Museum. One of the more interesting museums, and the way it has been arranged makes you almost transport to the 1940s and understand it much better!
nice little museum. nice little museum - if you're interested in the cities history a nice place.
Exellent museum. Give yourself loads of time to visit this place as there is a lot of reding to do.I found it very interesting.

Situated in a nice area of the city, opposite the zoo.. Tells the story of Amsterdam under the Nazi occupation in World war 2. Includes film and audio from the time, together with personal accounts. Very interesting, and at times quite moving. We enjoyed it as much as the Anne Frank house....plus there were no queues. A hidden gem.

Very detailed museum. Great museum, get a very good understanding of what the Dutch people went through leading up to and during the invasion. Not for children under 13, to intense and not a museum where ther are hands on stuff. Lots of reading and information, great for adults and older teenagers.

A fitting tribute to very brave partisans. Everything is very well laid out and explains what Amsterdammers (and beyond) had to endure during WW2. We were totally engrossed and found 4 hours pass without us noticing.

Found Museum Lacking. Found museum lacking in what the resistance actually did or how they organised themselves etc. It seemed to be no more than a collection of war photographs etc that you can see in any war museum

Glimpse of history. Make sure you watch the movie before you start going around - it makes more sense that way. Had younger children with us who didn't really let us take the amount of time we needed, but very informative. Teenage children enjoyed it and we all had a better understanding for having been through!

A must see.. One of the best museums I've been to in a long time. Seeing the dreadful acts of war through the eyes of the Dutch people. The displays were really well thought out and in different media forms. I highly recommend it.
Interesting!. It's a small museum, but very interesting and dense. If you have any interest about understanding the effects of WWII in Neitherlands, I highly recommend!

Moving experience of what life was like under the Nazis. My wife and I both found this to be a fascinating museum, showing everything that is involved in being occupied by foreign invaders, how brave those in the resistance movement were, and how risky what they did for their people and country was often resulting in them losing their lives. Very informative and moving, with some excellent audio explanations.

A model for a small museum. Excellent. We were all struck by the many small touches of inspiration in this museum.
It has been put together with much love and care. Our children were enthralled.
Don't miss it.
Fascinating historical museum. The displays were very vivid and real. You are able to experience what it was like to be in the Dutch Resistance. Video presentations run continuously.

Excellent little museum with a fantastic exhibition. very moving exhibition with lots of information. I lost myself in time while wondering around looking at all the objects and real life stories which made this a very memorable experience. One of the better mueseums I have been to

History of the DUtch Resistance in WWII. Great museum which does not always get a lot of attention in the tourist books. Worth a visit to learn about the Dutch resistance during WWII and the german occupation of the Netherlands.

great museum if into wwii history. We were recommeded this museum by Michael from omy tours the night before. This was a great museum. It was not crowded like the Anne Frank museum which we visited early in the morning with a bit of a headache. More content in this museum.

Don't miss this!. Extreemly well laid out and informative modern museum. Staff very friendly and helpful. Lockers to stow your coats etc. I really enjoyed the exhibit on the prison needle work/ story embroidery. lots of translated exhibits throughout. This is easy to get to, jump on a tram. It's also opposite the zoo. A good few nice cafes on the street for lunch or coffe and cake.

Fantastic a must do in Amsterdam!. Fantastic! great view of the Netherlands before and after German occupation WWII. Very interactive, not advertised enough in my opinion, better than the Anne Frank House, good value for money.
Hisorical. Well done display. Interesting pictures showing Amsterdan before and during German occupation.
Amazing.. I learned so much! It was a beautiful museum, with just the right amount of things to look at. Desk staff mocked and sneered at us a few times though. Politeness doesn't cost anything.

Gives a good view of the resistance during the 2nd World War. A must for everyone!!!! who has any interest for the Dutch Resistance history.Get to know the brave people who risked their lives for our freedom.
A very good museum.. A little bit out of the way, but a really worthwhile effort to visit this museum.

There couldn't be a better time to visit than right now. With the disgusting rise of anti semitism rife in the UK, led by fake islamic influences, there couldn't be a better time to visit this remarkable little museum. I had a lump in my throat most of the way through. The story of the dilemma faced by the Dutch people is touching and angst ridden and their responses inspirational. The lessons of history were never more apposite than today.
Amazing stories of resistance. Visit this museum! It's filled with photos, artifacts, and stories. How brave the Dutch were -- they resisted in large and small ways.

Very informative and interesting. Although it is a bit of a trek from the tourist core (or easily accessed by tram), the museum was well worth a stop. Excellent signage, with most of it in English as well, tells the story of occupation and resistance during WWII. Well done and worth the trip.
Brilliant little museum. Very moving simple museum about life before during and after German invasion. A very good find. One of the highlights of Amsterdam.

Great Little Museum and Very Well Done!. For WWII history buffs or those just interested in learning more about Amsterdam, the Dutch Resistance Museum is a great place to go. It is relatively small, but very well done and there are enough photographs and information displayed to keep you entranced for a couple of hours. They close at 5:00. We got there a bit late in the afternoon and ran short on time so were a bit rushed at the end. There is a part of the museum where you can hear personal stories from actual surviving members of the Dutch Resistance. Fascinating! The museum documents life in Holland from the time the Germans first invaded and the birth and subsequent activities of the Dutch Resistance Movement. Visitors will get a sense of the German brutality and the hard choices made by the Dutch in their efforts to resist. This museum brings home the realities of war, occupation, and oppression by ruthless invaders. You will come away with a sense of appreciation and respect for the bravery, commitment, and sacrifice of those who made the choice to resist and you will ask yourself, "What would I have done?"
excellent and informative. nicely presented and interesting with excellent exhibitions a/v presentations and audio tours

Interesting Museum. We realy enjoyed this museum. We had not been aware of how hard life was for the Dutch people as we tend to concentrate more on the horrible events centering on the Jewish popluation. This was an eye opener. I reccomend it.

Quiet, lots to see. The Resistance museum is a bit out of the way, opposite the entrance to the Zoo, but well worth a trip.I would suggest going here at the start of your holiday, as there is a lot to take in and no seating - we were there on the last day and achey feet definitely put a downer on our experience.The actual exhibits are crammed with information (possibly too much) and cover lots of different topics and areas of Amsterdam in the war. The section on the treatment of Jews and concentration camps is really moving.There are only 2 things I would suggest:1 - Seating around the museum2 - Some, but not all of the many propaganda posters on display are translated and unfortunatley the most interesting ones weren't.Highly recommended
Worth the time. Anothergood museum worth at least two hoursof you time, right accross the street from the zoo.
Surprising. We learned a lot during our visit to the museum. It was a surprising highlight to our trip!

Very historical. It is very painful to see what ALL the people of Amsterdam went through in 1941--and the ravages of Adolph Hitler and The Nazis. To anyone who says "this never happened"--go to this museum !!!!

great, non-mainstream museum. I am interested in World War II history. I visited the Anne Frank Museum but this was my favourite. I was recommended to this museum by Ryan a tour guide from the omy amsterdam group. Hardely anybody and I learnt more in tis museum than in the Anne Frank house.
HelloHello. Photographs taken during the events & historical documents. A little too much overall keen to leave by end of display

Experience the resistance. This place gives you plenty to think about, and the sense of resistance to an oppressive occupation comes over you as you walk from item to item. There's videos, actual artifacts and knowledge.
If you enjoy history, you'll love this place. If you don't, go find yourself a coffee shop.
WW 2 experiences in Hollalnd. A must-see for anyone interested in World War 2! All the exhibits were very informative, and it was one of the least crowded places we visited in Amsterdam.

well worth a visit. Visited the museum with my daughters and very glad we went. Definitely learned a lot and it wasn't a biased account of just the suffering of the Dutch people but gave some of the history of before and after the war. I really felt it was well laid out and worth a visit
History revisited. This museum gave me an insight like I never knew had happened. It is so much like what happened in Germany and really depicts what the Dutch went through
history. hard enough to find but its historical and interesting....go early or book online - queue moves relatively quickly
History worth seeing. See the real deal about fighting for your country.

Fascinating. Not really up on my WWII history, I didn't know what to expect from this museum. I must say that I was impressed with the array of artifacts, journals, letters and photos that make up their collection. But I was also surprised at the very unvarnished depiction of the Dutch during a terrifying chapter in world history. A lot to interact with and a great use of video and audio in many of the exhibits. It was very enlightening.
Learn from the past and look forward!. Resistance may be a good citizen's duty. Here's where you come to know how this was done under Nazi occupation, and more ... inspirational and informative.

The Resistance Museum gave me an indepth understanding of Amsterdam during WWII.. I had a free hour, and visited this museum. As an American, I didn't understand the various belief systems in the Netherlands prior to WWII, what life was like during the occupation, and how the resistance movement worked. Ended up being late for a meeting because there was so much to read, visualize, and think about. Probably not that interesting for younger children, but a great museum for someone who wants to learn more about the war.

A surprisingly well done museum. With less publicity surrounding it than other areas museums, I thought it would perhaps be a regional museum with little to offer a non-native. I was very surprised to find thorough explanations of exhibits (in Dutch and English), a smooth chronology to the layout and the inclusion of the Dutch experience in Indonesia during the war.This museum is well worth the 8 Euro fee--I wandered throughout it for two hours and still did not take everything in.
It was OK, but not the best museum in Holland.. Lots of paper displays, fake guns, and old pictures. If you have an hour to kill, go to this museum. Kind of out of the way, too!

Eye Opener. This museum across the street from the zoo and in the area where there was resistance activity is worth a visit. Anyone slightly interested in history will be captivated by the exhibits and personal notes and memorobilia.

So informative. A wonderful additon to visitng the Anne Frank House. Visiting this in conjuction to the Anne Frank House really gives you an understanding of lDutch life under the Nazis. Take the working tour from one to the other using the available guide and make a day of it.

Really interesting museum. This museum is quite far fromthe city centre but it is well worth a visit. It is beside the Artis Zoo and quite easy to miss. It is very interesting, interactive and I loved seeing the objects that the Resistance used during the war to to smuggle things or encode messages, it is very ingenious. You learn a lot in this museum but not in a boring way!
first time amsterdammers. Interesting and worth a visit and can be combined with the botanical garden which is within walking distance of this musseum
a great museum. Unfortunately we went late in the day and only got an hour in the museum before it closed. It was great, very informative, emotive and beautifully executed.

Great Museum!. Fantastic museum! We spent half the day here and could have stayed all day easily. Wonderfully presented information. Thoroughly enjoyed this museum. Highly recommend this on your visit to Amsterdam

Packed with fascinating information. The Dutch Resistance Museum is a very well thought out and balanced portrayal of the efforts of the Dutch people's resistance to German occupation of Holland. There are lots of nooks and crannies to look into, moving first person accounts of events and an excellent audio tour. You need a couple of hours here to understand how hard it was to resist yet how many of the Dutch did their best to thwart the efforts of their occupiers.
Excellent Experience!. The exhibit itself was fantastic with loads of informative displays. Staff were very pleasant and overall, I enjoyed my visit!
Interesting. Lots of information here but not as clearly organized as I would have liked. Lots of school kids during the weekday.

A lot of effort has gone into this museum. Not for families with children under 14, I would have said. Very political (for obvious reasons), lots of detail that my 13 year old struggled to understand and concentrate on after a while. I think they should make it clear before you part with your money. I probably would have sat outside with her in the sunshine. But for adults - wonderful !

Best museum in Amsterdam. A must-see. Fascinating, disturbing and heartbreaking. What a fantastic museum. We were there for 3 hours and only left then because our feet were hurting. I'd recommend this to anyone over Anne Frank house, which has long lines and not a whole lot to see.

The story of dutch heroes (and cowards) in WW II. This is a well laid out museum that gives you the history of the Netherlands from the 1930's pre-World War II time to the end of that war. It shows every day life that got more and more difficult through those years. It shows the gradual de-humanisation and eventually deportation of the Jewish population. It shows those who were cowards and did not stand up against the evil of the nazi's. And it shows the courage of those to whom this museum is dedicated: the men and woman of the dutch resistance. (verzet). There are many original artefacts that are sometimes moving like the letters sent home from concentration camps. The signs at the exhibits are both in dutch and english. The museum is only € 7,50 and is opposite the entrance of Artis, the Amsterdam Zoo. All-in-all well worth the visit. And don't miss the picture at the end of the exhibition. In this picture there is a sign which reads "This is Holland. Remember! The Dutch are our Allies".

Courage. This well laid out museum gives an insight to life during the occupation. It tells of the courage and ingenuity of the resistance movement. Well laid out, excellent exhibits and plenty of information. Well worth a visit.

its amazing how much teachers forgot to tell me.... i learned so much at this museum! i had no idea how much WWII history existed in amsterdam until this trip. this museum is amazing but a lot to take in!!! its not a large space but it is jam packed with information and artifacts! i'd say give yourself two hours, dont try to cram it in with other history museums because we were "museum-ed out" after attempting to absord all the information! there were amazing artifacts like a baby carriage with a trap door for guns, fake id's used by resistance members, amazing personal stories, a corset used to smuggle extra ration booklets... a must see for sure!!!

Informative and Inspiring. One thinks of the resistance and often thinks of the French, but the Netherlands has a significant history of resistance during the Second World War that deserves more attention. This museum is an important stop for any visitor to Amsterdam, a complement to the other historical sites in the city (the Anne Frank House, for instance). Another must-see.

Put aside plenty of time!. The resistance museum was a facinating place!! Situated opposite the zoo ( we missed it a few times! ) and only 15 euros entry fee - it was a bargain. My friend and I were expecting to spend about 1 hour there and were still there 2 1/2 hours later. It was very well laid out and packed with interesting information - excellent and thoroughly recommended if WW2 is of interest to you.

Fantastic memorial. Had our appetite whet by an enthusiastic guide, so dragged the kids to yet another WW2 museum...how wrong we were. The displays were modern and well presented, the stories personal and significant. I was very moved by individual plights, and proud of the prevailing behavior of the Dutch. Well worth a trip. You'll find it's tiny sign across the road from the Zoo . The part of the zoo closet to Dam square.

The audio tour was helpful. Good museum.. A well-laid out museum that clearly explains what happened in The Netherlands during WWII. The audio tour was useful because it took us through the exhibits in a logical pattern and gave additional information. The musuem is a good complement to the Anne Frank House.
A moving experience.. This small but interesting museum was full of WWII info and artifacts. Well worth the time( about 1hour).

Don't miss it!. I found it really interesting, well laid out and informative with really friendly people at the desk. It gave a great insight into the Dutch experience and added a kind of balance to my perspective after visiting the Anne Frank house.At Anne Frank's House they sell a little book for 50c at the desk and that takes you on a walk from the house to the museum, pointing out all sorts of things on the way - really worth doing and interesting to connect the two parts of the history.

Generally interesting about Dutch life during occupation.. The museum wasn't what i had expected as it covers a large part of the Dutch peoples struggle as a whole against the German invader. Whilst it is very interesting, i found there was an awful lot to constantly read and as you walk around. A lot of the displays are seen through peep holes or slivers of glass, so sometimes it can make it harder to see, if it was busy i should imagine it makes it very difficult indeed. Right at the end is another part about the Dutch fighting against the Japenese that goes into really good detail solely about this. I would recommend this attraction, but i felt it was generally about Dutch life during German occupation.

A Fascinating Museum. This Museum deserves rime. We spent 2.5 hours and did not give any real time to the Dutch in Indonesia section. Very well laid out and informative. If you have seen the Ann Frank House then you should see this

Excellently presented - lots to read. Good price - around 7 euros. Lost to see and read. Very interesting seeing how the resistance worked and who was involved. Good exhibition of the works of the women whilst in the camps. Takes a couple of hours to go round and read all the info, good film and footage to see in all languages. worth a visit.

Worthwhile. A little pricey but we were glad we went. The museum conveys to the visitor in a very personal way what life was like during Nazi occupation. It is something everyone needs to see to appreciate how easily freedom can slip away.

Take time. This is an insightful and honest recounting of the Dutch experience of occupation during WW2. Unfortunately I did not allow enough time to see everything and will have to go again to get it all in, not that I mind as this is well worth every Euro.

This was an extremly interesting museum. I thought that i would not really find this museum interesting -How wrong i was ! It was very interesting indeed. The exhibits were well laid out and the information was relevent and consise.I lost track of time and greatly enjoyed learnig about the work of the Dutch Resistance .

wonderfully designed and incredibly moving. I was stunned by my visit - it's probably one of the most imaginatively laid out museums I have ever been to. I hadn't read the reviews here and went because I picked up a leaflet in the Anne Frank House, expecting a few bits and pieces put together on some boards as something of an afterthought. Totally wrong! It's beautifully constructed and the design combined with the subject matter to make the two hours that I spent there truly memorable.

Absolutely fascinating well worth a visit. We went here not expecting much more than a rehash of other similar museums we had visited, however this is not the case. It was well designed with a easy to follow history of the Dutch resistance, from the day to day struggle to how funding was obtained to help the people at that time, this was one of the first museums that I have read all the displays. The visit takes about 1.5-2 hours to complete
Great. It was very interesting for us. The only thing was all the exhibits had english versions but all the audio only in Dutch .

Hidden Gem. If you don't like waiting in line and you have an interest in history, this hidden gem is for you. The story of the Resistance during WWII is told complelingly through photos, videos, artifacts and scene recreations. It helps you experience what the Dutch endured during those hard years and what they did to stymie their occupiers. Even though all exbits are in english there is also a good audio guide included in the reasonable price.
Absorbing. This is so interesting, we spent about 3 hours there and didn't see everything. A good reason to go again. Some very harrowing stories, about some very brave people.

Extremely educational and very well done. My husband and I got in free with the IAMsterdam card. Well worth it. Lots of "personal" remembrances and dairies. Each story told the full story of what happened to each person by the end of the war. Some resisted, some just tried to ignore the occupation and blend in and many died for their brave efforts. It was fascinating how one banker started a system of fraudulent bank notes and was able to funnel millions into the resistance effort. He was ultimately discovered, but his use of fraudulent bank notes and the system all the financiers used to fund the resistance would make any greedy banker happy today. Fortunately the money they gleaned off the system all went to to arming and providing for resistance fighters, so it was used for the common good. We spent at least 2 hours in there. You can read the English explanations or get an English audio tour. Other languages also available.

Over-rated. Keep this one for a rainy day when you have visited all the others. I found this only moderately interesting and most the exhibits to be very static. I had high hopes for this museum having read some of the previous reviews but left feeling disappointed.

Our favorite Amsterdam museum. We loved our visit to the Dutch Resistance Museum. Expecting to stay there for only a little while, we were quickly engrossed with the personal diaries, stories, and wonderful hands-on exploration of this fascinating time, and spent 3 hours there, and could have stayed longer. For anyone interested in the stories of how the Dutch resisted the Nazi occupiers, this is a "must". We saw many middle-level school groups there during our visit; I'm glad the Dutch children have access to this very accessible slice of history. A nice change from art museums and architecture, which we loved, as well. A very unique museum, well worth the time, for all ages.

Very worthwhile. I wasn't sure what to expect when I visited here, having known very little about the Resistance beforehand. But I can say now I have been very well informed from my visit. We went in at 4pm so we only had an hour to look around before they closed but we did get to see everything in the main exhibit I even got to read most of the information about the various displays. I found it a really interesting and informative place, It details the various ways the people of Holland supported the Jewish community by organizing various workers strikes, hiding people and arranging scams so they could get money. There was also a very touching display of a tiny Christmas tree that was made in one of the concentration camps using bits of the floor boards as branches and snow that was actually part of a bandage from a gunshot wound.  All I can say really is go there it's only 7.50 for a ticket and its absolutely worth it.
For a more detailed account of history. good audio, visuals, and in English. Unsung heroes depicted here and the affects and impact of WWII to all in Amsterdam and Holland.

Very good if you don't know your history. Full disclosure: my father and uncle were Dutch and highly active in opposing the Nazis in the Netherlands during WW2. As such, am very familiar with how incredibly the country suffered. And I must say was a tad disappointed. Much of my nit-picking is due to semantics. In other words, the museum talks about "agents" and the "resistance" when most people don't know the difference. Many think it is one and the same, therein lies a huge problem. My uncle was an SOE trained agent who was dropped (parachuted) twice into occupied Holland. His second mission was to organise the many Resistance groups under one umbrella/unit to have coordination/cohesion once the Allies liberated. It was mass confusion in reality and admittedly hard to depict in photographs. There was no mention of SOE (Special Operations Executive...SOE, the USA branch was the OSS precursor to CIA.) Some of the facts are incorrect and/or unclear but that is the way it was depicted. There were more than 10 Resistance groups and all had different functions and ideas. Therein is another confusion. Admittedly, I do not speak or read Dutch very well, my father insisted on teaching me more frequently spoken languages (French, Spanish etc.,) so somethings may be lost in translation. Overall would give the exhibit a "B-". Some of the films and photos were hard to decipher. Someone at the museum needs to do some research on recently declassified documents (National Archives Kew) and update some of their facts. This does not take away from the actual exhibits especially for those who know nothing. The Dutch suffered more than any other country overrun by the Nazis: lost more people per capita than any other Western European country, out of the Jewish population of appx 250,000 only about 6,000 came back or survived. I highly recommend this exhibit overall but some updating is needed or we should start a fund to help because none of us should every forget.

Absorbing and fascinating museum. I had not originally planned to go to this museum, but I found myself a block away at 3:45 PM, so decided to check it out. Good decision, but I should have gone earlier in the day.The museum is laid out in winding paths that provide personal accounts of Dutch citizens and they way they responded to the German occupation, subtly making each visitor personally involved in the times.

much more interesting than you expect very well done. Needs to be seen. Have been to Amsterdam many times now and have covered the obvious attractions. Wandered along to this after a great morning in the Tropenmuseum, we were very impressed by the serious, matter of fact but engaging way that the Dutch situation in WW2 was presented, never realized what they went through, the eyewitness statements are stark at times but very human, honest and you can't help but ask what would i have done. More one for the adults and young adults, but should not be missed. Go here then to Anne Frank, it puts the whole story in context.

Lest we forget.... Excellent museum with good multimedia attractions in both Dutch and English. Gives you a real feel for life before the WWII 1940 German invasion and during occupation. History of the Jewish population - out of 125,000 deported only 8,000 lived; out of 25,000 hidden only 8,000 survived.Very detailed overview of how an innovative banker led the funding of the resistance (£450m in today's money). Ask them to order you a taxi since difficult to find in the street.Well worth a visit.

Excellant alternative perspective. I found this museum using trip advisor and I'm so happy I did. I had already been to the Anne Frank House during my last stay in Amsterdam and since I am currently living in Germany, have been to other WWII museums. This was a great way to see the Dutch perspective of the Nazi regime and I definitely learned quite a bit during my visit. A little bit of a walk from the central station but well worth the visit. The cafe that is attached is also a good place to have lunch.
Very interesting indeed. Great museun, informative without being boring, pleasant in a serious way.Maybe not the best known museum in Amsterdam but it should be! Well worth a vsist !!!

Very interesting. This is a very interesting museum, it is good for people from countries that weren't occupied during WW2 to get an idea of what life was like for those who did. The majority of exhibits have english translations, and give accounts of individuals and events very clearly (the exhibit on smuggling jewish babies out hit very hard)
Excellent. Very interactive and showed good view of individuals before, during and after WWII.

Superb, informative and worthwhile. Free enterance with the I Amsterdam City Card but I would have paid anyway. All information is in Dutch and English. Good chronological overview of the Dutch resistance during WWII. Chilling statements, informative displays, don't forget to put this museum on your to do list !

Wonderful Museum. The Dutch Resistence Museum was an in depth, informative museum that tried to cover as many angles relating to World War II and the various political factions. The musuem is accessible via the trams and the price is reasonable.

Absolutely excellent.. Dovetailing nicely with a visit to the Anne Frank House, the Resistance Museum also proveds an excellent overview of one of the signature moments in the country’s history. The walking tour between the two attractions is in my mind an integral part of the Resistance Museum experience. I started the walk to the Resistance Museum at the Anne Frank House, and after an excellent visit there purchased a guided walk pamphlet in the gift shop for 0.5 Euros. Taking about 1 ½ hours, the walk takes one on a journey through the heart of Amsterdam past historically significant sites such as the soup kitchen used during the hunger winter and the site of the Groot shooting. The small pamphlet gives fairly thorough explanations of these events and, quite surprisingly, the buildings are still very much in existence and easily found. I found the guide very easy to follow and kind of felt like I was on a private walking tour. The tour continues through the Waterlooplein and the Plantage, with an emotional visit soon after at the deportation site before stopping at the Resistance museum proper.The museum itself stands alone as worthy of a visit whether one chooses to do the walk or not. Admission is 7.5 Euros and I was offered a complimentary audio/visual guide that the museum is trialing as they continue to upgrade the overall experience. After a brief introductory exhibit on the financing of the Resistance, the permanent exhibit starts through a pair of doors. Starting from an overview of Dutch Society in the 1930s and continuing chronologically in a counter-clockwise fashion, the main exhibit touches pretty much every main event, personality, and concept in the Dutch Resistance from May of 1940 until the end of the War. The audio/visual guide was valuable but not essential, adding emphasis to certain topics. There were artifacts, interactive exhibits, and even old radio broadcasts that you could listen to at the press of a button. The exhibits end with a brief description of the Dutch Colonial Empire focusing on the Dutch East Indies. Interspersed through the main hall are mini-exhibits (Help? Strike? Boycott?) that really put you in the shoes of the people at the time. In an era when people consider not getting a sunroof on their new car a "sacrifice," the museum gently suggests that you ask difficult questions about the events in question and provide your own answers. In my five-and-counting years of travel I can count on one hand the number of museum that I have literally lost track of time while touring and this is one of them. An excellent experience and one that demands many repeat visits.

Fantastic view into wartime Amsterdam.. A great museum! Tucked slightly away, and perhaps of specialist interest, but worth seeking out if you have an interest in WW2. Reasonably priced for an Amsterdam museum, and included in the Amsterdam city card. Not too crowded, you have the time and space to take in the museum at your own pace. All exhibitions are labelled in Dutch and English, and the history of occupied Amsterdam is told movingly and realistically. There is also an area looking at the Dutch Indies during the war. The museum also features temporary exhibitions, at the time of visit including the work of a Dutch wartime artist and an exhibition on football (very engaging as well). Family friendly (themes permitting) with interactive features scattered throughout the galleries. Overall, think it was fantastic experience and would look forward to going again.

Great history lesson, stop by, especially if planning to go to Zoo. Interesting and informative history on the Dutch and the resistance movement during World War II.
Young children probably would not enjoy this but even a brief visit is worth it, especially if you are using the IAmsterdam card.

This museum really gets you thinking. For those of us that grew up in the United States, and were born in the period after World War II, we really have no idea of what it was really like to live through a war taking place right where we lived. Movies are always going to be glorified in some way, but this is the very first museum I have ever gone to that really put into a terrible perspective just how terrible it was for the people that had to go one with their daily lives during the war. (notwithstanding the Anne Frank House, which focuses on the atrocities that happened to one family) The Dutch had a very active resistance movement, and it is quite rare to meet any Dutch people of a certain age that did not know someone or have a family member that was part of the Resistance. We always think that we, of course, would do the "right thing. That we would be able to resist torture if it meant turning in our neighbors. That we would be able to easily do espionage when the risk meant not only you getting shot, but your children one by one if you got caught. If you were caught, that meant watching your neighbors being killed in front of you as punishment. We can't imagine this, it has never happened to us. But it did happen to the Dutch people. They had to make some terrible choices. What other reviewers have mentioned that I also found to be the most compelling about this museum was that it really did make you question exactly what your choices would be, and make you realize that there were no easy choices, and all bore terrible consequences. If you are interested in the World War II era, this is definitely a place that is not to be missed. Younger children would find a lot of this information incomprehensible, this is really a "thinkers" museum.

Unexpectedly excellent and well curated account of Dutch resistance during WWII.. I'm not usually much of an art museum type, so this historical museum, recounting the details of the Dutch resistance to the German occupation during WWII, was much more my speed.This museum has a collection of Dutch resistance materials that are impressive: video, radio, photographs, letters, radios, propoganda posters, and so on. It's put together in a unique format with a timeline describing how the Dutch people reacted to each stage of the invasion and occupation, giving you a very good feeling for the actual events of the time. The museum is then broken out into different sections so you could get a feel for how the invasion and occupation affected different groups of society: Jews, Protestants, Liberals and so on. Fascinating and well put together.It was also a great prelude to visiting the Anne Frank Museum, as it really lays the groundwork for better understanding the Frank's situation while in hiding in Amsterdam.

Superb, worthwhile and absorbing museum. We were staying quite close to this museum, so thought we'd have a look and are so glad we did. This is one of the best museums on this topic I have ever been in. Not too large, but packed with period detail, the museum sets up the premise: what would you have done in the Nazi occupation: adjust, collaborate or resist? With hindsight, we often assume that we would have resisted, but would we really? The museum starts by showing you what life was like in the Netherlands in the Thirties, then takes you chronologically through the events of the occupation, going into greater detail on particular themes as you go round. What made it so special, and in some cases heartbreaking, for me were all the personal accounts: snippets of detail about individual people's experiences and actual artefacts from the period. There was also a great temporary exhibition about love in wartime. This museum really made me think and is a fantastic and non-judgmental testament to the people who lived through the occupation.

Interesting and informative. We really enjoyed this museum. It helped us to envision what life was like in Holland during the Nazi occupation. Of all the things I saw while in the Netherlands, this was my personal favorite.

Worth the time. This quiet, not-too-big museum is easy to reach by tram. The displays are thoughtfully organized, with some variety of presentation. They keep gently reminding you to think, "what would I have done?" and they explain how the situation changed as time passed, so that a decision that seemed harmless enough THEN could be disastrous NOW. Our visit in August 2010 also included a temporary exhibit on "love in wartime" which added some more dimensions to what we had just learned. We skipped the lines at Anne Frank House to see this instead, and we're glad we did.

Extermely Worthwhile Museum in Amsterdam. I was sceptical about going as I have doen extensive study of the period, but it was totally worth it and a highlight of Amsterdam (a city with many highlights!)It gives an excellent background to the second world war with interactive exhibits that cover different time periods and areas of the occupation in the Netherlands. By looking at individual people you better understand the reasons for doing nothing, resisting or collaborating.A definite must see in Amsterdam

Unique....well put together. I bicycle guide introduced me to this museum and claimed it was the best hidden secret in Amsterdam. I went back the next day and I totally agree. The museum begins by explaining the political situation in The Netherlands prior to the war and the attitudes or the different groups as the war approached. Then it shows how the resistance began and grew stronger and how they resisted. The people of the Netherlands were very brave during the war. I never had realized they had organized a strike in opposition to the Nazi's. It was a learning experience.

Very Informative But Should Be Better Set Out. This is a very interesting museum with an interesting insight into the war in Holland.However there is a major flaw.It is not set out in a way where one section follows on naturally from the previous,or with indicators of the route to be taken.As a result you have no idea where to go next and you even end up going round sections you have previously viewed,so more thought about this is needed.

factual and eye opening. The museum provides a good insight into what life was like in Amsterdam during the German occupation in WW2. It gives a good explanation of the different factions within Amsterdam and the hardship suffered by its residents.A real eye opener into this era and well worth a visit especially if your interested in 20th century/WW2 history.Some interactivity is provided but I think young children would be bored. The museum could be improved if there was more to do than watching short clips and reading lots of text.

Worthwhile-especially if you have children 10>. The tourist guides states that this is a great complement to the Anne Frank House and I couldn't agree more. It's inexpensive (free on the Amsterdam card) compact and wonderfully presented. The museum is a one floor walk through featuring film clips, artifacts, and captions. As you walk through and look and read, it is explained how international conflict arose in Europe pre-WW 2, what happened to the Netherlands in that era in general and how Dutch resistance to the Nazi party came into being. If you "connect the dots" it is yet another reminder that hate, discrimination and racism, left unchecked will have disastrous consequences.

It cleared up questions from our trip. This was the best thing we did in Amsterdam.We initially went to Anne Franks house, which in itself was interesting. This however raised questions with us as to how all of that could happen and what did the people do to let in continue for so long etcWe stumbled upon this museum on our last morning. There was good english descriptions and it clarified the whole process of the occupation and the way in which the Netherlands resisted the German forces.It was moving, varied and educational. there was a large school group at the time we visited, but the Museum is large enough to accommodate different groups.A definite see

Very Moving Exhibits. It gives a wonderful history of the Netherlands under German occupation. Actual artifacts as well as models, bring to life the trials and tribulations of the Dutch, at that time. It definitely was worth a visit, but a hall full of noisy school children , out on an excursion, did disturb us. Otherwise, we were glad not to have missed it.

One of the Best Resistance Museums!. We visited this Resistance Museum on June 26, 2009, after seeing the ones in Copenhagen and Oslo. We were very impressed with the layout and features of this Museum. It was truly one of the best we had seen on this trip and I encourage you to go if you are interested in this era. It is in a new facility and has pictures, posters, videos of life back in 1940-45, and areas of what everyday life was like back then. We spent over an hour going through every area, and it is worth the time. I just can't explain how effective it is. The time and effort spent on putting all this together is mind boggling! We did take a tram number 14, from where we were but walked back to city central. Make sure you take time to visit the Hollandsche Schouwbutg , which was once a theater but today a war memorial, with an exhibition inside. It commemorates the many thousand Jews who during WW11 were deported from this place and sent to be killed. Just ask at the front desk of the Museum where to find it. We saw it on the way to the Museum but didn't know what it was. It will make a nice addition to the Ann Frank House/Museum if you have time to see that.The front desk gals, at the Museum were very helpful in telling us where to eat lunch and other details.
Disappointing. It's okay, but not as informative as I thought it would be. Some interesting displays.

Not quite what I expected, but still enjoyable. The Resistance Museum is an interesting look at the impact of WWII on the Netherlands, but most of the information presented is about the war years in general. While the resistance movement was certainly highlighted, there were few specific stories about individuals and their actions during the war. Large scale events, like strikes and student demonstrations, were well covered, but I was hoping for a look at individuals and everyday actions that aren't in every history book. I was a bit disappointed to see things highlighted on the website (i.e. baby buggies with false bottoms and watches with a secret space for messages) and not have any accompanying stories about those who used them. Great for history buffs, but not quite as unique a perspective as I had hoped to see.

a must see so we never forget. This interactive museum is a moving tribute to the brave people of Holland who fought against the Germans. You move from year to year of the German occupation and see how the Dutch suffered and died and the brave resistance fighters who always fought back. Its across the street from the zoo, so after you have watched the animals just cross the street to the Resistance Museum. Or if you have an understanding spouse let them hang with the kiddies at the zoo, while you take this great option.

History Comes to Life at The Resistance Museum!. The The Resistance Museum (Amsterdams Verzetsmuseum) is a small but amazing museum that is a great compliment to the Anne Frank House! The museum focuses on the German Occupation and the Nazi rule in the Netherlands during the World War II (1940-1945). The exhibits are some of the best and most organized exhibits I have ever seen. The exhibits are a recreation of Holland during the terrible days of the World War II and the Holocaust. The museum is a multisensory experience with video screens, posters, war and spy gear and real testimonies from people who lived and faught for Holland during the War! It truly is an exceptional monument to the heroism and pride of Holland then, and Holland now!

Excellent and informative. The resistance museum takes you through a journey of Holland during the war years seeing how the occupation had a deep impact on Dutch people. You will need time to stop and read the real life stories to get a real feel for what happend and how it affected the lives of ordinary people. May not interest younger children. Ask for an interactive headst as they didn't give these out too readily but a great museum.

An inspirational experience. Such a lovely museum, packed full of interesting information and artefacts, and presented in an accessible way. it was so quiet when we visited too, which was lovely as the bigger museums get packed. I had tears i my eyes several times, it really is moving. Some amazingly inspirational sories to be found here, I recommend it highly.

An incredible new find for an avid visitor. Although I have been to Amsterdam many times over many years, finding this museum was an incredible and exciting new adventure. I was impressed by the depth and amount of information presented in a relatively small space, but also by the artistry and imagination of the exhibits.My favorite? An exhibit about letters, written by Jewish detainees being shipped off to the camps, that were thrown from trains to loved ones. The exhibit featured an old boxcar with the letters mounted so as to look like they were flying through the air. Poignant and memorable!

Great Museum. We opted for this museum in lieu of the Anne Frank House (which I had been to but my husband had not). This museum has so much information and is done in such a creative way that we could've spent 3 hours reading and watching everything. It's incredible the amount of information and what you learn about the Dutch people and the resistance to WWII. If you can only do one of the two museums mentioned I would choose this one for greater insight (and NO line!).This museum is easily accessible by tram from Rembrandt’s House and is directly across the street from the zoo (Artis). Plenty of cafes surround the area and the Botanical Garden is just a block away. A nice itinerary is Rembrandt’s House, Resistance Museum, lunch, Botanical Garden.

Poignant, and a must see. The thing of it is, the museum gets down to specifics and particular human interest stories. It tells of the national psyche pre-war, and who took what part in the conflict-collaborator, resistance, acqueiser...much individual paraphenelia . Dont look for armament here-tanks and guns. See and try to feel what the experience was like. It will surely touch you deeply.

Fantastic - if you visit just one museum, go to this one!. I am interested in the resistance and the German occupation so definitely wanted to go to this museum. It's right across the road from the zoo and is quite easy to miss. It doesn't seem all that big from the outside, but inside is so much information and exhibits, personal accounts of living in the Netherlands during the occupation and what the Dutch did to resist the Germans. There were sound effects which really brough the whole experience alive. I was in there for much longer than I anticipated and read everything I could. I only wish I could read Dutch so all the newspapers and memorabillia meant something to me. All the explanations etc were in English and it took me longer enough to read them!I really really loved this museum and definitely recommend it.

please take the time to see this museum!. i only allotted 2 hours to spend in this museum and it wasn't enough time! the museum itself isn't very big but it is packed with information. very well organized, engaging, interactive exhibits. museum begins with dutch life before the war: lifestyle, economy, religions, political parties. and then life during the war and then the nazi invasion. there are real newspapers, recordings of actual radio broadcasts- such a shame i don't know dutch! would have loved to understand what i was reading/hearing! the museum introduces important figures like mussert, the dutch leader of the dutch nazi party. it also intoduces lesser known political leaders like mayors and the dilemas they faced on a personal level in regards to their obligation to their citizens. the rest of the museum follows the timeline to liberation. side "rooms" focus on specific groups and their involvement (or lack of) in the resistance like the newspapers, theaters, and church. throughout the museum are accounts and pictures of regular people, what they went through, what they saw, how they felt. i was particularly interested in the exhibit regarding jewish children and those who saved them. last exhibit seperate from the rest was a room dedicted to indonesia during the war and the resistance to japan AND the dutch. regrettably didn't have time to spend there. i must go back!this museum is extraordinary. you aren't reading this history in a book. here, you see it, hear it, feel it, you can relive it. there are so many artifacts, actual items from the past, you become faced with the realization that all of it happened. so many lives affected, so much pain. it is thought provoking and emotional. i was angry, sad, sympathetic, moved, shocked, humbled. i learned so much and history was my worst and least favorite subject in school! please don't overlook this museum. it would be such a shame not to experience this very relevant part of netherlands history.also, please consider doing the persecution and resistance walk. the 50 cent booklet can be bought at either the anne frankhuis (where the walk begins) or the verzetsmuseum (where it ends) and takes you to points of interests, including some of the buildings you would learn about in the verzetsmuseum such as the building that used to house the registry of births and deaths where the resistance tried to destroy the records of their jewish neighbors in an effort to save their lives.

Good for those interested in WWII. I am a resident of Amsterdam (though British) and like most people who live and work in places that are heavily visited by tourists, they never really go to the museums very much. I write quite a lot on the forum so I decided it was time to rectify this and on a very windy and wet afternoon I trekked off to the Verzetsmusuem for a look around. Entrance is 6.50 euros at the time of writing (free entrance with the IAmsterdam card) and the museum can be easily reached via tram line 9. Get off at the stop for the Artis Zoo, Plantage Kerklaan.Currently at the entrance to the museum they have an exhibition of photographs of native prisoners forced by the Japanese to work on the Burmese railway as they are today. Once inside the main part of the museum there are exhibits with both Dutch and English descriptions. One thing to note is that the museum is not that big but if you stop to read everything it can take some time to get round. I spent two hours and could not look at absolutely everything as it was nearly closing time.The exhibits starts with life in Amsterdam in the late 1930’s before the German occupation of May 1940 of the then neutral Netherlands and then concentrates on how firstly the Germans tried to win the hearts and minds of the Dutch but then showed their true colours with the treatment of the Jews and other people not sympathetic to their views. Continuing on through the forced deportation to the camps and focuses quite a lot on the national strike by workers in 1941 in protest at these actions. There are examples of false papers printed for Jews who were taken in by the Dutch and I presume a real printing press. The trail finishes with the end of the occupation by the Allied forces.That’s the factual info now here’s my opinion of the museum. Well worth a visit if you want to learn more about life under the NAZI occupation. It is quite dark inside and does somewhat transport you back to those days, especially the interactive exhibits. I do think that they would be better using those headsets that you see at many museums these days so they you can get specific commentary at each point without disturbing anyone else. Presently everything is played through speakers which can be a bit loud in an enclosed space if you have not reached that part yet.Seems that the museum is not very busy although I think that there are quite a few school parties, one was leaving as I got there.

Don't Miss This Excellent Museum. If you are willing to wait on an endless line to visit the Anne Frank House (well worth the wait) than you MUST visit the Verzetsmuseum. This collection is a treasure trove of history recounting the valient resistance efforts of the Dutch people during WWII in their all out effort to save the Jewish, and ultimately, Dutch population from the ravages of the Nazi invaders. The exhibits grab your attention as they step out of history and engage you to learn and think...and ultimately haunt your soul. Yet they are presented in a sophisticated, artistic and media oriented manner. This is one of the world's finest history related museums I have visited, and no trip to Amsterdam is complete without a visit here.

This place really makes you think. This is simply an outstanding museum.It tells the story of the German invasion of the Netherlands in WWII, put on a friendly face to the populace, then gradually took their freedoms away, in a carefully calculated manner.The use of propaganda from all sides is covered with intriguing detail. Personal stories from Jews and their neighbors paint a brutal picture that is impossible to ignore.And yes, it makes you think, what would I do if I were in that situation? The answer is not easy.

Excellent Museum That is Often Overlooked by Tourists. This is one of the best museums I have ever been to. Extremely well-organized with fascinating stories from the Dutch Resistance Movement. At the same time, it did not shy away from the reality that many Dutch did not resist. The museum is a little off the beaten path (across from the Artis Zoo), but on a tram line. I was there on a Saturday and was shocked how empty it was -- quite a pity since I found this museum to be better than many of the other more popular Amsterdam sites.

One of the best museums I've ever been to. My husband and I spent over 3 hours in this incredible museum. The exhibits are so well done that you feel like you are a member of the Resistance. The musuem is incredibly alive with audio recordings and films and the most interactive displays I've ever seen in a museum dealing with an historical episode. You'll see how the Resistance operated and even fake papers. Yes, there are some emotional moments. Make sure you schedule time to visit here.
